HEADLINE: With President Gravely Ill, Croats Face Succession Issue

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Nov. 24

 BODY:
With Croatia's dominant political figure, President Franjo Tudjman, apparently on the brink of death, Parliament passed a constitutional amendment today that would allow the country to be governed in the meantime, with some of his duties passed on to the speaker of the Parliament.
Mr. Tudjman's doctors said today that his condition was grave, their most dire description yet in the three weeks since he entered the hospital for emergency intestinal surgery. There have been persistent rumors that Mr. Tudjman, who has stomach cancer, is being kept breathing artificially and is attached to life-support equipment while his divided party, the Croatian Democratic Union, figures out who will succeed him. Seeking to address those rumors, party officials said today that he was alive. 
 Mr. Tudjman is apparently unable to sign the documents for parliamentary elections, originally scheduled for Dec. 22, so the country is in a state of morbid expectation, reminding some people of the lingering, four-month death watch for Josip Broz Tito, the founder of Yugoslavia, who died in 1980.
Mr. Tudjman, 77, who has patterned his habits and his taste for uniforms on Tito's, is a historian and former Yugoslav Army general who pulled Croatia out of Yugoslavia in 1991, thereby helping to collapse the old Communist federation.
Mr. Tudjman has run Croatia as an autocrat since 1991 while winning repeated elections as its president, the last in 1997. But a pattern of economic corruption and cronyism, a disregard for human rights and a tight rein on the news media, especially television and radio, have brought Mr. Tudjman considerable criticism from Washington and the European Union.
In particular, the West would like the Croatian government to be more fully cooperative with the international war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in The Hague and to stop refusing to hand over people indicted as war criminals; to welcome, rather than discourage, the return to Croatia of Serbs driven from the country after Mr. Tudjman's forces recaptured the Serb-held territory in August 1995; and to hold free and fair elections with free and fair access granted to the news media.
Part of the political confusion here stems from the increasing unpopularity of Mr. Tudjman's umbrella party, since the economy is stagnant, corruption is visible and unemployment is very high. Reputable polls taken earlier this month indicated that an opposition grouping of center-left parties would probably win a majority in Parliament, although Mr. Tudjman's Croatian Democratic Union -- universally known here by its Croatian initials HDZ -- would remain the largest party.
Originally, parliamentary elections were scheduled for Dec. 22 -- a pre-Christmas date that seemed designed, in this largely Roman Catholic country, to help his party, since many of its critics, including Croats who also have homes abroad, would be on vacation or out of the country. But Parliament's mandate expires on Saturday, and no solution is yet in sight for calling fresh elections.
Mr. Tudjman's death would leave his party divided into roughly three factions. The first is led by Ivic Pasalic, Mr. Tudjman's adviser. Mr. Pasalic has no state function but is considered instrumental in internal and security policy. He is the leader of the "Herzegovina lobby" that supports the Bosnian Croats, fervent devotees of Mr. Tudjman's party who are also allowed to vote in Croatian elections despite their Bosnian citizenship.
The second faction is led by the deputy speaker of Parliament, Vladimir Seks, a hard-line Croatian nationalist who announced today on television that Mr. Tudjman "is alive."
The third faction, more liberal and pro-European, is led by Foreign Minister Mate Granic, a favorite of Washington. While Mr. Granic is popular in the country, he is less so within the party.
The party, then, is thought to be trying to buy time while the leadership decides who will run for the presidency and when to call parliamentary elections. If Mr. Tudjman dies, the parliamentary speaker, Vlatko Pavletic, a relatively colorless figure, will run the country before new presidential elections within 60 days. Parliament's term is scheduled to expire on Jan. 27, and new elections should be called by Dec. 26 at the latest, to allow 30 days of campaigning.
But to have them during the Christmas break would require Mr. Tudjman -- or, if he is declared incapable, Mr. Pavletic -- to sign an order this week.
Today's Parliament vote was an indication of the confusion. The Constitution describes procedures in the case of a president's death, resignation or "permanent incapacity." But Mr. Seks said that the party "will under no circumstances agree to apply the institute of permanent incapacitation." To do so, he said, would be "immoral and disgraceful."
So in extraordinary session, Parliament passed, by a vote of 85 to 28 with 24 abstentions, a constitutional amendment that created a category of "temporary incapacity," which must be decided upon by the Constitutional Court when asked to do so by the Cabinet. But the law allows 30 days for the whole procedure, causing opposition politicians to protest that the political instability would simply continue.
The Parliament also voted to extend the mandate of the speaker, Mr. Pavletic, so he could serve after the legislature is dissolved on Saturday but before new elections are held. That would enable him to assume some of Mr. Tudjman's duties if he is declared temporarily incapacitated or dies.

HEADLINE: U.S. Missile Shield Will Set Off a New Arms Race, China Warns

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 24

 BODY:
China's chief of arms control issued a new warning today that American plans for a national missile defense system, even if intended to stop attacks from countries like North Korea and Iraq, would set off a global arms race and cause more countries to develop nuclear weapons.
The existing Antiballistic Missile Treaty, which the United States proposes altering to allow limited defenses, has long been a cornerstone of nuclear stability, Sha Zukang, director of arms control and disarmament in China's foreign ministry, said today in an article in the official newspaper China Daily. 
 "Amending it in search of national missile defense will tip the global balance, trigger a new arms race and jeopardize world and regional stability," Mr. Sha wrote.
Russia has also been vociferous in opposing missile defenses.
China has objected to proposed theater missile defenses, local systems intended to protect American allies in Asia from missile attacks. China worries that such high-technology defenses would be offered to Taiwan, encouraging it to declare formal independence and cementing military ties between Taiwan and the United States.
Though the debate is already heated, theater defenses that could stop a blitz of short-range missiles are still in the unproved research stage.
But in today's article and recent speeches, Chinese officials have also vehemently challenged the progressing American plans for a national defense system, perhaps designed to stop a handful of incoming missiles.
A prime reason for Chinese concern, weapons experts say, is that even a limited system would undercut China's own nuclear strategy, forcing it to spend far more than it wants to build extra rockets and bombs and putting a drain on economic development.
Unlike the United States and Russia, each of which fielded thousands of nuclear weapons in a race for slim advantages, China has deployed small numbers of weapons intended simply to give adversaries second thoughts about attacking it.
Western analysts say China may have no more than two dozen long-range missiles capable of reaching parts of the United States with single warheads. China's theory is that if a prospective attacker believes that even one or two of China's missiles can get through to destroy a city, a nuclear attack will be deterred.
The Chinese know that their current aging, fixed-site missiles are vulnerable to a sudden attack and plan to replace them with more powerful missiles that are mobile and therefore far more difficult to take aim at.
Western officials do not know how many such missiles the Chinese plan to field. But even limited American defenses could reduce China's confidence that it could mount an effective counterattack in case of war. So China may feel that it needs a relatively larger force, perhaps including missiles that carry multiple warheads, to maintain its stature as a nuclear power.
Mr. Sha, in today's article and other speeches, does not mention such hard-nosed strategic concerns, only alluding darkly to a hastened arms race. In the article today, he also said an American missile defense would "undermine the conditions necessary for nuclear disarmament."
And without the promise of superpower arms reductions, he said, "who can guarantee that other non-nuclear states will not go nuclear?"

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Counters Critics of Its Cold War Work

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN 

DATELINE: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 20

 BODY:
After enduring a decade of second-guessing over whether it failed to detect Communism's impending demise, the Central Intelligence Agency is still a bit defensive about its performance in the waning years of the cold war.
But when the desire to set the historical record straight led the agency to cosponsor a conference on the subject with the George Bush School of Government and Public Service at Texas A&M University this weekend, the agency tried hard to produce a celebration of an intelligence victory. It even declassified 24 intelligence reports from the years 1988 to 1991 as proof that its assessments were more accurate than the critics have said. 
 Still, the conference could not ignore the harsh truth that some criticism of the agency's cold war reporting was well founded. In fact, its forecasts in the late 70's and early 80's were sometimes far off.
Although the agency began to detect signs of stagnation in the late 70's, it continued for years to overstate significantly the size and growth rate of the Soviet economy. The agency also badly understated the burden that military spending was placing on the Soviet economy and refused for years to accept evidence that Soviet production of nuclear missiles was not growing as rapidly as Washington had expected.
In 1985, for example, an outside panel of economists found that although the agency believed that the Soviet economy was about half the size of the American economy, the gross domestic product was no more than 30 percent of the United States output.
Charles Wolf, an economist at the RAND Corporation who was on the panel, recalled that the agency's estimates of the Soviet Union's annual economic growth were also significantly overstated, while its estimates of the economic burden of military spending were too low.
Douglas MacEachin, who headed the office of Soviet analysis in the 80's, acknowledged that the agency had moved too slowly to adjust its projections of military and strategic forces to reflect the worsening economic conditions. The projections of large increases in producing ballistic missiles, Mr. MacEachin said, were consistently too high until the late 80's.
Robert Gates, a former director of central intelligence, agreed, saying, "During the mid-80's, our projections of Soviet strategic forces were clearly too high."
In part, the overly hawkish forecasts of the missile buildup in the early 80's represented a bureaucratic response to intense pressure from the Reagan administration, which had called the Soviet Union an "evil empire."
Yet the estimates also stemmed from a natural inclination among experts to expect the Soviets to continue to act as they had in the past. The Soviets built up their strategic forces more quickly than the agency had anticipated in the late 60's and early 70's, and the agency expected that rapid pace to continue.
The agency did report accurately the growing signs of an economic slowdown in the late 70's and early 80's. But such reports were not welcome at the White House, said former intelligence officials who were at the conference. Some current and former intelligence officials recalled how the Reagan administration was furious with one report suggesting Soviet military spending had turned flat in the early 80's.
"They saw it as challenging the central thrust of their policy, a big U.S. defense buildup," recalled one former intelligence official who insisted on anonymity.
By the late 80's, the agency did accurately portray the growing instability in the Soviet Union, and it did so earlier and more clearly than the critics have suggested, a review of the newly declassified intelligence reports shows.
In December 1988, a national intelligence estimate, "Gorbachev's Economic Problems: The Challenges Ahead," said: "Gorbachev's efforts at reviving the Soviet economy will produce no substantial improvement over the next five years, although his efforts to raise consumer welfare could achieve some modest results. Soviet attempts to raise technology levels will not narrow the gap with the West in most sectors during the remainder of this century."
In September 1989, two months before the fall of the Berlin Wall, an intelligence assessment by the office of Soviet analysis at the C.I.A. predicted: "The unrest that has punctuated Gorbachev's rule is not a transient phenomenon. Conditions are likely to lead in the foreseeable future to continuing crises and instability on an even larger scale in the form of mass demonstrations, strikes, violence and, perhaps, even the localized emergence of parallel centers of power."
In April 1991, months before the unsuccessful coup against Mr. Gorbachev in August, an agency paper, "The Soviet Cauldron," warned that "explosive events have become increasingly possible."
On the espionage front, the record was also mixed until the final years of the cold war. The fears of the agency's longtime counterintelligence chief, James Jesus Angleton, who believed that every Soviet defector was a double agent, paralyzed operations until the 70's, when the agency finally began to recruit important agents in the Soviet Union and other Warsaw Pact countries.

HEADLINE: Boy Scouts Start Drive For Funds In Detroit

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 24

 BODY:
In this city of more than a million people, there are just 20,000 boy scouts. But there is an unusual, $17 million effort afoot to increase that number.
With an executive at the General Motors Corporation who was an eagle scout leading the charge, the Detroit Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America has begun a drive to raise $10 million for inner city Scout troops and another $7 million to build a new camp for cub scouts and make improvements on a Boy Scout camp in nearby Metamora, Mich. 
 The fund-raising drive is notable not only for its size, but also because it would earmark most of the money for long-term goals. If successful, the campaign would create a $10 million trust fund for inner-city troops. Interest and investment income from the fund would pay for costs like camping gear and uniforms.
Philanthropy experts say the drive is ambitious. "For scouts in Detroit, that's a lot of money," said Stacy E. Palmer, editor of The Chronicle of Philanthropy.
Nonprofit groups are increasingly taking advantage of the strong economy to build nest eggs.
"Everybody is figuring out that this is the smartest way to raise money and not have to keep going back to your donors," Ms. Palmer said. "The general prosperity is making people think of the long term."
People, as well as money, are being solicited as part of the drive to increase the number of inner-city scouts here. Detroit's 1,200 Baptist churches and its 73 Roman Catholic parishes have pledged to use scouting as part of their youth ministries. And the Detroit branch is looking for up to 500 volunteers from businesses and community groups to serve as assistant troop leaders, said Chuck J. Lang, senior director of development for the Detroit Area Council.
While Mr. Lang knew of no larger initiative targeting inner-city youths for Boy Scout membership, and a national spokesman for the Scouts was unable to provide any information about fund-raising drives in other cities, Detroit's is not the only multimillion-dollar drive for donations. Scouting organizations in Houston, Cincinnati and Indianapolis have held large fund-raising drives in recent years.
There are slightly more than 100,000 scouts in the Detroit metropolitan area, with about 80,000 in the suburbs and 20,000 in the inner city, Mr. Lang said.
Businesses have been receptive so far. General Motors has pledged $1 million toward the $17 million goal.
"Kids who are involved in scouting get exposed to skills and values in scouting," said John F. Smith, general manager of G.M.'s Cadillac division and a former eagle scout, who is one of the organizers of the drive. "Lots of surveys indicate they are changed and changed for the better by that experience."
Mr. Smith added: "If you are a business interest, you could selfishly look at this as early-on training for employees. We know it makes a difference."
Other companies are likely to pledge money later, when the fund-raising effort gets into full swing next month.
DaimlerChrysler "definitely will participate, but right now we are still considering the contribution amount," said a spokeswoman, Curtrise Garner, who added that the company had given $50,000 to the Scouts in Detroit so far this year. A spokeswoman for the Ford Motor Company, Gwynne Irvin, said that "news from Ford may be forthcoming."
Some billboard owners have donated advertising space on billboards along some of Detroit's highways, and the advertising agency D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has designed the advertisements without charge.

HEADLINE: Outspoken Chief Economist Leaving World Bank

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Joseph E. Stiglitz said today that he would resign as the World Bank's chief economist after using the position for nearly three years to raise pointed questions about the effectiveness of conventional approaches to helping poor countries.
Mr. Stiglitz, who joined the World Bank in February 1997 after serving as chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, said he would leave the bank at the end of the year and would soon return to his academic post at Stanford University. 
 His departure will remove from Washington perhaps the most outspoken voice in the debate over how rich countries can best aid economic development in poor and crisis-afflicted nations. Over the last two years in particular, Mr. Stiglitz had antagonized officials at the International Monetary Fund and within the Clinton administration by criticizing their response to the financial crisis in Asia and their strategy for encouraging the development of democratic capitalism in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Stiglitz said the decision to leave had been his. Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers praised Mr. Stiglitz as a "major creative and intellectual force," and administration officials said the United States had not sought Mr. Stiglitz's removal. Caroline Anstey, a spokeswoman for the World Bank, said Mr. Stiglitz had "absolutely not" been forced out, and the bank's president, James D. Wolfensohn, praised Mr. Stiglitz for having helped to move the institution "away from the so-called Washington consensus."
But Mr. Wolfensohn has suggested in the past that Mr. Stiglitz was too quick to second-guess the international aid agencies and the big industrial nations that control them. "I think that his recent things about Russia, in my judgment, are not wholly correct," Mr. Wolfensohn said during the bank's annual meeting this autumn. "I think to stand back later and say, 'If you'd done it my way everything would have been different,' is a little generous to yourself."
And Mr. Stiglitz made no secret today of feeling constrained in his ability to speak out as freely as he wished. He said he was looking forward to the unfettered freedom of expression afforded by his return to the academic world.
"Whenever you're in an organization there are some pressures," Mr. Stiglitz said in an interview. "I felt that it was important for my intellectual integrity to be able to express myself as forcefully as I thought was appropriate."
A liberal with a strong belief that governments and institutions have a significant role to play in economic development and that market forces cannot be counted on to deal with every problem, Mr. Stiglitz challenged the prevailing orthodoxy among policy makers in Washington.
He said that the monetary fund went overboard in Asia in demanding that the countries ensnared in the financial crisis cut their budgets, arguing that fiscal austerity sometimes extracted too high a price from poor people without generating a corresponding improvement in international economic confidence.
He took issue with the view held by the fund and the United States government that controls on the international flow of capital were counterproductive or impractical, saying that in some cases it was justified to restrict short-term flows of money in and out of a developing economy. He said industrialized countries sometimes pushed developing nations too fast to deregulate their financial systems.
And he suggested that the United States and the monetary fund had failed to acknowledge that their prescription for Russia -- quick privatization of state-owned industries, an end to state oversight of the economy, abolition of price controls and an opening up to the rest of the world -- had not produced the intended results and indeed had left many people worse off.
"Mr. Stiglitz has been a very strong advocate for the poor and the excluded, and he's been one of the best things in the World Bank in the last decade," said Seth Amgott, a spokesman for Oxfam, which promotes poverty-fighting policies. "He's also been very pointed and insightful in discussing the role of the I.M.F. We're not used to that kind of candor."
Mr. Stiglitz won few friends among economists and policy makers at the Treasury Department and the monetary fund. But his message was greeted enthusiastically in poor countries, and he said he was leaving the bank feeling that he had helped to stimulate a more vigorous debate about the policy prescriptions that wealthy nations impose on developing countries.
"On some of the specific issues, there has emerged really a broad consensus behind the views I took," Mr. Stiglitz said.
"There's a recognition that policies in East Asia were excessively contractionary on the fiscal side," he continued. "There's a recognition that capital market liberalization, in the absence of adequate regulatory structures, exposes countries to much higher risks. And on the debate about economies in transition, there's a general consensus that the issues I've been raising are the right issues, and that while no one has the answers, we're not going to get answers until we're willing to ask the questions."
Mr. Stiglitz had told friends recently that he intended to leave, and he informed Mr. Wolfensohn this morning of his decision. Mr. Wolfensohn said Mr. Stiglitz would continue to act as an adviser to him and Mr. Stiglitz would lead the search for a new chief economist.
Ms. Anstey, the bank's spokeswoman, said that asking Mr. Stiglitz to head the search committee was a signal of the institution's "intention to select someone who will continue the Wolfensohn-Stiglitz agenda" of focusing more on the needs of poor countries and less on more orthodox policies developed in Washington.
Mr. Stiglitz said his approach was built around two basic themes: giving more of a voice to poor nations in setting policy and recognizing the crucial role that government must play in economic development.
"We are rebalancing our thinking about the role of the state," Mr. Stiglitz said. "Some of the failures, like in East Asia, involve cases where government did too little, like in financial regulation, rather than too much."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Gore, Running in Iowa, Runs Hard From Clinton

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Nov. 23

 BODY:
As Vice President Al Gore tries to sell himself as his own man, unencumbered by President Clinton and his scandals, it is hardly a surprise that he plays down his ties to the politician he hopes to succeed.
But Mr. Gore may be taking things to an extreme. He has has practically banned the dreaded "C word" from his vocabulary. In a campaign swing on Monday and today that brought him before several partisan audiences in southeastern Iowa and western Iowa and in a quick flight to Chicago for a fund-raising dinner, Mr. Gore mentioned the president only once -- and only because he did not have much choice. 
 At the event in Chicago, he was listing the administrations that had advocated a nuclear test ban treaty -- "Clinton, Carter, Bush and Reagan administrations" -- so he could not easily have excluded his own.
Sometimes, Mr. Gore goes through verbal contortions to avoid mentioning Mr. Clinton. At an open meeting of undecided Democratic voters today in this town on the western border of Iowa, one person stood up and asked Mr. Gore to describe the best thing that has happened to this country in his lifetime.
Mr. Gore's instinct was to blow the Clinton administration's horn -- and his own. But that was no easy trick given that he did not dare mention the president.
So, using fractured sentences and odd tenses, the vice president cited the administration's economic accomplishments but did not cite the administration. It was as if he took his old talking points and excised any mention of Mr. Clinton.
"Right now we have the strongest economy in the history of the United States," Mr. Gore said, citing the "end of the recession of the Reagan-Bush years" and "having 20 million new jobs."
The "pretend Clinton does not exist" approach seemed to work. The audience applauded, heartily, for Mr. Gore.
 
A Chairman on a Tightrope
When Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia was installed as general chairman of the Democratic National Committee several weeks ago, some who back Mr. Gore's rival, former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, groused that Mr. Rendell had been a bit too friendly with the vice president.
The concern was that Mr. Rendell's past relationship with Mr. Gore would interfere with the custom that a party chairman is supposed to be neutral in a contested primary.
Mr. Bradley's backers would not have been heartened when Mr. Rendell introduced the vice president on Monday at a lavish fund-raising dinner in Chicago that raised about $700,000 for the national party.
At first, Mr. Rendell was even-handed. "We have two candidates who could both stand up and be president of the United States today," he said. "And they are right on the issues!"
Moments later, Mr. Rendell edged toward the Gore camp: "We also have, as I said, two good candidates -- but one who has served this country in a way that I think is unparalleled."
Mr. Rendell went on to recall that he had once described Mr. Gore as the best vice president in history. But then, not wanting to be accused of hyperbole, he scaled back his praise a bit, saying that "no question about it," he was the best No. 2 "in our lifetimes."
 
A Pop Quiz on Football
Brian Hansen, a retired civilian employee for the military, ambled up to Mr. Gore at the open meeting here and announced, "I have a pop quiz for you, sir."
The vice president visibly winced before managing a meek, "O.K."
Who could blame him? After Gov. George W. Bush of Texas flunked a pop quiz on foreign leaders earlier this month from a Boston television reporter, politicians are on the lookout.
Luckily for Mr. Gore, Mr. Hansen was only teasing. He asked him which team he favored for the national college football championship: Florida State, Nebraska or Virginia Tech.
It was hardly a stumper. When Mr. Hansen mentioned Nebraska, he stomped his foot. And Nebraska, of course, borders Iowa, so it was no surprise which team is the favorite in these parts.
It was an easy pander for the vice president. "Nebraska's looking good," Mr. Gore said.
 
A Bridge to Local Issues
Except when he steps off the stairs from Air Force Two, it is easy to forget these days that Al Gore is the understudy to the leader of the free world. On trips, he eschews the vice-presidential seal. And he eschews a tie (except at big-money fund-raisers like the one in Chicago). When he enters a room, no one announces, "The vice president of the United States."
But Mr. Gore may have gotten carried away with his "I'm just a man of the people" theme when he addressed members of a senior center in Fort Madison, in the southeast corner of Iowa. He sounded like Mayor Gore when he mentioned how he and the local Congressman, Leonard L. Boswell, had been chatting about repairs needed on a nearby bridge.
"Incidentally, Leonard's been talking to me about this bridge," Mr. Gore said. After describing how the lanes curved, Mr. Gore asked his audience, "Does that need to be changed?"
By tailoring his remarks for the locals, the vice president may have won some converts. But he also gave more fodder to Mr. Bradley, who likes to portray himself as the purveyor of big ideas.

LENGTH: 997 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMY PROVING IT'S MORE ROBUST THAN ANTICIPATED

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
The long-running expansion of the American economy rolled into autumn with even more momentum than had been thought, and is poised to set a record for longevity with the arrival of the year 2000.
With employment, incomes, confidence and major stock market gauges at or near peaks, the Commerce Department raised its estimate yesterday of economic growth from July to September to an annual pace of 5.5 percent from 4.8 percent, surpassing nearly all predictions. 
 "How can you not be thankful?" asked James Glassman, chief United States economist at Chase Securities.
The report arrived with few signs of revived inflation. "This is not something you expect to see this late in the game," Mr. Glassman said.
But unless growth slows drastically, analysts fear the Federal Reserve could feel compelled to raise interest rates again and dampen the expansion, which is now eight and a half years old.
One source of anxiety is the fact that inflation is creeping up in the early stages of production, before products reach consumers. Consumers are already seeing the highest oil prices since the Persian Gulf war.
The latest consensus, according to Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a monthly survey of economic forecasters, is for gross domestic product to rise at a 4.1 percent pace in the current quarter and by 3 percent next year.
"Growth is going to be well above historical averages," said John M. Youngdahl, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, which is forecasting a 4.5 percent growth rate in the final three months of 1999.
And stock prices keep rising. Yesterday, the technology-laden Nasdaq index sailed to a new peak that puts it 56 percent ahead for the year while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average hovered near records.
While the government's latest snapshot of the $8.9 trillion economy covers only the third quarter, the growth rate and separate data for October and November were said to bode well for the holiday shopping season.
Consumer spending, which makes up about two-thirds of overall economic activity, rose at a 4.6 percent annual rate in the third quarter, initially reported as an increase of 4.3 percent.
The latest figures also advanced the likelihood that January will become the 107th consecutive month of economic growth, breaking the mark set between 1961 and 1969, when national output was bolstered by the Vietnam War.
In a separate report yesterday, the Labor Department said first-time claims for unemployment insurance tumbled 13,000 last week, to 274,000, the third decline in the past five weeks.
With stores gearing up for Christmas, this was further evidence that little or no slack has yet developed in the tautest labor market -- an unemployment rate of only 4.1 percent -- in a generation. On a four-week moving average, initial claims have now totaled less than 300,000 for 18 consecutive weeks, the longest string since 1973.
Consumer optimism is also high, with the University of Michigan's confidence index climbing to 107.2 in November from 103.2 in October, according to subscribers to its polling service. The index reflects consumers' positive assessment of current economic conditions and their optimism about the future.
What accounts for the extraordinary longevity of the 1990's expansion, which has seemed little affected so far by the Federal Reserve's three quarter-point increases in its interest-rate target since midyear?
One reason is accelerated productivity, which Chase economists say is translating into compensation gains that exceed the expectations of workers who had become accustomed to increases averaging only about one percentage point more than inflation. This, the bank said, fostered "a general level of satisfaction" that has helped encourage big rises in consumer spending.
Another factor, analysts said, was the foreign economic crisis in Asia and Russia in the second half of 1998, which funneled overseas capital to the safety of the American securities markets, helping, along with cuts by the Federal Reserve in 1998, to keep interest rates low.
This, in turn, contributed to the rise in American stock, bond and home prices, all of which sustained confidence and buying power.
Uncertainty over possible disruptions from computer failures, the so-called Year 2000 problem, prompted some producers and consumers to stockpile products, like medicines, or to replace hardware or software they otherwise might only have fixed. This accounts for at least some of the surge in capital investment and inventories, the latter one of the biggest factors in yesterday's upward revision in G.D.P.
Economists said they could not quantify the Year 2000 effect, however, suggesting it might be turning out to be less than expected. If so, there would presumably be little falloff in such demand early next year, as some have feared.
"It's hard to disentangle" the Year 2000 moves from other rebuilding of depleted inventories, Mr. Youngdahl of Goldman, Sachs said.
The largest positive factor in the upward revision of the gross domestic product was fewer imports, the Commerce Department report also showed, while the biggest drag was less production of equipment and software than first estimated.
As for inflation, the price index for gross domestic purchases edged up to 1.7 percent from 1.6 percent last month, which analysts regarded as trivial.
Yesterday's report also included the government's first estimate of corporate profits for the quarter, which on a current production basis rose $8.2 billion in the summer after falling $6.5 billion in the spring.
Current production cash flow, which adjusts for inventory valuation and capital consumption, rose $16 billion after a $6.7 billion decline in the previous quarter.
Profits were reduced by about $8 billion because of the effects of Hurricane Floyd, the department said, $6 billion of this in benefits paid by insurance companies and $2 billion from uninsured losses.

HEADLINE: Keep Trucking Safe

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "In a Nonstop Economy, Truckers Keep Rolling" (news article, Nov. 24): These may be good times for truckers, but they aren't necessarily good times for the motorists who share the highways with them. More than 5,300 people died in truck crashes on United States highways last year. As you report, truckers routinely speed and break rules. 
 Fortunately, last week, Congress approved a bill to create a new Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration to oversee truck safety. The bill requires that safety must be the new agency's highest priority. The legislation is a good first step, but it should not be the final step. It is crucial that the person appointed to manage the new agency be knowledgeable about safety and wholly independent from the trucking industry.
 
JOAN CLAYBROOK
Washington, Nov. 24, 1999
 
The writer is president of Public Citizen.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 37; Column 4; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 4388 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
A Southern Legacy and a New Spirit

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C.

 BODY:
You can't say it about many cities, but you can say it about this one: One man changed its destiny.
His name is Joseph P. Riley Jr. He is Charleston's mayor. He halted its long decline, which lasted for a hundred years after the Civil War, turning it from a proud but rotting relic into a model modern city. After 24 years on the job, in an era of pervasive skepticism about politicians, he was elected to a seventh term on Nov. 9 with 71 percent of the vote.
Even the cabbies believe in him. One old-timer told me, "I'd bet my life that he's never stolen a nickel or cheated a soul." 
 Mayor Riley has had help, of course: from a business community galvanized into action when the 95-year-old Charleston Naval Base was closed in 1996; from a devoted band of preservationists determined to restore the beauties of antebellum Charleston; from an unconventional police chief, Reuben Greenberg, a black Jew with two degrees from Berkeley whose Deep South brand of tough love has slashed the crime rate and forged better race relations; and from Gian Carlo Menotti, who rejuvenated the city's cultural life when he established an American version of his Spoleto festival here.
The mayor has also been helped a lot by history. Charleston is steeped in it, and tourists flock here to trace its footprints in the jasmine-scented streets and aristocratic houses. They admire the porches, called piazzas, positioned to catch ocean breezes, and the Mediterranean interplay of light, sea and shade, and the narrow gardens, full of boxwood, old roses and neat brick paths. A few may recall the watchwords of the beloved Emily Whaley, whose blossom-filled plot at 58 Church Street measures only 30 feet by 100 feet: "Early to bed, early to rise, work like hell and fertilize."
They visit the ruined Fort Sumter, toward which Confederate gunners under the grandiloquently named Gen. Pierre Gustave Toutant Beauregard directed the first shots of the Civil War on April 12, 1861. They sit in the box pews at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, finished in 1761, where George Washington and Robert E. Lee both came to pray. Its noble white steeple, a near replica of the one at St. Martin's-in-the-Fields in London, may well have been designed by the same architect, James Gibbs. They stroll past the rice planters' Italianate and Greek Revival mansions along the Battery, the tourists do, and gaze out upon the point where, as the natives like to say, the Ashley River meets the Cooper to form the Atlantic Ocean.
They buy the baskets, made from dried sweetgrass, sold by elderly African-American women with soft Sea Island accents at the corner of Broad and Meeting Streets. And they tuck into the updated Dixie cooking, unashamedly rich and sweet, of restaurateurs like Louis Osteen, whose homely fried peach pie with butter pecan ice cream makes you forget Escoffier's peach Melba.
While they are here, the visitors account for a third of Charleston's economy. There is money in those old buildings, which Charleston was once "too poor to paint, too proud to whitewash," and in those oh-so-courtly Southern ways, which year after year win Charleston the No. 1 position on a list of Most Mannerly Cities in America compiled by Marjabelle Young Stewart, an etiquette expert.
Wiser travelers come in spring and fall, for Spoleto and the house and garden tours, avoiding the long, suffocating days of summer.
But Charleston seldom seems crowded or hurried, regardless of season. Life ambles along with all the speed and urgency of a drawl. This is a small city, centered on a narrow peninsula, with only 75,000 people, though the metropolitan area is several times that. Think Norwalk, Conn.
The scale is human. The streets are clean, free of graffiti and litter; motorists, except for the occasional surly outsider, rarely honk their horns. You can stroll down Ropemaker's Lane or Price's Alley, leaving the 20th century far behind, yet this is a real city, a living community, not a museum like Williamsburg.
 
'A Vast Cousinage'
I suppose that at this point I should declare an interest, as British politicians say. My wife's maiden name was Betsey Pinckney, and she comes from the storied clan that more or less invented Charleston. Two of her forebears signed the Constitution; one of them, Charles Pinckney, later served as minister to Spain; the other, Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, was named envoy to France and ran unsuccessfully as the Federalist nominee for president (twice) and vice president. Charles Cotesworth's brother, Thomas, served as minister to England. All three fought in the Revolutionary War.
The 18th-century Low Country elite was "a vast cousinage," one prominent historian has written, a hugely prosperous extended family. In 1774 the per capita wealth of Charleston and the Low Country was four times that of the Virginia plantations, six times that of New York City.
They say that Charlestonians are like the Japanese, in that they eat rice and worship their ancestors, and I admit that the Pinckney-tude of Charleston used to get my goat: Pinckney Street, Pinckney Island and Castle Pinckney, and graveyards full of Pinckneys. Betsey once rode in a carriage pulled by a horse named Charles Cotesworth Pinckney.
But Eliza Lucas Pinckney won me over. Born in Antigua, the daughter of a colonial governor, she married the first Charles Pinckney in 1744. In short order she bore three children (including Charles Cotesworth and Thomas), compiled one of the very first colonial recipe books and took over the management of several large plantations, where she taught many slaves to read and write. Most important, she introduced the cultivation of indigo to the state. It was a crop so valuable to the British textile industry for dyes that it made South Carolina a favored child of the mother country.
Like many of the early settlers, the Pinckneys came from England by way of Barbados. Others came directly from Britain and France. These last were almost all Huguenots, or French Calvinists, and their tradition lives on in names like Manigault and Huger (pronounced you-GEE).
The piazza, which on many houses functions as an outdoor room, is an adaptation of a Barbadian architectural style; in this particular form, it is found only in Charleston. St. James's, an Episcopal church that also draws on West Indian traditions, survives in the northern suburb of Goose Creek, all but hidden in a copse of trees. (Inquire locally.) The pale pink stucco building, without a steeple, has a dozen fine Palladian windows and, in a pediment over the main door, a relief of a pelican nourishing its young, the symbol of the missionary Society for the Propagation of the Gospel.
Built about 1713, set in a walled graveyard overhung with live oaks, the church still displays George I's coat of arms behind the pulpit.
 
Architectural Echoes
The planters who lived around Goose Creek and along the Low Country rivers maintained ties to Britain for generations. In 1715 Palladio's treatise on classical styles was first published in England, and 30 years later John Drayton built a porticoed plantation house on the Ashley whose Tuscan and Ionic columns come directly from Palladio's pages.
Drayton Hall still stands; alone among the great houses in its neighborhood, it was spared by General Sherman's soldiers because, it is said, the owner had his slaves tell the federal troops that the house was being used as a smallpox hospital. Never converted to central heating or electric lights, and painted only twice, the interior of the house retains its elaborate original architectural details and elegant plaster moldings and ceilings.
Boone Hall, with a famous half-mile allee of live oaks planted in 1743, is a 1935 re-creation of the original. Cypress Gardens and Magnolia Gardens, both laid out amid blackwater swamps, are set alight by a riot of camellias and azaleas every spring. Medway Plantation, on the Cooper, was built in 1705 and is probably the oldest brick building in the state. It is privately owned and open only occasionally for the garden tours.
But it is Middleton Place, marvelous Middleton, that always lures us out of the city on fine days. Its manor house is a ruin; only one small flanking building survives, and it has been much altered. Never mind. It is filled with family portraits by Benjamin West, valuable silver, 18th-century beds with posts carved to resemble rice stalks and other furniture from the workshop of Thomas Elfe, Charleston's most noted cabinetmaker.
Bookshelves and tables hold rare first editions by Catesby and Audubon, who came here to draw the ospreys and egrets that still nest in local marshes. Audubon formed a friendship with Joel Poinsett, an erudite Charleston-born diplomat, who brought the Christmas plant named for him to this country from Mexico.
Henry Middleton began to plot his classical gardens in 1741. Now grown to mellow maturity, they are anchored by a pair of lakes shaped like a butterfly's open wings, which lie just below a series of scalloped terraces. On another part of the plantation a flock of sheep grazes quietly. A pathway leads beneath arching camellia bushes that carpet it in pink in early March. And everywhere there are stupendous trees -- gums, magnolias, crape myrtles -- and a mighty oak, a marker on an Indian trail before Columbus reached America. The oak has reached a circumference of 30 feet and a spread of 145.
It took 100 slaves 10 years to lay out the parterres, the terraces, the canals and the rest of the rigorously geometric design. To my mind they created the greatest garden that we have from Colonial America.
 
The Role of the Blacks
Slavery and its legacy, white supremacy, hung over Charleston like a pall for generations.
The French author Simone de Beauvoir came here in 1947. She was bewitched by the place, especially the Spanish moss, exulting in her journal that "it is the color of smoke, the color of amber and twilight." But the plantations haunted her.
"Creating those private Edens, which are as extravagant as the Alhambra," she wrote a few pages later, "required the vast wealth of planters and the hell of slavery; the delicate petals of the azaleas and camellias are stained with blood."
Between 1700 and 1775, the peak years of the slave trade, 40 percent of the Africans brought to America in chains passed through Charleston. Ever since, blacks have formed a big portion of the city's population.
DuBose Heyward's 1925 novel, "Porgy," transformed by George Gershwin into the folk opera "Porgy and Bess" in 1935, portrayed the lives of some of the poorest of them, who lived on Church Street in the onetime slave dependencies of houses on Cabbage Row, or Catfish Row, as Heyward renamed it. The city's blacks gave another gift to Broadway, the kinetic dock workers' dance that was transformed into the Charleston for "Runnin' Wild," a 1923 hit.
Happily, Charleston has moved well beyond its darkest days, and in casting off the shroud of white supremacy it has gradually begun to remember and to acknowledge the black role in its history. The other half of the story is displayed for visitors in the slave quarters at Boone Hall and the Aiken-Rhett House downtown.
The College of Charleston's Avery Research Center delves into the African-American past, maintaining collections of manuscripts and papers, including the records of the 54th Massachusetts Regiment, the black unit that mounted the heroic assault on Fort Wagner depicted in the Civil War film "Glory." That battle, in which the 54th's commander, Robert Gould Shaw, lost his life, is fully described at the wonderful Charleston Museum.
 
Accounts of Progress
But the process is just beginning. Important moments of black history remain submerged. The plaque at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church on Calhoun Street says simply, "Founded 1818, closed 1822, reopened 1865." What heartbreak lurks behind that simple word "closed"! The church was closed because it had been burned down by a white mob in revenge for the actions of Denmark Vesey, a parishioner who tried to foment a slave uprising.
Mayor Riley told me that economic opportunity had provided the key to the dramatic improvement in relations between the races in his city.
"You make the table bigger," he said when we met in his office, which was piled high with files, newspapers and official documents. "You don't tell some people that they have to leave. We've made progress in housing, in police work, in guaranteeing the full participation of all our citizens in the affairs of the city council. But you can never relax. In a diverse society, there are always a lot of opportunities for misunderstanding, so you have to be sure that new bridges are built and old ones are maintained."
Mr. Riley has pioneered "scatter-site" public housing in an effort to combat the ghetto mentality. He has passed ordinances banning T-shirt shops, neon and tour buses in the historic district and hotels on the waterfront, lest the very element that brings visitors to Charleston, its charm, be submerged in tourist tattiness. He has built things that appeal to locals and visitors, rich and poor, like a brand-new Waterfront Park, which helped to revive a crumbling old port district, and a new minor-league ballpark. On King Street an old movie theater has been turned into a convention hall, a new Saks Fifth Avenue has opened nearby and a former bank now houses a Starbucks.
What sets Mr. Riley apart from run-of-the-mill mayors is a genuine passion for his work. He is -- dare we use the word in this cynical era? -- a true visionary, and it is his vision of a city reborn that has carried him and Charleston through nightmares like Hurricane Hugo in 1989, which damaged 90 percent of the city's roofs and made a shambles of businesses.
 
A Loss, Then a Surge
The closing of the naval base, Mr. Riley said soon after it happened, "was like death, because no one had ever imagined life in Charleston without the Navy." The city's longtime Congressman, L. Mendel Rivers, had poured Pentagon dollars into the city for decades; his slogan was, "Rivers Delivers." But the city not only survived the blow, it surged rapidly ahead.
"We're way on the plus side by now," said Ben Cole, the president of the Charleston Regional Development Alliance. "We lost about 22,500 jobs when the Navy left. Since then we've gained around 35,000 new ones."
The alliance, founded in February 1995, brought capital investments of more than $1.75 billion to the area in its first three years of existence, and it has kept up that pace. Ninety new companies have arrived, a third of them foreign, lured by the climate, the mostly nonunion labor force and above all the booming port.
Charleston, quaint little Charleston, is now the largest container port in the South and second only to New York on the east coast. There are plans afoot to make it much bigger by building port installations on Daniel Island, northeast of the city, but that worries conservationists.
 
Houses as Monuments
Meanwhile the restoration of old Charleston continues apace. At the moment scaffolding obscures the Market Hall, a little Doric temple that stands at the head of the city's public market, and the Fireproof Building, designed in 1826 by Robert Mills as a county records office. A draftsman for Thomas Jefferson at Monticello, Mills became South Carolina's greatest architect, building courthouses and churches, including the First Baptist on Church Street in Charleston, in a severe Classical Revival style. He later designed the Treasury and the Washington Monument in Washington.
A favorite of mine in the same style, though not by Mills, is the Hibernian Hall on Meeting Street, a chaste white structure with a gilded harp above the door, across from the Fireproof Building. It was designed by Thomas U. Walter, who also went on to greater architectural glory in Washington, designing the dome of the Capitol. Since the years after the Civil War the hall has been the site, on the third Thursday in January, of the annual St. Cecilia Ball, Charleston's oldest, most exclusive social function.
When they say "exclusive" in Charleston, they mean it. The right to attend is inherited. A favorite local put-down, Betsey's cousin Jane Hanahan told us, is to say of someone, "He doesn't go to the ball." To which Betsey's irreverent brother Tom replied, "It's the only thing left, now that the House of Lords is gone."
Portraits of the ancestors of today's ballgoers can be seen at the Gibbes Museum of Art, whose collection includes important works by Samuel F. B. Morse, Gilbert Stuart and Thomas Sully. The gem of the collection is an unforgettable image of John C. Calhoun, the ardent champion of states' rights, by Rembrandt Peale.
But the real monuments to the men and women who built Charleston are their houses, no fewer than 3,500 of them built before 1860. Two that should not be missed are the Nathaniel Russell House, with an oval staircase that vaults upward with no visible means of support, and the Heyward-Washington House, whose pine floors and cypress paneling date from 1772. Its unmatched collection of Charleston furniture includes a chest-on-chest-on-chest, one of only three in existence. Try to peek at the Sword Gates at 32 Legare Street, too, and the elegant Miles Brewton House, with a two-story portico.
 
Performance Time
When you have had your fill of houses, there are plays at the Dock Street Theater, where the Charleston Stage Company presents 120 performances a year, and at the Footlight Players' intimate 240-seat house. The Charleston Symphony, for which Mr. Riley dreams of building a proper hall one day, has attracted soloists of the caliber of Itzhak Perlman and Sherrill Milnes.
But it is at festival time that the city comes culturally alive. Next year's Spoleto Festival, accompanied by its "fringe," known as Piccolo Spoleto, is scheduled for May 26 through June 11. It will include new productions of Verdi's "Luisa Miller," directed by Christopher Alden, and Gluck's "Iphigenie en Tauride," directed by Patrice Caurier and Moshe Leiser, and the choreographer Mats Ek's profoundly radical "Swan Lake."
In late September comes the Mojo Arts Festival, a celebration of African-American and Caribbean art, with a rich array of jazz, gospel and storytelling. Another part of Charleston's enthusiastic rediscovery of itself.
 
A Stay in Charleston
 
Charleston is 763 miles south of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:
 
Where to Stay
 
CHARLESTON PLACE, 130 Market Street, (843) 724-8410. With a prime location, two top-flight restaurants and an indoor-outdoor rooftop pool, this 450-room sister ship of Venice's Cipriani easily tops the roster of Charleston hotels. The bustling lobby, dominated by a huge white Murano chandelier, is the city's crossroads. But too many little things misfire: front-desk phones go unanswered after 25 rings, for example, and bathroom lights are placed so the makeup-applier's or shaver's face is cast into shadow. Double room: $175 to $395.
PLANTERS INN, 112 North Market Street, (843) 722-2345. Nothing is more characteristic of Charleston than the piazza or veranda overlooking a brick-paved, palmetto-shaded courtyard. The Planters Inn has both, plus high-ceilinged rooms, many with four-poster beds, and a warmly welcoming attitude at the reception desk. The inn belongs to the well-regarded Relais & Chateaux group, and it offers all the modern electronic paraphernalia. Double room: $175 to $225.
WENTWORTH MANSION, 149 Wentworth Street, (843) 853-1886. It was built by a cotton merchant in the Gilded Age and looks it. Crystal chandeliers, tile and marble floors, carved paneling and Tiffany-style windows give the place an air of tasteful opulence. Each of the 21 rooms has a CD player, a big-screen television, a fireplace and lots of antiques; many have Jacuzzis, and the suites are seignorial. Sweeping views from the rooftop cupola. Double room: $275 and $375.
HARBOUR VIEW INN, 2 Vendue Range, (843) 853-8439. Despite the mock-English spelling of its name, the Harbour View really does have harbor views. Only 15 months old, it is just across the street from the arching fountains of Charleston's handsome new Waterfront Park. And the 52 agreeably furnished rooms are rather gently priced. Double room: $129 weekdays; $179 weekends.
 
Where to Eat
 
HOMINY GRILL, 207 Rutledge Avenue, (843) 937-0930, is as unpretentious as they come -- a former barbershop with clapboard walls and butcher paper on the tables -- but everyone in town knows how good and how fairly priced it is. One day not long ago, two pickups and a Rolls-Royce were parked outside. Try shrimp and grits or toasted banana bread for brunch, a pimento cheese sandwich with arugula (!) for lunch, Southern fried chicken with spiced peach sauce for dinner. Robert Stehling, the chef, earned his stripes in Chapel Hill, N.C., from Bill Neal, a culinary legend in the New South.
LOUIS'S, 200 Meeting Street, (843) 853-2550. Some people like Adam Tihany's hip decor and some don't (this is Charleston, after all), but nobody doesn't like Louis Osteen, a sweet-natured country boy with a golden touch at the stove. He blends Europe with the South in black-eyed pea cassoulet and sweetbreads braised with Madeira, Vidalia onions and country ham. Other dishes speak pure Carolina, like oyster stew with benne (sesame) seeds and pork porterhouse with corn bread dressing. It is all meltingly delicious, and Mrs. Osteen, Marlene, has chosen 350 pedigreed wines to go with it.
MAGNOLIAS, 185 East Bay, (843) 577-7771. Magnolias is always packed. With good reason; Donald Barickman, the clever chef, produces a host of crowd-pleasers like Down South egg rolls, stuffed with chicken, collard greens and spicy tasso ham, and fried green tomato B.L.T.'s. Bright paintings, ancient pine floors and a mix of locals and tourists enhance the casual mood.
PENINSULA GRILL, in the Planters Inn (see above), (843) 723-0700. A cosmopolitan, subtly lighted room with velvet walls, the grill delighted me with foie gras served with duck rillettes and peach jam, and a veal chop with cheesy, peppery grits. It let Betsey down with over-the-hill oysters and overbreaded sweetbreads. But the smiling service, the superb wines and the memorable five-layer coconut cake more than tipped the balance.
SLIGHTLY NORTH OF BROAD, 192 East Bay Street, (843) 723-3424. Like a lot of Charleston restaurants, S.N.O.B., as it's known locally, is a bit inconsistent. Saucing can be heavy-handed. But its mixed grill of quail, homemade sausage and apple-smoked bacon over cabbage is a winner.
WOODLANDS, 125 Parsons Road, Summerville, (843) 875-2600. Ken Vedrinski produces the closest thing to haute cuisine in the Low Country at this inn 30 minutes from Charleston. The regional accent is muted, with turbotin and skate displacing shrimps and crab meat. But don't go on Sunday: Woodlands serves a limited menu, and no wine at all, on the sabbath.
 
Attractions
 
CHARLESTON MUSEUM, 360 Meeting Street, (843) 722-2996. "City Under Siege: Charleston and the War Between the States," through Sept. 4, 2000. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $4 for children.
GIBBES MUSEUM OF ART, 135 Meeting Street, (843) 722-2706. "Treasures From the Collection: Three Centuries of Art in the American South," "Elizabeth O'Neill Verner: Charleston Renaissance Artist," "Beyond the Spanish Moss: The Contemporary Perspective in Charleston" and "A Different Perspective: 20th-Century African American Artists in the Collection," all through Aug. 27, 2000. "Water: A Contemporary American View," through Dec. 12, 1999. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.. Admission: $6; $5 for the elderly, students and members of the military; $3 for children.
FORT SUMTER, Sullivan's Island, South Carolina, (843) 883-3123. Boats leave from the city marina on Lockwood Drive and from Patriot's Point in the town of Mount Pleasant. For schedules: Fort Sumter Tours, (843) 722-1691. Boat fee: $9.50; $4.75 for children under 12; children under 6 free.
AIKEN-RHETT HOUSE, 48 Elizabeth Street, (843) 723-1159. Audio tour available. Opens at 10 a.m.; last tour at 4:15 p.m. Fee: $7; combination ticket with Russell House, $12.
NATHANIEL RUSSELL HOUSE, 51 Meeting Street, (843) 724-8481. Docent tours available. Opens at 10 a.m.; last tour starts at 4:15 p.m. Admission: $7; combination ticket with Aiken-Rhett House, $12.
HEYWARD-WASHINGTON HOUSE, 87 Church Street. (843)722-0354. A branch of the Charleston Museum and affiliated with the Joseph Manigault House. Opens at 10 a.m.; last tour starts at 4:30 p.m. Admission: $7; two-museum combination ticket, $12; three- museum combination ticket, $18.
DOCK STREET THEATER, 135 Church Street. (843) 720-3968. Dark this weekend.
FOOTLIGHT PLAYERS THEATER, 20 Queen Street, (843) 722-4487. N. Richard Nash's "The Rainmaker." Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Admission: $18; $13 for students and the elderly.
CHARLESTON SYMPHONY. Next concert is Handel's "Messiah" at 8 p.m. on Dec. 4 at the Gaillard Auditorium, 77 Calhoun Street, (843) 577-7400. Admission: $10 to $35.
MIDDLETON PLACE, 4300 Ashley River Road, West Ashley, (843) 556-6020. Daily, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $22; $7 for children.
DRAYTON HALL, 3380 Ashley River Road, (843) 766-0188. Self-guided tours of the marsh are available. An African-American Focus Program is held daily at 1:15 and 2:45 p.m. Hours: Opens at 9:30 a.m.; tours begin at 10 and run every hour, with the last tour beginning at 3 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, ages 12 to 18; $4, ages 6 to 11; free, under 5.
 
Getting There
 
BY AIR: Flights from New York City to Charleston are offered by U.S. Airways, (800) 241-6522; , Midway Airlines, (800) 446-4392; , Continental Airlines, (800) 525-0280; and Delta Airlines, (800) 221-1212 . A 14-day advance purchase is $298 and a three-day advance purchase is $398, leaving from Newark Airport. It is the same price from Kennedy and La Guardia Airports, but travel is limited to Saturdays and Sundays. R. W. APPLE Jr.
