The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 26, 1999

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 31; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 3962 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AMERICAN BEAUTY," starring Kevin Spacey, Annette Bening, Chris Cooper, Wes Bentley and Thora Birch. Written by Alan Ball. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 116 minutes). With heavenly finesse, Mr. Spacey plays a buttoned-down 42-year-old suburbanite who flips his lid for a teenage cheerleader. And he never gets it back on. The midlife crisis motif is familiar, but the stage director Sam Mendes brings terrific visual flair and dry humor to this barbecuing of the bourgeoisie. All the actors display coolly expert timing, especially Ms. Bening as the antihero's grasping wife. Although the story spreads itself thin among many characters, the film coalesces for a devastating finale (Janet Maslin). 

* "THE BUENA VISTA SOCIAL CLUB," with Ibrahim Ferrer, Compay Segundo and Ry Cooder. Directed by Wim Wenders (not rated, 106 minutes). When the American guitarist and producer Ry Cooder assembled a group of all-but-forgotten Cuban musicians to record an album, no one expected that the record would become a phenomenon, selling more than a million copies worldwide and revitalizing the Cuban music scene. Mr. Wenders's ebullient documentary follows the group on tour from Amsterdam to New York and includes interviews with the group's main members. The music pulsates, and the pictures of Havana compare the city's grand but faded architecture with the musicians' weather-beaten faces (Stephen Holden).
 
* "AMERICAN MOVIE," featuring Mark Borchardt and friends. Directed by Chris Smith (R, 104 minutes). An insightful, funny, not-to-be-missed documentary about a no-budget Wisconsin filmmaker who makes a horror film as if his life depended on it. And as Mr. Smith so affectingly reveals, Mr. Borchardt's hopes really do hang in the balance. This knowing and often hilarious look at try-anything indie filmmaking becomes a moving portrait of one man's uphill struggle and finds Mr. Borchardt often describing success and prosperity as his goals. Meanwhile his own life is eloquently presented as a very different, no less authentic kind of American Dream (Maslin).
 
* "ANYWHERE BUT HERE," starring Susan Sarandon and Natalie Portman. Directed by Wayne Wang (PG-13, 113 minutes). In a knowing film adaptation of Mona Simpson's widely praised, if not often wildly eventful, first novel, Ms. Sarandon is show-stopping as the 14-year-old heroine's mother and main nemesis. And Ms. Portman, who proves her mettle in a fully formed dramatic role, does a terrific job of holding her own in the film's battle of wills. Even when the material meanders, Mr. Wang supplies insightful, affectionate direction, just as he did for "The Joy Luck Club." A women's picture made with feeling and acted with great flair (Maslin).
 
* "BEING JOHN MALKOVICH," starring John Cusack, Catherine Keener, Cameron Diaz and (of course) John Malkovich. Written by Charlie Kaufman and directed by Spike Jonze (R, 112 minutes). Welcome to the fun house: in this exhilaratingly quirky first feature by a stellar video director, the reigning fears and obsessions of a technology-crazed, voyeuristic culture are given an even wilder workout than they got from "The Truman Show." Mr. Cusack plays a discouraged puppeteer who accidentally finds a way into Mr. Malkovich's mind. While the ordinary science-fiction plot might go downhill after revealing its gimmick, this one's inspired craziness goes on and on. Originality and cleverness abound (Maslin).
 
"THE BACHELOR," starring Chris O'Donnell and Renee Zellweger. Directed by Gary Sinyor (PG-13, 90 minutes). This crude, frantic yuppie farce stars Mr. O'Donnell as a selfish, marriage-shy bachelor who botches his proposal to his sweetheart (Ms. Zellweger) days before his grandfather dies and leaves him $100 million on the condition he marry before his 30th birthday. That gives him 27 hours either to win back his true love or find another wife. After running through his ex-girlfriends, he finds himself besieged by a horde of prospective brides chasing him through the streets of San Francisco. Based on a 1925 Buster Keaton classic, the movie lands a few satiric thrusts at the money-mad workaholic 90's (Holden).
 
"THE BEST MAN," starring Taye Diggs, Morris Chestnut, Nia Long and Harold Perrineau. Directed by Malcolm D. Lee (R, 118 minutes). This feel-good ensemble film turns Mr. Diggs into a spectacled but hunky novelist en route to a friend's wedding. There he finds temptation in the form of an old flame and a lot of genial guy talk about the meaning of marriage. No problem here is too complicated to be settled by a good-humored dance scene. Another demonstration that current movies about upscale black characters have much more solid traditional values than ones about catty white teenagers (Maslin).
 
"THE BONE COLLECTOR," starring Denzel Washington and Angelina Jolie. Directed by Phillip Noyce (R, 118 minutes). One of the year's most gruesome movies, the ingenious but preposterous whodunit stars Mr. Washington as a quadriplegic forensic detective tracking down a serial killer who plays cat and mouse with him by leaving elaborate clues at the crime scenes. Ms. Jolie is the police officer (and former model) whom he instructs by cell phone on how to gather evidence. Crammed with the usual manipulative jolts, this urban creepshow at least succeeds in sustaining an atmosphere of menace, and Mr. Washington's and Ms. Jolie's star chemistry smolders without the two exchanging so much as a kiss (Holden).
 
* "BOYS DON'T CRY," starring Hillary Swank and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Kimberley Pierce (R, 114 minutes). This stunning debut feature tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon went on to create a charismatic identity as a young man. Brandon's ultimately wrenching tale may sound tabloid-ready, but on screen it turns into Theodore Dreiser's idea of American tragedy. The film makes it hauntingly real and even tenderly romantic, with the astonishing acting needed to make it work. One of the year's best (Maslin).
 
"BRINGING OUT THE DEAD," starring Nicolas Cage and Patricia Arquette. Written by Paul Schrader from a novel by Joe Connelly. Directed by Martin Scorsese (R, 115 minutes). An intense, volatile film full of sorrow and wild, mordant humor. This time it took prop garbage on the streets of Hell's Kitchen to create a sufficiently hellish ambience for another nighttime tour of Manhattan. But Mr. Scorsese has mellowed significantly since his "Taxi Driver" days, and his uneven but impassioned, visually inventive new film is more contemplative than it looks. Mr. Cage gives a fine, soulful performance as a New York ambulance driver haunted by ghosts. Ving Rhames is a major scene-stealer as one of his partners (Maslin).
 
* "DOGMA," starring Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Linda Fiorentino, Chris Rock and Salma Hayek. Directed by Kevin Smith (R, 130 minutes). Mr. Smith's idea of angels in America is the notion of two cool dudes who take a hair-splitting, legalese approach to Roman Catholic doctrine and think it would be amusing to nullify all existence. And nothing in this wildly brazen, unexpectedly devout comedy is any less outrageous than that. Mr. Smith again shows off a rare gift for fusing his comic-book sensibility with serious debates and big, big laughs, even if some parts of his film (Ms. Fiorentino's performance, Mr. Rock's and semi-repartee from the ubiquitous Jay and Silent Bob) work better than others (an excrement monster). Making a gutsy leap into matters of faith, Mr. Smith miraculously emerges with his humor intact and his wings unsinged (Maslin).
 
"DOUBLE JEOPARDY," starring Ashley Judd, Tommy Lee Jones and Bruce Greenwood. Directed by Bruce Beresford (R, 106 minutes). In a touristy thriller that roams from the coastline of Washington State to the French Quarter of New Orleans, Ms. Judd plays a woman who is free to kill her husband because she has already gone to prison for the crime (see title). Not even she is beautiful enough to get away with rote acting and a far-fetched plot, but she perks up as her character becomes less of a victim. In this coed homage to "The Fugitive," Mr. Jones is on hand as another weathered sourpuss with a knack for barking orders. Mr. Beresford directs so unremarkably that it takes a line like "I feel like I've grown in the last six years" to signal the passage of time (Maslin).
 
* "FELICIA'S JOURNEY," starring Elaine Cassidy and Bob Hoskins. Directed by Atom Egoyan (PG-13, 116 minutes). In the brilliantly realized surreal thriller, adapted from William Trevor's popular novel, Felicia (Ms. Cassidy), a pregnant Irish girl searching for her boyfriend in the English midlands, is befriended by Joseph Hildritch (Mr. Hoskins), a catering manager who also happens to be a serial killer. Mr. Egoyan, Canada's most gifted filmmaker, elevates this cat-and-mouse game into a film that transcends genre by entering the characters' consciousness and implying a world of half-discernible connections in which the weather, the landscape and the chance encounters of strangers suggest the sense of a grand design (Holden).
 
"FLAWLESS," starring Robert De Niro and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Written and directed by Joel Schumacher (R, 110 minutes). Mr. De Niro is a retired New York City policeman recovering from a stroke and Mr. Hoffman the drag queen upstairs who gives him speech therapy in the form of singing lessons in this stridently campy comedy. Their flashy performances can't add dimension to a movie that is a message-laden duet for two caricatures, a homophobe and the angry, self-loathing drag queen who gets him out of his depression (Holden).
 
"HOUSE ON HAUNTED HILL," starring Geoffrey Rush, Taye Diggs and Peter Gallagher. Directed by William Malone (R, 115 minutes). If the ever vigilant Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is truly determined to snuff out inflation aborning, then he can do no better than to take sharpened pencil in hand, make his way to the nearest theater showing this film and strike fearlessly until its feeble pulse beats no more. This is a sorry reincarnation of the 1950's William Castle horror film in which an eccentric millionaire played by Vincent Price offered five strangers $10,000 each to spend the night in a spooky old mansion. In the new version the ante for survival has been raised to $1 million apiece. Even allowing for inflation in the 40 years since the original opened, the reward in 1999 should come to only $57,113.47, according to the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis. But some things have not become devalued over the years: words like junk, for example. "Hill" was pronounced junk in these pages in 1959. And it is still junk (Lawrence Van Gelder).
 
* "THE INSIDER," starring Al Pacino, Russell Crowe and Christopher Plummer. Directed by Michael Mann (R, 155 minutes). Mr. Mann directs this taut thriller about the tobacco industry whistle-blower Jeffrey Wigand with pulse-quickening panache. And he illustrates why, in the corporate climate of the 90's, truth-telling is a riskier business than it was circa "All the President's Men." While Mr. Pacino delivers galvanizing moral outrage as a producer for "60 Minutes," and Mr. Plummer wickedly mimics Mike Wallace, Mr. Crowe movingly captures the complexity of Mr. Wigand's situation. Shaky docudrama ethics cloud the film's take on "60 Minutes." But this is an inordinately well-played thriller, with Mr. Mann's stylistic brio at its best (Maslin).
 
* "LIBERTY HEIGHTS," starring Adrien Brody, Bebe Neuwirth, Joe Mantegna and Ben Foster. Directed and written by Barry Levinson (R, 134 minutes). This semi-autobiographical comedy-drama remembering teenage life, anti-Semitism and racism in mid-1950's Baltimore is the fourth movie by Mr. Levinson to be set in his native city. A deeply felt nostalgia trip, the movie adroitly captures the look and social attitudes of the city 45 years ago. But the screenplay and performances are too muted for the movie to come to terms with growing pains cushioned in the nostalgic haze (Holden).
 
* "THE LIMEY," starring Terence Stamp and Peter Fonda. Directed by Steven Soderbergh (R, 89 minutes). From a director for whom the quirky stylistic exercise is standard style, this is a handsome throwback to the salad days of its two iconic stars. Mr. Stamp, in a stony, magnetic performance punctuated by flashbacks to his early career, plays an ex-con seeking revenge for the death of his daughter. He becomes the nemesis of Mr. Fonda's slick Hollywood hipster, in another role that's piquantly tailor-made. Mr. Soderbergh resurrects the lean, hard-boiled look of John Boorman's "Point Blank" as he dissects and considers these two tough customers from every conceivable perspective (Maslin).
 
* "MANSFIELD PARK," starring Frances O'Connor and Jonny Lee Miller. Written and directed by Patricia Rozema (PG-13, 105 minutes). In Ms. Rozema's skillful screen adaptation of Jane Austen's third novel, the protagonist Fanny Price (Ms. O'Connor) has been sharpened into a proto-feminist heroine who triumphs over the materialist, patriarchal values of her wealthy relatives through a combination of wit, beauty and daring. Without bearing down too heavily, the screenplay (which incorporates fragments of Austen's letters and diaries) equates early 19th-century slave-trading with the oppression of women. The message is leavened with smart humor and warm three-dimensional performances (Holden).
 
"THE MESSENGER: THE STORY OF JOAN OF ARC," starring Milla Jovovich, John Malkovich, Tcheky Karyo and Faye Dunaway. Directed by Luc Besson (R, 130 minutes). The Hundred Years' War feels twice that long in this shrill, frenetic account of Joan of Arc. It's a film whose main revelation is that the Middle Ages may have been a lot more lurid than previously reported. Mr. Besson directs plenty of grisly, hand-held battle scenes and absurd scenes of royal scheming, while Ms. Jovovich talks. Like this. And doesn't seem faintly plausible as France's teenage martyr. Here's a case where "Don't shoot 'The Messenger' " would have been sound advice (Maslin).
 
"MUSIC OF THE HEART," starring Meryl Streep, Aidan Quinn, Angela Bassett and Gloria Estefan. Directed by Wes Craven (PG, 110 minutes). Not many of us enjoy being lectured by dressed-down Hollywood stars in gritty classroom situations. But the true story of Roberta Guaspari, a music teacher in East Harlem and a single mother surviving a nasty divorce, has been given a blunt, no-nonsense tone that works. Ms. Streep gives a down-to-earth performance that is sheer award bait. The story is inspirational enough to take Ms. Guaspari from no job prospects to watching her proud students play alongside Itzhak Perlman, Isaac Stern and other violin stars. Not a bad reason for Mr. Craven to have sidelined the claws and hatchets for a while (Maslin).
 
"POKEMON: THE FIRST MOVIE," with the voices of Veronica Taylor, Philip Bartlett, Rachael Lillis, Eric Stuart, Addie Blaustein and Ikue Otani. Directed by Kunihiko Yuyama (G, 90 minutes). Parents don't have to know all 151 monsters to understand "Pokemon: The First Movie," but they can observe several in action, including Pikachu, cutest of them all. The magic doesn't bridge the generation gap; whatever makes "Pokemon" such a huge pop-culture phenomenon is still a secret of the grammar school set, but the film is energetic and the animation is fun to watch. The plot is about a bioengineered Pokemon who lures young Pokemon trainers (including 12-year-old Ash of the television series) into a showdown. Characters spout pacifist profundities while pairs of monsters punch each other silly (Anita Gates).
 
* "PRINCESS MONONOKE," with the voices of Billy Crudup, Claire Danes, Billy Bob Thornton and Minnie Driver. Directed by Hayao Miyazaki (PG-13, 133 minutes). A landmark feat of Japanese animation from the acknowledged master of the genre. This complicated, exotically beautiful epic features gods and demons locked in battle for the future of the forest, and its visions are breathtakingly rendered. But it is the film's stirring use of nature, myth and Japanese history that makes it so special. Worth seeing just for its Forest Spirit, which takes animal form by day and roams the night as a diaphanous, Godzilla-like divinity. The image of plants and flowers springing to life beneath his hooves is ravishingly presented. Despite a superb blend of hand-drawn cels and fluid, computer-generated animation, the film's look is gratifyingly understated (Maslin).
 
* "RIDE WITH THE DEVIL," starring Skeet Ulrich, Tobey Maguire and Jewel. Directed by Ang Lee (R, 134 minutes). This contemplative Civil War epic, instead of concentrating on the major battles, looks at the outskirts of the conflict -- the Kansas-Missouri border -- where Confederate and Union guerrillas raid each other's outposts. The dramatic high point is a re-creation of Quantrill's Raid, in which a Confederate force swooped down on Lawrence, Kan., massacring 150 people. Mr. Maguire and Mr. Ulrich are childhood friends on the Confederate side, and the pop star Jewel (in her movie debut) is a young widow they both love. Even cooler in tone than "The Ice Storm," the movie is visually stunning and historically provocative but dramatically flat (Holden).
 
"ROSETTA," starring Emilie Dequenne. Directed by Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne (R, 90 minutes). This grim quasi-documentary, filmed with hand-held cameras (it's almost as jiggly as "The Blair Witch Project"), picked up the Palme d'Or (the top prize) at the Cannes Film Festival earlier this year. Ms. Dequenne was also chosen best actress for her portrayal of a miserable 17-year-old Belgian girl living in a trailer camp with her alcoholic mother. Her desperate quest for a job and what she calls a "normal life" leads her to betray her only friend, who works in a waffle stand, by stealing his job. Unlike the Dardenne brothers' last film, "La Promesse," the movie's social realist angst feels contrived, and its main character never fully comes to life (Holden).
 
"SLEEPY HOLLOW," starring Johnny Depp, Christina Ricci, Miranda Richardson, Michael Gambon, Jeffrey Jones, Michael Gough and Christopher Walken. Written by Andrew Kevin Walker and directed by Tim Burton (R, 110 minutes). This ornate visual fantasy, artfully concocted using a palette that suggests nuclear winter, has little to do with Washington Irving's story and everything to do with Mr. Burton's macabre vision. Mr. Depp makes a dashing hero as the film's shy detective, but the story (by the writer of "Seven" and "Fight Club") is determined to put the ick into Ichabod Crane. A first-rate cast and extraordinary technical talents are attention-getting here, but so is the film's penchant for sardonic beheadings. It's possible to admire Mr. Burton immensely, for the secret tenderness and rich imagination of his work, without wanting to peer at the exposed brain stems of his characters (Maslin).
 
* "THE STRAIGHT STORY," starring Richard Farnsworth and Sissy Spacek. Directed by David Lynch (G, 110 minutes). As the least likely filmmaker on the planet to pull off a G-rated miracle, Mr. Lynch rises to the challenge with exhilarating vigor. It may not sound like much, but this account of an old man making a long trip on a riding lawn mower turns out to be a slow-moving, folksy-looking, deeply spiritual film with the power to hold audiences in thrall. And as Oscar may well note next spring, it would not have been possible without Mr. Farnsworth's terse, no-nonsense honesty at its heart. Mr. Lynch's famously unwholesome imagination crosses a new frontier to explore simple virtues and natural beauty. The result: a supremely improbable triumph (Maslin).
 
"THREE KINGS," starring George Clooney, Mark Wahlberg and Ice Cube. Written and directed by David O. Russell (R, 105 minutes). The prodigiously talented writer-director of "Spanking the Monkey" and "Flirting With Disaster" has made a much more ambitious film, with mixed results. His gimlet-eyed Persian Gulf war film has a "Catch-22" absurdist edge, but it also has an oversupply of visual affectations. Vertiginous music-video camera tricks jazz up the otherwise straightforward story of American soldiers who have larcenous designs on Saddam Hussein's captured gold and then develop conscience pangs about their own roles in Iraq. There are many clever peripheral touches, but there's something tamely conventional at the film's core (Maslin).
 
* "TUMBLEWEEDS," starring Janet McTeer and Kimberly J. Brown. Directed by Gavin O'Connor (PG-13, 100 minutes). An astoundingly vital performance by the British actress Janet McTeer makes this small, beautifully acted slice of contemporary Americana a must-see film. Ms. McTeer is Mary Jo Walker, a sexy, free-spirited woman with four marriages behind her who travels across the country with her 12-year-old daughter, Ava (Ms. Brown). Like few other films, this one captures an intimately loving (though not conflict-free) relationship between a parent and child without becoming saccharine. The director plays Mary Jo's trucker boyfriend, who is only the latest in a series of her romantic disasters (Holden).
 
"THE WORLD IS NOT ENOUGH," starring Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Dame Judi Dench, Robert Carlyle and Denise Richards. Directed by Michael Apted (PG-13, 128 minutes). This director is much admired for his "Up" series chronicling the lives of former schoolchildren as they mature. And he has managed to make James Bond grow up a little, too. Mr. Brosnan has grown much more comfortable with the role of Bond, and most of the other characters are also more interesting than might have been expected. Ms. Marceau slinks memorably through the role of a treacherous oil heiress. Ms. Richards seemed a lot smarter playing high school vixens than she does as a brilliant scientist here. The itinerary roams from Scotland to Central Asia. And Mr. Apted handles the action as well as he does the talk (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
AFRICAN DIASPORA FILM FESTIVAL. Including 27 premieres, 52 films from 25 countries will be shown beginning today in the seventh African Diaspora Film Festival. Besides the features, shorts and documentaries from countries like South Africa, Ghana, Burkina Faso, Peru, Guyana, Australia, France, England and the United States, the festival includes question-and-answer sessions with directors and actors, panel discussions and a concluding concert. Among the highlights of the event, intended to portray the global black experience, are screenings of 11 award-winning films from Fespaco, Africa's largest film festival, and a focus on women as storytellers. The festival opens at 8:30 p.m. with Carlos Diegues's "Orfeu," a Brazilian film that updates the Greek myth and sets it in the pageantry of Carnival in Rio de Janeiro. The festival continues through Dec. 12. From today through Dec. 2, screenings are at Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 864-1760; from Dec. 3 to Dec. 8 at Twin Plaza Cinema, 314 Flatbush Avenue, Flatbush, Brooklyn, (718) 636-0110, and on Dec. 9 at Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, at 122nd Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 864-1760. Call the theaters for screening schedules. Tickets range from $8 for screenings to $20 for opening night (Van Gelder).

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 1; Column 2; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1828 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Stars in the Off Broadway Galaxy

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
ACTING awards may be self-indulgent and ever so tacky. But as long as we're stuck with them, why shouldn't there be a high-powered set of them for Off Broadway? Within the theater industry, the Obies, administered by The Village Voice, have considerable prestige, and the Drama Desks, parceled out to actors and productions on Broadway and off, certainly merit mention in Playbill bios.
Yet no one has devised the widely recognizable acting prizes that Off Broadway has so abundantly earned. I raise the issue (and not for the first time) not so much to encourage the further glitzing of New York's serious theater as to point out that when one has a hankering for great performances, more often than not the first places to look for satisfaction these days are the city's smaller stages. 
 Why this is so has a lot to do, of course, with the desperate recession of the straight play on Broadway: apart from John Pielmeier's failed thriller, "Voices in the Dark," and the comedy "Epic Proportions," no new Broadway play will have opened this season until David Hirson's "Wrong Mountain" bows in January. No such drought parches Off Broadway's landscape, however. There are, as always, a diverse and exceptional array of performers originating roles in new works and offering audiences that tantalizing drug of the theater: hope.
Earlier this year you could share the theatrical wealth with Viola Davis as the pitiable murderess in "Everybody's Ruby" at the Joseph Papp Public Theater; Lynne Thigpen setting off the bulk of the fireworks in "Jar the Floor" at Second Stage; Geoffrey Nauffts, Jodie Markell and David Alan Basche as unsettled yuppies in "Snakebit" for Naked Angels; and Darius de Haas as the young man lost to heroin and heartbreak in the Music-Theater Group's "Running Man."
They are only a sampling of who has come and gone of late (although there is talk of an impending transfer of "Jar the Floor" to Broadway). The pleasure of Off Broadway is that the door to discovery is a revolving one; the next terrific turn by an actor of note -- whether a familiar face or a complete unknown -- is only a matter of time.
As this is the season for giving, it's the ideal moment for a few reminders of the ways in which seamless, stylish performances are prizes unto themselves. Here, then, are a half-dozen examples of why casting directors for new Off Broadway plays may be the luckiest people in town.
STEPHEN SPINELLA. What a touching portrait of foolishness Mr. Spinella provides in "James Joyce's 'The Dead,' " the new musical based on the famous Joyce short story, now at Playwrights Horizons and moving to Broadway next month. On a stage overrun with fine singing actors -- among them Blair Brown, Marni Nixon, Sally Ann Howes and Emily Skinner -- Mr. Spinella sets his own ebullient pace as Freddy Malins, the happy drunk who so good-naturedly puts his foot in his mouth and leaves it there.
Not everyone is given such a beautifully drawn character in this musically rich if dramatically flawed evening; in thick mustache and natty bow tie, Mr. Spinella, who won back-to-back Tonys in 1993 and 1994 for his work in the two parts of "Angels in America," makes of Freddy a poignant party clown.
The actor, thankfully, avoids the pitfalls of ethnic stereotype. His bar song, "Three Jolly Pigeons," lifts the spirits as it celebrates spirits. Yet his Freddy is also a vaguely tragic character, drifting and remote, you intuit, whenever the music isn't playing.
 
Lisa Emery
In a crucial Act II encounter in "Dinner With Friends," Donald Margulies's splendid dissection of the anxiety that exists side by side with the comfort of long-term companionship, Ms. Emery's Karen sits down to lunch on a patio with her best friend, Beth, who is recently divorced and newly ecstatic over finding love again.
The scene progresses amiably until Beth, played wonderfully by Julie White, announces that she is going to marry again. The news upsets Karen in ways that seem unreasonable, and Beth lets her have it, accusing Karen of casting her as the perennial loser, of always needing her to remain a basket case.
Watching Ms. Emery process the information at the Variety Arts Theater is like peering into the back of a television set: you marvel at the sophisticated circuitry. Ms. Emery's Karen is a fuse that never burns completely down in "Dinner With Friends," and you are thankful for that. There is the sense in her performance of a fury that is better kept in check, and the thrill of her work here is that the danger of its exploding is ever present.
 
Mark McKinney
Daffy plays can go skin-crawlingly awry in the wrong hands. In the right ones, they're lighter than lemon meringue. And no one in the seriously loopy "Fuddy Meers" is righter or lighter than Mr. McKinney, who is emerging as one of the top-flight comic actors on the New York stage.
You may know his face from television, mostly squeezed into the wee hours: he performed for many years with the all-male Canadian comedy troupe "Kids in the Hall." His Spanish ambassador was the funniest player in the Roundabout's "Flea in Her Ear" a couple of years back, and his Millet, the dimwitted master of the sock puppet in David Lindsay-Abaire's hilarious new seven-character play on Stage II at the Manhattan Theater Club, is a goofball whom any fan of "The Three Stooges" can love.
In "Fuddy Meers," the puppet, Hinky Binky, which looks like a golf club cover with hands, is Millet's alter ego. Think of a Muppet with the mouth of Andrew Dice Clay, and you're in Hinky Binky's ballpark. Playing Millet and the puppet off each other, Mr. McKinney is a regular riot. One-man shows in New York have played to acclaim with a lot less going for them.
 
Linda Emond
Ms. Emond is one of those heroes of the theater who seem incapable of anything but excellence. In "An Experiment With an Air Pump" on the Manhattan Theater Club's main stage, she contributes yet another deeply intelligent and fully rounded performance to a growing list of personal successes, in shows like "The Dying Gaul," "Baby Anger" and "1776."
The cast of Shelagh Stephenson's "Experiment," which deals with the price of progress in two eras 200 years apart, is uniformly good. (Daniel Gerroll and Seana Kofoed are among the other standouts.) Ms. Emond, though, provides an extra level of satisfaction in the difficult task of doubling in the roles of two women -- one a frustrated wife in 1799, the other an ambitious geneticist in 1999 -- who offer a concise history lesson in the changing role of women across the ages.
Her introductory moments as the geneticist are some of her best. Called upon to reveal the character's passion for science, Ms. Emond takes us through a study of the 18th-century painting that gives the play its title. As related by the actress, it's a lovely, inviting prologue that offers immediate access to the interlocking themes of Ms. Stephenson's time-traveling play.
 
Sean Martin Hingston
Everyone makes a fuss about the Girl in the Yellow Dress. But what about the Guy in the Hairnet? Mr. Hingston is one of only two members of the 22-person ensemble who appear in all three of the dance plays that make up "Contact," the hit evening of dance-driven narrative at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater (and moving to the Beaumont in March).
Can you spot him in all three? In the first, "Swinging," a teasing curtain-raiser inspired by an 18th-century painting, "The Swing," Mr. Hingston is the hunky, poker-faced servant, pushing a sexually available young maid on a swing at her afternoon tryst with another man. In the third piece, "Contact," he plays one of the virile young swing dancers rejected again and again by the woman in yellow (Deborah Yates).
The inside joke is apparent in the second piece, "Did You Move?," in which Mr. Hingston is disguised as a cretinous restaurant employee, in glasses and hairnet, dragging Italian foodstuffs across the floor of the Queens restaurant in which Karen Ziemba dances her whimsical dream ballet. The gamut he runs in "Contact," from desirable to repulsive, is in both choreographic and dramatic terms, a leap of imagination.
 
Paula Pizzi
Ms. Pizzi has a slightly mysterious accent: it sounds vaguely Mediterranean. Her character's name, Susie Monahan, sheds no light on her origins. But there's nothing the least bit inauthentic about her performance as the empathetic nurse in "Wit," the Pulitzer Prize-winning and astonishingly long-running play at the Union Square Theater about a poetry professor's intellectual, emotional and terminal struggle with cancer.
If it is surprising that a play that deals so realistically with illness has developed a loyal following -- any drama that runs more than a year in New York has to qualify as a minor miracle -- the work of actors like Ms. Pizzi goes some way in explaining why. Her rendering of a nurse who ministers as much to the person as to the disease is the playwright Margaret Edson's sole acknowledgment here of the medical world's ability to feel as well as heal.
The director Derek Anson Jones could not have cast the role with a more profound sense of where the play's conscience lies. Ms. Pizzi's Susie is a lamb until her patient requires a tiger, and it is when this actress crosses over to fierceness in the climactic scene that "Wit" gives full vent to the outrages against the soul that some doctors may perpetrate in the name of fixing the body.
 
Where and When They're Playing
 
Here are the Off Broadway shows discussed in the critic's notebook article on noteworthy performances:
 
"AN EXPERIMENT WITH AN AIR PUMP." Manhattan Theater Club, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2:30 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2:30 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $50.
"CONTACT." Newhouse, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3. Tickets: $55 and $80; very limited. Moves to the Beaumont on March 9.
"FUDDY MEERS." Manhattan Theater Club, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. Tuesdays through Fridays at 7:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays at 3 and 7:30 p.m.; Tickets: $40.

SECTION: Section A; Page 43; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 697 words

HEADLINE: A Missile Shield Could Backfire

BYLINE: By James Lindsay and Michael O'Hanlon; James Lindsay and Michael O'Hanlon are senior fellows at the Brookings Institution.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The presidential campaign may be heating up, but Republicans and Democrats are sounding remarkably alike on at least one important issue. Candidates on both sides want to build a national defense against missile attack.
The idea is sound, but a politically motivated rush to carry it out could do more harm than good. The technology for a missile shield isn't ready, and there's another, larger problem: Building it too fast risks damaging our relationship with Russia and could fuel nationalist fervor just as a Russian presidential election approaches. 
 A missile defense was once a Republican idea, and, predictably, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has pledged to begin deploying a system soon after taking office.
But the Clinton administration has also announced plans for a limited version capable of intercepting a few warheads and set to be ready in Alaska by 2005. Vice President Al Gore has not strayed from that position.
The administration hopes to reach a formal decision on its plan by the spring and to begin work before the Alaskan soil freezes in the fall, with official groundbreaking in the spring of 2001. Somewhere along that time line, the United States would violate the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, which prohibits a nationwide missile defense.
Despite its political appeal, a spring 2000 decision to build such a shield makes little sense technologically. Earlier this fall, the Pentagon successfully maneuvered a missile to strike and destroy a target warhead. But only 3 of a planned 19 tests are to be complete by next spring. Some technology for the system has yet to be developed, requiring tests to use jury-rigged rockets, and the program is short of parts. In 1998, a panel of defense experts headed by Larry D. Welch, a former Air Force chief of staff, described the compressed development schedule as a technological "rush to failure." It reiterated that conclusion several weeks ago.
The diplomatic dangers are even more compelling. Deciding to break the ABM Treaty would fan anti-Americanism in Russia just as the furor there over NATO's war against Serbia could be expected to be ebbing -- and just as Russian voters get ready to choose a new president next summer. That atmosphere could easily help elect a hard-line candidate, and the new government might retaliate by suspending work on bilateral programs intended to secure Russian nuclear materials and by refusing to take further steps to reduce the size of Russia's decrepit yet dangerous nuclear force.
The prospects for Russian economic reform might also suffer if the country's leaders decided to increase military spending. Finally, an embittered Russia might retaliate by selling nuclear and ballistic-missile technologies to rogue countries.
The United States does have good reasons to build a missile defense eventually. The ABM Treaty was intended to curb the superpower arms race of the cold war, and much of its basic logic no longer applies. The number of countries capable of attacking the United States with long-range missiles is growing; North Korea may soon be in this club.
Russia's concerns about missile defense, while partially understandable, are exaggerated. The small system that the administration is considering would not threaten Russia's nuclear deterrent. If Russia rejects reasonable efforts to reach an accommodation, the United States should eventually withdraw from the ABM Treaty.
But for now, we shouldn't have to choose between building a missile defense and maintaining good relations and cooperation on nuclear security with Russia. Before deploying any such system, we should work with the new Russian president to try to modify the treaty.
We may have to consider steps like reducing American nuclear forces, suspending the steps toward eastward NATO expansion and otherwise demonstrating to leaders in Moscow that the proposed system is a response not to their missiles, but to weapons from countries like Iraq and North Korea.
Rushing a decision on missile defense during a presidential year, when tempers are short in both countries and the necessary technology is not even ready, is nothing short of foolhardy.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Morgan Stanley Sets Price on Japanese Debt

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The Tokyo office of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter priced the first set of bonds linked to nonperforming Japanese real estate loans today, paving the way for what may be a flood of deals aimed at clearing away the mountain of bad debt on the balance sheets of Japanese banks and financial institutions.
"This is the first time a capital markets solution has been used to bring new investors and liquidity into the real estate market here," said Douglas Kennedy, executive director of the securitized products group at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo. 
 The deal was worth 21 billion yen, or about $200 million, making it larger than many in the market had thought. Mr. Kennedy said all but 4 billion yen of the bonds had AAA or AA credit ratings.
He said about 60 percent of the securities would be sold to Japanese investors, with the rest distributed about equally between Europe and the United States.
Foreign investment bankers have long advocated the development of a market in securities tied to Japan's large pool of nonperforming real estate debt. The precise figures are still unknown, but rough estimates suggest that Japanese financial institutions hold 80 trillion to 100 trillion yen, or $766 billion to $957 billion, in bad debt. As much as 50 percent of it is related to real estate, which lends itself to securitization, in which loans are packaged and sold as bonds to investors.
Mr. Kennedy said that if only 10 percent of those real estate loans were suitable for securitization, underwriters would have the opportunity for 250 deals.
But until a year or so ago, banks and other financial institutions had been slow to jettison their bad debts, afraid of damaging long-held relationships. Banks have tended to write off their bad loans by gathering reserves against them, which leaves the assets on their books.
That is changing, Mr. Kennedy said, noting that the mortgages that Morgan Stanley cobbled together to sell today had all been bought by Morgan Stanley between August 1998 and March 1999. "Financial institutions are really serious about cleaning up their balance sheets now, but it's only happened in the last two years," he said.
That, coupled with a renewed appetite for Japanese assets in general among global investors, and changes in laws governing real estate transactions, led to the opportunity that Morgan Stanley took today.

HEADLINE: Canadian Index at Record High On SurgingTechnology Shares

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Canada's benchmark stock index rose to a record yesterday, its first in more than a year and a half, powered by a monthlong surge in technology stocks.
The index, the Toronto Stock Exchange 300 composite, jumped 88.89 points, or 1.1 percent, to 7,853.39, surpassing the previous record of 7,822.55 set on April 22, 1998. Recessions in emerging markets, declining commodity prices and a falling Canadian dollar brought the index down from its previous high and dragged it as low as 5,336.16 on Oct. 5, 1998. 
 Trading was light yesterday with the United States markets closed in observance of Thanksgiving.
While Toronto-Dominion Bank and other financial-services stocks accounted for a portion of the gains, technology stocks like Nortel Networks, BCE and JDS Uniphase were the principal engine of the index's 10 percent rally through November.
Nortel, BCE and JDS account for more than 25 percent of the total market capitalization of the index, and their shares have been lifted by the soaring Nasdaq market in the United States. More than half of the Nortel and JDS shares traded in North America are traded in the United States.
In London, British stocks rose, pushing the FTSE 100 index to a record as three of Britain's biggest companies closed in on mergers.
The FTSE 100 rose 121 points, or 1.8 percent, to 6,682.80 and hit a record 6,686.10. About as many shares rose as fell, with buying focused on the biggest stocks.
German stocks rose, paced by Mannesmann amid optimism Vodafone may raise its hostile offer for the mobile phone company. Deutsche Telekom followed Mannesmann's lead. The DAX Xetra index of 30 major companies rose 142.72 points, or 2.45 percent, to 5,961.45.
In France, stocks rose, pushing the benchmark CAC 40 index up 163.22 points, or 3.15 percent, to a record 5,352.60.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei average of 225 Japanese stocks fell 174.43 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 18,721.78.

HEADLINE: The S.E.C. Tries to Make Companies TakeSmaller Baths

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
HERE was a time when the accounting police worried about companies that tried to avoid reporting losses. Now the cops are trying to keep companies from taking excessive write-downs.
That such vigilance is necessary is a commentary on the fads and fashions of Wall Street. Starting in the 1980's, companies discovered that they could look good if they reported certain kinds of losses that reflected efforts to become lean and mean. Analysts were persuaded to ignore such charges and concentrate on operating earnings. 
 Over time, the size and frequency of such write-offs grew. "Call this behavior Son of Gresham," wrote Warren E. Buffett in Berkshire Hathaway's latest annual report. "Bad accounting drives out good." He added that "the distortion du jour is the 'restructuring charge,' an accounting entry that can, of course, be legitimate but that all too often is a device for manipulating earnings."
The accounting rule makers tried in 1994 and 1995 to put limits on such write-offs, but their efforts met with success that can be generously described as limited. Last year, Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, complained that companies were taking "big baths" to get costs out of the way and make their subsequent profits look better than they were. Now the S.E.C. has produced a staff accounting bulletin that may reduce the abuses.
"There is a growing trend here which is disturbing," said Lynn E. Turner, the S.E.C.'s chief accountant, in an interview just after the bulletin was released on Thanksgiving Eve. He recalled how Americans used to mock the way European companies could create reserves to hide earnings swings and said that such things were now happening in this country.
Mr. Turner thinks the rules on such write-offs should be tightened and said he hoped the Financial Accounting Standards Board would do just that. But for now, the bulletin simply lays out the existing rules with details and examples that may make restructuring reserves smaller and less common. It should strenghten auditors' backbones when their clients try to take the biggest possible baths.
When taking a restructuring write-off, companies must specifically identify and disclose the costs involved and the anticipated effects on future profits. They must say which plants will be closed and which departments and locations will make layoffs. They need to be certain that the restructuring will happen. "When you set up one of these reserves, you have to be pretty sure that those are the costs you'll incur," Mr. Turner said. "When you get out there two or three years down the road, I don't see how you can do that." If cost estimates prove to be too high, companies may not use the reserve to hide other expenses.
I've talked to enough companies over the years to know that many companies have taken a more cavalier approach than the S.E.C. thinks correct, either in disclosing details of restructuring charges or in taking write-offs for things that may never happen. A couple of weeks ago, General Motors reported that it may have to reverse a good part of a $1.1 billion reserve because the strong economy means that it won't be cutting jobs as previously planned.
It will be interesting to see how many companies, confronted with the new bulletin, decide that they need to make adjustments to previous restructuring charges. What advice, I asked Mr. Turner, would he give to a chief financial officer in such a position?
"Take Maalox," he said, "before you eat turkey."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Low-Income Bronx Apartments Near Completion

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Occupancy will begin in January at an apartment complex taking shape in the shadow of Yankee Stadium. The two buildings, with 252 apartments, represent one of the largest low-income rental housing projects erected in the South Bronx in recent years.
The $32 million project, to be completed in June, stands on a long-vacant two-acre site off East 165th Street between Gerard and River Avenues, four blocks north of the stadium. It will have two seven-story buildings facing Gerard Avenue, each with two three-story wings extending west to River Avenue and separated by landscaped courtyards, as well as a parking area for 50 cars. 
 The apartments, from studios to two bedrooms, with 450 to 750 square feet each, will be offered to families earning $14,000 to $34,620 a year, depending on family size, at rents of $350 to $637 a month. The developers have received more than 10,000 applications for the apartments, and are creating a list of eligible occupants. The buildings, called River Court and Gerard Court, are being developed by Related Companies, a large Manhattan developer, in partnership with the Leewood Real Estate Group of Staten Island.
The project is part of a new crop of more than 10,000 low- and moderate-income houses and rental apartments that have been built in the South Bronx since 1993. The activity has been spurred by city, state and federal financing programs.
One is the 100 Percent Low-Income Tax-Exempt Program, under which River Court and Gerard Court received financing. The program, started in 1997 by the city's Housing Development Corporation, combines low-interest loans financed by tax-exempt bonds with other public funding sources. The below-market loans allow developers to build apartments affordable to people earning no more than 60 percent of their area's median income.
Under the program, developers receive a loan from the housing corporation for at least half of a building's construction cost. In exchange, they agree to make all of the units affordable to low-income tenants.
The rest of the financing comes primarily from the sale of federal low-income housing tax credits to investors who use them to reduce federal taxes.
To repay the bonds, the developers can tap one of several other public- financing sources. One of them is the city's tax-abatement-certificates program, which links subsidies for market-rate housing in parts of Manhattan to production of low-income units elsewhere in the city.
Under that program, developers of the low-income housing get five certificates for every low-income apartment they build, which they can sell to developers of market-rate housing south of 96th Street in Manhattan. Each certificate entitles such developers to a property-tax exemption on an apartment; the exemptions are phased out over 10 years.
Russell A. Harding, the president of the housing corporation, said that pairing bond financing with federal tax credits as well as other funding sources in a single project, rather than allocating them separately, has proven effective in creating low-income housing at a time of limited public financing.
In the two years since the program began, the housing corporation has issued $118 million in tax-exempt bonds to finance 34 projects, most of which, Mr. Harding said, and developers agreed, would probably not have been built otherwise. The projects have or will produce over the next year 1,740 new and renovated rental apartments, mainly in northern Manhattan, eastern Brooklyn and the south-central Bronx.
In addition to River Court and Gerard Court, four other projects, with a total of 221 rentals, have been or will soon be completed in the Bronx. And two others, one with 79 units on East 148th Street and Brook Avenue, the other with 68 apartments at 1118 Intervale Avenue, will be developed over the next 12 months.
The River Court and Gerard Court project illustrates how the program works. The developers received $16.2 million in bond financing and secured a letter of credit from Hypo Bank to guard the bondholders from default. The sale of federal tax credits raised an additional $13.2 million, and the rest was the partners' own money, said R. Randy Lee, president of Leewood Real Estate.
The partners will sell 1,260 tax certificates generated by the project to repay the bonds and recoup their investment. The certificates will be sold to several Manhattan builders, and Related will also buy some for market-rate projects it is developing.
Mr. Lee said that without this program "a project of this scale could not have been built, because there are no other governmental programs that allow you to develop affordable rentals for working families."
This is the seventh low-income rental project the partners have developed in New York City in the last decade, and their first in the South Bronx. Its site, across River Avenue from the No. 4 train line, was once part of a larger empty parcel that another developer began to transform into low-income housing in the late 1980's. But that developer built only one 110-apartment building, on the corner of 166th Street and Gerard Avenue, before the city's housing market fizzled in the early 1990's.
The remaining two acres sat vacant until 1997, when Related and Leewood decided to build housing on it.
The two buildings were designed by Meltzer/Mandl Architects of Manhattan with varying heights of three and seven stories to provide more light and air into the apartments and avoid creating "a single giant box of a building," said Mr. Lee. The taller part of the structures also are on Gerard Avenue, farthest away from the noise of the No. 4 train line, which is elevated at that point, The entrance to the low-rise sections are off the interior courtyards, which will also have seating areas for tenants, Mr. Lee said. Occupancy will begin in January at River Court, and in June at Gerard Court.

HEADLINE: An Oasis of Peace in Somalia Seeks Freedom

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: BURAO, Somalia

 BODY:
It has been nearly nine years since the people of northwest Somalia gathered here to declare themselves separate from the chaos of the rest of their country. They created a government. They rebuilt their villages and businesses. A young veterinarian named Mohammed Nur Arale saw enough peace recently to invest in a luxury unknown in this town since 1988: a gas station with a pump that actually works.
"The mentality of the people is not the same," he said. "Now everyone has put down their arms. Everyone was just fed up with all of it." 
 The self-proclaimed Republic of Somaliland has become one of Africa's fledgling success stories -- but a success the outside world has been reluctant to help because no one is quite sure what to do with it.
Somaliland presents a quandary because it wants to be recognized as an independent nation. Its people argue that this would acknowledge their land as an island of peace separate from Somalia, a country so lawless that Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, recently referred to it as a "black hole."
African leaders hold few notions as sacred as the usually arbitrary borders drawn by and inherited from their European colonial rulers, because those frontiers define their power. They fear that if Somaliland splits off and becomes independent, what might happen to Nigeria, whose vast territory is riven by ethnic and religious differences? Or to Congo, Sudan and Angola, where competing factions and countries have exploited civil wars to carve fiefs that are essentially self-contained states? Is Africa to go the way of the old Yugoslavia, or Indonesia, where violence and strivings for independence have redrawn frontiers and led to new states?
And so, with another round of peace talks on the whole of Somalia scheduled to begin imminently, Somaliland is caught in what its foreign minister calls a "twilight zone," in which it exists in nearly every way as its own state, but survives on a mere trickle of foreign aid and cannot get access to international loans or banks.
The rest of the world, and the United States in particular, has done their best to forget Somalia since 1993. That year, 24 peacekeepers were killed in an ambush in June and, four months later, 18 American servicemen died in a battle in Mogadishu during the United Nations' effort to bring food and stability to a starving Somalia.
The United States, which had entered Somalia with great fanfare in 1992, proclaiming this the sort of intervention that would define the new world order that was supposed to follow the cold war, pulled out soon after those killings. So did the United Nations. Outside help dried up to nearly nothing. And Somalia became a symbol for anarchy, the disaster of misplaced foreign aid -- and how costly it can be for the West to intervene in conflicts it does not understand.
Now, a new consensus has begun to emerge among many outside nations and certainly among Somalis themselves: something needs to be done.
Certainly, that is the view of people in Somaliland, from businessmen like Mohammed Ahmed Barji, who trades in television sets, generators and mopeds and must load up suitcases with up to $50,000 in cash to go on buying trips abroad, to its president, Mohammed Ibrahim Egal, who says simply: "We want to be let in from the cold."
"After nine years we feel frozen," Mr. Egal, 69, a big man with a gray goatee, said in an interview. "Today it is a question of pride sustaining them," he said of the two million people of Somaliland. "But it may not be that way in five years. How much longer will they be able to be sustained by pride but on an empty stomach?"
For the outside world, there is another motive to attempt to restore something resembling order to Somalia, which has been without a central government since 1991, when the dictatorship of Siad Barre was overthrown after 22 years of misrule and an interminable civil war. The warlords and militias -- though substantially weakened -- continue to block peace.
In this power vacuum, diplomats and other experts say, Somalia is becoming a center for Islamic fundamentalism, for the smuggling of arms and drugs and the export of terrorism. Parts of the bombs that exploded in August 1998 at the United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania reportedly passed through Somalia, and supposedly the bombings' suspected mastermind, Osama bin Laden, did too, sometime later.
"We share the concerns that this place is in a state of chaos and is definitely a breeding ground for all kinds of trouble," said one American official.
That is exactly how the rest of Somalia is viewed by the people of Somaliland, who consider themselves different from the south.
Since colonial days -- when the Somali people were divided into five states -- Somaliland has had its own history. It was a British protectorate until 1960. It united with the Italian Somali colony four days after independence, creating modern Somalia. But Somaliland was never happy with the arrangement, wanting to revert to the borders of the British protectorate.
So in 1991, after Mr. Barre fell, a group of elders, intellectuals and other leaders came to this town to create the independent Somaliland republic. Progress was slow -- two civil wars were fought since then -- but over time the clan militias disarmed. The people created an unusual parliament mixing democracy with the traditional leadership of elders and clans.
And Somaliland has largely been blessed with peace.
"There was fighting five years ago and lots of banditry," said Muhammad Ahmed, 34, who calls out prayers in the biggest mosque in Hargeysa, about 100 miles west of here. "But it has completely changed. It's like the difference between the ground and the sky."
Ahmed Abdi Edan, 30, said he could never find work during the years of war. But in 1995 he got a job as an English teacher in Hargeysa.
"I really do think it is peace that let me find a job," he said. "Without peace you cannot live."
On a recent day, he was wandering around downtown Hargeysa -- still littered with what is left of the buildings bombed by the Barre government in 1988 -- to do a little investing: He was buying up American currency in the hope that it will rise against the Somaliland shilling.
That entrepreneurial spirit is perhaps the greatest strength of the Somalilanders, half of whom still live as nomads with their camels and goats.
In a few years, businessmen there have created one of cheapest telephone systems in Africa: international calls are $1.50 a minute in the day and only 80 cents at night. Traders are working to export frankincense and myrrh, and exploration has begun for oil and gemstones.
But the success of Somaliland rests on a shaky foundation. Its greatest accomplishment is undoubtedly peace, though the price is high: Over 70 percent of the budget (itself only $20 million) goes to maintaining a huge army and police force -- composed of former militia members who have agreed not to fight each other in return for their jobs.
That leaves nothing for education, health or roads. Many Somalis are thus becoming impatient with Mr. Egal and his government.
"Of course they can do more," said Hussein Egeh, a 59-year-old livestock trader who had fled Somalia 20 years ago but has returned to do business because of the peace in Somaliland. "What is a government for? When you have peace you don't just sit back."
Moreover, many in Somaliland distrust Mr. Egal, fearing that he may compromise on Somaliland's independence -- and may, as many foreign powers have urged him to do, find a way to reunite with the south.
"That will be the end of him, if he says we're going to the south," said Ismail Hirsi, a 30-year-old street businessman who changes as much $1,000 a day, money sent from Somalis living abroad. "He can't do that."
Mr. Egal argues that the answer to Somaliland's problems lies in recognition from other nations, which would open the floodgates for foreign aid and borrowing. As it stands, the United Nations and European Union are the biggest investors in Somaliland's recovery but the money is "peanuts," as one European aid worker put it.
On a recent trip abroad, Mr. Egal and his ministers argued their case with senior officials in Italy, Libya and the United States. They received lots of sympathy but little success. The international community, Somaliland leaders say, has promised a peace dividend for parts of Somalia that find stability. But without recognition, Somaliland has been unable to get money from institutions like the World Bank or the International Monetary Fund.
"They are very generous in dishing out promises," the foreign minister, Mahmoud Saleh Nour, said. "But very stingy in delivering."
Both Mr. Annan and American officials have discussed a kind of compromise -- a special status, similar to the West Bank or Kosovo, that would allow Somaliland to gain loans and more aid from outside nations without full recognition. But that seems unlikely while a new peace initiative, led by neighboring Djibouti, still holds promise.
This initiative is different because it looks for leadership in the south, not among the warlords but from elders, intellectuals, women's groups as well as businessmen and religious leaders.
Still, few experts hold much hope that even after nearly a decade of anarchy Somalia is ready to find peace -- or that Somaliland will go along.

HEADLINE: Strange Can't Begin to Describe It;
Fulani and Buchanan See an Upside to Political Marriage

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
One day soon, if all goes as planned, a woman who has campaigned time and again in Harlem for political office will do so again. But this time, Lenora Fulani, two-time presidential candidate, former standard-bearer of the now-defunct New Alliance Party, and perpetual thorn in the Democratic Party's side, will have company.
Ms. Fulani, long known as a far-left espouser of Marxist-Leninist politics, has promised to help Patrick J. Buchanan, a Reaganite and cold warrior known for his far-right politics, in his quest for the Reform Party nomination for president. In endorsing him earlier this month, she promised to take him to Harlem. 
 The reaction of Representative Charles Rangel, whose district includes Harlem, was typical. "Only in America," he said. "I just wish I had been the fly on the wall when they made that alliance."
Everyone agrees the alliance is unusual; some would call it unholy. Either way, Ms. Fulani, one of the more colorful, perennial figures in New York politics, has once again formed a relationship that allows her to keep a toehold in American politics.
By working within the Reform Party, where Ms. Fulani has a significant base of support and is its most prominent black member, she may be on the verge of gaining a national foothold for the first time -- much to the dismay of her critics, who are legion. Ms. Fulani and her close associate, Fred Newman, the founder of the New Alliance Party, have been accused repeatedly of anti-Semitism, entwining group therapy and politics in a cult-like way, and of enriching personal enterprises through public monies in the form of federal election funds.
Roger J. Stone, the director of the presidential exploratory committee of Donald J. Trump, a potential Reform Party rival of Mr. Buchanan, wasted no time calling Ms. Fulani a "con artist" and a "huckster."
Speaking of Mr. Trump's recent criticism of Fidel Castro, Mr. Stone said: "We find it ironic that on the same day Donald Trump was in Miami condemning a Marxist, Pat Buchanan was climbing into bed with one."
While Ms. Fulani and Mr. Buchanan have tried to stress their common economic populism, and particularly their antipathy for free trade, neither has made a real attempt to pretend they had, or would, reach agreement on the issues.
"He and I have never had an issue-oriented dialogue because there's nothing to talk about," Ms. Fulani said.
Mr. Newman, who has been Ms. Fulani's political Pygmalion, shaping her career, her image, her decisions, said: "He has positions that are antithetical to everything Fulani has said for years and everything I have stood for for years. Some of his rhetoric on immigration I find repulsive -- I can use no other word."
What brought Mr. Buchanan and Ms. Fulani together, they said at a news conference, was the banner that Ms. Fulani has carried since the early 1980's, and that Mr. Buchanan has suddenly hoisted: breaking the "iron grip" of the two-party system on American politics.
Ms. Fulani's driving issues are things like same-day voter registration, which she believes could give independent parties a fairer shot at the polls. She has arrived at a politics about process, bleached, for the time being, of issues and ideology.
"Issue politics were not given to us by Moses," she said.
Mr. Stone and other critics say that the real reason the two have pooled their efforts is to pursue the millions of dollars in federal matching funds that will go to the Reform Party nominee.
How much minority support Ms. Fulani can deliver is hard to gauge. Where she can help Mr. Buchanan is in complying with Reform Party rules that require him to gain enough signatures to qualify for the ballot in the 29 states -- and the District of Columbia -- where the party does not have an automatic slot.
It is a daunting task, requiring 700,000 to 800,000 signatures in total. Mr. Buchanan has said he does not have the personnel to do it. Ms. Fulani -- who collected 1.5 million signatures to get on the ballots in 1988 -- has both the foot soldiers and expertise (she has waged numerous court battles over ballot access).
In return, she gets, if not legitimacy, publicity. Eleven years ago, this self-described "poor black woman from Chester, Pa." waged a largely unheralded candidacy for president. She managed to get on the ballot in all 50 states, the first woman and the first black to do so, and received more than 200,000 votes.
The process was exhilarating to her; the lack of recognition -- by the media and political establishment -- embittering. So Ms. Fulani's endorsement of Mr. Buchanan seemed as much about drawing the spotlight to her as bolstering his campaign.
It worked. The endorsement quickly became grist for the talk show mill. It provoked agitated commentary everywhere from the Rush Limbaugh show to callers on WLIB. Ms. Fulani, on the margins for her entire political career, was suddenly in an eddy of the mainstream.
"She's now getting media attention she's never gotten and she can speak for these issues," Mr. Newman said, referring to her political reform agenda.
Mr. Newman and Ms. Fulani are also banking that Mr. Buchanan can earn enough votes to ensure that the Reform Party retains its federal matching funds.
The cost has been some blistering criticism. "I know politics makes strange bedfellows, but there has to be principles involved, and there are no principles here," said Michael A. Hardy, a former Fulani associate -- and admirer -- who serves as the lawyer for the Rev. Al Sharpton. "This is worse than Hitler-Stalin: this destroys a movement," he said, referring to a third party's potential to benefit African-Americans.
In the end, the endorsement is more likely to hurt Mr. Buchanan, who does have a core of committed supporters, than Ms. Fulani, who for all her talk about broadening American democracy, has often been most effective marshalling a committed cadre within a political party.
"Fulani and myself have such little credibility that there's not that much to lose," Mr. Newman said.
Pat Choate, the co-chairman of Mr. Buchanan's campaign, rejected the criticism that Mr. Buchanan had betrayed his base. "He's a candidate going out to win the presidency and he is building a coalition that can win it," he said.
For Ms. Fulani, however, there is, however, much to gain: along with a national stage, real power in New York politics -- and specifically, next year's Senate race. Over the past five years, Ms. Fulani and her supporters have gradually gained power in the state's Independence Party. The party now has the third line on the ballot; who it lends that line to in the Senate race could be crucial in a close election. (In New York State, the Independence Party is the Reform Party's outlet.)
Ms. Fulani is part of a "Democracy Coalition" that is trying to unseat the current chairman, Jack Essenberg, along with two-thirds of the party's executive committee, for "disloyalty and corruption."
"The Fulani group has basically infiltrated the party and wants to take it over and control it," Mr. Essenberg said.
Ms. Fulani responded by saying: "It's a democracy war. It's magnificent."
Laureen Oliver, the party co-founder and the leader of the Democracy Coalition, said that she has worked with Ms. Fulani because so far, she has done nothing to betray non-centrist leanings. "She has not made any extreme leftist statements since she's been in the party," Ms. Oliver said. "Lenora's what you call 'blending' now. She's blending into the party."
If she blends effectively enough, it could lead to this improbable scenario: Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton both having to court Ms. Fulani's support to win the Independence Party's backing.
Mr. Newman said that Cathy Stewart, a close Fulani ally and the chairwoman of the Manhattan County Independence Party, had already had a brief discussion with Judith Hope, the chairwoman of the state Democratic Party. Ms. Hope would say only of the party generally, "Where we can find mutual goals and cooperation, it can be helpful."
Giuliani campaign officials would not comment on either Ms. Fulani or the Independence Party.
Of course, it is also possible that neither candidate will pass muster, and Ms. Fulani herself will run. She is coy about the prospect, but does not deny that it is a possibility.
She has already run for mayor, governor, lieutenant governor, and president, attracting columns of controversy along the way. She has embraced Muammar Qaddafi and Louis Farrakhan, and heckled Bill Clinton. She and Mr. Newman have made statements that have been denounced as anti-Semitic by Jewish groups like the Anti-Defamation League, even as they have repeatedly repudiated anti-Semitism.
The New Alliance Party, which was disbanded when Mr. Newman and Ms. Fulani joined forces first with the Patriot Party, then the Reform Party, was also criticized for its close links to Mr. Newman's extensive "social therapy" practice. The practice operated on the premise that political activism could help overcome emotional problems, and numerous therapy recipients also went into party work.
Mr. Newman also heads a complex constellation of businesses and nonprofit organizations, including a theater and publishing house, some of which benefited from the federal matching funds Ms. Fulani's 1992 presidential campaign earned. The funds went to different Newman and New Alliance Party enterprises for services like consulting and advertising, to buy -- at an elevated rate -- copies of the party newspaper, to rent office space from the party, and so on. The Federal Election Commission ordered the party to repay the government $117,000 for not doing arms-length transactions.
Ms. Fulani and Mr. Newman say (and Congressman Rangel, for one, agrees) that their practices were no different from the Democratic Party's, which they said also gives business and contracts to patrons and supporters. She has accused the Democratic Party of "postmodern political apartheid." Black leaders, she says, have sold out by insisting on support for a party that has repeatedly ignored black interests.
But even those who agree with that assessment wonder if Mr. Buchanan is the answer. Ms. Fulani's flirtation with him dates back at least to 1996, when she wrote that, like Ross Perot and Mr. Farrakhan, he had been demonized by the media: "He has tapped into the anti-government, anti-big-business, pro-people sentiments of a significant portion of the American people."
Now Ms. Fulani is forging ahead with her plan to bring Mr. Buchanan to Harlem, and specifically to the National Action Network, the headquarters of her erstwhile ally, the Rev. Al Sharpton.
The two worked closely together in the late 1980's and early 1990's, when "Rev.," as she calls him, was just venturing into electoral politics.
But Ms. Fulani says she felt betrayed when Mr. Sharpton ran for Senate as a Democrat in 1992, rather than under the New Alliance Party, after she had collected tens of thousands of signatures to help get him on the ballot. The break, she said, affected their friendship. Mr. Sharpton now plays down that friendship, saying they were never as close as the media projected.
He has yet to hear an explanation of the endorsement, he said. "Their concern is how do you build another party," he said of Ms. Fulani and her allies. "My view is, if the issues aren't more important than the party, then what are we in it for?"
