HEADLINE: Radiation Ripples From Big Bang Illuminate Geometry of Universe

BYLINE: By JAMES GLANZ 

 BODY:
Like the great navigators who first sailed around the world, establishing its size and the curvature of its surface, astronomers have made new observations that show with startling directness the large-scale geometry of the universe and the total amount of matter and energy that it contains.
The results of those observations have provided powerful support for an audacious theory, first proposed 20 years ago, that may help answer the ultimate existential question: what ignited the Big Bang explosion in which scientists believe the universe was born? 
 The delicate measurements relied on telescopes placed high on mountains or borne by balloons to observe slight irregularities, or ripples, in a faint glow that permeates space and is thought to have been emitted from the fading fireball of the Big Bang explosion itself.
That glow is called the cosmic microwave background radiation, and the ripples imprinted on it can be used like ticks on a ruler to measure the cosmos.
The new data also provides fresh evidence to support a finding two years ago that the expansion of the universe is accelerating under the influence of a strange form of energy that fills empty space and apparently acts against gravity.
Many researchers had assumed that the bizarre finding would eventually be disproved, but the new observations support the existence of this energy, as well as the theory of what set off the Big Bang, called inflation, which was first proposed in 1980 by Dr. Alan Guth, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
"It has such tremendous implications for the universe," Dr. Rocky Kolb, a cosmologist at the University of Chicago, said of the new work. Dr. Kolb described the range of its implications as as staggering.
One set of results, released yesterday, was obtained by a team led by scientists at the California Institute of Technology and La Sapienza, the main campus of the University of Rome, using a balloon-borne telescope for observing microwaves. A report describing the results of this so-called Boomerang experiment was posted on a Web site maintained at the Los Alamos National Laboratory; it has not yet been subjected to peer review. The Web site is:
http://xxx.lanl.gov
 Last month, scientists at Princeton University and the University of Pennsylvania, who placed a telescope on a high plateau in Chile, published similar results in Astrophysical Journal Letters. Dr. Mark Devlin, from the University of Pennsylvania and a member of the team that worked in Chile, said, "These are completely different experiments with completely different calibrations and they fall right on top of each other."
A third team, centered at the University of California at Berkeley, has also released its preliminary map of the microwave background, made with another balloon-borne telescope.
The teams' conclusions rest on measurements of the precise size of the ripples in the microwave background radiation. That size turns out to be about one degree on the sky, or about twice the apparent size of the full Moon as seen from Earth.
The size of the ripples is a direct indicator of the large-scale geometry of the universe, which, according to Einstein's general theory of relativity, is in turn determined by the total amount of matter and energy that the universe contains. Ripples of one degree indicate a "flat" universe, in which parallel lines never cross. Inflation, the theory of what provided the fuel for the Big Bang, predicts a universe that is almost exactly flat.
"We're seeing that the universe is flat to amazing precision," said Dr. Craig Hogan, a cosmologist at the University of Washington. "It's what inflation predicted."
Dr. Scott Dodelson, a cosmologist at the University of Chicago, said, "Basically it gets a flat universe dead-on."
And that leads astronomers to their next conclusion: because the amount of matter found by astronomers cannot produce a flat universe, Dr. Dodelson said, "the inescapable conclusion is that there is some unknown form of energy contributing to the total density." (This unknown energy is distinct from so-called dark matter, once described as the missing mass of the universe.)
The most likely candidate for that exotic energy, Dr. Hogan and Dr. Dodelson said, is what has come to be known as the cosmological constant, an energy with repulsive gravity that may fill apparently empty space. Einstein first proposed the concept, thinking that he needed it to keep the universe from collapsing, but he later renounced the idea when it was discovered that the universe was expanding.
The geometry of the universe is determined solely by the amount of matter and energy contained in it, according to Einstein's general theory of relativity, which explains gravity as the "curvature" of space-time. In a geometrically "closed" universe, photons of light, initially traveling parallel to each other, would eventually converge, just as lines of longitude on Earth's curved surface meet at the poles.
Cosmologists agree that the universe could have three possible geometries. Besides the closed geometry, the universe might be open or flat. In an open geometry, parallel lines would diverge, and in a flat universe they would simply remain parallel.
Relativity predicts that a closed universe contains more matter and energy than a certain fixed amount. An open universe contains less, and a flat universe holds precisely that amount: the one predicted by Dr. Guth's theory.
According to the theory of inflation, a small piece of space became catastrophically stretched by the energy of fields that are predicted by advanced theories of physics. Those theories unify all known interactions between particles. No matter how curved that part of space might have been to begin with, this "inflation" would have stretched it out, like the surface of a balloon as it is blown up, in a tiny fraction of a second and created a flat universe. The tremendous well of energy in the inflated piece of space would have served as the fuel for the subsequent fireball of the Big Bang.
In the present universe, gravity does warp the relatively small regions of space close to massive objects like the Sun, neutron stars or black holes. Still, some cosmologists had suggested, on purely aesthetic grounds, that the universe in the large would be free of curvature. Inflation, with its cosmic stretching, was the first theory to explain why those suspicions might be true.
But despite that stretching, inflation would also leave telltale ripples on this exploding, Big Bang universe. The ripples occur because of principles of quantum mechanics, which impose a kind of small-scale fuzziness on all particles. The ripples in the microwave background are thought to be the legacy of that early quantum fuzziness.
The background radiation, cosmologists believe, was emitted from the fireball of the Big Bang after the inflationary expansion a few hundred thousand years after the creation event. The radiation then traveled through space for roughly 15 billion years, the present estimated age of the universe, and arrives at Earth as a sort of cosmic fossil.
"The ripples themselves were produced during inflation," Dr. Kolb said.
Because cosmologists can calculate the actual size of the ripples in the young universe, their apparent size on the sky is a measure of whether radiation from them traveled to Earth on straight or curved paths. The paths turned out to be straight, providing the main piece of evidence for the flat universe.
The Boomerang experiment measured the ripples using a telescope based on reflecting, aluminum optics and a cooled, semiconducting detector that looks like a tiny spider web, said Dr. Paolo de Bernardis, an astrophysicist at La Sapienza, who is a principal investigator of the Boomerang experiment. The microwaves heat the detector very slightly, and that change is converted into an electronic signal.
"The system is so cool and so clean that you can detect these changes in the system," he said.
The Maxima experiment, based at Berkeley, used a related balloon-borne system. The Microwave Anistropy Telescope, which made its own measurements from a high plateau in Chile, used an entirely different detector based on powerful electronic amplifiers.
All the data are consistent with a flat universe, said scientists on the projects and others who have read the teams' reports.
"These really favor a flat universe," said Dr. Alessandro Melchiorri, an astrophysicist at La Sapienza.
Dr. Kolb of the University of Chicago said that the new results easily represented the biggest step in the field since NASA's Cosmic Microwave Background Explorer first saw the barest outlines of the ripples in 1992. Even that satellite could not detect the much tinier ripples that have been measured by the new telescopes. Dr. Kolb described the reaction of inflationary cosmologists to the new data as one of "guarded euphoria."
Scientists on all the experiments said that even more precise data would soon be made public, offering the promise of even tighter tests of inflation, and of the geometry and contents of the universe.
"You haven't seen anything yet," said Dr. Adrian T. Lee, a Maxima collaborator at Berkeley. "We are entering the era of precision cosmology."

New observations of temperature variations, or ripples, in radiation left over from the Big Bang may enable astronomers to measure the total amount of mass and energy in the universe and its geometric structure. HEADLINE: Civilian Police Force Brings New Problems in Haiti

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
Renan Etienne keeps his military academy diploma hanging in his office, although it is an odd decorative touch. He is the Port-au-Prince commander for the Haitian National Police, the civilian force that replaced the brutal and corrupt Haitian Army.
After Mr. Etienne spent eight years as a military officer, his career there ended in 1994 when the reformist President Jean-Bertrand Aristide disbanded the army. 
 The Haitian military had worked hand in hand with the country's dictators, terrorizing civilians in the decades that preceded Mr. Aristide's election in 1990. Then the military deposed him and forced him into exile, but after he returned with American backing, he replaced the military with a civilian police force.
Mr. Etienne, like only a handful of other former officers, had both the experience and clean record to qualify as a commander for the mostly rookie police force.
"It's the same job," he said tersely on a recent day.
But his two careers are hardly comparable. Unlike the army, the civilian force, which was trained by police officers from a United Nations-led mission, is seen as relatively respectful of human rights. But also unlike the army, which had ample weapons and resources, the fledgling force finds itself at times scrambling to meet its basic needs. That has led, he said, to a morale crisis.
"We do not have enough human and material resources," Mr. Etienne said. "It seems if you have radios, they have no batteries. If you have cars, they have no tires. If you have guns, they have no bullets."
Nearly four years since it was founded, and just months away from the end of the full-time American military presence in the capital, the Haitian National Police is struggling to maintain order while people complain increasingly about crime and a lack of security.
Of the original 5,300 members, 1,000 have been dismissed for corruption or human rights abuses, and the force is trying to recruit replacements. A lack of seasoned commanders means that some towns have no police supervisors. Specialized units critical to investigative work are just now being formed.
These internal challenges are made more difficult by external pressures. Haiti's judicial system badly needs reform. Caseloads are backlogged for years. Judges are poorly trained, and many are believed to be corrupt. Criminals with enough influence are freed soon after their arrests. Human rights monitors suspect that several police officers, frustrated by the failings of the courts, have taken part in vigilante killings.
"It would be hard enough under normal conditions," said Pierre Denize, the chief of the Haitian National Police. "The conditions here have been less than normal. If I, as the head of this institution, said we do not need anything more, I would be very wrong. Institutional development is a notion that entails 15-year spans of time. Here, we're talking about four years."
The most troubling challenges yet emerged in February, when popular organizations aligned with Mr. Aristide's Fanmi Lavalas political party, citing the crime problem, clamored for the resignation of Robert Manuel, the vice minister for state security. Mr. Manuel, whose jurisdiction included the police force, was part of the administration of Rene Preval, Mr. Aristide's hand-picked successor. But with Mr. Aristide apparently planning to run again next year, the two became rivals.
Mr. Manuel finally resigned under pressure in October, and soon afterward, Jean Lamy, considered to be a candidate to replace him, was assassinated. No arrest has been made. When Mr. Denize went to Mr. Lamy's funeral, demonstrators loyal to Mr. Aristide disrupted the service and heckled him.
The events are an echo of old-style Haitian politics, with the police leaders coming under relentless criticism by political groups seeking to put their allies in key positions to gain an advantage in legislative elections scheduled for March. The fear is that the police will be used to intimidate voters or to protect fraud.
"There has always been the courting of the force by different political parties," Mr. Denize said.
Colin Granderson, the executive director of the United Nations/ Organization of American States International Civilian Mission in Haiti, said the pressures on the police are of special concern at a time when the government is already functioning without a Parliament or constitutionally appointed prime minister. The government has been virtually paralyzed for two years over the refusal of an opposition legislation to approve a prime minister and then the end of the legislative terms and a postponement of new elections.
"There is a lot of concern about what is happening with the police and if they are going to be destabilized or fall into the clutches of Aristide," Mr. Granderson said. "You are dealing with a police force started from scratch and thrown into a cauldron. It is not a propitious environment."
The force's top commanders, as well as other government officials, insist they will not allow the police to become politicized. The officials are supported by international officials and diplomats, who have conveyed a similar message to Mr. Aristide.
Yvon Neptune, a spokesman for Fanmi Lavalas, suggested that some of the recent disturbances, protesting a lack of security for citizens, were the work of provocateurs opposed to Mr. Aristide. He added that his party was not in a position to choose police commanders, but that its criticism of the police force's performance was legitimate.
"We have not contented ourselves to say the police force is young and doesn't have enough material," he said. "We also have to question those who are in charge, not only how they perform, but what are their policies."
Along the streets of the capital, police officers are rarely seen, except for a handful in crisp blue-and-tan uniforms directing traffic. There have been some brazen assaults, like the recent robbery of a food wholesaler in which 10 armed men exchanged gunfire with the police. Two robbers were killed, but the rest escaped.
Some downtown merchants are so fearful of crime that they allow only one customer at a time into their stores, while many residents stay inside in early morning and evening hours to avoid bandits.
"This is a Dracula country," said Fredy Antoine, a mattress salesman at the teeming Solomon Market. "If you have a couple of dollars in your pocket, anyone can come and tell you to give it to them."
The man appointed prime minister after the legislature went out of office, Jacques Alexis, said the original design of the police force was part of the problem. "When we asked for high school diplomas for the new recruits, we ended up with people who saw the police as a transitory position and who were waiting for the next opportunity to move on when something better showed up," he said.
"There was the temptation of drug trafficking and other cases of corruption," he said. "That is why the next group of recruits will be selected from candidates without high school diplomas who see the police as a job where they feel valued and as a way to move up."
Mr. Alexis also said that Haiti needs the files on political crimes and human rights abuses committed by supporters of the coup against Mr. Aristide because they might still be involved in criminal activity. The documents were seized by American troops and have not been released because they contain the names of American agents and information on intelligence methods.
"Maybe we could not prosecute all the cases," Mr. Alexis said. "But the fact that the people who are still out on the street know we have the files -- then perhaps that would be a means of controlling them and calming them down."
While conceding that crime has increased, Mr. Denize said that it is not as bad as in some other countries. He said the level of violence is "inexplicably low" considering that most people in the capital live crowded in impoverished shantytowns. He said some of the growing outcry about security comes from upper-class residents who have lived comfortably in the hills overlooking Port-au-Prince.
These people, he said, traditionally were "very well protected by the army that served them and the repressive, dysfunctional system that went with it."
"When this bulletproofing was no longer there, they fell prey to criminality like everyone else," he added.
The concerns over security, he said, must be seen as part of a complex of problems facing the nation: an economic crisis, criminals deported to Haiti from the United States and Canada, and drug traffickers who can buy favors and silence.
"We have real social factors that put criminality on the rise," he said. "And it is a very democratic criminality.

HEADLINE: Former Drug Chief Says U.S. Brushed Aside Mexico's Role

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
During the five years that Thomas A. Constantine spent as the nation's top drug-enforcement official, he never sat down with President Clinton to discuss drug policy. He was never called to brief the president on a major enforcement issue. The phone never rang for a chat.
Mr. Constantine, who came to the job after more than three decades in the New York State Police, initially took some pride in being a Washington outsider. But by his retirement last summer, he acknowledges, he had become a different kind of outsider -- one circumvented by the White House, particularly in its annual evaluation of anti-drug efforts in Mexico. 
 "The policy makers from the National Security Council and the State Department started with the premise that they were going to certify Mexico," Mr. Constantine said recently of what he described as the administration's unspoken determination to put economic concerns ahead of drug issues. "Their question was, 'How do we get around the facts presented by Tom Constantine?' "
Depending on one's perspective, Mr. Constantine emerged at the head of the Drug Enforcement Administration as either a truth-teller among cynical bureaucrats or a resonance box for the sometimes conspiratorial views of his agents.
Mr. Constantine uses the word whistle-blower with a beat cop's derision; when the subject of his bureaucratic battles arises, he says he has no interest in attacking the president or his policies, even those with which he disagreed. Still, it is hard to leave a few long conversations with Mr. Constantine, 61, without the impression of a man struggling to hold his tongue out of loyalty to a system he sees as flawed and a president he does not seem to respect.
"I watched that situation for five and a half years, and every year it became worse," he finally said of the drug trade in Mexico. "We were not adequately protecting the citizens of the United States from these organized-crime figures."
A White House spokesman, Mike Hammer, said the administration would have no comment on Mr. Constantine's remarks.
At a time when the nation's drug policies are coming under their sharpest public attack in decades, Mr. Constantine came through his tenure as the drug-enforcement agency's administrator relatively unscathed.
Challenges to the Clinton administration's limited efforts to reduce the demand for illegal drugs have been directed mainly at the White House and its drug-policy adviser, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey. Criticism of its policies on drug laws and other enforcement issues has mostly fallen on General McCaffrey and Attorney General Janet Reno.
But while budgets rose steadily at the Drug Enforcement Administration under Mr. Constantine, allowing for the hiring of hundreds of new agents, there has been relatively little evidence that the agency is making any real headway against the world's most powerful traffickers.
The Drug Enforcement Administration played a central role in the arrests of Colombian cocaine bosses in 1995 and 1996, only to see smaller, more elusive groups quickly take their place. After having some success in Bolivia and Peru, the agency has watched much of the drug business there shift to Colombia. And while the agency has struck at some important traffickers in Asia, it has been mostly helpless as drug production has reportedly risen sharply in Burma and Afghanistan.
Nor is it clear that Mr. Constantine's efforts to strengthen the drug agency's ties to local and state police forces contributed significantly to the declines in drug violence. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said in July that it was hard to assess the agency's work at all because of its failure to set measurable standards of performance.
A notoriously demanding boss, Mr. Constantine was said by some of his critics within the agency to have driven away some of its most experienced officials, a charge he denies.
Still, Mr. Constantine said his greatest frustration came from Mexico. Evidence of the growing power of Mexican drug mafias greeted him almost as soon as he took over the agency in March 1994. Mexican traffickers were by then taking as much as half of the Colombian cocaine they moved into the United States as payment for their services. Mexicans were also dominating the growing American market for methamphetamine and expanding their distribution of heroin across the western United States. "In retrospect, we underestimated their importance," Mr. Constantine said of the Mexican traffickers. "The focus at the time was all on Colombia."
Mr. Constantine said he quickly detected another pattern as well.
"Every time we had a major case involving a criminal organization from Mexico operating in the United States, there was a significant allegation of corruption involving the Mexican Attorney General's office, a Mexican state police force, the highway police," he said.
But, Mr. Constantine said, other Clinton administration officials were resolute: American concerns about Mexico's corruption and drug-trafficking problems were secondary to trade and other economic interests.
"The idea was, if you said those things publicly, if you release documents, you will just aggravate the situation," he said. "My concern was that we had kids in this country dropping like flies. Maybe that was parochial, but I felt like I was the only person there who felt like that."
Even after Mr. Constantine's counterpart in Mexico was found in 1997 to have been colluding with the country's biggest cocaine trafficker, serious discussion of the issue within the Clinton administration was minimal, even negligible, he said. The exception was the annual debate over whether to certify the anti-drug efforts of Mexico and other nations that produce or ship illegal drugs.
"Everyone would say, 'Your facts are correct, but there are bigger policy issues involved,' " Mr. Constantine recalled.
Mr. Constantine, who now teaches at State University of New York at Albany and consults on law enforcement, said it had never occurred to him to resign in protest. "My sense was that you always ought to try to make it work," he said.

HEADLINE: Croatia Moves to Declare President Temporarily Incapacitated

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The Croatian government, meeting today in emergency session, asked the Constitutional Court to declare the ailing President, Franjo Tudjman, temporarily incapable of carrying out his duties.
The court is expected to agree within 24 hours, the period stipulated in a constitutional amendment passed on Wednesday. Mr. Tudjman, who has run Croatia like an autocrat since it became independent of Yugoslavia in 1991, has been incommunicado in a hospital since Nov. 1. He is 77 and is reported to be close to death from stomach cancer. 
 Once the court agrees, the speaker of Parliament, a member of Mr. Tudjman's governing Croatian Democratic Union, will take over key presidential powers. The speaker, Vlatko Pavletic, is expected to authorize parliamentary elections on Dec. 28 or 29, timing seen as favoring the governing party, which fears losing power to a center-left opposition coalition now ahead in the polls.
There must be at least 30 days for campaigning after the announcement of an election. Mr. Tudjman, before falling so ill, had favored an election date of Dec. 22, but did not formally declare it. Parliament's term expires on Saturday, and new elections must be held by Jan. 27.
Ivo Pukanic, the editor of the independent weekly Nacional, said in an interview today that an election in the holiday period favored the conservative, more rural-based Tudjman party, because Croatian workers abroad will be home to vote, urban workers will be in their native villages and richer, more liberal Croats "will be abroad skiing, in Austria, Italy or Slovenia."
Abstentions are also likely to be higher during the holiday, also favoring the more tightly organized governing party. Still, Mr. Pukanic believes that with the party unpopular because of corruption and a weak economy, the opposition will win a majority in Parliament. But he said the party was likely to win a separate election for president to succeed Mr. Tudjman, if it can agree on the centrist foreign minister, Mate Granic, a favorite of Washington, as its candidate.
In a daily medical bulletin today, doctors said Mr. Tudjman's condition remained grave but "is stabilizing thanks to intensive treatment." There were no other details.
But the leadership of his party asked the government to meet to declare the temporary incapacity of Mr. Tudjman.
"After receiving the opinion of the medical team, the government has decided to ask the Constitutional Court to determine temporary incapacitation of President Tudjman," Prime Minister Zlatko Matesa told reporters after the cabinet met.
The death of Mr. Tudjman, who has had a sometimes confrontational relationship with Washington and the European Union over questions of war crimes, autocracy, media control and political repression, is expected to ease Croatia's entry into the West. An opposition victory in elections deemed free and fair would have a significant impact, not just on Croatia's relations with the West, but also on the rest of the Balkans, including Serbia, where a democratic opposition is trying to oust President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.
Mr. Pavletic, whose own mandate was extended by Parliament on Wednesday, can hold temporary presidential powers for 60 days, but they are renewable.

HEADLINE: After Open Enrollment: CUNY's New World

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The controversy on admissions of students who need remediation to the senior colleges of the City University of New York (front page, Nov. 23) misses a vital point: what goes on inside the colleges. 
 Huge grade curves are the order of the day, to push failing students into a passing grade. This is the university equivalent of "social promotion" in the high schools.
Our department conducted an assessment of the large lecture courses in basic economics last spring. The average grade curve was 15 points, making the passing grade 45 percent. In a four-choice multiple-choice exam, the average knowledge required to achieve this score is 26 percent (with the rest achieved by guessing).
 
PETER GUTMANN
New York, Nov. 23, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Baruch College, CUNY.

HEADLINE: Federal Budgets, Both Ways

 BODY:
With tempers still sore from their recent federal budget battles, Congress and the White House are quietly preparing for the next fight. Both Republicans and Democrats are offering a split personality to voters, proclaiming a love for fiscal discipline and also for calculated spending increases in defense, education, health programs and financing for research. The latest economic projections suggest that both parties will be able to continue avoiding hard choices. If the year finishes up in robust economic health, federal revenues ought to be plentiful enough for Congress and the White House to save some money and pay for targeted programs at the same time. The election may also prove that voters like having it both ways.
With the last completed budget of the Clinton era now in place, it is possible to take stock of just what President Clinton has accomplished in budgetary terms. Since 1992, he has brought the discretionary domestic spending portion of the budget down from about 3.5 percent of the domestic economy to roughly 3.2 percent, about the level that it was in 1969, according to Robert Reischauer of the Brookings Institution. That figure will no doubt disappoint the liberals and progressives who had hoped that the first Democrat elected since the 1970's would reorder the nation's political priorities. 
 On the other hand, since Mr. Clinton has presided over what could turn out to be the longest economic boom in American history, there has been room to increase domestic spending in real terms even though it is now less of a percentage of the economy than before. Mr. Reischauer calculates that domestic discretionary spending -- the core of what the battles with Congress have been about -- has gone up 13.5 percent since Mr. Clinton took office, after inflation. That is less than 2 percent a year, a modest increase but one that has had a significant impact in certain areas.
The administration can rightly claim to have achieved some targeted increases that go beyond these modest numbers, most notably in education. Head Start is now financed at nearly twice the level it was in 1993. The administration was able to win much more support for after-school programs, job training and acquisition of green spaces than many would have thought possible after the Republicans took over Congress in 1995. On top of these efforts has been the expansion of three major entitlement programs -- the tax credit for the working poor, a health insurance program for children in working-poor families and expanded health care for disabled workers. These are all steps that, while incremental in nature, have advanced the social welfare agenda under Mr. Clinton.
Whoever wins the next election, it seems safe to say that the paradigm defined by Mr. Clinton in the 1990's may well prove irresistible to his successor. The attraction of fiscal discipline and balanced budgets has been used successfully by the Democrats to blunt Republican efforts to enact big tax cuts. But the same tactic has meant that the Democrats themselves cannot advocate big new spending initiatives without opening themselves up to the same charge of fiscal recklessness. Stringent budgets that allow increased spending on the margins may be the hallmark of this era of prosperity.
For all their sparring over fiscal issues, the major presidential candidates in both parties have said little to indicate that they would change this cautious approach to federal budgets. Indeed, it is hard to imagine the model being reversed until and unless there is an economic collapse. Having it both ways is what politicians and many voters like best.

HEADLINE: Long Road in Nigeria

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Nov. 26 editorial "Nigeria's Clean Broom" realistically highlighted the political and socioeconomic challenges for Nigeria. The outside world and news media would do well not to expect too much too soon. 
 In a nearly bankrupt country of more than 100 million people speaking 300 different languages and ruled and terrorized by the army for 29 of its 39 years of independence, torn by tribalism and sectarian violence, President Olusegun Obasanjo's democratic government faces monumental obstacles.
But beyond complying with international human rights standards, as you suggest, Nigeria should privatize its ailing industries and reprivatize those that it nationalized during the 1970's, driving away foreign investors. When I left Nigeria in the early 1980's for the United States, the naira was almost equal to the United States dollar in value. Today, one dollar can fetch 100 naira, depending on the medium of exchange. This is a measure of how low the Nigerian economy has sunk under corrupt regimes, civilian and military.
 
IGONIKON S. JACK
Baton Rouge, La., Nov. 26, 1999

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq Reaches Another Record During Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq stock market sprinted to another record yesterday, as investors gave Internet retailers a boost at the traditional start of the holiday shopping season. But stocks over all had a mixed performance in light post-Thanksgiving trading.
And in the bond market, prices fell for a fourth consecutive session, dragged down by weak overseas bond markets and strong economic numbers that have prompted fears of rising inflation. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dipped 13/32 , to 9818/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.23 percent from 6.20 percent on Wednesday. 
 The Nasdaq composite index rose 27.31 points, to 3,447.81, for its 16th record in the last four weeks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 0.46 points, to 1,416.62, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.26 points, to 10,988.91.
For the week, the Nasdaq composite index added 78.56 points, and is now up 57.24 percent so far this year. The Dow Jones industrials dropped 14.98 for the week, while the S.& P. 500 slipped 5.38.
"A tremendous pocket of strength in technology is pulling up the Nasdaq," said Richard McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
But he cautioned that over all, the declining stocks are outpacing those advancing, which should raise a cautionary note for investors.
Stock gains were held back by inflationary concerns related to a Commerce Department report yesterday that Americans' personal income in October posted its biggest jump in more than five years, and rose more than twice as fast as spending. Personal income, which includes wages, interest and government benefits, surged by 1.3 percent in October.
It was another sign of the nation's economic strength, which added to bond-market jitters that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates again early next year to hold down inflationary pressures.
Trading was listless as the stock market closed at 1 p.m. yesterday, three hours earlier than usual, as traders were on a holiday weekend schedule.
Benefiting from the traditional kickoff of the holiday shopping season on the day after Thanksgiving, the online retailer eToys rose 3 3/8, to 67 13/16, along with Amazon.com, up 7 1/16, to 94 1/4. Toys "R" Us gained 1 1/4, to 18 3/8. Wall Street has high hopes for brisk online selling in the next month.
Leading the Dow was AT&T, up 4 1/4, to 57 7/16. The company, the largest United States long-distance phone concern, is reportedly considering selling stock in its wireless unit.
Technology concerns benefited from institutional investors buying the year's hottest equities so that those issues are included in their year-end portfolios, Mr. McCabe said. "Strength is begetting strength and for no particular fundamental reason," he said.

HEADLINE: Study Details Sacrifices In Caring for Elderly Kin

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

 BODY:
A small study that surveyed the economic cost to individuals who provide informal care for elderly relatives has found that working caregivers sacrifice substantial wages and benefits by passing up promotions, training and transfers, and taking extended time off from their jobs to fulfill their family responsibilities.
Of the 55 individuals surveyed, nearly two-thirds reported that taking care of an elderly relative or friend had cut into their earnings, and the cost to 30 of those who were able to provide enough information to quantify the financial effect was estimated at an average of $659,139 in lost wages, Social Security and pension benefits over their lifetimes. 
 The study, conducted for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company by the National Alliance for Caregivers and the National Center for Women and Aging at Brandeis University, was intended as a follow-up to a larger study in 1997 by the alliance and AARP.
The 1997 study, which surveyed 1,509 people, found that 1 in 4 families had at least one adult who had provided care for an elderly relative or friend in the past 12 months in which they were interviewed. The 55 people who were surveyed recently were selected from the 1997 study.
In honoring their obligations to elderly relatives, those who provide care may endanger their own long-term financial health, said Phyllis Mutschler, executive director of the National Center for Women and Aging at Brandeis.
Concerns about the costs of long-term care are rising along with the skyrocketing numbers of elderly Americans; the National Alliance for Caregivers estimates that the number of employed people who provide such family care will grow to 11 million to 15.6 million over the next 10 years.
"Elder care is to the 21st century what child care has been for the last few decades," said Joyce Ruddock, a gerontologist who heads the Long-Term Care Group at Metropolitan Life.
The caregivers surveyed were 45 years of age or older in 1996, and they provided, on average, about eight years of care.
Of those interviewed, 29 percent said they passed up a job promotion or training, 25 percent passed up a job transfer and 22 percent were not able to acquire new job skills.
Among those providing financial information, the average total loss in wage wealth, which the survey defined as the current value of lifetime wages calculated as of the date of the retirement, was $566,443. In addition to current income, they also lost retirement savings.
As a result of their taking care of the elderly, those surveyed estimated that their Social Security benefits decreased an average of $2,160 annually. Over their retirement years, their lost Social Security wealth averages $25,494.
Among those surveyed who are eligible for pensions and able to provide information about them, their estimated average pension benefits fell by $5,339 annually as a result of their elder care, or $67,202 in pension wealth, on average, over their retirement years.
Providing care at home is expensive, with those surveyed reporting that they spent an average $364 a month for assistance with rent or mortgages for the elderly relative they were helping, and $322 a month for home care professionals. On average, caregivers helped with these expenses for two to six years, spending a total of $19,525 in out-of-pocket expenses.
Being responsible for an elderly relative can strain the health of those who work and provide such care, and result in missed days of work, early retirement and decreased effectiveness on the job. Almost three-fourths of those surveyed said that elder care had affected their health.
Sixty-two percent of those surveyed reporting asking supervisors, co-workers or management for some kind of support or help with their responsibilities at home. The support received was primarily informal, the survey said. Few companies provide formal support for employees who provide care for elderly relatives; only 23 percent of companies with 100 or more employees have programs in place to support elder care, the Families and Work Institute said.

HEADLINE: Malaysia Autocrat May Win Now but Lose Later

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is all but certain to win a parliamentary election next week, but already, to many people here, he seems like a relic of the past.
Campaigning against a disorganized and overmatched opposition, he is demanding -- and is likely to gain -- a vote of thanks on Monday for the stability and economic growth he has brought during his 18-year-old rule, the longest of any elected leader in Asia. 
 The goal of his opponents, however, is to make his expected victory seem like a loss. If his party falls below the symbolically dominant two-thirds majority it has always held in Parliament, politicians agree, it could drum him out of leadership at a party congress next year.
The campaign has been an exercise in raw political dominance by Dr. Mahathir, despite widespread public uneasiness over his actions in firing, trying and publicly humiliating his former deputy and heir apparent, Anwar Ibrahim.
But like other countries in the region, Malaysia has begun to outgrow the father-knows-best style of leadership that the 73-year-old Dr. Mahathir helped to promote under the label "Asian values." Like people in other Southeast Asian countries, Malaysians have grown more prosperous, better educated, better informed and more politically assertive.
"You have a more questioning electorate, no longer bound by the traditional mentality of accepting goodies from the government in exchange for their loyalty," said Husein Mutalib, an expert on Malaysia at the National University of Singapore. "For better or for worse, Mahathir's days are numbered."
The shift is part of a tide of political change that is sweeping through Southeast Asia, fueled by more than a decade of rapid economic growth and in some cases accelerated by the shock of the region's economic crisis during the last two years.
From the upheavals of Indonesia to the hard-fought constitutional changes of Thailand, strongman rule is giving way to the clamor and jostle of democracy.
"The key word is participation," said William J. Klausner, an American political scientist who teaches at Chulalongkorn University in Thailand. "It's the creation of alternative centers of power, whether they are nongovernmental organizations or the media or investigative reporting or bolder academic research."
"In one form or another, this is happening in all the countries in the region," he said. "People like Mahathir have to face up to this, face up to the fact that they can no longer operate unchallenged."
For now, Dr. Mahathir -- who was a practicing physician and is widely known here as "Dr. M" -- could be forgiven if he misses this point. With a crack of the whip and a shout through the bullhorn, he still has his people jumping through hoops.
The press and the airwaves belong to him. So does almost all of the country's political infrastructure. Much of Malaysia's wealth is his to distribute. When it counts, the police and the courts answer to his needs.
"Without authority and stability, there can be no civility," Dr. Mahathir argues in a recently published book, "A New Deal for Asia."
But even some of his strongest allies -- as once happened with the former Indonesian president, Suharto -- whisper that he has outstayed his welcome.
They are using the governing party's overwhelming dominance to keep the opposition on the run. But they are hearing the kinds of criticisms that also preceded Mr. Suharto's forced resignation in May 1998.
"We are seeing the last stages not only of Mahathir's rule but also of the type of leadership he represents," said Lim Guan Eng, a prominent opponent of the prime minister. "Whether he wins or not, the point is many Malaysians are fed up with the corruption, the abuses of power and the crony capitalism. He feels he can get away with anything he wants."
Though they have not run an effective campaign, Dr. Mahathir's mutually antagonistic political opponents -- an ethnic Chinese party, Islamic fundamentalists and liberal democrats -- have united for the first time in an attempt to capitalize on the growing discontent with his autocratic ways.
"I expect things to change no matter who wins," said M. G. G. Pillai, a political commentator. "The government has lost its right to dictate. The attitude has always been, 'You elected us, now shut up. We have the mandate.' That doesn't work any more."
The changes surfaced in Malaysia in 1997, when the region's economic crisis halted its decade-long growth spurt of 8 percent a year and made Dr. Mahathir's obsession with monumental building projects look foolish.
"That year was to be the apotheosis; Mahathir was to be taken up bodily into Valhalla," said Ronald Palmer, a former American ambassador here who now teaches at George Washington University in Washington, D.C. Malaysia was host to the Commonwealth games, it opened a new airport, it prepared to move the seat of government to a newly built city and it inaugurated the twin Petronas Towers, the world's tallest buildings.
When things went wrong, Dr. Mahathir turned his anger on the West, blaming George Soros and other currency traders, who he said were upset at his success.
Then, in September 1998, he shocked his countrymen by firing and shaming Mr. Anwar, 52, who has since been sentenced to six years in prison for corruption and is now on trial on charges of sexual misconduct.
That trial has been suspended during the election campaign, and few people here have any doubt that the intention was to remove Mr. Anwar from the public eye. The chief judge pleaded a backache.
"I don't like Anwar; I think he's just as much a rascal as the others, only better packaged," said Mr. Pillai, the political commentator. But in a commonly heard view, he added: "I support him because I don't want to see my deputy prime minister treated this way. If this can happen to my deputy prime minister, it can happen to me, and there'll be nobody to cry for me."
Discontent over the treatment of Mr. Anwar has divided the ethnic Malays who make up about 60 percent of the population. Dr. Maha thir's most solid support now comes from the Chinese minority of 30 percent and the Indians, who make up about 10 percent of the population.
Another key constituency worries the governing party: the young. Some political experts say Dr. Mahathir called an early election to keep at bay 680,000 newly registered voters who will not be eligible to take part until next year.
"It's generational, the ideas of liberalism, of wanting to chart Asia on a different course of participatory democracy," said Charles Santiago, who heads the Center for Economic and Social Research at Stamford College in Kuala Lumpur.
"There has been dissent in the past but not in the magnitude you see it right now," he said. "And that was because of prosperity. Prosperity has a certain co-opting tendency. But now people are waking up and saying, 'Wow, what's going on? What's happening to this poor country of ours?' "

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Hong Kong Bounces Back, But Faces New Challenges

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Nov. 26

 BODY:
In a report that made the Asian crisis seem like a distant memory, Hong Kong said today that its economy grew 4.5 percent in the third quarter of this year. The government also upgraded its forecast of growth for the full year to 1.8 percent from 0.5 percent.
The numbers, which were well above estimates, attest to Hong Kong's remarkable recovery from its worst recession since World War II. Like other Asian economies, Hong Kong has shrugged off the calamitous events of two years ago and is regaining its strength far faster than analysts had predicted. 
 "Hong Kong is poised for a dramatic rebound," said Victor Fung, the chairman of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council. "The conditions were there, but we needed a strong confirmation and a boost to confidence. We've now had a whole series of such events."
In addition to the new data, Hong Kong has been buoyed in recent weeks by the Walt Disney Company's announcement that it would build a theme park here, by the successful debut of a government-linked investment fund, and by the landmark trade deal between the United States and China.
That last milestone, however, could prove to be a distinctly mixed blessing. As China opens up its economy in an effort to enter the World Trade Organization, analysts said, this former British colony could lose its prized role as the middleman between China and the outside world.
Nor is that the only cloud looming over Hong Kong. Today's numbers also show that the territory is caught in a deflationary spiral unique among the recovering economies of Asia. The consumer price index declined 3.9 percent in the first 10 months of 1999, and the government increased its projection of the full-year decline in the index to 4 percent from an earlier forecast of 3.5 percent.
Prices of everything from office space and imported wine to designer clothes and cars are plunging here. Although people are spending more in stores -- retail sales rose 2 percent in the third quarter -- they are lured by deep discounts. The number of tourists visiting Hong Kong is up 11 percent so far this year, but they are spending much less per person, economists said.
Much of this deflation is viewed as necessary. Hong Kong's prices were among the highest in the world, and made the territory a forbidding place to do business. But the falling prices are cutting profits at local companies, a trend that discourages them from resuming investment. "This is what I call a profitless recovery," said Dong Tao, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston in Hong Kong.
Mr. Tao said the recovery would remain tenuous as long as companies did not have the confidence to take out fresh loans and begin spending. Also, even though commercial rents have fallen by more than 40 percent, Hong Kong is still more expensive than New York or London, he said.
Ian K. Perkin, the chief economist of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce, said the government had masked the effect of weak corporate investment by starting several costly projects, including the $3.6 billion Disneyland, which will be built largely with public money.
"We have to persuade domestic companies to begin investing again -- and real investments, not just the stock market," Mr. Perkin said. "I don't know how we do that."
The new trade agreement between the United States and China is a more long-term challenge for Hong Kong. The government's economist, K. Y. Tang, said that it was premature to estimate what impact the deal would have on economic output. "In general terms, I agree with those who say that it must be a very positive development for both the mainland and Hong Kong," he said.
Mr. Fung, of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council, and others contend that Hong Kong will benefit from the agreement because it will generate vast new trading opportunities for China. As the world's largest container port and the main clearinghouse for Chinese exports, Hong Kong will get a share of that increased traffic.
But a growing number of experts are questioning whether Hong Kong will miss out on most of the new wealth. As China opens its markets to foreign companies and products, American and other foreign companies could start dealing directly with the mainland Chinese.
"Hong Kong has been very successful in exploiting the gray areas of doing business in China," said Jason Felton, the chairman of the American Chamber of Commerce here. "But the W.T.O. is going to force the Chinese to be more transparent. Hong Kong companies will lose that niche, and they are clearly worried about it."
Mr. Fung said the trade agreement would encourage hundreds of small and midsize American companies to try to crack the China market. Lacking the resources or connections of major corporations, these companies would need the advice of people in Hong Kong, he said.
"If you're talking about the Fortune 100, it's probably true that these companies will put increased emphasis on dealing directly with China," he said. "What I think we'll get is a rush of medium-size multinationals, who have heretofore not dealt with China."
Mr. Fung acknowledged that Hong Kong would be forced to change. But he predicted that the territory would remake itself -- much as it did in 1979, when Deng Xiaoping opened the Chinese economy. At that time, Hong Kong was a center for low-cost manufacturing. But companies here recognized that China would usurp that role, so they moved their factories to neighboring Guangdong Province.
Now, Mr. Fung said, Hong Kong needs to retool its economy to provide information-age services to the growing Chinese market. The territory has become a hothouse for Internet companies that are focusing on the mainland. On Thursday, in an effort to create a Nasdaq exchange for Asia, the Hong Kong Stock Exchange opened a second board for technology-related stocks.

HEADLINE: Personal Incomes in October Had LargestRise Since 1994

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Personal incomes in October rose at the fastest pace in five and a half years, bolstering consumer spending and paving the way for what may be the strongest holiday shopping season this decade.
"The economy is red hot, and consumers are out with money to spend," said Jeffrey Stone, president of Tweeter Home Entertainment Group Inc. of Canton, Mass., which operates Tweeter, Bryn Mawr and HiFi Buys electronics stores. 
 Incomes rose 1.3 percent in October after no change in September, the Commerce Department said. More than $5.5 billion in emergency government payments to farmers after passage of an agriculture spending bill by Congress contributed to last month's increase, as did union contract-signing bonuses.
Personal spending grew 0.6 percent last month, topping the 0.5 percent increase in September. Spending has risen at a 7.4 percent annual rate in the first 10 months of this year, compared with 6.8 percent a year earlier, and that is before today's start of the Christmas shopping season.
Spending of that magnitude is also likely to lift the nation's economy to a 5.5 percent annualized growth rate in the fourth quarter, the same rate as in the third quarter, according to economists at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. Consumer spending accounts for roughly two-thirds of the nation's output of goods and services.
Income in October was helped by union-led signing bonuses at the Boeing Company and for workers represented by the United Automobile Workers.
The October increase in personal incomes was the largest since a 1.3 percent increase in April 1994. Excluding the bonuses and subsidies, incomes rose 0.5 percent last month, Commerce officials said. That still would be the largest gain since 0.8 percent in June.
Spending on autos increased, according to the government numbers. Private-industry figures showed the sales pace slipped in October to an annual rate of 16.6 million units from 17.1 million units in September.
With consumers' incomes increasing, employment opportunities plentiful and inflation low, retailers have raised their expectations for the shopping season. Merchants said they expect retail sales to increase 4.4 percent over last year's holiday season and profits to rise 17 percent, according to a recent survey by the National Retail Federation and Deloitte & Touche. Reflecting optimism about holiday sales, the Standard & Poor's retail stores composite index -- representing 37 companies, including Wal-Mart, Gap and Circuit City -- is up more than 10 percent since the end of September.

HEADLINE: Free Trade, Up To a Point

BYLINE: By James V. Feinerman; James V. Feinerman is a law professor at Georgetown University.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It's usually smart to be wary of the hard sell. And the hard sell is what we will hear coming from Seattle next week, as the World Trade Organization meets there. The Clinton administration has been pushing for China's entry into the trade group, optimistically predicting immediate gains for American businesses. Markets will be opened, tariffs will be reduced and regulations will be loosened, we're told. W.T.O. membership, the administration claims, would transform China because its regulations, on trade and other matters, would become public and subject to foreign scrutiny.
Here's the catch: It may take a decade or more to reach that rosy result, if we reach it at all. In the short term, China's membership promises to be rocky, and any honest assessment should at least acknowledge the pitfalls ahead. A reality check should consider the following: 
 Myth: The agreement would quickly lower our trade deficit with China.
Fact: While the agreement would probably help our trade deficit in the long term, the deficit would be just as likely to grow in the short term. After all, the United States would also have to lower its own trade barriers, eliminating remaining tariffs and restrictions like environmental regulations, or risk being penalized.
Myth: Admission into the W.T.O. would force China to privatize its state-owned enterprises and open its telecommunications, banking and insurance markets to American companies.
Fact: It would take years to pry open China's markets. Why? Reformers must deal with other Chinese leaders who aren't interested in changing to a market economy and with lower-level bureaucrats who stymie orders from above. Then there is the sheer complexity of governing such a large and disparate country. Take, for example, our experience in trying to persuade China to strengthen intellectual property rights law. Over the last 12 years, we have had three memorandums of understanding with China, each trying to close loopholes. The United States has had some success in persuading China to draft its own intellectual property rights laws, and even to close an illegal factory or two. But over all, these changes haven't made a tremendous amount of difference. Indeed, even China's own reformers, including Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, can't force change. After two decades of reform, they now hope that international trade regulations will accomplish what they couldn't.
Myth: The trade agreement would force China to abide by our rules.
Fact: The Chinese would have as much influence on the W.T.O. as it does on them. Over the 13 years it has sought membership in the W.T.O. and its precedessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, China has indicated that it wants its voice heard on trade issues. Indeed, if China had been part of the negotiations in the early 1990's on intellectual property, the trade group's rules today might be far less protective of such interests. In the near future, China could well press for rules on labor and the environment that are far less stringent than what the United States wants.
Myth: The trade organization is the most efficient place to settle international disputes with China.
Fact: The Clinton administration presumes, perhaps rightly, that the vast majority of disputes between the two countries would be settled in favor of the United States. It also assumes that China would be likely to abide by W.T.O. decisions, because it wouldn't be just the United States pressuring China, but the 135 member nations. The downside is that every member country with a grievance against China would bring its own case to the trade group. The American market is already saturated with Chinese products; Europe and Japan have been much less receptive. A flood of Chinese imports in their stores could very well create friction. Right now, the trade organization handles fewer than 50 cases a year. If hundreds of disputes clogged the system, support for China and the W.T.O itself could disappear.
Despite all these problems, the decision to admit China to the trade group is a good one; it can only help global relations. But let's walk into this with our eyes wide open. President Clinton must be more candid about the extent of the problems and the time it will take to resolve them. Otherwise, at the first impasse, a backlash could undermine not only our relations with China, but also our support for free trade.

HEADLINE: California Gasoline Prices Are a Focus forRegulators

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Californians paid an average of about 26 cents more for a gallon of gasoline than other Americans in the first eight months of this year, according to a report released this week by the state's attorney general. And those high prices have become a focal point as federal and most state regulators prepare to approve the merger of Exxon and Mobil and continue to debate the acquisition of the Atlantic Richfield Company by BP Amoco.
Californians paid nearly $1.32 a gallon for regular gasoline from January through August, according to the attorney general's report. That was the third-highest price in the nation behind isolated Hawaii and Nevada, which gets much of its gasoline from California. Other Western states also have relatively high pricing. The national average excluding California was a little over $1.05 while in Georgia, which had the lowest prices, it was less than 89 cents. 
 Higher taxes accounted for about 5 cents of the difference and California's requirements for specially clean gasoline accounted for another 4 cents, the report said. But the main difference, it maintained, stems from concentration in the market, with more than 90 percent of the state's refinery capacity and the vast majority of its gasoline sales controlled by six big oil companies.
In other states, independent refiners and independent marketers tend to play a larger role in the market. And because of its need for special gasoline, California is basically cut off from sources of supply in the rest of the country. When the state's own refineries have problems -- such as occurred earlier this year -- gasoline prices can quickly spike.
The report did not find any wrong-doing by the oil companies, though it was not likely to since it looked only at publicly available information. But the issue of market concentration has become a key one in the pending oil mergers.
The Federal Trade Commission is expected to approve the merger of Exxon and Mobil next week, subject to the condition that they divest themselves of more than 2,000 gasoline stations, mainly on the East Coast, according to officials in Washington and elsewhere. In California, where the two companies together control 14 percent of refining capacity and nearly 19 percent of gasoline sales, about 360 gas stations are to be shed, along with Exxon's refinery in Benicia.
California is expected to go along with this decision but will have a veto over the purchasers of those stations and the refinery. That would ensure that the assets would not go to one of the existing participants in the California market.
The merger of BP Amoco and ARCO is still problematical because the two companies together would have formidable control over oil from Alaska's North Slope, which accounts for nearly half the oil refined in California.
Alaska has reached its own tentative agreement with BP Amoco and ARCO, calling for the divestiture of some North Slope production and leases. But that agreement does not satisfy California and other Western States, which are consumers of the oil, while Alaska's interests are partly to maximize its revenues from that oil.
"That only took care of Alaska's problems," Bill Lockyer, the California attorney general, said.
Earlier this month, Sir John Browne, the chief executive of BP Amoco, met with Gov. Gray Davis of California and promised that ARCO, which is based in Los Angeles, would retain its low-price gasoline sales strategy.
But Mr. Lockyer, the attorney general, said that did not go far enough.
Consumer groups and some California politicians have long made an issue of gasoline prices, particularly in San Diego and San Francisco, where prices are 6 cents to more than 20 cents a gallon higher than in Los Angeles. The Utility Consumers' Action Network, a San Diego consumer group, posts on its Web site a "gouge gap," the difference between San Diego and Los Angeles prices. The attorney general's report said the reasons for the differences are unclear; oil companies say the prices simply reflect market forces.
Consumer groups and some gasoline dealers have backed legislation in San Diego, San Francisco and in the California Legislature that would either forbid oil companies from owning gas stations or take other measures to give gas stations more supply options. But so far, none of these efforts have been successful.
Mike Libbey, a spokesman for Chevron, the largest refiner in the state, said the issue of gasoline prices "is all a red herring in terms of what most motorists are concerned with." He said Chevron had been gaining market share despite having relatively high prices and that consumers continued to buy gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles.
Mr. Libbey said that California environmental rules were chiefly responsible for the higher prices here.
Still, oil companies are fighting any proposed legislation. Chevron this month sent a letter to dealers saying it would have to double their rents if legislation such as that proposed in California, or in other states like Oregon and Arizona, became law. Chevron said this reflected economic realities, but some dealers said it was a heavy-handed attempt to silence them.
"What this basically says is, 'We'll put you out of business if you exercise your rights,' " said Dennis C. DeCota, executive director of the California Service Station and Automotive Repair Association.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Holiday Shopping Season Begins in Malls and on Web
As the holiday shopping season began the big question was not whether Americans would spend a lot of money -- sales of merchandise, are expected to reach $184 billion for November and December -- but where they will spend it: online or at the mall. Estimates for Web sales run as high as $12 billion. 
 Early spot reports indicated that e-shopping is fast becoming as much a holiday tradition as strolling the concourse. And at least on the first day after Thanksgiving, there were also sporadic reports of service trouble on the Web (KBkids.com was down for much of the day and was offering $5 off coupons to appease consumers), while traditional merchants were doing a better-than-expected job of making visitors comfortable. Page A12.
 
Exxon-Mobil Approval Expected
Antitrust officials at the Federal Trade Commission have notified the states that they intend to recommend the approval of Exxon's $81 billion acquisition of Mobil next week. The move came after the companies agreed to the largest divestiture in the commission's history. At the same time, federal and some state officials have raised serious antitrust questions about BP Amoco's proposed $29 billion purchase of Atlantic Richfield. A1.
 
Californians paid an average of about 26 cents more for a gallon of gas than other Americans in the first eight months of this year, according to a report released this week by the state's attorney general. And those high prices have become a focal point as federal and state regulators consider whether to approve the mergers between Exxon and Mobil and between BP Amoco and Atlantic Richfield. C2.
 
Ariel Shares Have Strong Week
Ariel, a technology company that was forced only last month to renegotiate its debts, rose more than 800 percent this week after it announced that it would begin selling a product to compete with offerings from the much larger Cisco Systems and Lucent Technologies. C5.
 
Personal Incomes Jump 1.3 Percent
Personal incomes in October rose at the fastest pace in five and a half years, 1.3 percent, and personal spending grew 0.6 percent. C2.
 
Sega Losses More Than Expected
Sega Enterprises, the beleaguered video game company, said its losses in the first half of the fiscal year were larger than had been expected. The company blamed a 50 percent increase in marketing and other costs associated with the introduction of its Dreamcast video console for the losses at the parent company of 19.1 billion yen, or $183.8 million, in the six months that ended Sept. 30. C3.
 
Bond Yield Soars to 6.23 Percent
The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.23 percent from 6.20 percent on Wednesday. The Nasdaq composite index set its 16th record in the last four weeks, jumping 27.31 points, to 3,447.81. But the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 0.46 points, to 1,416.62, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.26 points, to 10,988.91. C4.
 
Experts Checking N.Y. Computers
New York City has spent more than any other city to avert Year 2000 computer problems, but even so its technology and emergency-management experts say things may yet go wrong. A1.
 
Growth in Hong Kong Reaches 4.5%
Hong Kong said its economy grew 4.5 percent in the third quarter of this year. The government also upgraded its forecast of growth for the full year to 1.8 percent. C3.

HEADLINE: Busy Season Begins for Merchants

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Ed and Kathy Blasco kicked off their holiday shopping today the same way they have for the last 15 years: they headed for the Country Club Plaza in Kansas City. The Blascos were set to enjoy the balmy weather and the Christmas songs being played by a live band, but they did not plan to make many purchases.
"If we get ideas today, we may very well do online shopping," Mr. Blasco said. 
 They intended to take advantage of an online retailer's free shipping offer on a playground set for their 1-year-old granddaughter and said they had already bought a doll on Ebay.com.
With unemployment at record lows and the stock market flying high, economists and retail analysts have been predicting that Christmas 1999 will be very strong indeed. Sales of merchandise, excluding autos, will reach $184 billion for November and December, up 6 percent from last year, predicts the National Retail Federation. So the real issue is not whether Americans will shop, but where. The Internet is growing rapidly, and estimates vary on just how big a chunk the virtual vendors will divert from stores. Estimates of holiday sales on the Web run from $6 billion by Forrester Research to $12 billion by Ernst & Young, numbers that are comparatively small, but at least twice last year's.
The day after Thanksgiving, known as Black Friday because merchants historically have relied on sales leading up to Christmas to move them from the red into the black, is no longer the busiest shopping day of the year. (That honor is now held by the days nearest Christmas Eve, as Americans conditioned to sale shopping delay buying as long as possible.) Still, the Thanksgiving weekend does send millions of families to the mall and provides a snapshot of how the season will shape up.
Early reports indicate that online shopping is fast becoming as much a holiday tradition as strolling along eating chestnuts and gawking at decorated store windows. And at least on the first day of the holiday shopping season, there were sporadic reports of service trouble on the Web (KBkids.com was down much of the day and offering $5 off coupons to appease consumers), while merchants on the ground were doing a better than expected job of making visitors comfortable.
At Crate & Barrel's flagship store on Michigan Avenue in Chicago, there were more clerks than people at 10 a.m., including a full-time janitorial staff that was meticulously polishing escalators and handrails almost the minute they were marred by fingerprints.
Kay Barker, of Carmel, Calif., who was visiting Manhattan, stocked up on perfume and sweaters at Bloomingdale's and then waited while her son tried on clothes at Banana Republic. She was like many other shoppers in offering praise of New York sales clerks. "The personnel have been very patient with all the crowds," Ms. Barker said.
Despite heightened attention to customer service and warm weather that encouraged shopping outdoors, many Americans still chose to stay home and bathe in the light of their computer screens, much to the delight of cybermerchants.
"From what we can tell by traffic to our Web site as of noon, today will be the No. 1 day for our Web site all year," said Mike Goldstein, chief executive of Toys "R" Us. Amazon.com, which sells books, music and toys, reported a sales increase of 267 percent over Black Friday last year. And Richard Rogowski, a spokesman for Yahoo!, said, "This is our biggest day of the year so far. We are getting almost five times as many orders on Yahoo! stores as we got last year on Black Friday."
At Outpost.com, a supplier of high-technology gifts, big sellers included DVD players and flat-screen computer monitors. "It is very darn good this week," said Bob Bowman, Outpost's chief executive. "We already have orders exceeding last year. We will do north of a million today."
Consumers were drawn, Mr. Bowman said, by the offer of free overnight shipping and a promotion that rewarded a shopper every 15 minutes with a gift appropriate for Internet surfing, like a bathrobe and a pretzel-popcorn snack.
But the increased traffic did not come without a price. In the week leading up to Black Friday, many Web shoppers complained that sites were responding slowly and that some did not take orders at all. Among the most troubled were the toy sites, with Toys "R" Us and Etoys having down time during the week, and KBKids.com suffering badly today.
Because Internet retailers must ship goods, they tend to hit their Christmas peak a little earlier than traditional merchants, who can provide cash-and-carry gratification. Perhaps this explains why reports from stores were mostly positive but a bit mixed.
"It was a slow start, to tell you the truth, because there was not one big toy this season," John Konarski, president of the International Council of Shopping Centers, said this morning. "There was no reason to get up at 4:30 in the morning and wait on line."
Consumers strolling the avenues in the big urban centers reported that they had every intention of spending lots of money and plenty of it in plain old stores. And there were signs everywhere that retailers were not going to cede sales readily. Many stores were already promoting big markdowns, and in what may be a service emphasis inspired by a fear of the Internet, most had salespeople clamoring to help browsers.
Sue and Brad Briddell, who traveled from Toledo, Ohio, to shop in Chicago, had only praise for the service they had found on Michigan Avenue. The two had been out of their hotel and on the hunt by 7:30 a.m., and by mid-morning had already visited Marshall Field's and Old Navy and had fingered the parachute flight pants at Express. The couple did not find the stereotypical scarce or gruff sales help. Both said they had been served well.
"Oh, it has been fantastic," Ms. Briddell said. "Everyone's been very up and very friendly."
Whether stores can maintain that first-day polish will be the question as the shopping season gathers steam.
The Web's popularity might be changing the world of shopping, but certain things remain constant online or off. Discounted merchandise or anything Pokemon was a good thing today.
Jeff Tauber, chairman and chief executive of Cybershop, an online merchant specializing in toys, apparel and housewares, said, "We are definitely exceeding last year's numbers, and this day last year was one of our top three or four days of the entire year. People are always looking for a good deal."
Among Cybershop's specials was a $99 bundle of Pokemon paraphernalia, including trading cards, the coveted Pikachu plush animal, a pencil set and a key chain.
In Atlanta, more than 50 shoppers rushed to the electronics department to buy Pokemon items when Target, the low-price division of Dayton Hudson, opened its doors at 7 a.m. While shopping at Target, Starla Littleton and her niece Shelly Park used walkie-talkies to make their trip more efficient.
"She goes to get one thing, and I go to get another," Ms. Littleton said. They kept in touch as one checked out the Pokemon display and the other headed to the Furbie Babies.
Meanwhile, the department stores, which offer mid-range prices and few toys, were rather empty before midday. Diana Brown, who was shopping at Barney's in New York with a couple of girlfriends, said that just before her excursion she had heard that today was Black Friday. "We thought, 'Oh, no,' " Ms. Brown said. "But it's not bad at all."
Cathy Joiner, of Nashville, who was fingering Pashmina shawls at the Bloomingdale's on 59th Street, while her husband, Don, looked on, said, "I was here last year, and it was a whole lot worse than this."
But if the fashionable clothiers were worried, they did not admit it. In sales, "we are up double digit above last year," said Judy Collinson, the Barney's Inc. general merchandise manager for women's wear, "and we don't even expect this to be one of our biggest days."
Ms. Collinson said that luxury items selling well included Fendi purses, shearling jackets and Pashmina shawls, which run up to $3,000 for the hand-embroidered variety.
"Our customers purchase things on the Internet," Ms. Collinson said firmly, "but not the things they buy from us."
