HEADLINE: State Subsidies to Hospitals Face Renewal Deadline, Spurring Policy Debate

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
New York hospitals are being suffocated, according to one viewpoint, by the government and by insurance companies that place profits perilously above patients' needs. Or, from another vantage point, the hospitals are hopelessly inefficient spendthrifts whose practices have not kept pace with cost-cutting trends in health care.
Administrators running the hospitals say they are Dickensian institutions, reeling from federal and state budgets cuts, barely able to eke out a profit. They are places where nurses frantically toil to take care of wards crowded with patients, and where doctors waste precious time fighting with managed-care companies. To make matters worse, administrators argue, state business leaders want to abandon their critical role of paying high medical-insurance premiums to help these hospitals absorb the costs of caring for the poorest and sickest, and Congress is taking away precious teaching dollars. 
 Health insurance companies and business groups counter that health care costs in New York State are nearly 20 percent higher than in the rest of the country, fueled in large part by hospitals in the city that they see as temples of medical arrogance and fiscal insouciance. Too many specialists, eager to try out their latest costly toys, hospitalize people for problems that could be solved in a doctor's office, and labor leaders, loath to lose a single job, resist the closing of the most under-used hospitals, the business argument goes.
The two sides have been at the heart of protracted debates over how to fix New York hospitals' ailing financial picture. And their characterizations of the health care system and its troubles and expenses, however contradictory they seem, are both accurate. New York hospitals ended 1998 with operating losses of $115 million, according to figures released this week. Yet their traditions are deeply embedded, so much so that long-term solutions to stem those losses have eluded experts for years.
This year, the people who provide health care and those who pay for it are finding themselves at a crucial juncture as they prepare to do battle with the State Legislature over the future of state health care financing, because the state's Health Care Reform Act expires at the end of next month. Further, teaching hospitals stand to lose tens of millions of dollars in Medicare money under a new Congressional budget bill.
If the Health Care Reform Act is not renewed, hospitals will lose a large portion of their state funds. So parties on all sides are scrambling to devise ways to deal legislatively with two significant and incendiary portions of the law: paying to educate medical students, which in New York is a huge and prestigious business, and covering the hospital bills of the state's poor uninsured patients, which is a huge burden.
Hospital and labor organizations have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on an advertising campaign expressing outrage at plans to cut the amount of money devoted to health care. And business leaders have raced around the state in recent months trying to convince anyone who will listen that it is time for someone else -- they have not specified whom -- to start footing the bills.
Both sides hope to influence any plan that Gov. George E. Pataki may have.
The reasons why the city's hospitals and the health care industry arrived at this point are many and varied, and to a great extent, are rooted in some obvious economic realities. Almost everything in New York, from electricity to labor to peanut butter, costs more than it does in the rest of the country. Thousands of people in the state are uninsured, and the health care system in New York City reinforces the outmoded practice of placing teaching hospitals front and center for even the most basic care.
At the same time, the Medicare and charity pools that historically combined to allow the state to build top-notch medical centers while also serving its poorest residents have either dried up or been threatened, while managed care companies have tightened the reimbursement screws.
"The hospitals' story about being broke is fundamentally accurate," said James R. Tallon, the president of the United Hospital Fund, a health care research and philanthropic organization. Insurers' arguments that hospitals could be more efficient are "also legitimate," he added.
"There is room for more efficient use of resources across the board," Mr. Tallon said. "But the question is, are you going to achieve that in a fair fashion?"
For decades, hospitals in New York, like those in many other areas of the country, enjoyed prosperity. Through a combination of the federal Medicare program and a state plan that paid for educating doctors, hospitals could afford to eat the costs of the uninsured while building many highly esteemed medical centers and training thousands of residents, many in highly specialized areas that attracted people from around the country to New York hospitals.
But in the last several years, a confluence of events reined in the flow of cash. Governor Pataki made major cuts in the state's Medicaid program, which pays for care for the poor, while Congress pulled back on Medicare, which primarily pays for care for retirees and disabled people.
At the same time, a state system that set the rates that insurers paid hospitals ended at Mr. Pataki's behest, forcing hospitals to start negotiating $16 billion a year in charges with the insurers. This freed health maintenance organizations to vastly decrease their reimbursement rates to the hospitals.
All the while, the ranks of the uninsured swelled. Suddenly, hospitals found themselves competing for patients and making budget cuts, anathema just a decade ago. Add on the high cost of labor -- which health care financing experts says is 70 percent of health care costs -- and the system has become more expensive while less profitable.
The state's method of paying hospitals for care they give essentially free is also unorthodox, coming in the form of an 8 percent surcharge on every hospital and laboratory bill. Businesses find this practice unfair because they feel it is ultimately passed to them in insurance rate increases. But that pool of money helps to cover the state's three million uninsured, who tend to seek almost all their care in hospitals, and many medical centers, especially the New York City public hospital system, say that they could not survive without this subsidized public service.
In any other industry -- say, retail -- the competition that results from tight times creates fallout. In New York City, Macy's and Bloomingdale's have survived. Bonwit Teller and A.& S. have closed. But New York has yet to close hospitals, and indeed many centers have expanded, reasoning that they need to offer comprehensive cancer centers and top-notch cardiac care to compete for patients.
"It is starting to look like the collapse of the Soviet empire," said Megan McAndrew Cooper, the editor of the Dartmouth Atlas, which tracks regional variations in health care. "Everyone in New York had to have the best of everything. There was no cooperative planning or constraint on resources, and now all of a sudden reimbursements get cut back and they are left supporting incredible overhead with no income. Things are getting very wobbly."
In fact, while New York has greatly reduced the number of days people stay in the hospital (that figure is still higher than the national average), the number of hospitals has not decreased. "If you have too many hospital beds, getting someone out of one earlier just frees up the bed for someone else," Ms. Cooper said. "What they should be doing is admitting fewer patients."
Further, the trend in medicine in the 1990's has been to do more procedures and treatments outside the hospital, in doctor's offices or even in the home. But in New York City, 82 Medicare patients out of 1,000 are still treated in the hospital for things that could be done in an ambulatory center; in San Francisco, that number is 51.
Hospital administrators and doctors contend that they have worked hard to move a huge system into the future, and add that it is infuriating to hear arguments about how they should be treating fewer patients when the number of uninsured patients in the state has risen at a far faster rate than in the rest of the country, and managed care companies are whittling down payments.
"We may not be 100 percent there," said Ruth Levin, vice president in charge of managed care for Continuum Health Partners, parent to Beth Israel and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.
But it does not help hospitals' efficiency when insurance firms "call us every day to remind us what the doctors should be doing," she said.
"Actually, it costs us a lot of money," she said. "I have eight nurses who do nothing but communicate with managed care companies."
This circles back to the sticky issue of doctors. New York trains them by the thousands; the doctor to population ratio in New York is about 50 percent higher than in the rest of the country. And the state has far more specialists: 175 per 100,000 residents, compared with a national average of 122 per 100,000.
While all states receive some Medicare money to pay for educating doctors, each has its own system of supplementing that pot. Many, including New York, use a portion of Medicaid dollars. But New York has a unique system under which employers pay a state tax based on the number of teaching hospitals in their region, a charge reflected in higher medical insurance premiums.
"No one in the country has a system of taxing businesses to train doctors," argues Elliott Shaw, the director of government affairs for the New York Business Council, which would like to see this portion of the Health Care Reform Act eliminated.
But supporters of this system, unusual and costly as it is, argue that training doctors has economic and social benefits for the state, because fine teaching hospitals attract patients from around the world. "It is a cost well worth paying," said State Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, chairman of the State Assembly Committee. "The local economy benefits because one person's decision to come to our hospital for a surgery is worth $100,000 to the local economy. And graduate medical education is also a way we pay for a lot of health care for the uninsured, because a lot of what residents do is provide uncompensated care."
And so it may be that while New York's costs are extremely high, the argument over whether to help keep hospitals afloat could center on shifts in the mind-sets on both sides of the debate. Should people in less-populated areas of Brooklyn be forced to travel an hour to a hospital because their local center fell to insolvency, as people do, say, in remote areas of North Dakota? Can young people in medical school adapt to the notion of becoming family doctors instead of super sub-specialists, and how would that affect the popularity of some of the more renowned hospitals? And where is the policy proposal for the city's ranks of uninsured?
"You always have to be careful about applying market forces in health care," Mr. Gottfried said, "because the values of the marketplace say if something isn't a profit center we cut it out. And in health care there are things we need that are not profitable. People are trying to figure out how to change their internal culture here. It is complicated."

HEADLINE: 45 Arrested in a Protest Against Capitalism

BYLINE: By KATHERINE E. FINKELSTEIN 

 BODY:
Four days before the World Trade Organization is to convene in Seattle to lay the groundwork for a global round of trade negotiations, about 400 young anti-capitalists held a roving protest in Manhattan yesterday afternoon that blocked traffic and resulted in 45 arrests.
The event, called "Buy Nothing Day," was staged by members of an international group, Reclaim the Streets, to oppose the traditional consumer frenzy on the day after Thanksgiving. 
 Wearing ties with images of dollar bills, pink feather boas and face paint, the protesters denounced corporate globalization, environmental destruction and consumerism, and passed out Chinese cookies with messages like "Globalize Liberation, Not Corporate Power."
The protesters, who did not have a permit, moved continually to avoid the police. They started in Union Square at 14th Street, moved to Times Square and continued to Bryant Park at 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas, as organizers moved them along with an air horn.
The demonstration stopped traffic at Broadway and 44th Street for about 40 minutes, group leaders estimated.
The group opposes the World Trade Organization's summit meeting, demonstrators said, because the W.T.O.'s leaders are not democratically elected, yet make economic decisions that affect health, safety and the environment.
One protester, Tim Santamour of Brooklyn, said, "In a week, the World Trade Organization will decide some huge economic issues without asking us -- just corporations and C.E.O.'s."
At Bryant Park, Ross Bingham, 36, a caterer and social worker, said of multinational corporations: "You can't control them. They're above the law of the country and they do what they please."
Another protester, who gave his name as Pogo and wore a red clown nose with orange wig, said that he was demonstrating against "the loss of individual and community power to corporations."
Standing in Times Square, where most of the 45 arrests on disorderly conduct charges were made, he added that the area had come to symbolize the takeover of neighborhoods by corporations.
Reclaim the Streets was formed in London in 1991 to protest the creation of new highways. Since then, the group has branched out and, according to a leaflet, has attracted "ecologists, anti-road activists, squatters, artists" and even "fire breathers."
Protesters yelled, "Unnecessary force, unnecessary force," as police officers carried them away from Times Square with their hands bound behind their backs with plastic handcuffs.
One protester clambered to the top of a 25-foot-high tripod as the crowd cheered. Police officers pulled him down and arrested him.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Euro Declines to Record Lows Against Dollar, Pound and Yen

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Defying predictions of accelerated growth in Europe, Europe's single currency sank to record lows today against the American dollar, the British pound and the Japanese yen.
In a move with tremendous symbolic value, Europe's 11-month-old euro slipped to barely one penny above one-to-one parity with the dollar. 
 The euro was introduced at nearly $1.18 on Jan. 4 amid buoyant enthusiasm about new opportunities in Europe's unified market. Today, the euro sank as low as $1.0076 before closing at $1.0156.
Though the decline was not in itself alarming, it provided yet another reminder of Europe's nagging economic problems and its inability to match the relentless growth of the United States.
The euro also hit record lows against the British pound, which is certain to aggravate the new wave of hostility within Britain about joining the European currency union.
The euro's most drastic decline has been against the Japanese yen, which has climbed sharply against all major currencies and is now about 30 percent higher against the euro than it was in January.
The euro's problems have repeatedly defied investors' expectations. At the time it was introduced, the euro seemed so strong that some economists and political leaders worried about its climbing so high that it might make European exports too expensive.
Instead, the euro sank throughout the first six months of its life and came quite close to parity with the dollar back in June. The euro then recovered part of its lost ground, a rebound partly attributed to signs of new economic growth and to speculators who were convinced that the euro was poised for a big bounce.
Europe's economy has indeed perked up in recent months, but it is still growing much more slowly than that of the United States. The United States economy expanded at a surprisingly strong rate of 5.5 percent in the third quarter of this year. By contrast, growth in the 11-nation euro zone is about 2.5 percent this year and is expected to reach about 3 percent next year.
Analysts said the euro had also been hobbled by growing skittishness among Japanese investors, who have seen the value of euro-denominated stocks and bonds plunge as a result of the yen's surge.
The European Central Bank added to that skittishness on Wednesday, when top officials said they would do nothing to shore up the euro against the yen.
On top of that, many currency traders who bet on a strong recovery in the euro last summer are now selling euros to adopt a more neutral stance relative to other currencies.
"This isn't about economic growth or this week's economic numbers," Michael Saunders, European economist at Salomon Smith Barney in London, said. "This is about investors trying to reduce their risks before year-end and trying to get back to neutral positions."
Officials at the European Central Bank, which governs monetary policy in the euro zone, made it clear this week that they would not try to shore up the euro through their trading operations.
Eugenio Domingo Solans, the bank's board member in charge of international issues, said on Thursday that the bank had no intention of intervening to prevent the euro from sinking below parity against the dollar.
And Wim Duisenberg, the European bank's president, in an interview published today in The Financial Times, reiterated his long-held position that the euro's exchange rate is only important if it fuels inflation.
"Does the actual movement give rise to concern?" Mr. Duisenberg asked rhetorically. "The answer is no. It doesn't matter very much."
But even Mr. Duisenberg admitted to "some concern" about perceptions created by a falling euro. "A continued further movement in this direction would contribute to undermining the confidence in the euro," he said. "Unjustified, but still it is a public perception."
In Brussels, officials at the European Commission said the euro's decline was attributable merely to strong economic data in the United States rather than to fundamental weaknesses in Europe.
"It's the strength of the dollar rather than the weakness of the euro that has led to these developments in the past few days," said Gerassimos Thomas, a commission spokesman.
Japanese central bankers and investors may well be the most worried about the euro. The extraordinary surge of the yen against the euro threatens to strangle Japanese exports to Europe because Japanese goods cost more in European currencies.
Although euro notes and coins will not enter circulation until 2002, the euro trades in the financial markets, and the existing currencies of the euro-member countries have been permanently locked to the value of the euro.
Haruhiko Kuroda, a senior official at the Japanese Finance Ministry, was quoted by Reuters today as saying that the euro's fall was unjustified. Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa has previously said that Japan is ready to intervene if necessary, and the Bank of Japan did in fact intervene, with assistance from the European Central Bank, earlier this summer.
Some analysts have speculated that the euro has been hurt by recent political machinations in Germany. In the last week, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany has inveighed against Vodafone AirTouch's hostile takeover bid against Mannesmann, giving rise to fears that Germany might try to block certain types of mergers.
Mr. Schroder started another round of controversy on Wednesday, when he orchestrated a $2.2 billion bailout ofa huge but woefully mismanaged construction company, Philipp Holzmann A.G.
But most economists say the euro's problems are rooted in more mundane issues. They note that many institutions increased their stocks of euro-denominated assets in the summer, convinced that the euro had hit bottom.
But as the end of the year approaches, they said, investors are shifting back to a neutral stance -- which means selling euros.
"People are very uncertain about what the correct level of the euro should be," Jens Dallmeyer, an economist at Deutsche Bank Research in Frankfurt, said. "The boom in the United States is still alive and kicking and everyone can feel it. But people are still waiting for hard evidence of an economic upswing in Europe."

HEADLINE: Desolation Row

BYLINE: By Michael Kazin; Michael Kazin is co-author, with Maurice Isserman, of "America Divided: The Civil War of the 1960s." He teaches history at Georgetown University.

 BODY:

 THE HUNGRY YEARS
 A Narrative History of the
 Great Depression in America.
 By T. H. Watkins.
 Illustrated. 587 pp. New York:
 A Marian Wood Book/
 Henry Holt & Company. $32.50. 
 The 1930's is the first American decade remembered chiefly with the eyes. Images of men in soup lines, mothers in migrant camps, veterans marching on Washington, strikers sitting down in auto plants and one ever-buoyant president tend to overshadow debates about the merits of the New Deal and why the Great Depression lasted long enough to earn its adjective. Most authors who write broad surveys of the period evoke the visual references, or seek to tell a different kind of story.
In "The Hungry Years," T. H. Watkins, a former editor of Wilderness magazine who now teaches history at Montana State University, attempts to do both. With richly graphic detail, he refreshes old accounts about the misery and insurgencies of the decade. Then he departs from the familiar to devote the last third of the text to the wrenching fortunes of rural America, a subject few historians of the 30's have found worthy of their sustained attention. The result is a set of discrete narratives, most about ordinary Americans, that often shine as literary performance but are ultimately unsatisfying as an interpretation of the period.
Like the great documentary photographers of the era, Watkins is an empathetic connoisseur of the particular. He is especially good at describing flaws in the execution of New Deal programs, whose intentions he generally applauds. Writing about the Civilian Conservation Corps, he points out the high desertion rate (near 20 percent), the prevalence of food riots and the extreme difficulty black Southerners had getting enrolled at all. He praises the Tennessee Valley Authority for bringing electrical power and jobs to rural Southerners. But building those huge T.V.A. dams, he notes, meant the destruction of numerous homes and villages. "I don't want to move," an East Tennessee woman in her 70's said. "I want to sit here and look out over these hills where I was born. My folks are buried down the road a piece and our babies are over there on the hill under the cedars."
Watkins's informed reverence for the natural world illumines his chapters on agrarian history. Whether explaining the drought that created the Dust Bowl or the slaughter of pigs by farmers desperate to raise the price of meat, he mingles evidence of human foibles and struggles with a sense of awe about the land. During the mid-30's, he writes, the unremitting wind from the plains "came down on all that exposed and crippled land, scooped up hundreds of millions of tons of it as dust, then boiled it all up into choking clouds that rolled across entire states and at least twice . . . sailed so high into the jet stream that airborne earth . . . darkened Eastern cities in the daytime and dusted the decks of trans-Atlantic liners." Such passages suggest how environmentalists have begun to alter the conventions of historical narrative, making political actors seem more like Sisyphus and less like Caesar.
Still, the Depression did touch off a political upheaval, and Watkins is not a fully reliable guide through its complexities. His penchant for the dramatic leads him to overemphasize the extent of organized resistance from the left. The unionists of the new Congress of Industrial Organizations were a critical force, but Watkins's lavish attention to them implies that they represented most workers at the time. In fact, the older, more conservative American Federation of Labor was never "in an unaccustomed subordinate position," as he claims. Jolted by the competition with its upstart rival, the A.F.L. signed up more new members than did the C.I.O., and helped steer the labor movement away from the anticapitalist stance espoused by radical organizers.
Watkins also inflates the significance of the Communist Party as an instigator of grass-roots rebellion and scants other insurgent voices who spoke for millions. He carefully charts each shift in policy by home-grown Leninists but neglects the sources and consequences of the huge, if short-lived, populist movements led by Charles Coughlin, Huey Long and Francis Townsend. At times, Watkins suggests that the country was on the brink of revolution. Yet the real contest was between an unsteady coalition of reformers and pragmatic radicals on one side and conservatives in both major parties who loathed the New Deal.
Focusing almost entirely on stories about collective anger also misses a sober reality about the Depression: millions of suffering Americans, spawn of an individualist culture, blamed themselves for their plight. They had assumed that the consumer-driven prosperity of the 1920's would only expand and did not recover easily or quickly from the shock of economic collapse. The familial crisis of the 30's was as profound as the political one, as marriages frayed and teenagers left home in search of work. The hunger for security under paternal leadership did much to keep Franklin Roosevelt in power, gaining him votes even from citizens who were troubled by the expansion of government during his long years in office. The coming of World War II did more than end the Depression by creating millions of jobs, for those in and out of uniform. It also liberated Americans from an epidemic of self-doubt.
"The Hungry Years" certainly has a great deal to offer readers unfamiliar with the history of the 30's. And Watkins's prose often has the intensity and warmth of a photo by Dorothea Lange or a novel by John Steinbeck, artists whom the author clearly admires. At a time when most Americans learn about the past by watching large and small screens, a historian who can write so vividly ought to find a wide audience.
The book ends with the author's childhood memory of the day Pearl Harbor was bombed. After the radio announced news of the Japanese attack, his mother went to his room and methodically checked each of his toys to see where it had been manufactured. Then "she started a fire with some trash and a big kitchen match, and when it was going well handed me some of the toys. . . . As she tossed in each 'Made in Japan' toy, so did I, one at a time, until they were all consumed or shriveled."
It's a pity that Watkins rarely steps back from telling his fine story, or rather group of stories, to point out any larger meaning. If his interpretive gifts equaled his narrative ones, he might have produced a masterpiece. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Beyond Money

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria; Fareed Zakaria, the managing editor of Foreign Affairs, is working on a book about the future of democracy.

 BODY:

Development As Freedom
 By Amartya Sen.
 366 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50. 
 A MARTYA SEN was an odd choice for the Nobel in economic science in 1998. In a field increasingly obsessed with narrow technical virtuosity, Sen has persisted in asking big, messy questions, mixing ethics with his equations. The choice was also unusual because, unlike most Nobel laureates, he was not associated with a single grand idea -- a "killer theorem," in the language of the field -- having written across a range of topics, even disciplines. But with his new book, "Development as Freedom," Sen, who is Master of Trinity College, Cambridge, has brought together many of his ideas and put them under one theoretical umbrella.The result is a somewhat disjointed work, part collected essays, part magnum opus.
If there is an underlying theme in Sen's work -- and it takes up a few chapters here -- it is skepticism that money is the measure of all things. He has persistently posed this question: What do we mean when we say that a person or a group or a country is better off? The conventional answer -- higher incomes -- is not enough for Sen. He points out that many places with low per capita incomes, like Sri Lanka, China and the Indian state of Kerala, have achieved higher life expectancies and literacy rates than much richer lands like Brazil, South Africa and Namibia. In fact the people of these poor countries (and there are others, like Costa Rica and Gabon) can expect to live longer than some groups in industrial countries, like American black men, who in monetary terms are much richer. Sen recognizes that in most countries higher incomes do produce improvements across most measures of the quality of life. But in looking at the exceptions he forces us to examine the connection between income and well-being, between money and happiness.
Some of the other chapters contain reprises of Sen's justly famous studies. Perhaps his best-known paper argues that democracy is crucial to the prevention of famine and points out the striking fact that there has never been a famine in a functioning multiparty democracy. Another makes vivid the neglect of women's health in Asia and North Africa by calculating the number who are "missing" -- that is, who would have lived if given the same care and attention as men; it is close to 100 million.
Another chapter, more polemical than scholarly, rejects claims made by Singapore's founding prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, and others that development in poor countries often requires tough decisions and the ability to delay gratification, both of which generally require ignoring popular pressures. Sen observes that this analysis rests on the success of a few East Asian countries, not the full range of autocracies, many of which have proved to be disastrous at economic development. He correctly notes that more complete studies are inconclusive as to whether, on average, dictatorships outperform democracies. To put it simply, if a country gets an autocrat there's no way of ensuring that the autocrat will be Lee Kuan Yew and not Mobutu Sese Seko.
But Sen is much too dismissive of the interesting case of East Asia's "tigers." They are, after all, the only third world countries to move from poverty to near plenty -- and in one generation! It might be worth considering, for instance, that these countries adopted more free-market-oriented policies than other third world countries did, policies that were wildly unpopular until very recently. The easiest way to win an election in South Asia or Africa during the 1960's and 1970's was to brand your opponent a capitalist.
Sen lauds the East Asians for investing in human capital through health care and education because these policies not only produced growth but also improved people's quality of life. But again, in most third world countries organized political and labor groups insisted on a very different course. They demanded large-scale employment projects, often through nationalization; huge subsidies; and tariff protection for local industries. Politically powerful farmers prevented land reform and other interest groups still block cuts in subsidies and deregulation. In Chile, for example, it was Pinochet's military government that pushed through the land reform policies of the socialist Salvador Allende. Today central planning is in disfavor and capitalism seems irresistible, so perhaps good economics also makes for good politics. But this has not always been so and may not be so in the future.
Sen's claims for democracy, however, are not really about economic performance. He argues that democratic government is an end in and of itself because it furthers human freedom. This is a powerful, well-established statement that few would disagree with. Sen places it at the center of his overall theoretical framework. But this governing idea, which takes up several chapters, has neither the originality nor the power of Sen's more specific insights.
Development, for Sen, is the process of expanding human freedom -- hence his book's title. Raising peoples' incomes is important, he says, but so is giving them political rights like the ability to choose their governments and express themselves without fear. Fair enough. But freedom for Sen goes well beyond providing people with basic political and civil rights. True freedom -- "substantive freedom" is his term -- requires "economic facilities," "social opportunities" and "protective security" -- in other words, state-funded jobs, services and income subsidies for the less successful in society.
Now this might strike many as a familiar argument for redistribution, and one that has been accepted by most industrial societies -- they all underwrite some version of the welfare system Sen seems to be advocating. The philosophical rationale for this setup was also made, comprehensively and brilliantly, almost 30 years ago by John Rawls in "A Theory of Justice." Sen believes he is different from Rawls, and more radical, but in ways that strike me as quibbles. Sen considers his theoretical innovation to be his expansive definition of substantive freedom as whatever helps human beings fully exercise their capabilities -- "or, less formally put, the freedom to achieve various lifestyles." He criticizes Rawls for giving priority to the narrower, traditional conception of liberty -- freedom from physical or mental coercion. "Why should the status of intense economic needs," Sen asks, "which can be matters of life and death, be lower than that of personal liberties?"
But Sen's is hardly an original definition. T. H. Green wrote of "true freedom," in 1881, as "the maximum power for all members of human society alike to make the best of themselves." And he was far from the first to propose this kind of broad conception of liberty. But if one seeks the redistribution of wealth or the promotion of egalitarianism or any other such value, why call it freedom? At the very least it confounds plain discourse. And at worst, it can lead to the neglect of basic liberties in the search for more extravagant ones. Philosophers like Rawls and Isaiah Berlin, hardly libertarians, give priority to personal liberties for good historical reasons; over the centuries, governments have routinely abused them, often justifying coercion by claiming to be fulfilling some positive vision of freedom.
In awarding Sen his prize, the Swedish Academy of Sciences noted that he had "restored an ethical dimension to the discussion of vital economic problems." He has done this and more. His book is rich in insight and moral imagination. Sen raises more questions than he answers. He almost always handles thorny choices by declaring that we must balance values, even when they are, as they often are, competing. So much of his high intelligence is devoted to moving between subjects and fields -- a little public choice theory here and a little moral philosophy there -- that the book has a discursive and diffuse quality. "Development As Freedom" has neither the comprehensiveness of the best political philosophy nor the elegance of the best economics. It makes one long for a killer theorem.

HEADLINE: Made in Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his review of "In Praise of Hard Industries: Why Manufacturing, Not the Information Economy, Is the Key to Future Prosperity" (Sept. 12), James K. Galbraith says that the argumentation in my book is sometimes "daft": "In two places Fingleton asserts that the high-tech hotshots who make so much money in San Jose are so bright that they could do equally well in, let us say, Akron, if only they chose to move there. So why didn't they?" In reality what I say is quite different -- that "in a manufacturing-based economy" (by which it is clear I am talking about an economy like that of Japan), intelligent and capable workers can expect to earn at least as high wages in manufacturing as in postindustrial services. 
 In challenging my evaluation of how far the United States has fallen behind its foreign competitors in advanced manufacturing, Galbraith cites Boeing as a counterexample. I happen to know from personal experience that Boeing is quite defensive about how hollowed out it has become. Its embarrassment is understandable. Remember that Boeing is now heavily dependent on Japan not only for its most advanced components but for key production technologies. That this is evidence of American manufacturing weakness is clearly apparent when you realize that wages in Japan have long been considerably higher than in the United States. Using statistics from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, I calculate that at the current market exchange rate, wages in Japan are at least 30 percent higher than in the United States. This undoubtedly seems surprising in view of the way the Japanese economy has been reported since the bubble burst in 1990, but it is nonetheless a historically crucial fact.
 
Eamonn Fingleton
Tokyo

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Manhattan Avenue Between 104th and 106th Streets;
1880's Brick Row Houses With a Bostonian Air

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE picturesque pocket of Victorian row houses on Manhattan Avenue from 104th to 106th Streets, which date from the time the thoroughfare got its name, has a calm Bostonian air that makes it seem a bit removed from city life.
Manhattan Avenue was not on the original street plan for New York City, but by 1868 it was mapped -- as New Avenue -- running north from 100th Street between what are now Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. This was well before any real development in the area, but in the mid-1880's sales activity picked up, and the thoroughfare received its current name in 1884. High land prices discouraged row house building on Central Park West, although in 1884 the New York Cancer Hospital -- now abandoned -- started its giant rounded building on Central Park West from 105th to 106th Streets. 
 The first building activity on Manhattan Avenue occurred in 1885, when Frederick Seitz put up the row houses on the west side of the street from 105th to 106th, designed by Joseph M. Dunn. The next year the developer John Brown built up the east side of the same block with houses designed by C. P. H. Gilbert, and in 1889 Joseph Turner had the architect Edward Angell design the houses on the west side of Manhattan Avenue from 104th to 105th.
Although other developers were still putting up traditional high-stoop brownstones elsewhere in Manhattan, all these buildings were brick, with stone and terra cotta trim and lower stoops; they were only three stories tall, costing between $8,000 and $12,000 to build. The houses designed by Gilbert, who later did Fifth Avenue mansions like what is now the original wing of the Jewish Museum at 92nd Street, are close to the Queen Anne style, with sunburst motifs in the gables, wavy linear ornament on the cornice, and multilight windows with stained glass.
Those by Dunn are a little wilder, with widely varying arches and gables. The critic Montgomery Schuyler coined the phrase "reign of terror" style to describe them because of their startling and alarming appearance. The Angell houses are neo-Romanesque and more sophisticated, although still quite varied. All have unusual ornament -- terra cotta panels with rivet-head figuring, sunburst ironwork and subtly varying brickwork.
The early occupants were modestly successful, like George B. Sharp, a stable owner, at 122 Manhattan Avenue; Albert H. Kohn, a jeweler, at 132; and Paris Fletcher, an electrician, at 138.
Sometime in the 1910's the family of Charles Gruppe moved into 138 Manhattan Avenue; a landscape painter, Gruppe lived there with his wife and three sons, Paul, a cellist, Karl, a sculptor, and Emile, a painter. At the same time more and more houses were renting out rooms -- George C. Hammer, a sea captain, was a roomer at 119 Manhattan Avenue.
By then, the houses on Manhattan Avenue were holdouts in a sea of tenements and apartment buildings, their status reinforced when the giant Frederick Douglass housing project went up at the southwest corner of 104th Street and Manhattan Avenue in the 1950's.
Daniel and Elsie Matos are among the senior residents of the row-house stretch of Manhattan Avenue -- they moved into the top floor of 122 Manhattan Avenue in 1959. "We were living on East 117th Street and came over here for something different," Mrs. Matos said. Mr. Matos, a retired cabdriver, said that "when we moved in this was a drug dealer's neighborhood."
His building has spongy linoleum-covered stairs, ancient paint and battered front doors, but it also has its original encaustic tile vestibule floor and original woodwork. He said that his monthly rent was between $200 and $300 and he estimated that the rent for each full-floor apartment in the building was about the same. "It's great -- you go to bed at night and you don't hear a fly in here," he said.
Ella S. McDonald bought the building at 138 Manhattan Avenue in 1972. She said that Karl Gruppe would not sell unless she and her husband promised not to convert the building into a rooming house. "I said, 'What's a rooming house?' and he let us buy it," she recalled. "The block was unbelievably bad. My family thought I had lost my mind -- a couple of houses were boarded up, street people all over the place, bongos 24 hours a day. But five or six of us families got together, and we decided we were not going to let the drug people push us out."
ELIZABETH KELLNER said that she and her husband, David, both lawyers, bought their house, at 132 Manhattan Avenue, in 1976 for $25,000. She said they stripped all the woodwork and installed period fixtures. The fireplaces on the lower floors are heavily worked oak pieces, with figured tiles in earth tones, but the top-floor fireplaces are plain slate, with geometric incised lines, spare and abstract.
Their living room -- perhaps 12 by 16 feet -- is small and cozy, but big enough for a baby grand, a small sofa and a large television. Like the other three-story Manhattan Avenue houses, theirs is much more livable than the standard dark Manhattan row house, usually built very deep and four or five stories high.
In December 1986 Mr. Kellner used an old statute, the Bawdy House Law, to evict squatting drug dealers who had taken over the building at 124 Manhattan Avenue. Since then, neighbors agree, the neighborhood has continued to improve. Mrs. Kellner said that although the available shopping is not what she would prefer, "I really like the fact that the neighborhood is racially, ethnically and economically integrated." They have taken down the board fences separating their backyard from their neighbors'.
All this has taken place in the shadow of the old New York Cancer Hospital, later a nursing home, designated a landmark in 1976 and vacant since. There have been various plans for redevelopment, but the building remains a majestic wreck. Some call it a blight, but it is also a peaceful interlude in the area, a sort of architectural preserve.
Mrs. McDonald said she likes it on Manhattan Avenue. "It's a neighborhood," she said. "When my brother came by to come in with a key, people asked him who he was -- my brother was very impressed. Why would I move from here?"

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Greenport, N.Y.;
A Working Seaport, Reliant on Visitors

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THERE can be few waterside views as nautically inspiring as those in the Village of Greenport, an authentic seaport on eastern Long Island that depends on tourism but stubbornly resists becoming a parody of itself.
Situated 95 miles east of Manhattan on the Peconic Bay side of the still rural North Fork, it is a deep-water port where fishing vessels back from the Hudson Canyon and Georges Banks tie up at piers near ferryboats shuttling between the village and nearby Shelter Island. 
 In recent years, Greenport has reversed a period of economic decline and stagnation that was odd for a place so well situated and steeped in history. Some attribute the turnaround to an energetic mayor, David E. Kapell, the village's third real estate broker-mayor.
Mr. Kapell, the owner of Kapell Real Estate and the son of the late concert pianist William Kapell, moved to Greenport from the Upper East Side of Manhattan in 1979 and raised a family here with his wife, Eileen. First elected in 1994, he said he sought the office in part to revive the village's lagging real estate market.
Now he worries that if housing prices rise too high the village will be too rich for the blue-collar families that are at its core. And he frets when new residents complain about the nocturnal noises of the fishing fleet and the smell of fish from the docks and two fish-processing plants.
"This is the type of thing we confront in Greenport, and it's what is going to determine whether we maintain our tradition or become just another charming has-been Victorian seaport," Mr. Kapell said. "We are going to resist change with every ounce of energy we've got if it means a loss of our identity, and if the fish smell keeps change at bay then we're all for it."
Although prices are rising, Greenport's predominantly 19th century and pre-World War II Victorian, colonial, Arts and Crafts and other homes, ranging from frankly humble to fantastical and from nondescript to nonpareil, are also among the most affordable on Long Island.
Three-bedroom, two-bath Victorians or colonials on small lots may still be found for comfortably less than $200,000. The highest recent home sale price, a record, was just under $900,000 for a waterfront Victorian on two acres. A one-bedroom bungalow on a corner lot three blocks from the water recently sold for $60,000.
Some of Greenport's finer homes are in West Dublin, named for the Irish railway workers who settled there after the Long Island Rail Road reached Greenport in 1844. Other sections include Stirling, the most venerable, and Easy Street, once the sailors' bordello and bar district.
The village has three condominiums, all with water views and built within the last 20 years. At the 35-unit Sterling Cove and 26-unit Oyster Point, two-bedroom apartments sell for about $250,000. At the nine-unit Pipes Cove, they go for $350,000 to $400,000.
House rentals, which are occasionally available, range from about $800 to $1,200 a month on a year-round basis.
Sally A. Heitel, a broker associate and manager at Century 21 Albertson Realty, formerly Victorian Realty, said the local real estate market was humming.
"It's hot, very hot," she said. "We've seen prices increase by probably 20 or 30 percent in the last year. Inventory is the problem."
Ms. Heitel moved to Greenport a year ago from Greenwich Village, drawn by Greenport's pedestrian scale and "creaky screen doors like you never hear in the city."
"I had always imagined coming out here and living somewhere really remote," she said. "And living in the village is about as remote as you can get."
REMOTE or not, the village is a favorite place for day-trippers, who on weekends crowd the narrow sidewalks along Front and Main Streets in the main commercial district.
Stores include the Book Scout, a used book and record emporium where discards share shelf space with semiprecious volumes; S. T. Preston and Sons, a maritime hardware store crammed with nautical supplies and just a few steps from the Main Street wharf; the Coronet, a time-warp 1950's era luncheonette; the Arcade, an old-fashioned general merchandise store that stocks everything from odd buttons to low-cost work clothes; several art galleries and restaurants.
Though it relies on visitors, Greenport also gladly ushers in newcomers provided they take the village on its own terms.
"Unlike a lot of other places on the North Fork, Greenport welcomes growth," said Joseph L. Townsend an insurance broker, former mayor, and descendant of some the village's earliest English settlers. "But we want to make it hard to buy a two-acre plot, and easy to buy a house that is already here and have it restored."
Mr. Townsend, like many others, said the village was on an upward track. "The atmosphere has become a lot more cosmopolitan," he said. "It's not quite as chichi as Sag Harbor, but it's getting there."
STILL, people looking for a nascent Hampton will turn on their heels in this place without pretense, whose rough past is recalled in a Front Street tavern called the Whiskey Wind, an allusion to rum-running during Prohibition.
"There's no snobbery here, people are themselves," said John A. Serkin, a piano technician, son of the late concert pianist Rudolf Serkin and brother of concert pianist Peter Serkin.
After years of visiting, John Serkin and his wife, Catherine Kurland, a decorative arts consultant and writer, moved to Greenport from Manhattan about eight years ago. "Once I tasted life out here I didn't ever want to go back to the city," Mr. Serkin said.
Mr. Serkin is now involved in a program to bring classical music to Greenport schools. With an architect friend, Gary Paul, he has designed a camera obscura for the waterfront Mitchell Park on Front Street, which will include an amphitheater, a skating rink, a public marina and a 1920's era carousel when it opens in two phases, beginning in April. The carousel is temporarily housed at the corner of Front Street and Third Street. Rides cost $1.
In another part of the village at the foot of Webb Street the Peconic County Miniature Railroad Company gives rides on 16-inch gauge tracks running through the woods. Rides are free but donations are accepted.
At the Polo Grounds, another village park, a new skateboarding center charges $3 for a three-hour session. There are also ballfields and a traveling carnival visits in the summer. The park is near Moore's Woods, a 190-acre village-owned woodland, and the privately owned, April-to-October Eastern Long Island Kamp Grounds just outside the village boundary.
There is a small public beach at the foot of Sixth Street. In addition to several private marinas, there are 43 moorings at $600 a season each available to village residents.
The village has its own electric utility, which has kept electric rates low.
TRAIN service is limited and the only weekday commuter train takes nearly three hours, with changes at Ronkonkoma and Jamaica, to reach Pennsylvania Station. Sunrise Coach buses are quicker and discharge passengers in midtown.
The 625-student Greenport public schools have all the advantages and disadvantages of a small district. All classes, from kindergarten through high school, are held in a single building erected in 1932 as a Depression-era public works project.
Dr. Charles Kozora, the superintendent, said teachers and students get to know each other well. "We never have anybody fall through the cracks," he said. But he said there were fewer electives than in larger districts.
Among the 33 graduates in the class of 1999, more than half earned Regents diplomas and 84 percent went on to higher education. Average College Board scores were 529 in verbal and 513 in math, compared with state averages of 495 and 502, respectively. The class had the highest passing rate in Suffolk County for the English Regents exam.
In a cooperative program with the Southampton Campus of Long Island University, academically qualified juniors and seniors may take accelerated courses in advanced chemistry and calculus. Advanced placement courses are also offered.
All classes are academically heterogeneous. Special education students attend regular classes, but get extra help from teachers assigned to them. Computer-assisted lessons begin in kindergarten. Students have access to computers in the library and in a computer lab.
The Youngs family, descendants of Puritans who arrived on the North Fork in 1640, bought land and settled in what is now Greenport in 1682. From the late 18th century to the mid-1800's, Greenport prospered as a fishing and whaling center.
Known in earlier times as Winter Harbor and Stirling, the village adopted the name Greenport when it incorporated in 1838. When the Long Island Rail Road's Main Line arrived in 1844, a rail-and-steamboat link was forged between New York City and Boston. Demand for the service waned after the two cities were joined by overland rails not long afterward.
In an event that brought Greenport notoriety, village residents voted in 1994 to sack their police department for incompetence and worse, saving $1 million a year in taxes. The village is now patrolled by the Southold Town police department.

TRAIN BANE: Greenport's romance with the railroad soured last year when new diesel locomotives went into service with whistles so loud and shrill they wake people from their sleep. Most notorious of all is an early morning train that lumbers eastward across the North Fork between 4 and 5 a.m. and departs from Greenport at 5:30 a.m. with a handful of passengers. "The whistle is causing a lot of problems," said Joseph L. Townsend, the former Greenport mayor. "People hate it." Now, responding to complaints from residents and public officials from areas of Long Island where the new diesels are in service, the railroad has agreed to tone the whistles down and make them more melodious.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
High-Tech Growth Filling Financial District Offices

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
JOSEPH MOINIAN stood at the corner of John and Gold Streets recently and recalled what it was like in this downtown office district in the middle of the decade. "Eighty John Street was fully vacant, 90 John Street was 68 percent vacant, 99 John Street was about to become fully vacant and 90 William Street was 60 percent vacant," he said. "It was a ghost town." 
 The area had been badly hit by the decline of employment in the financial services and insurance industries and the departures of some of the more prominent companies to new buildings in Midtown.
 The overall downtown vacancy rate was more than 30 percent and some real estate executives said some of the older buildings were too obsolete to ever be used for offices again.
Nevertheless, Mr. Moinian, the chief executive of the Moinian Group, a developer, saw opportunities in the area. He was convinced that the growth of a new industry -- computer related software and services -- along with a city development plan that provided rent and energy tax benefits and a promotion sponsored by the Alliance for Downtown New York would draw tenants to the area.
So in 1995 he bought the 29-story building at 90 John Street. The following year he purchased another building a block away at 90 William Street and began rewiring both so they would be ready for the high tech tenants he hoped to attract. The wiring included optical fiber telecommunications backbones and upgraded electrical service to power the devices the new companies would use.
Today both buildings are fully rented to tenants like Gobi Inc., which gives computers to people who sign up for its services, and Spendcash, which enables users to buy things over the Internet without disclosing credit information. Both buildings have waiting lists of tenants who want to move into an area that has been dubbed Silicon Alley because of the concentration of computer-based companies.
The growth of this industry, much more than the expansion of downtown's traditional mainstay of financial services, has pushed down the area's office vacancy rate to 9.2 percent as of the end of the third quarter, according to a report by Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate services company.
Employment in the media and entertainment sector, much of it computer-based, has increased by 25,138 jobs over the last five years, according to an analysis of New York State Department of Labor data by Colliers ABR, a real estate services company. Meanwhile the financial, insurance and real estate category only increased by 9,856 jobs, indicating the decrease in relative importance of the financial sector for office space demand.
As a result, the Moinian buildings are no longer participants in the Plug 'n' Go program sponsored by the Alliance for Downtown New York, the business improvement district for the southern tip of Manhattan. The program offers below market initial rents and other incentives to lure companies to a part of town that once seemed a backwater.
To participate in the program, the owner of a building has to build out and wire at least 20,000 square feet of space and offer it to the market at a rental rate that started at $15 a foot in 1996 and has increased to $19 a foot in the current program. The rates, which increase in later years of a lease, have been 20 to 30 percent below market rates.
Six buildings have participated in each of the three years the Plug 'n' Go program has been in effect, for a total of 14 so far, according to Sharon Greenberger, vice president for economic development at the alliance. "There have been 225 leases signed under the program, covering 570,000 square feet," Ms. Greenberger said.
LOW rental rates were the initial lure, Ms. Greenberger said, but since then the concentration of technology-based companies has become a lure for others in similar fields. "We have over 700 high-technology companies here in what has become a marquee location," she said. "It is the rebirth of the area as a technology community."
She said the alliance matches the city's contribution of $100,000 a year to promote the Plug 'n' Go program. The city's incentives for new tenants, part of a broader effort to revive the downtown area, include a reduction in the rent tax that real estate executives say amounts to about $1 per square foot and discounts on electrical power.
Mr. Moinian said he decided to buy the buildings and participate in the Plug 'n' Go program because the high vacancy rates at the time meant there was probably more to gain than lose. "My philosophy at the time was that it made sense to rent for $15 a square foot. The downside was that somebody would rent for $15 a foot and go out of business. But the upside was that somebody would go from 2,500 square feet to 25,000 square feet."
While there have been a few failures, he said, most of the companies have survived and expanded. He said the program had attracted more than 60 technology companies to the buildings, one of which, 90 William Street, has been renamed One Silicon Alley Plaza to emphasize its orientation.
Mr. Moinian said the often frenetic operating style of the technology companies had changed the way the buildings are managed. Cutting back services during the evenings and weekends is not acceptable to them. "These guys have deadlines they have to meet," he said. "They have to have 7/24 access," he said, using the shorthand term for 24 hour a day, 7 day a week operations.
Another departure from traditional management practice was the installation of a 20,000 square foot gym at 90 John Street to provide a recreational outlet for the most young employees of the companies.
Renovations to the buildings included some standard upgrades such as sprucing up the lobbies, replacing leaky old windows and improving the heating and air-conditioning. But the new wiring and telecommunications were the critical attractions.
"We had to bring fiber to the buildings, because it was not there," Mr. Moinian said. "It's a revolution, like the addition of air conditioning to buildings. In a few years, I don't think you will be able to rent a building without fiber, just like you couldn't rent a building without air-conditioning."
He said brokers would point out the pre-installed connections in the wall to prospective high-technology tenants. "If they knew technology, they knew exactly what those plugs were for," Mr. Moinian said.
The vacant space in the buildings was built out in units of 1,000 to 10,000 square feet. These relatively modest spaces have become something of a problem as fast-growing companies have hired more people than they have the space to accommodate.
"Some of these companies have people sitting in their kitchens," said William G. Cohen, an executive vice president of Newmark & Company Real Estate, a real estate services firm that represents the Moinian Group.
He said landlords try to retain growing tenants by finding them other areas in their buildings that have more space. But even if they are forced to leave, it is not a total loss. "That allows us to rent the space at higher rates," said Mr. Cohen, who added that current rates started at $27 a foot."
He said many of these start-up companies would prefer to be in trendier part of the city, such as SoHo or Midtown South, but did not want to face higher rental rates and unfinished space at a time when they really want to plug in and get going. "They come downtown and find the space all prewired and ready to do business," Mr. Cohen said. "And then they discover that wherever their employees are coming from -- Brooklyn, Queens, New Jersey or Manhattan -- it is a really easy location to get to."
Mr. Moinian said he was convinced that advanced wiring and telecommunications were attractions for all categories of real estate. "I've got the building at 17 Battery that's being converted to 500 apartments," he said. "And I'm going to put the infrastructure into those apartments."

HEADLINE: Q & A;
Providing Heat in an Apartment

 BODY:

Q I live in a small rent-controlled apartment. Its only sources of heat are a small radiator and two vertical steam pipes, one in the kitchen and the other in the bathroom. The riser in the bathroom is equipped with a steam valve near the ceiling that noisily spews dirty, rusty water and a foul-smelling gas that floods the bathroom and makes me sick. Management's response to my complaints have been to change the valve -- which produces no result -- or to remove it -- which deprives me of heat. Am I not entitled to enough heat, including in the bathroom, and to clean healthy air? . . . Anne-Marie Kunzler, Manhattan.
 
A Sandy Russo, housing law coordinator for Legal Services for New York City, said that every residential lease agreement in New York carries with it an implied warranty that the premises are suitable for human habitation. 
 "The failure to provide adequate heat throughout the apartment, failure to correct noxious odors, unreasonable noise and flooding all constitute a breach of the warranty of habitability," Ms. Russo said.
She added that the New York City Housing Maintenance Code requires that between Oct. 1 and May 31, a landlord must provide sufficient heat to maintain apartments at 68 degrees Fahrenheit between 6 a.m. and 10 p.m. when the outside temperature falls below 55.
Between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., she said, heat must be maintained at 55 degrees when the outside temperature falls below 40 degrees. And while it is not uncommon for a steam pipe riser to be the source of heat for a small room such as a bathroom or kitchen, Ms. Russo said, the landlord is nevertheless required by law to provide the minimum heat required by law throughout the apartment.
She said that if a landlord violates the heat law, or otherwise breaches the warranty of habitability, a tenant has several options. For example, Ms. Russo said, a tenant can withhold the rent to compel the landlord to correct the problem. If the landlord begins nonpayment proceedings in housing court, she said, the tenant can assert the landlord's breach of the warranty of habitability as a defense and can demand a rent abatement for the period during which the condition existed.
In addition, Ms. Russo said, if a landlord fails, after reasonable notice, to correct a serious condition affecting habitability, a tenant may perform the necessary work and deduct the cost from the rent owed.
In New York City, she said, a tenant can also bring a case against a landlord in housing court seeking a court order for the landlord to correct the violations. And finally, Ms. Russo said, rent-regulated tenants can apply for a rent reduction order from the Division of Housing and Community Renewal when the landlord has failed to provide services or maintain the premises as required by law.
Tenants with complaints about insufficient heat in their apartments can also call the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development's heat hot line: (212) 960-4800.
 
An Apartment Without a Stove
 
Q I have a friend who lives in an apartment in the West 30's that I believe is rent-controlled. He has been there for more than 15 years and has had no stove for the entire time. Is the landlord required to provide a stove? . . . Jennifer Williams Ketay, Manhattan.
 
A Jeffrey Ween, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said that both the New York City Housing Maintenance Code and the state's Multiple Dwelling Law require a landlord to provide gas or electricity for cooking facilities, but neither requires the landlord to provide the appliances themselves.
Mr. Ween added, however, that under both rent control and rent stabilization, any services provided by a landlord at the time an apartment became subject to regulation must be maintained even if there is a change in occupancy. Accordingly, he said, if there was a stove in the friend's apartment at the time the apartment became subject to regulation, the friend is entitled to a stove now, even if he accepted the apartment without one.
Mr. Ween said that since information regarding the services provided in specific rent-regulated apartments is kept on file with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the friend should contact the division to determine what is on file for the apartment.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEWS;
For the Mind as Well as the Eyes

BYLINE: By Phyllis Braff 

 BODY:

'Souvenirs: Collecting, Memory
And Material Culture'
Guild Hall Museum, 158 Main Street, East Hampton. Through Jan. 9. (631) 324-0806.
Exerting a wide reach that jogs the mind in a rewarding way, this large exhibition mixes contemporary art with art and artifacts that have a clear place in Long Island's history. It demonstrates that current pieces, too, can be repositories of memory, longing and nostalgia. There are vintage souvenir plates, scrapbooks, old maps, matchbooks and calendars, along with paintings, photographs and sculpture by a number of 19th- and 20th-century artists. 
 Determining an order, or pattern, for any collection is standard procedure. In the hands of artists, the configurations can have tremendous visual energy, and one of the exhibition's strengths is its focus on the arrangements imposed on various accumulations of things. High-impact examples include Donald Lip ski's wheel of trophies, Michelle Stuart's table of seed specimens and Matt Mullican's collage of matchbooks.
The scheme can also involve the artist's concept for collecting data. Billy Sullivan's bird drawings, for example, record sightings during a specific span of minutes on specific days.
Landscape themes have an important role throughout the exhibition, and there is an emphasis on the way attitudes toward subject matter can differ and adjust, causing meanings to shift. Special attention is given to the process of committing a favorite site to memory. The abstract black-and-gray structured surface of Clifford Ross's photograph "Jetty II," the uncanny, oddly illuminated photographs by Susan Wides and the blurred, fractured paintings by Darragh Park are good examples. So are Howard Clifford's blend of diaristic entries and sensuous abstract paintings that capture direct experiences.
Two large, particularly successful recent works comment on the environment. They are linked to both the show's configuration theme and its feeling for souvenirs of a chosen place. In "Waters of East Hampton," Stacy Levy has covered a map of the township with 60 etched-glass containers, each holding a liquid sample from a different site. Hope Sandrow's sprawling but rationally organized installation has a title that corresponds to her process-oriented approach: "Within a Golden Rectangle: Moon Snail shells, numbering almost 10,000. Found November 12, 1997, washing up on the beach near the Mecox Bay Inlet to the Atlantic Ocean."
 
Loren Madsen: '6 Billion Monkeys'
Art Gallery, State University at Stony Brook. Through Dec. 11. (631) 632-7240.
In recent years, sculpture projects inspired by socio-economic and historical statistics have become central for the Manhattan-based artist Loren Madsen, whose three-decade career has included a number of dramatic works that thrust through space in their museum, gallery and public settings. His new piece, having its inaugural showing in Stony Brook, combines weighty population figures with a bit of whimsical humor.
Mr. Madsen has devised a visually engaging, multipart probability machine to test the old aphorism that, given 1,000 years, 1,000 monkeys sitting at typewriters will eventually produce a "Hamlet." An announcement that the world's population would reach six billion this fall was behind his numerical adjustment to the literary proposition.
The installation's largest unit, a dazzling, suspended 20-foot gilded circular form at the end of a 60-foot stem, represents the mushrooming count of humans on the planet. Smaller, quite different components include a ticking clockwork apparatus that regularly releases and alphabet marbles and sends them through the channels of a troughlike construction. These random letters occasionally create words.
There are moments when the piece projects a decided playfulness, but other moments when the sensuousness of the subtle, illusive metallic tones, reflections and shadows surrounding the main sculpture makes the effect quite powerful and beautiful. The work's resonance feels right for its statistical message. An appropriate parallel occurs, too, in the way the constant click of the clock's gears symbolizes counting, the passage of time and further growth in the world's population.
 
'Measurement'
Amelie Wallace Gallery, State University at Old Westbury. Through Dec. 4. (516) 876-3148.
Snappy and engaging, this provocative though small exhibition looks at various ways artists have used ideas about measurement. Its five examples generally lean toward a conceptual orientation and date from 1968 to 1979. All use commonplace elements and, in doing so, also raise issues about art's relationship to everyday life.
Viewers quickly feel part of the spatial situation established by Mel Bochner's "Measurement: Wall," a horizontal black tape and numerical reading (36 feet in this installation of the variable-size piece) that spans the central point on one gallery wall, turning its definition of space and dimension into the subject.
Projects by Vito Acconci and Mierle Laderman Ukeles are experienced, in part, through photodocumentation. Mr. Acconci's sequence traces his endurance scores over a period of months as he tested his ability to climb a step stool rapidly. Ms. Ukeles's measurements of labor activities, like trash collecting and sweeping, uses the photographic record she made in her rather well-known study of maintenance-as-art. In both instances the artist's investigation started with a specific format, which provided shape for the finished piece.
On Kawara's measurement-sequence pieces, usually works on paper, are considered to be classics of Conceptual Art. The example here is taken from a series of postcards mailed to friends during a 10-year period. Each notes the time the artist awoke on a specific day.
In a particularly memorable work, Mimi Smith uses tape measures to draw the outlines of bureaus and a bed. The transitory nature of her soft fabric lines and the airy spaces they describe contradict conventional notions of the bulky scale of household furniture with great effect.
