HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Energy-Efficient, Ecology-Sensitive Housing

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE 128-apartment development in Newark -- involving both the conversion of a 19th century factory into 62 units and the construction of a 66-unit apartment building on the nearby site of a factory that is to be demolished -- appears to be much like other low- and moderate-income rental housing projects in New Jersey.
But the two buildings are being designed to be environmentally sensitive, energy efficient and more affordable for residents to maintain, thanks to a $17 million state pilot program. 
 The two-building project is one of eight that the state's Department of Community Affairs is financing under its Sustainable Development/Affordable Housing Program, which was initiated last year. Among the others are projects involving the construction and restoration of one- and two-family houses in a historic area of Trenton and the development of 100 rentals on a patch of farmland in Eastampton, in Burlington County. The eight projects will produce 424 new and renovated rental and for-sale units for people earning 50 to 80 percent of their area's median income.
Under the program, which state officials say is the first of its kind in the nation, $12 million in low-interest loans of up to $55,500 a unit is available to developers to offset the cost of designing housing with higher energy efficiency and lower impact on the environment. In addition, $5 million in below-market-rate mortgages will be offered to income-qualified buyers by the New Jersey Housing Mortgage Finance Agency.
The aim is to encourage developers to build housing "that will be low-cost to people and low-cost to the environment," said Jane M. Kenny, commissioner of the Department of the Department of Community Affairs, which oversees housing issues. It is, she said, "a radical approach and the first step in what will raise the bar for and be a trend in affordable housing production."
While the idea of developing so-called "green" buildings, is not new, combining it with low- and moderate-cost housing, known as affordable housing, has been slow to take hold. A key reason, industry professionals say, is the cost to incorporate energy-efficient and environmentally sensitive features into housing that relies heavily on public financing. Another difficulty is that "developers are entrenched in doing business as usual and often need an incentive to try something different, which is what New Jersey's program provides," said Joseph W. Lstibureck, a principal of Building Science Corporation, an engineering and architectural firm in Westford, Mass. His company works with developers to change their construction techniques to reduce costs and warranty claims.
The pilot program will show developers that "while they may spend more on the shell of the house, they will save on its mechanical system, making their investment a wash," Mr. Lstibureck said. The new technologies will initially cost more, but as they become more widely used costs will drop, he added.
Commissioner Kenny said that affordable homes built with energy-saving features, such as added insulation or extra-efficient equipment, will cost less for residents to maintain. The homes built under the program are expected to reduce a residential utility bill by at least $378 a year for a typical three-bedroom home, she said.
To participate in the program, a developer's homes must meet or exceed standards established by Public Service Gas & Electric, the state's largest utility, which also reflect federal standards. The standards call for them to be at least 30 percent more energy efficient than a typical house constructed or renovated in the state. The utility, which is a partner in the program, will also pay the developer $1,500, plus 42 cents per square foot for each home that meets its standards. For example, for a 2,200-square-foot house a developer would get $2,424.
In addition, the state's Board of Public Utilities will provide additional financial incentives to developers who use solar heating techniques, such as solar panels and photovoltaic cells to convert sunlight into electricity, in their projects. Commissioner Kenny said there was a pool of $200,000 available to developers to design and implement such features.
The program encourages developers to try to limit a project's impact on the environment by, among other things, using building materials that contain recycled contents, are durable, have reduced toxicity and help improve indoor air quality. They are also encouraged to preserve trees and to develop the housing near shopping and mass transit links.
DEVELOPERS say they got involved in the program to stay abreast of new technologies and ahead of the competition. They add that they probably would not have incorporated the technologies into their projects without the state subsidies
Commissioner Kenny said the program "will enable us to identify which strategies work and can be replicated." To ensure that the production of such housing continues, she said, her department will begin as early as this spring to require developers to incorporate the successful strategies into their projects as part of the competition for state funding.
The $15 million two-building development under way in Newark is being developed by RPM Development Corporation of Montclair, using mostly public funds, including $900,000 it received under the new state program. That money is being used to incorporate into both buildings -- the renovated factory on North 13th Street, between Park and Sixth Avenues and the new structure on Park Avenue at North 11th Street, a couple of blocks away -- such features as energy-efficient fluorescent lighting and fiberglass, instead of vinyl, window frames, which are considered better for the environment. In addition, the buildings will have cellulose insulation, which is made from recycled newspapers and blown into walls, filling air cavities more tightly and conserving energy more efficiently.
Bricks salvaged from the factory that is to be demolished will also be recycled and used for walkways as well as to repoint the facade of the building being renovated. And at each building, storm water will be collected and used to irrigate lawns and plants.
"Meeting the energy efficiency standards will make for better buildings, and in the long term will probably save us from going back to fix things 10 to 15 years from now," said Edward Martoglio, a principal at RPM. Mr. Martoglio said the program also "encourages more thoughtful ways to fit projects into the neighborhood."
The 128 units will have one to three bedrooms, with 650 to 1,100 square feet. Rents will range from $480 for a one-bedroom unit to $630 for a three-bedroom.
In Trenton, $1 million from the pilot program will be combined with $3 million in other, mostly public subsidies to develop Clinton Park Townhouses, comprising 23 new and renovated one- and two-family for-sale houses, with a rental apartment in each of the two-family houses They will rise along Ewing and Southard Streets in the city's Ewing-Carroll historic district. Construction is to start this spring, with completion to follow a year later.
"The program forces you to use products and designs you would not normally use because affordable housing projects are built on such tight budgets you don't want to stray too far from what is known to work," said Christiana Foglio, a principal of Home Properties of New Brunswick, the developer.
The homes will have such features as energy efficient mechanical systems, additional insulation, and air handling systems that increase indoor air quality. The front and rear yards also will be landscaped with plantings that absorb storm water runoff and the homes will laid out to have a southern exposure to the sun, maximizing passive solar energy, Ms. Foglio said.
The one-family homes will have 1,011 square feet of space; the two-family homes will have an owner's unit, with 969 to 1,051 square feet plus a rental apartment with 562 to 637 square feet. The sale price is expected to be $85,000 and the apartments are to rent for $500 to $550 a month.
In Eastampton, Pennrose Properties of Philadelphia will use $1.3 million from the program to build a 100-unit low-rise rental development. It will be built on 25 acres of a 300-acre site just off the intersection of Woodlane and Monmouth Roads. The remaining 275 acres, which contain wetlands, will be left undeveloped.
THE project will have a road system that encourages walking and the units will be grouped in clusters of four instead of eight as originally planned, providing additional open space. They also will be arranged on the site to take advantage of sun and shade, and will be built with better insulated foundations and stack framing, which requires less lumber, said Charles M. Lewis, a vice president at Pennrose.
Most of the two- and three-bedroom rentals will be town-house-style apartments with 990 to 1,150 square feet; some will be condominium flats with 910 to 1090 square feet. Rents are expected to be $517 to $596 a month. Construction of the $13 million project is scheduled to begin in the spring and take a year to complete.
Pennrose is also involved with a project in Camden, where it will receive $800,000 to rehabilitate an apartment building and an adjacent three-building garden-style rental complex, both abandoned historic landmarks, into 51 apartments for low-income elderly residents.
"When you talk about affordable, it is not only what it costs to build but what it costs residents to maintain, which could make an affordable house unaffordable," Mr. Lewis said. "If nothing else, the state program forces you to think about these issues."

LENGTH: 1066 words

HEADLINE: Overcoming the Obstacles in One's Career

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
TWENTY years ago when Faye Woocher began her practice as a career counselor she was frequently mistaken for someone who worked in a high school. And she found that women were primarily looking for advice on how to get into the job market.
But now, with women making up 46 percent of the country's labor force and with 49 percent of them in managerial and professional positions, the picture is vastly different. Or is it? 
 Sherri Lamoreaux is not so sure. Ms. Lamoreaux. who is a client of Ms. Woocher's, spent 11 years as a trader on the investment side of the business for three different hedge funds.
"I left Wall Street two years ago, suffering from burnout and a situation at work that was not congenial," she said. "So I changed direction completely and opened a store, Sorelle, a high-end boutique in Armonk. I started it from scratch and funded it completely myself."
Although her store has done very well, Ms. Lamoreaux said, she wants to go back to Wall Street.
"Quite frankly, the store has been fun," she said, "but doing essentially the same thing every day is no challenge for me. I felt removed from the world."
And so Ms. Lamoreaux contacted Ms. Woocher. "I needed someone to help me realistically assess my skills and potential," she said. "I had a professor at college who told us in business we should be able to 'function in disaster, finish in style.' I wanted to have the ability to do that."
Ms. Woocher, Ms. Lamoreaux said, helped her identify the obstacles in her way. "They were distasteful so I never really dealt with them before," she said, "but Faye is a remarkable counselor who has the ability to look and listen before she analyzed my problems and suggested strategies to help me navigate successfully on Wall Street."
Two things Ms. Woocher tells her clients to do is choose the company and the job very carefully.
"Understanding the company culture is very important," Ms. Woocher said. She described the plight of a client who was recruited for a job as chief financial officer at a manufacturing company.
"She was offered a very high salary plus bonuses and charged with not only upgrading the computer operations but with reorganization of the company, which meant a lot of downsizing," Ms. Woocher said. "She successfully completed everything asked of her, yet after two years she was fired. Why? Because she made enemies along the way."
Ms. Woocher, who has her office in Tarrytown, advises her clients to find a mentor she can rely on within the company. "My job as a counselor is to listen and ask questions in order to give clients a clearer sense of self and strengths, then they make decisions on their own," she said.
And in an era of low unemployment and few good employees, increasing numbers of corporations are seeking Ms. Woocher's services. "Companies that make a big investment in training employees want to retain them," she said.
One such employee, a valued employee, had good ideas but lacked assertiveness, she said. Another was reluctant to take a risky and challenging assignment.
"Career counseling is the most benign retention tool a company can use," Ms. Woocher said. "It has become the helper of choice in the workplace."
Gloria Goldstein, who teaches career counseling at Manhattan College in the Bronx, agreed. She also has a private practice in Larchmont. She said: "Women, much the same as men, recognize that long-term employment with one company is not a fact of life today. I encourage my clients to identify their skills, put together a skills portfolio, which can be transferred from job to job."
Ms. Goldstein said she believed assertiveness was more difficult for women than for men. "Many women tend to be meek and grateful for the job," she said. "Even young women lack a sense of upward mobility." She recalled a 27-year-old client, an underwriter, who was in a male-dominated business.
"She had a mentor, a relative who saw her ability to excel in math and encouraged her, but she has been in the same job for five years and should be moving on. She is learning how to be assertive and how to network, something she never did before."
Ms. Goldstein said: "Most of us also do outplacement work. People are working longer today, and many want or need second careers to get by. And my clients are older than they once were, ranging from 40 to 55."
Certified career counselors charge anywhere from $75 to $125 an hour, said Ms. Goldstein, adding that in her practice she sees equal numbers of men and women. To receive certification as a career counselor, in addition to a master's degree in counseling and two and a half years of job experience, applicants must pass a four-hour exam given by the National Board for Certified Counselors, based in Greensboro, N.C., Ms. Goldstein said.
Certification by the National Board began in 1984. Since then, about 800 career counselors nationwide, have been certified.
But that number is unlikely to grow, Ms. Goldstein said. The board stopped giving the exam this year because not enough people were taking it, she said, adding that as the number of people who may call themselves career counselors has increased for the consumer, it has become a case of buyer beware.
To find a certified career counselor, she suggests that consumers log on to the National Certified Counselors Web site, www.nbcc.org.
There are about 800 certified counselors nationwide, she said.
Both Ms. Woocher and Ms. Goldstein are members of the Westchester Career Counselors Network, an organization founded by Ms. Woocher in 1986, which draws 150 participants who pool their experiences and attend educational programs.
"We have speakers who tackle topics that aid us in our work," Ms. Woocher said. "They discuss such subjects as using the Internet in job searches, strategies that work and legal questions. We leave with practical hands-on tools and advice for assisting women clients to understand and navigate the corporate landscape."
To maintain certification, counselors must take 100 hours of continuing education every five years, which the Westchester Career Counselors Network provides, Ms. Woocher said.
Progress continues, she said, adding that a recent survey by Catalyst showed that in 1998 the top eight most profitable Fortune 500 companies had two or more female directors. "General Motors, the No. 1 ranked company, has three," she said.

HEADLINE: FILM;
From Russia, With Dark Humor, Like the Old Days

BYLINE: By NANCY RAMSEY; Nancy Ramsey's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about Srdjan Dragojevic, director of "The Wounds."

 BODY:
AT last year's New York Film Festival, the director Aleksei Guerman, a bear of a man with a disarming wit and a typically Russian sense of irony, introduced his latest work, "Khroustaliov, My Car!" to the press. It was the first time in his 40-year career, he said, that he had completed a film that had not been immediately shelved by the authorities. His previous work, "My Friend Ivan Lapshin," spent four years in limbo before its release in 1985, when it became a celebrated film of the perestroika era. "After every film I made, I was fired from my job," he said.
"Khroustaliov, My Car!" which on Friday opens FilmFest, a series of recent films from Russia and the former Soviet republics at the Museum of Modern Art, is set in 1953, during the last days of Stalin's reign of terror. It was a time when it was not clear from one minute to the next who would fall out of favor, often with deadly consequences. 
 Shot in black and white and centering on an army brain surgeon who swills cognac and lusts after women with equal fervor, the film boldly addresses the paranoia, anti-Semitism and sheer lunacy of the times. Resembling an oversize Hieronymus Bosch painting, the film offers at least one scene that isn't for the faint of heart.
For Mr. Guerman, it's a film that he felt he had to make. He recently turned 60, and, he said at the press conference, "it was time to tally the score."
"The words are expressed by the grandmother in my film, 'I know so much; what a shame this is all going to vanish with me!' "
Mr. Guerman began "Khroustaliov" before the collapse of the Soviet Union. French financing of the film was subject to the fall of the ruble, and production sometimes shut down for up to a year. Yet he persevered. "So you realize," he said wryly, "how foolish I am."
Foolish, perhaps, but not atypical for a Russian director. Filmmaking in the Soviet Union was a serious matter. Shortly after the Revolution, Lenin reportedly declared, "Of all the arts, the most important to us is the cinema." What evolved over the next 70 years was an industry that not only glorified sailors, workers and young women falling blissfully in love with both tractors and heroes of the Revolution, but also, after Stalin's death, a parallel aesthetic, one based on irony, satire, humor, metaphor and surrealism. Working within the state-run film industry, writers and directors created a sort of "kitchen democracy," presenting the humor and pathos of everyday life in a way that would pass the censors.
"A whole generation developed this secret language," said Sergei Solovyev, the director and former head of the Russian filmmakers union, at the Moscow International Film Festival in 1997. "But along with the social system, the aesthetic system collapsed. Now you can go to Red Square and shout whatever you want."
Artfulness often took a back seat to freedom of expression as films began to criticize the Soviet system. Chernukha, or blackness, became the rage during perestroika. The death of the regime brought mobster shoot-'em-ups and deliriously self-indulgent meditations on the Russian soul. But gradually filmmakers are returning to the irony, humor and subtle pathos that had endeared Soviet films to their audiences. Many of the better films that will be shown at the Modern (and at another festival of more than a dozen Russian films that runs Dec. 10-12 at both the Directors Guild Theater and the Anthology Film Archives in Manhattan) are, if not documentaries, then at least documentary-style. It is not only a wise stylistic choice but also a sound economic one in an industry sorely lacking money.
One such film, Larissa Sadilova's fictional "Happy Birthday," was shot cinema verite style on a low budget ($70,000, according to the director) in a provincial maternity hospital. Praised by Russian critics, the film is warm, sometimes humorous, but not sentimental. "In Russian literature, medical institutions are often metaphors for the state," said Susan Larsen, who teaches Russian literature and film at the University of California at San Diego. "They are places that are supposed to be about nurture but often aren't. 'Happy Birthday' has the gritty quality of chernukha films, but it's not rubbing your nose in the despair."
As if picking up where Ms. Sadilova left off, Viktor Kossakovsky's "Wednesday" tracks down people born on his birth date, July 19, 1961, in Leningrad. The camera takes us over the rooftops of what is now St. Petersburg and down into its apartments. A pregnant woman phones hospitals searching for an empty bed; a new Russian describes his plans for converting a Soviet naval vessel into a luxury yacht.
In "Pavel and Lyalya," the first in a trilogy about love and devoted to Pushkin, Mr. Kossakovsky visits a former teacher and his wife, an emigre couple in Jerusalem, for a warm and respectful look at their life.
Taking a less tender approach to the lives of the elderly is "Bread Day" by Sergei Dvortsevoy; his style is to let life unfold before his camera. In a remote, snowy village, pensioners meet the train for the weekly delivery of bread. Recriminations ensue, with the characters revealing more than they had intended.
In "An Ordinary President," the President of Belarus, Aleksandr Lukaschenko, shows himself in a bad light once footage of him is spliced into this piercing satirical documentary by Yuri Khashchevatsky. The film opens with a parable: When God granted the Belarussians their land, no one could believe how beautiful it was. But God frowned and said, "So that life shouldn't seem a paradise to you, you will always have the worst bosses."
Although "President" was officially banned in Belarus, some 150,000 bootleg videos have reportedly been distributed. It has been shown abroad too, with dire consequences for the filmmaker; in late 1997, after "An Ordinary President" was shown on French television, two men broke into Mr. Khashchevatsky's studio, beat him and stole only his scripts.
POLITICS are also engaged in Aleksandr Rogozhkin's fictional "Checkpoint," featuring a platoon of Russian soldiers stationed on a border in the Caucuses. "It is one of the first Russian films to tackle the problems of an ethnically splintered society," Ms. Larsen said.
Set in Tajikistan, "The Flight of the Bee," directed by Jamshed Usmonov and Min Biong Hun, is driven by a lyrical simplicity. When his rich neighbor builds a latrine next to his house, a schoolteacher sets out to right a wrong. "Central Asian films take their cues from oral traditions," said Jytte Jensen, FilmFest's curator. "A simple story turns into something poetic and beautiful about how you have to live with each other."
Earlier this month, Nikita Mikhalkov, the Academy Award-winning director of "Burnt by the Sun" (1994) and the current head of the Russian filmmakers' union, was in New York on a trip sponsored by a consultancy, Eurasia Group. (Mr. Mikhalkov's ambitions are not confined to films; he's reportedly toying with the idea of running for the presidency.) He recently completed "Barber of Siberia," a romanticized epic set during the reign of Czar Aleksandr III. His reason for returning to the past? "As a Russian poet once said, 'You can see something big at a distance,' " he answered. " 'When you're close you can't see it.' Cinema is not a gazette. In Russia, we have dramatic, serious problems. It's as if we're trying to balance in asphalt that's still not dry."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2190 words

HEADLINE: A Record of Despair Born of a Single Image

BYLINE: By GREIL MARCUS; Greil Marcus's most recent book is "Invisible Republic: Bob Dylan's Basement Tapes." This article is adapted from an essay that appeared in the 1999 Telluride Film Festival newsletter.

 BODY:
WHEN I first heard that someone had made a movie out of Michael Lesy's shocking, genre-defying "Wisconsin Death Trip," I couldn't imagine the result, or think of a book less amenable to film. It seemed absolutely a thing in itself: its own construct, its own nightmare, its own scream.
The film's director, James Marsh, of Arena, an adventurous division of the British Broadcasting Corporation, found Lesy's legendary 1973 title in a New York used-book store. "I made the book," Mr. Lesy says. "The book found James." 
 The mystical language is appropriate; the book can cast a spell. It is a progressively horrifying portrait of one small town, Black River Falls, Wis., crumbling -- socially, morally, psychologically, physically -- under the impact of the great depression of the 1890's. The words "great depression" do not take capitals here, as with the Great Depression of the 1930's; unlike that calamity, the depression of a century ago did not enter American folklore.
This collapse of the American economy was denied even as it happened: the 1893 Columbian Exposition, in Chicago, which introduced the Ferris wheel to the United States, was the denial as theme park. The depression hit farm states the hardest. There, where the weather had been understood as the greatest threat to an orderly life, all other foundations of predictability -- the assumption that in domestic and working life one day would be much like the one before it -- were destroyed.
The films Mr. Marsh made before "Wisconsin Death Trip" are imaginative, playful and well-defined; they hardly seem preparation for anything so dark and potentially borderless and out of control as his latest, which opens at the Film Forum in Manhattan on Wednesday.
Mr. Marsh received his first directorial assignment in 1989, when he was 25. Arena, says Mr. Marsh -- an Englishman now living in New York -- was putting on "themed evenings, four or five hours a night on a single subject." One was "Food night," and for it Mr. Marsh conceived a 15-minute segment on the last meals of condemned prisoners. "I wanted to know what the ritual meant in a bureaucratic system of execution," he says, recalling that in the British tradition a prisoner's last meal might also have involved a last drunk, complete with prostitutes. Because capital punishment had been all but abolished in the United Kingdom since the 1960's, Mr. Marsh set off for a two-day shoot on Death Row in Louisiana. "I wanted to expose the process in one detail," he says. He ended up focusing on a single prisoner, a man "outraged by the crazy idea of hospitality at the end of his life."
There is probably a more direct line from this first project to Mr. Marsh's "Wisconsin Death Trip" than to another food piece by him, "The Burger and the King." In this graceful account of "The Life and Cuisine of Elvis Presley," the fine David Adler book on which the film is based, cooks from throughout Presley's life -- from his high school cafeteria, the Army, Graceland -- present their dishes proudly and so lovingly that by the end one may want nothing more than to copy down the recipe for fried banana and peanut-butter sandwiches and make one.
"I became increasingly aware of the power of a single image, especially in photography: Diane Arbus, W. Eugene Smith," Mr. Marsh says when asked about the inspirations behind his films. That inspiration is most visible in Arena's revelatory 1993 series, "Story of a Song," Mr. Marsh's expansive accounts of Presley's "Heartbreak Hotel," Lou Reed's "Walk on the Wild Side," Buddy Holly's "Peggy Sue" and, especially, Bob Dylan's "Highway 61 Revisited." There Mr. Marsh offered not so much a story of a song as its biography -- as if it were a person, with ancestors and descendants. Watching the film, you can follow U.S. Highway 61 from Minnesota to the Gulf of Mexico as the Dylan song carries with it not only Highway 61 blues numbers but also the death of Bessie Smith, on Highway 61; Presley's childhood years in public housing, on Highway 61, and the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Highway 61.
The single image that seals the film, though, is a a dramatization of a young Bob Dylan leaving Minnesota for New York City in 1961. Running through the shot is an early, hesitant version of his epochal "Like a Rolling Stone." Then the soundtrack moves into the triumphant performance of "Like a Rolling Stone" from the 1965 LP that made Mr. Dylan a world figure: "Highway 61 Revisited," the album named for the song, which speaks for the United States itself. Highway 61 traces the spine of the nation, but by this point in the film you're ready to acknowledge every American road as Highway 61.
You've also seen blues singers who have never heard of Bob Dylan singing their Highway 61 songs. You've heard homemade 1950's tapes of Mr. Dylan as a teenage Bobby Zimmerman singing his own composition "Little Richard" and then scorning Presley, Johnny Cash and Ricky Nelson for their thefts and failings. But all of that is now subsumed into the looming night lights of Manhattan. "In a film you can create a whole complex of emotions, a situation, in a single image," Mr. Marsh says. "For 'Wisconsin Death Trip' I was already informed as to the power of the single image: looking at the book and the ghosts staring back at me."
Michael Lesy's book, a new edition of which will be published in February by the University of New Mexico Press, was born 30 years ago when Mr. Lesy, then a graduate student at the University of Wisconsin, found an archive of 3,000 images left by one Charles Van Schaick, the town photographer of Black River Falls. In Van Schaick's time, ordinary people did not have cameras, difficult contraptions that involved black powder and heavy glass plates; to record the passages of a life -- births, marriages, store openings, funerals -- they turned to a professional. Mr. Lesy noticed Van Schaick's many pictures of dead infants and children, dressed in their christening gowns, now placed in tiny coffins. As he looked for the story behind these photos, he found a tale of plagues: of murder, suicide, farm and business failures, madness, addiction, tramp armies, and the ruin of childhood and the desolation of families by epidemics of diptheria, typhoid, smallpox and flu.
Mr. Lesy made a montage, using items from the local paper, contemporaneous regional fiction and poetry, asylum records and the photographs left by Van Schaick, who in Mr. Lesy's pages emerges as Arbus's unknown ancestor. In words, the story was almost too much to take in, the accumulation of awful facts nearly mute in their cacophony. But the pictures spoke. From Van Schaick's archive Mr. Lesy made a tableau of disassociation, terror and insanity passing for everyday life. It was all in the blank eyes, the frozen mouths in family portraits: those were the ghosts James Marsh saw.
Mr. Marsh's "Wisconsin Death Trip" is less a film of Mr. Lesy's book than a quiet reinhabiting of the world it found, or made. "In a way the book is unfilmable," says Mr. Marsh. So he left the book. For the movie, he alternates long black-and-white segments set a century ago -- through prairie-flat re-enactments, you see an 1890's avatar of Susan Smith sitting by the lake where she has drowned her children, a farmer randomly killed by a young boy, farmers who have killed themselves, two women murdered by a tramp they have fed and then the tramp's own suicide, a madwoman traveling the county in search of windows to break, and, in parlor scenes, just how dead children were positioned to have their pictures taken -- with brief, prosaic interludes of present-day Black River Falls shot in color. "What today speaks for the town," says Mr. Marsh, "what binds it, what is undermining it."
"What I did get from the book," Mr. Marsh says, "was the rhythm: the emerging incremental idea. But in terms of the stories themselves, the starting point was definitely photographic. Start with an image, a single image, and then move -- a lot of long tracking shots, to keep a sense of the still image moving. But I knew I couldn't film it. Do I try to contextualize the story, or do I let the stories yield their own mysteries -- or do I have someone sitting in a chair, explaining? That was the first choice I made, not to try and explain the social-political-cultural history of anything. The stories are based on a respect for these individual tragedies and disasters. If the film lacks one thing, it's a governing idea on that level -- but it would have been a travesty."
What one takes away from Mr. Lesy's book are faces. In the film, it's a series of incidents that hangs in the memory like half-remembered dreams: true, undeniable, but unbidden and incomplete. The actors seem both physically present and psychologically anonymous. Often you don't register their faces at all; they could be anyone. "A lot of the casting had to do with financial constraints," Mr. Marsh says. He worked first with a limited "documentary budget" from Arena, then with money he made from projects he took on mainly to pay for "Death Trip." Finally, after rejections from European companies on the ground that the project was, in Mr. Marsh's words, "morbid, distasteful and obsessed with the wrong aspects of human life" and after no response at all from the PBS series "The American Experience," he was rescued by a co-sponsorship from HBO's Cinemax division, which paid for a 35-millimeter print.
"We had open casting calls in Madison and Milwaukee: old thesps from the local theater, lots of people with interesting faces who hadn't acted," Mr. Marsh says. "A lot of the acting was improvised or: 'Do nothing.' 'Stand.' " The re-enactments were shot at 30 frames a second, he says, to get "a barely perceptible slow-motion effect: that disconcerting stillness in the scenes." The actors, he adds, "can't hit marks; they don't know the grammar.
"But most of it wasn't acting; it's like striking poses."
This is the source of the bluntness of the violence that is shown, which in Mr. Marsh's film is far more stark, and seemingly unmediated, than the stylized violence that movies conventionally offer. The ordinariness of the postures and gestures of the actors puts the viewer in their shoes.
You can feel the rope pulling at your throat as a farmer dangles from a tree, go suddenly cold as another lies down in the snow across the railroad tracks, flinch and want to run as a man chases, shoots and kills the woman who will not marry him. You can even feel the deadened peace of the mother at the lake.
The instruction to do nothing, to just stand, also creates the single image, and the single face, that most people will very likely take away from "Wisconsin Death Trip": that of Jo Vukelich as Mary Sweeney, the window smasher. As the film follows her from town to town, as she picks her targets -- with care, apparently, as if in an effort to make meaning, to send a message, to lodge some sort of protest -- you see glass shattering, then a strongly built woman staring straight at those of her fellows who are merely watching her, or those who have come to take her away. Her fearsomely unreadable countenance seems to be insisting that by her actions she has said all that need be said, that through her destructions she is writing the book of her place and time. Only at the end of the movie is any explanation offered, but it's hardly needed. "I am mad but not without my reasons," she seems to say with the turn of her body and the dull gleam in her eyes. "And if you had my courage you would know my reasons are yours."
One "veers and turns," Howie Movshovitz wrote in The Los Angeles Times after seeing the premiere of "Wisconsin Death Trip" at the Telluride Film Festival in September, "trying to avoid the possibility that the history of Black River Falls is not unlike the present all over the country." All that allows you to avoid that conclusion, though, is the sense of insulation, of a world in suspension, that one gets from watching a movie. The day the film was shown at Telluride, in Colorado, the headline in The Denver Post was generic for the reader, singular only for the people in it: "Gunman kills wife, two others at grocery store -- Grand Junction woman had just served divorce papers on husband."
As a historian, Mr. Lesy is a dramatist. Perhaps for that reason, the events he recorded and the people who made them seem very far away. The people in Mr. Marsh's picture are all without affect, and they seem to claim the present as much as the past.
The film realizes the ambitions of its small team (along with Mr. Marsh, the producer, Maureen Ryan; the director of photography, Eigil Bryld, and the editor, Jinx Godfrey): the wish, in Mr. Marsh's words, "to create rhythm, in the shooting and the editing, relentlessly putting together little fragments of stories, building to them and building away from them." What they got, though, was the illusion of a tale complete and whole, a distant story from a century ago that with the force of prophecy seems to rush forward, to our time and past it.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Artistry and Social Compassion in Counterpoint

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
ANOTHER opening, another show: surely there are more humane ways than this to think about earthquakes. But unless you have the misfortune to be struck by one, a seismologic event usually arrives packaged as prime-time entertainment, with unctuous news anchors or made-for-TV actors reciting their lines over numbing boom-de-boom soundtracks.
Shigeru Ban, an architect who lives in Tokyo, has not allowed himself the safe distance enjoyed by our remote controllers. In the last five years, he has responded to the news of earthquakes and other disasters as if to a call of conscience. After the Kobe quake in 1994, Mr. Ban designed units of cardboard and plastic housing for the thousands who had been driven from their homes. The following year, he established the Volunteer Architects Network, a nongovernmental agency of the United Nations. This year, under the aegis of that agency, he has coordinated the production and shipment of cardboard housing units for refugees in Turkey. 
 It happens that Mr. Ban is also a brilliant designer of private houses, apartment houses, public buildings and museum exhibitions. In these, he has displayed a striking talent for innovative form, structure and spatial organization. This diverse body of work plays havoc with our Western inclination to plug architects into mutually exclusive categories: the artistically gifted or the socially committed. In Mr. Ban's case, they stem from the same outlook. He himself distinguishes between the refugee housing and his other work, but the difference is one of application, not of the principles behind it. In this work, we are invited to see the social dimension within the aesthetic, the artist inside the humanitarian.
Chief among the principles guiding Mr. Ban's architecture is economy of means. In his houses, this has resulted in the reduction of the dwelling to simple lines and planes and the volumes of space contained within them. The effect is a minimalist aesthetic. It can be appreciated as a look, a style, a fashion. For Mr. Ban, however, architecture is only incidentally concerned with effects. It is mostly a matter of causes.
Mr. Ban, who is 42, is a true cosmopolite. Born in Tokyo in 1957, he studied architecture at the California Institute of the Arts and then Cooper Union in New York, from which he graduated in 1984. In those years, the attention of many Cooper Union students was focused on a group of architects known as the New York Five: Peter Eisenman, Richard Meier, Charles Gwathmey, John Hejduk and Michael Graves. The five were also called the Whites, because their forms were typically rendered as colorless geometric abstractions.
Returning to Japan, Mr. Ban began his professional practice with a series of Case Study houses that gave so-called White architecture a Japanese twist. These spare exercises are dominated by the Cartesian grid, a form that had assumed nearly sacred status among the Five as a link with Mies van der Rohe and Le Corbusier. In Mr. Ban's projects, the grid form also became a bond with Japanese tradition: the architecture of the shoji screen, the tatami mat and the flexible division of space.
In the West, Mr. Ban is best known for the Curtain Wall House, a 1995 project with billowing drapery that was featured earlier this year in the "(Un)private House" show at the Museum of Modern Art. But his most radical example of East-West fusion is the Wall-less House, a project completed two years ago in the rural town of Karuizawa. The design is a play on the Wall House, an unbuilt project by John Hejduk, in which pockets of dwelling space are suspended from an upright concrete slab. In Mr. Ban's house, which occupies a hillside site, the slab is rotated into a horizontal position to create a floor. The slab curves upward at one end, where it meets the sloping ground. A thinner slab is cantilevered from the upturned edge to form the roof, which is additionally supported by two slender columns at the far end.
Apart from the hillside, which serves as an earth berm, there are no exterior walls, no fixed partitions between floor and roof. Screens can be moved into place to conceal or reveal bathroom, bedroom and kitchen. The largest permanent fixture is a kitchen counter cantilevered from the upturn in the floor slab. The curve of the counter's underside echoes that of the upturn and of the ground to which the house is moored.
In this almost unrelieved horizontal composition, the eye is magnetically drawn most powerfully to the bathroom sink, crowned with a round mirror, that sits on the outward perimeter of the floor slab. A pair of fixtures typically clamped against a wall, the arrangement underscores the absence of perpendicular planes. It also reads as a comic play on the view that practical considerations like plumbing are what distinguish architecture from sculpture. Here, we get the bathroom sink without the bathroom.
Mr. Ban's work with cardboard -- or what he calls paper -- architecture began with installations he designed in the mid-1980's for shows on the work of Emilio Ambasz and Alvar Aalto. Later, he began to work with paper structurally, using cardboard tubes. Employing steel cables to compress the tubes, Mr. Ban continued the experiments in tensile structure developed by Buckminster Fuller, Frei Otto and Robert Le Ricolais. (New Yorkers will get to see an example of this technique next summer, when the Museum of Modern Art will enclose part of its sculpture garden beneath Mr. Ban's open, lattice-like roof.)
Mr. Ban's first venture into refugee housing came in response to the 1994 civil strife in Rwanda. Deforestation had depleted the timber needed for building shelters. Working with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Mr. Ban designed simple tents of blue plastic sheets, using cardboard tubes to support them. Fifty units were eventually shipped abroad.
THE shelters Mr. Ban designed for refugees of the Kobe earthquake were more ambitious. These were miniature one-room houses made of cardboard, with operable door and windows. Plastic beer can crates, filled with sacks of sand, provided foundations for the simple, pitched-roof pavilions. Mr. Ban also designed a community church made from cardboard tube columns, arranged in an elliptical shape. The Kobe housing became the model for the shelters that BMr. an's United Nations group has deployed in Turkey this year.
The connection between Mr. Ban's humanitarian work and his Case Study houses is more easily seen if one compares the relief housing to minimalist art. Mr. Ban's use of humble materials, his elemental Monopoly-house shape and his repetition of the basic module echo themes developed in the work of Donald Judd, Carl Andre and Dan Flavin. The cracked earth, meanwhile assumes the cosmic dimension of landscape in 15th century Japanese ink painting.
Cosmopolitanism today signifies much more than urban sophistication. It also denotes awareness that the globe is rapidly urbanizing in some highly unsophisticated ways. This is true even in relatively modern countries like Turkey. Those jerry-built, orange masonry housing blocks, many occupied by squatters, are familiar to anyone who has taken a taxi from Istanbul's airport into town. Cosmopolitanism also means knowing that land is part of the earth, that the earth is finite and has plans of its own, that the undeveloped land that developers like to call greentop is linked to something larger, and therefore so is architecture. As such, there is a sacred aspect to the relationship between even secular buildings and the space they occupy.
Mr. Ban's description of his relief work as paper architecture is ironic. In the West, the term refers to unbuilt projects designed by architects like Mr. Hejduk, who hold themselves in such artistic high regard that they seldom deign to build. Kenneth Frampton, the architectural historian, once observed that, in the 1970's, architecture became divided between those who sought to practice architecture as a form of fine art and those who approached it as direct social action. Hailing from a country where paper has long been a common building material, Mr. Ban has embraced the cause of healing the quake in his profession.

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

Festival in Bethlehem
The Town of Bethlehem in Connecticut is braced for the thousands of visitors who will attend its 19th holiday festival from Thursday evening through Saturday. Mostly, they come to the quiet Litchfield County community to go to the post office.
Many years ago the Bethlehem postmaster initiated the practice of decorating customers' Christmas cards with a special Christmas cachet. Out-of-towners began arriving in droves with their stacks of cards, not only for the cachet but also to mail them bearing the Bethlehem postmark. 
 Soon, even with extended hours, the post office could only accommodate so many people at a time, leaving lots of visitors and local people milling about. Naturally, a full blown festival evolved.
There will be music and readings on Thursday evening at 7:30 in Memorial Hall, followed by Friday's activities beginning at 5 p.m. with the arrival of Santa Claus and the lighting of a 90-foot tree.
Until 10 p.m. on Friday and all day Saturday, from 10 to 5, there will be music by choirs, bell ringers, bands and madrigal singers; hay rides, exhibits at the Bellamy-Ferriday House and Garden and the Old Bethlem Historical Society Museum; visits to the 18th-century Neapolitan creche at the Abbey of Regina Laudis, readings by authors of children's books, and a vast array of crafts, gifts and holiday foods to browse and buy.
The town is at the junction of Routes 61 and 132 in Litchfield County. For more information, call (203) 266-5557.
 
Remembering Gary Cooper
Today, from 10 to noon, the Abbey of Regina Laudis will mark the first weekend of its annual Christmas Fair with a book signing by Maria Cooper Janis, the only child of Gary Cooper and his wife, Rocky. Ms. Janis has written a book about her famous Dad, called "Gary Cooper Off Camera: A Daughter Remembers."
An intimate portrait of the actor, his family life and his legendary career have been revealed by Ms. Janis through material from her own journals and from her father's writings. The book also contains a treasury of photographs of Cooper and Picasso, Cooper and Hemingway, Cooper and Sinatra -- and many others that have never been published.
For more information or directions to the abbey, call (203) 266-7637.
 
Connecticut Forum
The nonprofit Connecticut Forum has put together one of its customary power panels for a discussion on "Global Issues, Global Views," to be presented on Saturday at 8 p.m. at the Bushnell in Hartford.
Its mission to raise the public level of communication about world events, conflicts and issues is evident in the mere mention of the names serving on this panel.
They are Senator George Mitchell, special adviser to the President and Secretary of State for economic initiatives in Ireland; Benazir Bhutto, former Pakistani Prime Minister, author of "Foreign Policy in Perspective" and "Daughter of Destiny"; Jeane Kirkpatrick, former United States Ambassador to the United Nations, and Medal of Freedom honoree; and as moderator, Ray Suarez, senior correspondent for the Jim Lehrer News Hour on Public Television, and host of "Talk of the Nation" on National Public Radio.
Tickets at $25, $35, and $45 may be reserved by calling (860) 509-0909.
 
Vintage Radios
What to do with that old Atwater Kent tabletop radio stashed in the attic? Head for the Antique Radio Swap Meet on Saturday from 8 to 1 at St. John's Parish Hall, Main Street and Burnside Avenue in East Hartford.
Once a year, the Vintage Radio and Communications Museum of Connecticut holds this event, allowing radio buffs to buy, sell and check out the flea market for an admission price of $1. Vendors can rent a table for $12.
The museum, a nonprofit company founded in 1990, is dedicated to the preservation of vintage communications equipment, and to educating the public about its value as history and as collectibles.
At its 711 Main St. site in East Hartford the museum displays radios, televisions, motion picture and telephone equipment, old advertising and memorabilia. Audio, video and paper libraries are available for research on Thursdays and even-dated Fridays from 10 to 2, Saturdays from 11 to 4, and Sundays from 1 to 4. Call (860) 675-9916 or (860) 683-0496 for more information.
 
Author Lectures
Authors who have interesting day jobs of one sort or another will share their expertise in a series of lectures at the Garden Education Center in Greenwich this week.
Tomorrow, from 11 to 2, Sally Maraventano, culinary tour leader to regions of Italy, will be the first speaker. Her subject will be "Festa del Giardino: A Feast of Italian Recipes and the Memories Surrounding Them," drawn from her experiences in writing her new vegetable cookbook. A fee of $50 includes lunch.
Donald Kaufman, a founding partner of Donald Kaufman Color, a consulting firm, will talk about his new book, "Color and Light, Luminous Atmospheres for Painted Rooms," on Wednesday at 10 a.m. His observations include the fact that light passing thorugh the air affects how we see color. Example: a terra cotta-painted wall in Santa Fe looks very different from a terra cotta-painted wall in Manhattan. Tickets are $25.
"The Writer in the Garden" by Jane Garney explores the craziness that otherwise sane, successful people like Edith Wharton or Charles Kuralt experience when they obsess over their gardens, plants and flowers. Ms. Garney has collected vignettes from more than 50 people, forming an usual how-to and how-not-to for gardeners everywhere. The fee for the Friday lecture at 10 a.m. is $25.
Call the center on Bible Street, at (203) 869-9242 to register or obtain more information. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
National Geographic Puts Atlas Online

 BODY:
With its newly published seventh edition of the Atlas of the World, the National Geographic Society not only puts the whole world in your hands but also allows you to keep up with it.
A new interactive atlas, available on the Web at www.nationalgeographic.com /mapmachine, will record the latest geographical and political changes so that users can download maps and paste them into their atlases. This feature will be available by the end of the month, according to Allen Carroll, the society's chief cartographer. As of mid-November, there were two changes: the Black Canyon of the Gunnison in Colorado, formerly a national monument, was expanded and became a national park, and the height of Mount Everest was increased from 29,028 to 29,035 feet. 
 The seventh edition, published this month, is a complete reworking of the sixth edition, which was first published in 1990 and subsequently revised. It takes account of such major changes as the renaming of Zaire (now the Democratic Republic of Congo), the creation of the Nunavut Territory in Canada and the redrawing of provincial boundaries in South Africa.
As in the past, the atlas, which sells for $125, roams beyond the strictly cartographic, with articles on such subjects as climate, economy, tectonics, cultures and energy. All told, there are 280 pages of maps and text plus a 134-page index with 140,000 entries.
Those who prefer more rather than less will be cheered to know that the Web site has two million entries. Some are variations on place names (separate entries for Florence and Firenze, for example); others are place names that that simply could not be included even in a large-format atlas.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Juneau Votes to Charge Cruise Passenger Fees

 BODY:
Voters in Juneau, Alaska, last month approved by a 5-to-2 ratio an initiative to charge each cruise ship passenger $5 for visiting their city. The result came three months after a guilty plea by the Royal Caribbean International cruise line to charges of dumping pollutants into Alaskan waters. A similar measure failed three years ago, Mayor Dennis W. Egan said.
Mayor Egan said that despite apologies to three southeastern Alaska cities by the president of Royal Caribbean, the residents remained outraged. The line, which agreed in court to pay $18 million in fines, pleaded guilty to polluting coastal waters around the United States; this included dumping dry-cleaning chemicals and other toxic wastes into a channel within the Juneau city limits and dumping oily bilge water into a canal between Skagway and Haines. 
 The convention and visitors bureau in Juneau, the state capital, estimates that nearly 600,000 cruise passengers visited the city in the 1999 season -- May through September -- and that they accounted for most of the $90 million in economic activity generated by tourism.
Although many Caribbean islands levy port charges on ships based on passenger totals, cruise lines operating in Alaska may challenge the user fee on the basis that it is too narrow: visitors arriving by plane or car are not similarly surcharged. John Hansen, president of the North West CruiseShip Association, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, said that the group would examine its constitutionality. "There may be some legal issues with a narrow, targeted fee," Mr. Hansen said. "On another level, what is the money going to be used for: dock development, tourism improvements or just for the city's operating budget?"
Mayor Egan said that a regulation, to be effective March 1, was being written on the basis of the referendum. He said that the income would be spent on infrastructure improvements related to the cruise industry, possibly including landscaping.

HEADLINE: The Assault On Good News

 BODY:
Andrew Sullivan cites falling poverty and joblessness rates as evidence that the poor in America never had it so good (Counter Culture, Nov. 7). But these indicators mask ugly realities. For the past decade, we have kept the household income threshold that officially denotes poverty at an absurdly low level; in addition, the proliferation of low-wage jobs has shattered the traditional link between finding full-time work and escaping poverty. Government and private economists agree that the bottom 40 percent of United States households are worse off now than they were 20 years ago. This is not an invention of the political left, and it should be discussed and debated in the coming presidential election campaign -- Sullivan's swipes at Bill Bradley notwithstanding.
 
The Rev. Peter Laarman
Senior Minister
Judson Memorial Church
New York

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 11-28-99;
Safety in Numbers

BYLINE: By Robert H. Frank; Robert H. Frank is a professor of economics at Cornell University and the author of "Luxury Fever."

 BODY:
It seems almost funny to remember that as recently as the 1980's, hardly anyone outside the financial industry had any real interest in forecasting stock prices. An exception was one of my colleagues, a professor who actively managed his own portfolio long before the advent of Internet trading. His crowning achievement was predicting the October 1987 crash with far greater accuracy than almost all the experts. In the weeks following the crash, many stepped forward claiming to have seen it coming, but almost alone among them, my colleague had taken a major chunk of his money out of the market just weeks before it happened. In the risk-averse world of tenured academics, this gutsy move earned him instant superstar status.
These days, of course, you seldom meet anyone who is not an expert stock picker. A natural outgrowth of this phenomenon has recently begun to take form: our nation of stock pickers is rapidly turning into a nation of economic forecasters. 
 The mainstream media's coverage of hard economic data used to be perfunctory: a spot of news about the direction of interest rates, or a calculation of how the dollar was holding up against the yen. Now these reports have grown bewilderingly detailed and complex. One recent morning, a cable-network news reader reported with a straight face that although the monthly trade deficit had shown a sharp decline in the quarter just ended, the movement should not be interpreted as a positive indicator because export figures contained a large commercial aircraft shipment that markets had known about for months. Another correspondent advised viewers that the rise in the wholesale price index should be discounted heavily, because much of it was attributable to movements in traditionally volatile energy components.
Every day, some government agency reports at least one major figure, and the financial-news channels cover it with the pageantry and suspense of the Academy Award nominations. A couple of weeks ago, the day-by-day fix went like this: Monday was Business Inventories, Tuesday was a double dose of Industrial Production and Capacity Utilization, Wednesday we got the Consumer Price Index, Housing Starts and Building Permits and Thursday was International Trade. Friday, we were permitted to rest.
I'm a university economist and the author of several books about how the economy works, and even I had to ask, who cares? Aside from people whose work is directly dependent on these figures, who would be interested in them? And what in the world can individual investors possibly learn from this endless torrent of information? If, say, we find out that sales of existing homes in the Southwest were expected to rise 0.3 percent in September but actually rose only 0.25 percent, should we shift our portfolios to firms in the Pacific Northwest? Or divest them of stock in roofing-nail suppliers?
Whatever we decide to do, it's a sure bet that the market has already beaten us to it. Economists disagree about many things, but one belief we share is that investors can almost never make financial headway by trading on the basis of numbers they hear about through the media.
That, however, has not stopped the number of financial-news outlets from proliferating still further in recent months. Countless new Web sites and cable channels and newsletters and e-mail services urge their services upon us. Indeed, the reporting of financial trivia now threatens to drown out all other news.
This information does serve an important function, just not the one it claims to serve. What it is, in fact, is a palliative to ease our anxiety about the eventual downturn. Old-school Wall Street cognoscenti have generally stuck to the view that the current boom will come to a spectacular end. As in 1929, we may wake up one morning to find all those paper billions up in smoke. But as the market has continued its ascent, swelling our faith in ourselves as master investors, fatalism has been tempered by the idea that a crash need not take down everyone. In a world in which investors make millions from trading stock in companies that may never earn a dime, official economic data provide a reassuring kind of white noise. They won't help the citizen-investor predict whether Amazon.com stock is a good buy, but they're pure and direct and unimpeachable: this is your government talking, this is the state of your country. More than that, the numbers make this tantalizing promise: If we just keep watching them, maybe we'll spot the downturn in time to bail out.
But if and when the crash does come, the number crunchers who manage to get out in time will confront a second challenge. They must decide when to get back in. And here the experience of my colleague who sold out just before the 1987 crash sounds a cautionary note. "I thought prices would continue to decline for at least the next year," he once told me with chagrin, "so I wasn't eager to get back in the market right away." But as often happens, prices began to recover almost immediately after the October downturn, and by the time my colleague finally got back into the market in mid-1988, prices were higher than when he'd sold. He has no illusions that he would have done any better if only those critical Capacity Utilization reports had been blasted over the airwaves back then.

Chart: "Reading Greenspan: An Indicator"
 
Mark Haines, anchor of CNBC's morning finance program "Squawk Box," on the rise and fall of the show's Briefcase Indicator:
 
"The premise is that the thickness of Alan Greenspan's briefcase -- when he's leaving his office to meet with the Federal Reserve Board of Governors -- is an indicator of whether they plan to change interest rates. A full briefcase indicates that they are.
 
"It was right 17 out of the first 20 times, but has a built-in destruct mechanism, because Greenspan packs his briefcase. He can make it wrong or right. He has never publicly acknowledged the Indicator, but we have reason to believe that he knows about it. We have to consider the fact that he wants us to stop doing it because the last two times the briefcase has been wrong, and that's disturbing."

HEADLINE: Not Enough Substitute Teachers To Go Around

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: CROTON-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
WHEN Janet Lindner shows up for work on any given morning at Croton High School, she always carries a briefcase with the basic tools of her trade: scissors, Post-Its, Scotch tape, a stapler, pens and paper. After that, it is her more than 25 years' experience as a full-time substitute teacher that helps her maintain her equilibrium, whether she is asked to lead a chemistry experiment, supervise a French test or teach physics.
Such versatility might unnerve many regular teachers, accustomed to the routines of their permanent classroom domain. Not Mrs. Lindner, who chose to be a substitute teacher to have time to manage family responsibilities. 
 "This is my career," Mrs. Lindner said. "When kids say, 'You're a sub,' I say, 'I'm your teacher.' You have to let the kids know you're a teacher. It's not baby-sitting. It's an honor for teachers to ask for me to come in, and it's a pleasure for me to go."
Mrs. Lindner is a well-trained, experienced substitute teacher, whose competency and cooperative attitude could make school administrators the envy of their peers -- not only in the county but also in the rest the state, Connecticut, New Jersey and across the country.
There is one small problem. There are not enough Mrs. Lindners to go around, even in Croton-on-Hudson.
"We continually try to add to our substitute list," said Dr. Marjorie Castro, superintendent of the Croton-Harmon school district, which recently increased its daily pay for substitute teachers to $75 from $65. "We try to cultivate people wherever we can."
For many districts that are struggling to find qualified full-time staff, finding equally competent substitutes is just as challenging.
"There's not enough supply," said Dr. Stacy Holmes, district superintendent for the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services. "Our people are sharing frustrations at getting enough people. Time has to be productively spent. It can't be just baby-sitting."
With school administrators, teachers and parents concerned about meeting the state's more rigorous instructional standards and making sure students are prepared for new state tests, few districts can afford to miss productive time in the classroom. That means recruiting, training and retaining the best possible substitute teachers.
"The exams are high stake, which adds a layer of tension, and makes it more complex," said Dr. Judith Fox, superintendent of the Byram Hills Central school district in Armonk. "I'm discouraged. It's a seller's market."
What makes the situation more difficult, educators say, is in some measure a result of the new requirements.
"It's a critical situation," said Dr. Constance Iervolino, assistant superintendent for curriculum in the White Plains public schools. "I've never seen it as bad as this year. I think it's because a lot of teachers who intended to be substitutes got jobs right away.
"There's a need for staff development, which has not been at the same level of urgency in the past. With the new assessments, there's a tremendous need for staff development, but the state doesn't build that into the calendar. There's the tension of releasing teachers from the class and having the class covered in a meaningful way. It's a major headache."
For instance, Dr. Iervolino said, "The state has dictated that some of the tests, like the English language arts, be done in a regional scoring situation. That means that in White Plains, I'll have 33 teachers absent over 3 days, days that the kids will be in school. It's catastrophic. There's real pressure to not reduce teacher contact time and to get the best substitutes. The state really needs to extend the school year for teachers to allow for training before and after the school year."
As Dr. Holmes said, "With the need to take teachers out of the classroom, we're catching it from both directions. It's a scramble."
Under state regulations, there is no "substitute teacher" certification -- substitutes are either certified as teachers or there is no certification. A district unable to find a certified teacher to substitute in a classroom may hire people with a college degree as a substitute for up to 40 days a year. Similar rules exist in Connecticut. In New Jersey, someone who has at least 60 hours of instruction from an accredited college may substitute for up to 20 consecutive days a year. In both Connecticut and New Jersey, criminal background checks are expected for anyone hired by a school district.
"Getting substitute teachers who are qualified and trained is a major problem," said Donald McKenzie, district superintendent for the Putnam/Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, whose organization not only developed a computerized system to help link substitutes with daily vacancies but also ran a recent Saturday training session to recruit substitutes.
"Districts can't afford to lose a minute of instructional time," McKenzie said. "There are not enough people who hold teaching certificates who want to be substitutes. The challenges of being a substitute, with the challenges of increasing curriculum demands, makes it difficult. We're keenly aware of the shortages, and we've tried to build the pool on a number of different levels."
Dr. Salvatore Corda, superintendent of the Peekskill schools, said "The pool of substitutes is not as deep as it was five years ago" because "people are in full-time jobs."
Charles C. Mackey, director of the Office of Teaching Initiatives for the State Department of Education, said: "It is a chronic issue endemic to the entire state. It exists in urban, rural and suburban areas."
There are many factors that have contributed to the substitute shortage, among them a strong economy that offers potential teachers, retirees or stay-at-home moms other employment options.
"There are a number of market forces coming into play for the shortages," said Thomas Murphy, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Education. "The largest labor market group for substitutes has traditionally been aspiring teachers. In Connecticut, we scooped up a bigger portion of those for full-time teaching. There have also been a lot of retirements, and many of the stay-at-home moms who used to be substitutes are working in the corporate economy."
Some districts have tried innovation to ease the situation. In Connecticut, for example, the Norwich district had a town meeting to invite parents and community members to apply for substitute teacher positions. In West Haven, the district offers an extension of enhanced health benefits to retired teachers to lure them back to the classroom.
Some districts are also working with undergraduate and graduate schools of education to find substitutes, and they contacted former teachers, retirees and parents. In some schools, the teacher aides, librarians and even administrators are tapped for substitute work -- as are teachers themselves. At Westlake High School in Thornwood, the principal, Louis Cuglietto, recently took over a chemistry course for nearly two weeks when the school was between teachers in that subject.
Some districts have turned to parents to act as noncertified substitutes, with varying results.
In some places, like Croton, it has been a boon for the district.
"We always say we look for the very best person we can find," said Dr. Castro, the Croton superintendent. "We know them, they know the schools, they're committed to the schools, and that's a plus. They have to be very professional, and we have an evaluation for the classroom teacher to fill out on how they did."
For one Croton parent, Elise Yates, who has been substituting in the elementary school since September, there is never any question about her role. "When I'm in the classroom, my son knows I'd be 'Mrs. Yates,' not 'Mommy,' " she said. Mrs. Yates, who had previously been in advertising, has a son in the eighth grade and another in the first grade. "I look at teaching in the same professional way as I would any other job."
Peter M. Lisi, superintendent of the Pocantico Hills Central school district, said: "We don't hire parents. There's an inherent problem with the students' having a relationship with someone's parent that makes it difficult for that parent to now be a teacher. We feel very strongly about who is standing before the kids. Our administrators cover classrooms on occasion, and if there is a substitute on a given day, either I or our assistant principal floats into the classroom. We may pull our teachers from a prep period to rotate through a classroom. We never put an unknown commodity in the classroom and close the door."
Districts want to avoid scenarios like the following. Earlier this fall, a noncertified parent substitute left a kindergarten child, who had been unable to gather up her belongings in time, alone in the classroom at dismissal. The child missed her bus. Her mother was not called, and there were serious questions raised about the safety of the children under that substitute's supervision.
Financial incentives offer another motivation. In Peekskill, Dr. Corda said, the district not only provides a handbook designed to acquaint substitutes with policies and procedures and installs a greeter in each building to help substitutes find their way but it also has a tiered compensation system to encourage long-term relationships. The basic daily rate for a substitute is $65; a substitute who works 3 days out of 5 receives $85 a day and a substitute who works 10 consecutive days receives $95 a day.
In Edgemont, where the district recently raised its substitute rate from $60 to $70 a day, the district has permanent substitutes on call in each building.
"Our priority is having people who know what we want to teach and who care about students," said Nancy Taddiken, superintendent in the Edgemont Union Free school district. "It could be a paraprofessional, like a teacher's aide, who knows the routine and knows the children."

HEADLINE: New Brunswick, Meet New Haven

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
DAVID SAINT and Doug Hughes don't just believe that regional theaters should work together; they are making it happen with two new plays: "Down the Garden Paths," by Anne Meara, and "Syncopation," by Allan Knee.
Mr. Saint, artistic director of George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, and Mr. Hughes, his counterpart at Long Wharf in New Haven, are co-producing, collaborating, pooling resources, dividing expenses, and lengthening the lives of plays and the employment of actors. 
 On Tuesday, "Down the Garden Paths" opened at George Street; it moves to Long Wharf in January. "Syncopation" opened at Long Wharf the same night and also moves in January.
"A co-production gives the play a chance to be worked on in two venues, both outside New York," Mr. Saint said. "Working in New York is an invitation to excruciating pressure. You're constantly under the gun by theaters that want to make sure the first audience sees a finished product, or else the word will get out there and we're finished. 'Give us a chance to create something here, folks,' you want to say. Here, we have that great opportunity."
During rehearsals of "Syncopation" at Long Wharf, Mr. Hughes said: "We do our work so often to tear it down." That often means "taking stuff to the Dumpster," he said, "and I've always been unhappy about that."
Actors who immerse themselves in a role and want to deepen it, with no thought of racing on to the next one, are especially foiled by short runs. Mr. Saint recalled Penny Fuller's remark on the closing night of George Street's recent production of the musical "Do I Hear a Waltz?": "Now I'm ready to open," Ms. Fuller said.
A regional theater production can have its run of, say, four or five weeks, or it can fulfill the wish, if not the mission, of nonprofit theater, "to go on to an extended commercial afterlife," Mr. Hughes said. He is delighted there is "something in the middle," he added.
That something in the middle -- an alliance between two important regional theaters -- happened in recent seasons between the McCarter Theater in Princeton and the Hartford Stage (Shakespeare's "Cymbeline," staged by Mark Lamos) and between Long Wharf and the McCarter (John Henry Redwood's "Old Settler").
It helps that Mr. Saint and Mr. Hughes, friends for 20 years, have had a professional affiliation in tandem and overlapping. Mr. Saint assisted Mr. Hughes when the latter was associate artistic director at Manhattan Theater Club from 1980 to 1982; he began directing at Seattle Repertory in 1990, when Mr. Hughes was associate artistic director there. When Mr. Hughes went on to the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis as head of the creative department, Mr. Saint wound up succeeding him in Seattle.
Critically speaking, the audience at the second theater benefits from a play refined by time.
"We continue to wave the flag for the new American play," Mr. Hughes said. And he cheered "this sort of shared responsibility for producing one and extending its life -- providing the luxury of a longer run -- especially when we have compatible tastes and the flexibility of dovetailing our schedules with crisscrossing productions."
Both theaters reap economic advantages. "We can stretch our money across the season," Mr. Hughes said. "This deal allowed Long Wharf to lavish more on cast size in other productions, to make sure the population of our stage doesn't dwindle."
And Mr. Saint added, "We share costs without compromising artistic merit."
Ms. Meara made her playwriting debut with "After-Play." Mr. Saint directed it as his first George Street production two seasons ago with Ms. Meara in the cast.
"Down the Garden Paths," a nine-character play that takes place in one night, depicts "three different configurations in one family," Ms. Meara said. "It's about the what-ifs that happen in life."
In the play's parallel realities, a writer receives a prestigious award, and the family celebration is viewed in three different ways. Amy Stiller, daughter of Ms. Meara and Jerry Stiller, plays a daughter in one reality, a granddaughter in another. Mr. Stiller appears on video. Roberta Wallach, daughter of Eli Wallach and Anne Jackson, who are also in the cast, appears twice as the same character.
Mr. Saint said the play dealt with "alternate realities within one family, deep metaphysical thoughts and quantum physics." But he added, "It is funny and deeply moving, and by the time it ends, you're devastated."
"Syncopation" is set in 1911, when ballroom dancing was all the rage. Such dancing was still popular in the 1950's when Mr. Knee was growing up on the Upper West Side of Manhattan; he remembers being taken to dance contests at the old Madison Square Garden.
In the two-character play, being staged at Long Wharf after a series of readings in New York, dance is a metaphor for partnering and the struggles inherent in all relationships, Mr. Knee said.
"In New York, there is such a shortage of theaters, people keep hoping a play will close," Ms. Meara said. Regional theater collaboration "is wonderful," she added. "Instead of being confrontational, theaters are supportive."
"Down the Garden Paths" continues through Dec. 19 at the George Street Playhouse, 9 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick; (732) 246-7717. From Jan. 19 to Feb. 20, it moves to the Long Wharf Theater, 229 Sargent Drive, New Haven; (203) 787-4282. "Syncopation" continues through Dec. 19 at Long Wharf and plays at George Street from Jan. 8 to Feb. 6.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Rutgers Estimates Its Value To the State, In Dollars

BYLINE: By KAREN DEMASTERS

 BODY:
Rutgers University contributes $2.19 billion to the state economy in salaries, taxes and other expenditures each year, according to a study conducted by the university.
The university directly and indirectly accounts for 28,600 jobs, 8,000 of which are made up of faculty and other staff members, according to Joseph J. Seneca, vice president of academic affairs and chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisers. As a research institution with more than 130 research centers, the university holds 238 patents, has formed 31 start-up companies and earned more than $8.1 million in income from royalties and accumulated equities last year. 
 Many students in Rutgers' 29 schools and colleges have requirements to provide community service. During the last decade students provided 425,000 hours of community service, according to the study, which also noted that 60 percent of the 300,000 living Rutgers alumni live within the state. KAREN DeMASTERS
