HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Air Carrier to County

 BODY:
Atlas Air, the third largest air cargo carrier in the United States, will lease 120,000 square feet of space at Texaco's Corporate Center at 2000 Westchester Avenue in Harrison beginning in the spring.
The company, listed on the New York Stock Exchange as CGO, is planning to invest $8 million in Westchester on construction and new equipment and add jobs over the next five years as part of an expansion plan. Initially, 295 employees will be moved from a division at Kennedy International Airport, and an additional 55 will come from the company's headquarters in Golden, Colo. 
 Its fleet of 18 Boeing 747's will continue to operate out of Kennedy International. Atlas is a United States certificated air carrier for some of the world's leading international carriers, operating scheduled flights to 101 cities in 46 countries.
Michael Chowdry, chairman, chief executive and president of Atlas, said new contracts and customers had produced a 42 percent increase in the company's revenues in the last year, prompting staff increases.
"We had outgrown our facilities in Golden and at J.F.K., and the lease on the J.F.K. facility was set to expire in June of next year," Mr. Chowdry said.
Westchester's Office of Economic Development worked with the Empire State Development Corporation and Texaco, which had unused space available, to bring Atlas to the county. Atlas will receive a $4 million incentive package from the state, Con Edison and the Westchester Industrial Development Agency.

HEADLINE: ACCIDENTAL TRADER;
A Ticker Symbol, Writ Much Larger

BYLINE: By RAY LEWIS; The Accidental Trader column, chronicling the experiences of non-professional investors, will appear occasionally in the Investing pages of Money & Business. Ray Lewis is assistant to the technology editor of The Times.

 BODY:
AH, China. I bought my tiny piece of the awakening giant, in the form of a struggling penny-stock steel company, more than a year ago. That was long before the country struck its trade agreement with the United States this month, prompting a buying frenzy.
I'd like to say I was prescient. But actually, I had expected the company to fold, not to skyrocket. My motivation in buying the stock was extremely odd, and I am not sure I understand it even now. You see, I had $300 in leftover cash after buying shares of a group of blue-chip technology leaders -- America Online, Qualcomm, Sun Microsystems -- and I wanted to buy at least 100 shares of something. Sorting through microcap stocks was too much work, so I looked for total losers, which some call value stocks these days. 
 I stumbled upon a list, from an e-brokerage firm, of 50 small stocks with terrible 52-week price performance: I decided to pick the stock with the most evocative ticker symbol.
To assemble 99.5 percent of my portfolio, I had used accepted, tedious valuation techniques -- price-to-earnings multiples and so on -- so perhaps I was just being defiant with the remainder of my cash. It is also possible that I was nervous, because my other stocks were doing well, and I subconsciously wanted a dud to provide a sort of karmic balance.
Whatever the reasons, I culled through the ticker symbols. Most of them were meaningless.
Then I came across CHNA, for China Pacific Inc., a Chinese iron and steel maker. The company had a mountain of debt and declining revenue. The stock price had plunged $13 in the past year, to 75 cents, on the Nasdaq small-cap market. Prospects for the company were dim, and Asian economies were in recession.
But oh, that stock symbol. Gazing at it, I supplied the missing "I" to come up with "China." Buying the stock would be like buying an entire country. Impressed, I got 360 shares.
During the next several months, my CHNA failed to pay its debts. Nasdaq delisted it. The stock price dropped from 75 to 25 cents.
Then, on March 2, China Pacific entered bankruptcy, and the ticker symbol was eventually changed to CHNAQ. I almost sold, because, after all, the nifty ticker symbol had been a fundamental reason for buying. But I seemed to have developed a ghoulish desire to watch it suffer. (A "Q," as I learned only a few days ago, is the ticker designation of a bankrupt company.)
By October, CHNAQ had fallen to 8 cents a share -- a 90 percent loss for me. The end seemed near.
Then, on Nov. 17, the lid blew sky high. The stock jumped to 50 cents in early morning trading. I was excited. Had the company somehow paid off its debt? Perhaps it had received a buyout offer? I drank my Bengal Spice tea and headed to work.
By the time I got to the office, China Pacific was already at $2 a share. Was the company selling slag over the Internet? Then it hit $3.50. I started to feel woozy. A frantic search for news turned up nothing. (Note to Terry, my boss: I did this on my lunch hour.)
The stock peaked at $12.375. In one morning, the value of my holdings had increased from $28.80 to $4,455, a gain of more than 15,000 percent. But the price stayed there only 10 minutes before dropping back to $5. (I missed the last leg of that run-up, as well as the plunge, having stepped away from my computer to attend a meeting -- and I'm grateful for that. I think I would have pulled my head off if I had seen those gyrations.)
WHY didn't I sell? I choked. In the past, I bailed out of a stock after deciding that its price had risen beyond a reasonable level. But this was beyond imagination. I couldn't make any sense of the numbers. I felt powerless.
Late in the afternoon, I saw a wire report about the China buying mania that resulted, of course, from the trade pact. I regained my bearings and got greedy. The stock settled at $2, and I refused to sell and take a $10 "loss" from the intraday high. That evening, I said to a friend, "If I'd margined 100,000 shares on Tuesday afternoon for a lousy $8,000 and sold at the peak Wednesday, I'd have a pretax profit of $1.23 million."
Thoughts like this, and a look at my portfolio, made me lose my way again. The returns on most of my other stocks were better than ever, but CHNAQ, my little running dog of mainland capitalism, had outperformed every stock I had ever sold and almost every one I still held.
It was, I thought, time to get out. Shortly after the opening bell on Thursday, I sat at the keyboard, humbled by the market's machinations, and tapped out a market order. I sold my 360 shares at $3.875, for a profit of $1,125, a gain of 417 percent.
I learned one thing. During the last two years of investing, I've often wondered how crazy the market would have to get before I'd sell my positions. The answer: when it makes me crazy.
I haven't looked at CHNAQ's price since. I often critique my investing decisions, but this one made so little sense in the buying or the selling that I don't regret a thing.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MOTT HAVEN;
Undertaker Feels the Ebb Tide of a Sinking Crime Rate

BYLINE: By GUILLAUME DEBRE 

 BODY:
It was very quiet one recent week at La Paz Funeral Home in Mott Haven. Just a single case, an old person who passed away from natural causes.
The South Bronx has changed drastically in the last few years. It is no longer a neighborhood of fear and death, plagued by gangs and crack, guns and syringes. And everyone seems cheered by the revival. 
 Everyone but the undertaker.
Since the rebirth of the area, business has never been so bad, said Hector Marquez, 57, who has owned La Paz since 1977. "Ten, or even five, years ago we used to do a crime-related case every week or two," he said. "Now that it is clean, it is down to once a year."
In 1994, he said, he buried 400 clients. Last year it was 275. This year, he predicts, it will be worse.
La Paz stands squat at 285 East 149th Street, across from Lincoln Hospital. Everyone jokes that it is a great location for a funeral business, and not so long ago it was flourishing.
"When the economy was bad, people used to go out, to drink, to have accidents, they got stabbed, they did drugs," Mr. Marquez said. "Now that people have jobs, they just buy cable, stay at home and watch all the movies in the world."
Still, Mr. Marquez, who lives above La Paz, is pleased by the neighborhood's revival. "It is very safe, very clean," he said.
But his business is indisputably bad. The mortality rate in Mott Haven, a neighborhood of 130,000, dropped by 28 percent between 1994 and 1998 -- double the 14 percent decrease for the city as a whole.
Besides economic growth and a drop in crime, experts say new H.I.V. treatments explain this reduction.
"We had one case a month" involving AIDS in the late 1080's, said Robert Klein, 55, La Paz's licensed funeral director.
Seated in his dark, airless office, just below a handmade sign saying all funerals must be paid for the night before burial, Mr. Marquez also attributes some of the drop in business to cremation.
"A few years ago, the religious people would not choose cremation," Mr. Marquez said. "Today everybody does it. It is cheaper. One half of them do it because they don't have the money. The other half because they want to save money."
Around 45 percent of clients are cremated today compared to 5 percent a decade ago, said Raymond Olmo, the La Paz office manager. The parlor charges $1,400 for a basic funeral and $600 for a cremation.
Five years ago, Mr. Klein said, he often worked six days a week. Now, it is sometimes four.
Indeed, Mr. Marquez said he had recently forbidden one of his two sons-in-law to buy a funeral home. "This business doesn't pay anymore," he said.
 GUILLAUME DEBRE
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
InflationIs Still The Only Real Threat

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
THE American economy is on track to break the record set in the 1960's of 8 years and 10 months of uninterrupted growth without a recession. So before the real celebrations begin early next year, it's only fair to ask the question: What will bring the good times to an end?
You can be sure something will. For while there is no end in sight for the current expansion, which began in March 1991, and there is plenty of evidence that the American economy has entered a new era of higher productivity growth than in the 1970's and 80's, that does not mean the business cycle is dead. 
 "The mix of growth and inflation looks pretty good to us," said Kim Schoenholtz, chief economist at Salomon Smith Barney, the investment banking arm of Citigroup.
Indeed, Mr. Schoenholtz and his team at Salomon Smith Barney are convinced that the economy has plenty of life in it still. They are probably right. "But if you want to find reasons to worry," he says, "you can round up the usual suspects."
Ah, the usual suspects. The words made me think not so much of Claude Rains's great line near the end of "Casablanca," as of the 1995 movie that used the phrase as its title and made Kevin Spacey a star. And the echoes from that film are even more apt: Just as Keyser Soze, the hero-villain in "The Usual Suspects," walks away from the mayhem with a fortune, so too the American economy is likely to emerge relatively unscathed from the next downturn, whenever it comes.
Here's why: There are several clear sources of tension within the economy today. Household debt has risen to record levels, just as it did before nearly every previous recession. The current account deficit -- which requires Americans to sell off assets to pay for all the extra imports we buy -- has soared well past its old peak. Oil prices are on the upswing. And the stock market, by almost any measure, is overvalued, stirring fears that a sharp fall on Wall Street could prompt many affluent Americans, no longer so flush with their winnings, to tighten their belts.
But consider the suspects one by one.
As a rule, Americans have never stopped spending on their own merely because their debts reached what seemed like excessive levels. Yes, real consumer spending cannot continue growing at its breathless pace of over 5 percent a year. But even when consumers do take a much-needed breather, a slowdown in spending would almost certainly not be enough to bring the expansion to a halt. It is only after a recession hits and job losses rise that Americans tend to begin repairing their personal balance sheets.
The one recession sometimes attributed to a spontaneous drop in consumer spending -- the 1990-91 downturn that coincided with the buildup and fighting of the gulf war -- is more logically blamed on the sudden shock of higher oil prices on top of the Federal Reserve's earlier efforts, at the end of the 1980's, to reverse a buildup of inflation.
Speaking of oil prices, they played a starring role in the recession of 1973-74 (Arab oil embargo), the extended downturn at the beginning of the 1980's (Iranian revolution) and at the time of the gulf war. But each time oil prices took off, they also prompted or helped perpetuate a broader wage-price spiral, forcing the Fed to react by sharply raising interest rates to control inflation. There is no sign in the markets that the latest jump in oil prices, to around $27 a barrel, will have a similarly broad effect.
And even if higher oil prices, combined perhaps with a drop in the value of the dollar from worries over the big deficits with America's trading partners, caused a flurry of inflation fears, the Fed could probably dampen them with only a modest further tightening of the monetary spigot.
OF the handful of usual suspects, then, only one, a stock market collapse, probably can spread enough fear to cause a recession by itself. That's clearly worth worrying about -- but remember October 1987 (or October 1998, for that matter) vs. October 1929. The Fed does.
Policy makers have a clear script to follow in response to panic on Wall Street: flood the markets with cash and bring interest rates down quickly. That may create problems later on, but such moves would certainly limit any damage to the real economy from the financial turmoil.
So for all these other worries, the real risk to the economy remains the traditional bad guy: price inflation driven by wage gains well in excess of productivity improvements. "The danger," says Robert DiClemente, who watches the American economy for Salomon Smith Barney, "is that success breeds excess."
Inflation, like Franco, is still dead. But just as in "The Usual Suspects," the least likely suspect could turn out to be the murderer in the end.
"Keaton once said, 'I don't believe in God, but I'm afraid of him,' " Kevin Spacey's character, Verbal Kint, tells the agents investigating the crime. "Well, I believe in God, and the only thing that scares me is Keyser Soze."
The only thing that should scare us these days is the threat of inflation. Allowed to escape, inflation could kill our remarkably healthy economy just as it is beginning to help those long left out of America's rising prosperity. Fortunately, the villain -- at least for now -- is safely locked away.

HEADLINE: For Harlem, More to a Boom Than Shopping Centers

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
IT was no ordinary night on 122nd Street. The crowd of about 100 people pressed into the carved cherrywood corners of Martha Chandler Dolly's historic brownstone, turned out in an assortment of little black dresses, tiny spectacles and wildly coifed dreadlocks.
A troupe of models wearing battle-weary expressions stepped Kabuki-like through the house, displaying the fall and spring collections of Epperson, a SoHo fashion designer. 
 But even with its strictly-below-14th-Street airs, this was a uniquely Harlem event. Where else would Epperson's subtly Afrocentric designs (which sometimes adorn Lauryn Hill and Erykah Badu) be set against a lavishly detailed, turn-of-the-century brownstone? Where else would fashion designers mingle with politicians, and artists stand toe-to-toe with businessmen, with barely a smirk between them?
"It's really eclectic," said James R. Reynolds, an artist and teacher, who sings in the choir at the Abyssinian Baptist Church but admits to drifting southward most nights for socializing. "When I go to parties downtown, you don't have as much of a mixture of people, beyond color."
The eclecticism was cultivated by Lenn Shebar and Larry Ortiz, who organized the event, part of a recently established series of cocktail parties known as the Harlem Affair. The party, on Nov. 6, was the second in the series (a third, by invitation only, is scheduled for February), designed as a kind of homage to the literary and artistic salons of the Harlem Renaissance.
Mr. Shebar, 35, a public relations and political consultant, and Mr. Ortiz, 29, a retail specialist and fashion consultant, served as the hosts of the evening, with the help of Nikoa Evans, 30, the director for business investments of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a development corporation created by the federal government in 1994 to promote economic revitalization, and Andrew A. Babb, 30, an editorial assistant for Martha Stewart Weddings magazine.
"We consider ourselves to be love children of the Harlem Renaissance," Mr. Ortiz said, noting that he and Mr. Shebar were born and raised in Harlem, and live there now. "We love poetry and we love the arts, and that's what we want to bring back to Harlem."
Because Harlem is experiencing an economic boom, with retail complexes opening throughout the area, now is the time, Mr. Ortiz and Mr. Shebar said, to tap the neighborhood's cultural heritage and to add an artistic component to what is being called the Second Renaissance. Hoping to bring together artists of various disciplines, they asked Epperson to showcase his fashions and also invited Mr. Reynolds to exhibit his work, black-and-white portraits of family and friends, in Ms. Dolly's home.
The hosts clearly chose the setting, bordering Marcus Garvey Park in the Mount Morris Historic District, to conjure the feel of Harlem's heyday. Ms. Dolly's brownstone, completed in 1889 by William B. Tuthill, the architect for Carnegie Hall, was designed as the home of a New York developer, William A. Martin.
It was the widest and one of the most lovingly decorated row houses on the block, featuring Tiffany stained-glass windows, intricate parquet floors of oak and mahogany, and fireplaces in almost every room. (It will be profiled in a planned PBS documentary about Harlem.)
Michael Henry Adams, a neighborhood historian and preservationist, leaned on an ivory-handled cane while recounting the home's history. Mr. Adams, a friend of Ms. Dolly's, created elaborate flower arrangements for the party, with white roses, orchids and tulips. Such touches, Mr. Shebar said, help "raise the bar on expectations."
"So often, Harlem is associated with social services and as a village that's in need," he said. "But this is identifying another aspect of Harlem: that there are people here who entertain on the same social level as anyone on Park Avenue."
As much as the event was a gathering of artists, it might just as easily have been promoted as a networking opportunity for the city's black elite. "I've met several people of caliber here tonight," said Jackie Rowe-Adams, 51, a member of central Harlem's community and school boards. "District leaders, actors, models, some entrepreneurs. I think you're seeing the beginning of the rising stars of the neighborhood's leadership."
Before the fashion show, Epperson, who uses only his last name professionally, and his wife and partner, Lisha Gh'Rael Epperson, waited near the grand piano in Ms. Dolly's furnished basement. Their studio is on Thompson Street in SoHo, but they have both lived in Harlem and said they wanted to use the Harlem Affair as a way to promote their work for a new audience. "We haven't had a presence in Harlem," Mrs. Epperson said. "It's really transcultural work, it's not really downtown or uptown."
Princess Jenkins, an image consultant and an owner of the Brownstone, a retail shop on Fifth Avenue near 125th Street, sat on an antique velvet sofa in the living room under a painting by Mr. Reynolds. She said the event was the perfect way to promote new designs for black consumers, because "this is who you would want in a room." She added, "These are the people who would see it, recognize it, and take it to the right audience."
She saw advantages for Harlem, too. "Any event like this that brings important style to this community is going to be key, because Harlem has not been known for fashion and cutting-edge work," she said. "We want some more high-end style uptown. We want some SoHo uptown."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS UP CLOSE;
Some Rejoice, Some Mourn as Store Sites Change Hands

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIR 

 BODY:
The sun-yellowed newspapers that blanket the windows of the long-empty Woolworth's on Roosevelt Avenue may soon give way to displays for Old Navy, the national clothing chain.
Based in San Francisco, Old Navy announced last week that it planned to open a 54,000-square-foot corner store on Roosevelt Avenue and Main Street, in downtown Flushing, by spring 2001. The news thrilled many local merchants. "It's good to have some new blood," said Richard Gelman, the owner of a local bank and co-president of the Flushing Chamber of Commerce and Business Association. 
 But in another part of the borough, community groups were wringing their hands over development plans for the soon-to-be-vacated Stern's department store on Queens Boulevard, one block northwest of the Queens Center Mall in Elmhurst.
Last month Federated Department Stores, which owns the Stern's chain, said it planned to close the 346,000-square-foot store in February. Stern's has occupied the site ever since Macy's relocated to the mall in 1995.
Federated has hired a developer, Forest City Ratner, to revamp the round concrete structure, which has a distinctive fortresslike appearance. The company intends to build another level of retail space; that space and the existing retail area will be occupied by various national retailers, including a Target store. At the top of the building, Federated will put a 12- to 14-screen Regal cinema, raising the structure's height to 112 feet.
Opponents of the project have argued that the new development will bring more cars to the neighborhood and for more hours of the day, since the theater will stay open later than Stern's has.
"This area is already one of the most congested and most dangerous areas in all of New York City," said Tony Moreno, a member of Community Board 4.
Rose Rothschild, district manager for the community board, noted that another developer was planning to build a Sony multiplex on a municipal parking field next to the Queens Center Mall.
"Do we need 32 screens for 7,000 people in the span of three blocks?" she asked.
But Joyce Baumgarten, a spokeswoman for Forest City Ratner, said the company had conducted traffic studies for the project and submitted the results to the city's Planning Department. So far, she said, the city had not asked Forest City Ratner to make any changes in the traffic projections.
As for a glut of movie screens, Ms. Baumgarten replied: "The movie operators did their own marketing surveys. Obviously, they determined that this is an area they feel is underscreened."
But back in downtown Flushing, Old Navy's announcement that it had signed a lease with Empire Associates Realty of Manhattan, the owner of the former Woolworth's building, relieved the people who worried that two shuttered department stores on the same block would damage the area's economic vitality.
Adjacent to the two-story building that Woolworth's vacated in early 1998 is a Caldor's, which has also been vacant for many months.
"Everyone was concerned," said Marilyn Bitterman, district manager of Community Board 7. "It's a prime piece of real estate right in the middle of downtown Flushing. They did not want the sites to be vacant."
 RICHARD WEIR

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
OfDolls and Online Dollars

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
TWENTY-NINE, single and childless, Dmitri Gurevich may seem an odd man to be plotting an assault on the fantasy life of young girls.
But soon, his Web design studio in this city's thriving "cyberdistrict,"on the South Side, will roll out a new Internet-based service that he hopes will transform the way that girls play with -- and buy -- dolls. 
 The new Web site, called iDolls, lets girls design their dolls from scratch, choosing facial features, clothes and accessories in any of 69 billion possible combinations. Paid for with a parent's credit card, an ordered doll is manufactured to specifications in China and shipped to the customer within two weeks.
"This is the beginning of an attempt to create a whole new set of options for girls," said Mr. Gurevich, who immigrated from Russia in 1990 and founded his company, Double Decker Studios, three years later. "This is not a set piece. This is a revolutionary thing."
Although not the first doll Web site, iDolls is a mold-breaker, using technology to overturn conventional marketing notions in the industry. Mike Collins, president of iDolls, noted that dollmakers like Mattel have spent millions of dollars developing and promoting specific doll characters like the Barbie and Friends line or the American Girl historical figures made by the Pleasant Company, a Mattel subsidiary in Middleton, Wis.
Mr. Collins contended that iDolls' approach, with its huge range of possible designs and no set characters, represents "the future of doll play."
This notion of giving power to young shoppers is the latest trend in an increasingly expensive and sophisticated drive to tap a market that is growing in numbers and buying potential: girls 8 to 12 years old.
These girls have emerged as a prime target for companies from camera makers to entertainment conglomerates. Their impact is visible in the strong ratings of television shows like "Buffy, the Vampire Slayer," and they are credited with much of the success of films like "Titanic" and "Mulan" and pop groups like the Spice Girls, 'N Sync and the Backstreet Boys.
The 8-to-12 group of girls, now numbering more than 15 million nationwide, is also having more impact at the shopping mall. Retail chains like Limited Too have sprung up specifically to address the $5 billion-a-year market in preadolescent girls' clothing. And mainstream cosmetics marketers like Bath & Body Works (owned by Intimate Apparel Inc.), Avon and Estee Lauder have introduced lipstick, blush and accessory brands for girls.
Perhaps the most impressive brick-and-mortar expression of niche marketing to girls may be the Pleasant Company's American Girl Place, a 35,000-square-foot retail outlet in downtown Chicago. The sprawling emporium of dolls and girls' clothing opened a year ago and features a tea room, live entertainment and elaborate displays about the historical characters upon whom the Pleasant Company bases its dolls.
In its first year, American Girl Place counted more than 750,000 visitors; the store has become a tourist destination.
LOOKING ahead, the real action for dollmakers seems to be in cyberspace, where, perhaps surprisingly, preteenage girls appear to outnumber preteenage boys. Two-thirds of girls in the 8 to 12 group have access to a computer, compared with only 58 percent of boys, according to surveys by the Zandl Group, a New York market research firm.
And girls seem to use the computer differently, according to Irma Zandl, one of the firm's principals: they generally prefer to treat it as a communication device or a way to exercise their imaginations, rather than as a platform for playing competitive or shoot-'em-up games, the preferred mode for boys of similar ages.
"They like designing things," Ms. Zandl said. "They are checking out looks and outfits -- like playing with dolls in a more sophisticated and contemporary way."
Mr. Collins of iDolls said he believes these characteristics will give his company's business model an online edge over vendors like the Pleasant Company, where he worked until Mattel acquired it in 1995. Companies like Mattel are stuck in the past, he said, selling girls a story of a 1980's vintage, while Barbie herself reflects "an essentially 50's image of girls."
MATTEL doesn't see it that way, of course, and its quintessential California-girl flagship product is putting up a fight in cyberspace. Despite Mattel's well-publicized financial woes -- its stock price has fallen by more than half in the last two years -- the company has maintained a strong hold on computer software for girls, with Barbie-related CD-ROM's accounting for 6 of the 10 best-selling titles last year. Its year-old Barbie.Com Web site, which features a "my design" program that allows some customization of Barbie dolls, averages more than a million hits a month.
"This brand is very vital," said Adrian Fontenella, president of Mattel's Barbie Girls division. Noting that the Barbie brand continues to bring in about $1.5 billion in annual sales, or roughly 30 percent of Mattel's total revenue, Mr. Fontenella dismissed the suggestion that Barbie was outdated: "People like to advertise a perception about our being old, but reality tells you something different."
Ultimately, the fate of the dollmakers is in the hands of the young shoppers themselves. Laurie Meyer, 27, a Web page designer brought to Double Decker by Mr. Gurevich to give the iDolls site a feminine feel, thinks the power of computer technology will make girls impatient to exercise control and make choices far beyond what even the most flexible traditional dollmaker can offer.
"When I was that little, nothing like that existed," Ms. Meyer said of iDolls. "This has opened a whole realm of activity" for preteenage girls, she added. "It creates a new world of imaginary play. You can design them -- and you can own them. It opens all kinds of doors."

HEADLINE: Is the Sun Setting on Farmers?

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: DEKALB, Ill.

 BODY:
BEFORE the fall harvest was over, Vince Faivre was surveying row after row of soybeans and counting his losses.
Neither the best technology nor the promise of a bumper crop seemed to matter. For the second consecutive year, he expected to lose money, as much as $60 an acre. 
 And his thoughts ran to three things that are hardly good for the independent farmer: the growing public concern about bio-engineered crops, a spate of huge agricultural mergers and commodity prices that had plummeted to their lowest levels in nearly 30 years.
"There's just no profit in farming anymore," said Mr. Faivre, (pronounced FAY-ver) 39, as he stepped out of the cab of his combine on his 700-acre spread about 60 miles west of Chicago. "A year ago, I would have said we've been through these valleys before, but it's a much gloomier picture right now."
While the government has kept many farmers afloat with emergency aid, which the Agriculture Department says could reach $22 billion this year, net farm income has fallen more than 38 percent since 1997.
Indeed, agricultural experts say these are hard times for farmers. "Prices are as low as they have been in decades," said Keith Collins, chief economist at the Agriculture Department.
With a new array of scientific and technological processes lifting crop yields and tailoring food products to individual companies and specific markets, farmers are producing more food on fewer acres in less time. And therein lies both the promise and the perils for the independent farmer.
The nation's largest farms -- those with more than $250,000 in sales -- now account for more than 72 percent of all agricultural sales, up from 53 percent a decade ago. And after the elimination last year of many government regulations on production, farmers are being subjected to market forces they have not faced since before the New Deal.
Many farmers are worried about being squeezed by giant agricultural companies. "There's a fear this will turn into 14th-century feudalism," Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said. "Those farmers will become serfs. We're not there yet, but it may be coming."
Among farmers' worries is whether to plant seeds that have been bio-engineered to ward off pests. Bio-engineering has been hailed as a godsend to farmers looking for higher crop yields, but it also faces growing opposition. Although genetically modified seeds have been approved by federal regulators and were planted on more than 70 million acres of farmland in the United States in 1999, critics have repeatedly and volubly questioned whether genetically modified crops are safe for consumption and the environment.
"The issue for many farmers is not just about the current financial situation and their income," said Michael Boehlje, a professor of agricultural economics at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind. "In the back of their minds, there's a set of concerns about the long term. They want to know how they are going to participate in the new agriculture."
BUT the new agriculture involves far more than bio-engineering. Farmers have complained periodically that big corporations have gained dominance and unfair bargaining power, and now a host of economists, regulators and lawmakers are taking up the farmers' cause, arguing that the Darwinian pace has quickened.
Though some economists caution that the downturn may be causing American farmers to search for scapegoats, a growing number of economists, regulators and lawmakers are worried about the shifting balance of power that favors a handful of agricultural giants over a shrinking number of independent farmers, confused and bedeviled by all the changes.
On the Iowa plains, the new economics of agriculture is a hardship on farmers like John Whitaker, 43, who is struggling to make his mortgage payments. To support their three children, his wife, Lorrie, has taken a job, and he also works in county government and as president of the Iowa Farmers Union.
"I'm looking for anything out there that will make money," said Mr. Whitaker, who has a 500-acre farm in Hillsboro, where he raises cattle and sheep and grows corn, wheat and soybeans.
Here in De Kalb, the declining prospects mean that Mr. Faivre is relying more heavily on what his wife, Jerilyn, earns as a cook at a local university. There will not be a new John Deere combine for next year's harvest. And the Faivres will not be replacing their 1989 Dodge Caravan, which has already logged 186,000 miles.
After nearly 20 years of farming on his own, Mr. Faivre is having new doubts about how the independent farmer can survive. "Not many people are coming into this business," Mr. Faivre said. "I can only think of a handful of farmers who are younger than myself."
In some ways, agricultural experts say, Mr. Faivre represents a dying breed, as many small farmers are trading in the gloom and doom down on the farm for the booming economy that has sprouted just beyond its borders.
There is no reliable data on the number of people who have left farming in the last few years, but agricultural officials see a growing body of anecdotal evidence suggesting that many are retiring early, cashing in what equity they have or simply selling their farmland into a booming housing market and looking elsewhere for work.
Of course, agriculture has been undergoing big changes for decades. Farms have grown bigger and bigger, swallowing many small operations, and huge agricultural business conglomerates have emerged. In the last two years, however, mergers in the agricultural industry have resulted in such huge companies that the nation's largest farm groups are warning that the dwindling competition among suppliers will doom the family farm.
Most of the nation's seed supply has been consolidated into two giant camps, one controlled by Monsanto and the other by DuPont, which recently acquired Pioneer Hi-Bred International, the nation's largest seed company. Together, they control 80 percent of the nation's corn seeds and are planning to alter more of their products genetically.
Two of the world's largest grain handlers, Cargill and Continental Grain, merged their grain operations this year. The hog industry has also consolidated. Smithfield Foods, the nation's largest pork producer, agreed last September to acquire Murphy Family Farms, the second-biggest producer, and the pork unit of Tyson Foods, the No. 5 producer.
The concentration is staggering. More than a fifth of the nation's pork is now slaughtered at one company. Four big companies now control about 70 percent of all cattle slaughter, up from 39 percent in 1985, according to the government.
Not everyone is alarmed. George L. Priest, who specializes in antitrust issues as a law professor at Yale University, says the mergers are creating greater efficiencies in the market. "There have been tremendous concentrations in agriculture since World War II," Mr. Priest said. "But it's a sign there are economies of scale. The basic consumer will benefit, but it will be tough on farmers who may have to go into a different line of work."
THE industry giants also dispute the notion that big agriculture translates into bad agriculture or the end of the family farm.
Cargill says a desire for efficiency is behind its own deal. "In the grain business there is enormous pressure for efficiency," said Lori Johnson, a spokeswoman for the company in Minneapolis. "In Continental, we knew we could reduce our costs, which would lower the cost to the final consumer and put some money in the hands of the farmer."
Still, farmers complain that whether they are buying seeds, shopping for new farm machinery or moving grain to market, they are being forced to bargain with just a handful of companies.
Mr. Glickman of the Agriculture Department said a "giant shadow" looms over the family farm, making it more difficult for the independent farmer to get a fair shake.
Farmers like Mr. Faivre face the most difficult period since the 1980's, when American agriculture went into a long, steep decline. Although farmers now benefit from low interest rates, grain prices are disastrously low. Corn prices, for example, are $1.85 a bushel now, down from $2.40 two years ago. Even farmers awaiting relief from an $8.7 billion emergency aid package approved last month by Congress and President Clinton say they are considering new occupations.
Federal officials are also taking notice. The Agriculture and Justice departments say they are looking into whether the agriculture market is too heavily concentrated, and therefore anticompetitive.
Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat, has asked the Justice Department to give the "most stringent scrutiny" to Smithfield's proposed acquisition of Tyson's pork division.
"What's happening with our pork farmers is that they have fewer and fewer places to go with their hogs," Mr. Harkin said in an interview.
When it comes to genetically modified seeds, Mr. Faivre, for one, says he has new doubts about whether he should be planting them. Because of growing opposition to modified crops in Europe and Asia, and rising domestic concerns, he is already trimming back his acreage for next year.
Although genetically modified plants have been approved as safe by the government, some scientists and environmental groups say they can harm certain species like monarch butterflies or create superweeds that could not be killed easily.
Jane Rissler, a scientist at the Union of Concerned Scientists in Washington, said: "This is a very powerful technology that is able to produce combinations of genes that have never been produced before. And it's far from clear what the impact will be on the environment and on humans who consume them. There have been studies that indicate their potential environmental problems."
The leading makers of bio-engineered foods have vigorously defended their safety, deriding as "hysteria" the campaign against them, which has labeled bio-engineered crops as "Frankenstein food." But with the public's confidence waning, biotechnology companies are being put on the defensive.
"There is a concerted attack on the entire industry," said Carl Feldbaum, president of the Biotechnology Industry Organization, a trade group based in Washington.
Farmers who have been planting genetically modified seeds, meanwhile, have begun wondering whether they are worth the trouble. Because some modified foods have not been approved for export and may be unwelcome in Europe and even at home, many farmers say they may cut back their acreage.
"Farmers just can't take the risk that the crops they plant in the spring won't be marketable in the fall," said Gary Goldberg, head of the American Corn Growers Association. He is not against modified foods, he said, "but our concern is that as long as there's uncertainty, we have to protect our members."
Mr. Faivre is reducing his modified-soybean acreage to 50 percent from 70 percent and is dropping modified corn. "I've totally ruled out going with genetically modified corn," he said. "I'm not going to separate it and go through all the hoops and hassles. It's just too much."
Mr. Faivre, who has four young children, says his situation is dire. He just sold 15,000 bushels of corn for $1.80 a bushel; he is holding the rest in storage, hoping that prices rally.
Most everyone in his region is suffering. Average net farm income in Illinois in 1998 slumped to about $11,074 from $62,000 in 1996, according to the Illinois Farm Bureau.
The cost of farming, meanwhile, has risen 12 percent in four years. In Iowa, Mr. Whitaker says he spends about $35 an acre on seed, $116 on fertilizers, herbicides and other chemicals and fuels and $50 on interest, depreciation and repair on his farm equipment -- a total of more than $200 an acre. He is losing $60 to $70 an acre.
Hoping that the market will take a turn for the better, Mr. Faivre is holding on to his 1979 John Deere combine that broke down repeatedly during the harvest.
"You can only tighten your belt so much," he said. "You can only live off your depreciation so long."
One of Mr. Faivre's neighbors, Joseph White, 44, says his chief worry is prices. He is also cutting back on modified crops and worrying about consolidation. "What we fear is the inability of farmers to make management decisions," says Mr. White, who grows corn and soybeans on about 950 acres in Kaneville, Ill., about 10 miles east of De Kalb. "You worry about companies telling you if you're going to put in ABC seedcorn, you're going to use DEF herbicide."
The more immediate concern for farmers, however, is depressed prices, even in the face of vastly improved efficiency. More precise farm machinery, pest-resistant crops and generally favorable weather patterns have helped triple many crop yields in the last quarter-century. Last year, a record 2.8 billion bushels of soybeans were harvested in this country, more than triple the level of the early 1970's.
"We're mapping our fields with satellites, we're harvesting four and five times as many acres per day without much more fuel," said Lynn Jensen, president of the National Corn Growers Association.
Even so, farmers are losing ground on prices. They have complained about the Freedom to Farm Act, which went into effect in 1996, and ended production restraints.
"Some believe it's the reason for the low prices," said John Lawrence, a professor of agricultural economics at Iowa State University in Ames. "Under the old system, the government would set aside land, but now farmers can plant whatever they want. So there are now 12 million new acres of soybeans."
BUT with grain prices in a slump, Mr. Faivre says that to some extent, he has given in to big agriculture. He is becoming a contract farmer for a corporation, getting additional income from a hog operation he built a few years ago. He contracted to house and feed the hogs, not own them.
"Basically, it's a pig motel for me," he says, wiping his brow. "We get them at 50 pounds and they leave at 250 pounds. The pigs are in an automated system that feeds them. That's the way things operate nowadays."

HEADLINE: The World;
A Middle East Choice: Peace or Democracy

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the last several months, even as a final peace between Israel and the Palestinians has come to seem more plausible, a new element of uncertainty has been creeping into the Middle East. The static pantheon of Arab leaders is beginning to crumble, and generational change has started to sweep through the region as aging and entrenched leaders give way to sons or designate heirs. So these are anxious times, as iron men begin to fade and courtiers plot their futures. Within five years, say experts on the region, the current lineup of Arab leaders is likely to be totally transformed.
And so a new question has entered the calculations of those who plan for peace or war in the region: Would democracies or dictatorships make the best neighbors and partners in the emerging peace with Israel? 
 In the West, it is common to assume that the answer is simple: democracies. But the Arab Middle East is a vast area where Western-style democracy exists only in its infancy, if at all. Its countries are riven with tribal, religious and ethnic fault lines, and in many places extremes of wealth and poverty have left the mass of people young, ill-educated and disaffected.
So it is not a simple question whether opening the floodgates to free expression of the tensions in these societies would provide the quickest way to regional peace. These are places where anti-Israeli sentiment is sometimes a passionate rallying cry for all kinds of opposition groups, and where a monarch or dictator can take a lead that a president who depends on consensus might not. On the other hand, any regime maintained through repression risks, over the years, lapsing into tyranny and instability, which are among the worst long-run risks to peace.
So the question of how to think about balancing the goals of democracy and peace is increasingly being wrestled with in Washington as well as in Israel -- a democracy itself, but one that has long made deals with whatever regimes would accept it, even as it pointed out the absence of democracy in its neighbors.
"The region is coming to the end of the postwar era, where countries were ruled by a king or a military personality," said Stephen P. Cohen, vice president of the center for Middle East Studies in New York. But as the era ends, the style of rule is unlikely to evolve much, he said. "We're in a very sensitive time concerning the self image of the Arab world. The idea that the fundamentalist threat can only be controlled by hard military rulers prevails."
One common thread runs through the process: the new leaders are likely to emerge for reasons of bloodline rather than merit, and it gives some analysts pause, no matter how pro-Western or pro-peace these leaders are.
"These people are not being chosen for competence in modern society but for loyalty and kinship," said Lisa Anderson, the dean of the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University. "There is not a layer of technocrats who appear to be poised to take the reins of power."
The two countries where change has occurred this year -- Jordan and Morocco -- are monarchies that managed smooth transitions: King Abdullah succeeded his father, King Hussein of Jordan, and Mohammed VI succeeded his father, King Hassan of Morocco. Both sons are in their 30's and have experienced life in Western democracies: King Abdullah in Britain and America, King Mohammed in France.
BOTH of their fathers were partners of Israel in making peace, and the sons both see the need for economic reform to alleviate poverty. So they may turn out to be the most open and forward leaning of the new rulers in the region. Jordan, notably, has an active parliament and its new king sees the peace with Israel as a linchpin for his country's future.
In Syria, by contrast, the dynastic impulse in a tightly run dictatorship is literally impeding peace. President Hafez al-Assad is so busy organizing the succession of his son Bashar, who faces challenges from other pretenders, that he has put any negotiations for peace with Israel on hold. And a driving motivation for the Israeli Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, as he negotiates on final status issues with Yasir Arafat is the belief that the ailing Palestinian leader may well be a more reliable partner than anyone who might succeed him.
For Israel, the most immediate question is what will happen in Syria, where Mr. Assad, who is from the minority Alawite tribe, has fashioned the army, the Ba'ath party and other institutions around fealty to him. Now 69, Mr. Assad is reported to be suffering from memory loss. He looks haggard and is no longer able to sustain the marathon negotiating sessions of the past, a recent American visitor said.
Mr. Assad has also resisted reform, and this will not help his successor establish a peaceful transition. "Assad knows if he opens the door, the wind will carry him off," said Fouad Ajami, a scholar of the region. "He doesn't want to be the Gorbachev of Syria. I don't know if he can hold it together."
For two decades now, Egypt has played a pivotal position in the Middle East's peacemaking, and Americans often identify with it as if it were a like-minded democracy. In reality, despite the trappings of elections and a parliament, the system is tightly controlled by one party and the military; corruption is endemic, as is tension over Islamic activism and the repression of it. A new class of businessmen has emerged in recent years, providing an elite interested in keeping the peace with Israel. But it is not much interested in basic reforms, preferring to use state and crony contacts to maintain its income, experts here say.
RECENTLY, President Hosni Mubarak, who is 71, declared that his son Gamal, a banker, would not succeed him, drawing a distinction between Egypt and its neighbors. But that doesn't mean a democratic succession. Mr. Ajami thinks the army will designate a successor if Mr. Mubarak dies in office, which has become the standard way of giving up power in Egypt.
Ms. Anderson gives credit to Israeli leaders for placing value on democracy as they think about their neighbors' futures, even as they recognize that Israel is probably the last country that could promote democracy in them. "The Israelis are quite aware of the dilemma they are in," she said. "They think democracy is a good thing but if they make it known, they run the risk of being a political football in the domestic politics of these countries. So there is a temptation to say: 'Let's sign on with this person, even if he's unpopular at home.' "

HEADLINE: The World: Big Blur;
Meet Your Government, Inc.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THEY are pouring into Seattle this weekend in vans and on buses, by air and on foot -- the college students and the church groups, the environmental campaigners, the Teamsters, Ralph Nader, Chinese dissidents and the man who became a hero in France for defacing a McDonald's.
All of them say they are outraged at the growing power of a group few even heard about five years ago, the World Trade Organization. And so, with tens of thousands massing, they are planning to turn what initially sounded like the yawner of all international meetings -- a gathering of trade ministers from 135 countries to start the "Millennium Round" of trade liberalization talks -- into the Woodstock of the era of globalization. 
 But of course the W.T.O. itself, with its paltry annual budget of $80 million, not even enough to buy a fleet of black helicopters, isn't the real target of the protesters. It's merely a symbol, a bureaucratic metaphor for the idea that the markets have become the real governing force of the '90's -- frequently with the willing participation of governments and politicians.
The real target is the blurring of the role of the private sector and the role of the public sector, which is supposed to rein in of market forces. For a ready example, think of those so-called non-commercials on public TV that, with each passing year, seem to turn into longer and longer plugs for corporate sponsors.
It is not simply that governments have shrunk and the private sector has risen. In fact, the public sector has increasingly become the champion of private enterprise. That reflects a sea change in traditional political constituencies. The parties that used to get elected by arguing that government must tame capitalism's excesses and stand up for those left behind -- big-government Democrats, Europe's battered Socialists -- have mostly retooled themselves and changed the priorities of governments, aligning them more closely than ever with those of corporations and their swelling class of worker-investors.
Not surprisingly, the shift has created a lot of political confusion about whose interests are being protected. Consider the union members in Seattle. True, the forces of global trade are threatening to move their jobs to China. But like many workers across America, the union members have huge pension funds and 401-K's spiking upward precisely because they are invested in companies and countries that have benefited greatly from ever-freer trade.
"It used to be that trade only affected major corporations," Mickey Kantor, the former Trade Representative and long-time Democratic political strategist, said last week. "Now it affects people's jobs, their education and of course their portfolios. And it creates some pretty wacky politics."
The degree to which left and right have unified to become the champion of corporate priorities was on full display in the Congressional session that just ended. Democrats and Republicans may be in a death-battle for control of the White House and Congress, but they managed to find common ground on repealing Depression-era laws preventing banks, securities firms and insurance concerns from merging those businesses (while doing nothing about those $1.50 ATM fees that drive most banking customers crazy) and passing a law limiting lawsuits arising out of Y2K disasters.
And look at the legislation that business got killed: There was no increase in the minimum wage, no new limits on "soft money" in political campaigns, no ban on agricultural mergers.
Or look abroad: The generals who staged the coup in Pakistan made their first priority a crackdown on corruption. The country's terrible reputation among foreign investors, they warned, was as big a threat to the nation as India's nukes.
This is not to say governments have entirely given up on reining in market forces. Japan is focusing its attentions at Seattle on retaining protections for farmers, steelmakers and industrial dinosaurs. France is forever battling the spread of American-dominated industry and culture. Here at home, even the market-friendly new Democrats of the Clinton administration have breathed new life into anti-trust laws.
Drive a few miles north of the W.T.O. meeting in Seattle, and Microsoft employees will offer up an earful about how the Justice Department is mired in old economic thinking, and is threatening the economic engine that has driven one of the greatest expansions in American history.
But even those protests are muted by the not-so-secret belief among Microsoft's investors that a breakup of the company might turn into a bonanza for their shareholdings -- exactly what happened after the government went after A.T.&T.
So is the public good suffering as the role of government and the role of business blur? It depends on what you think governments ought to be doing for a living.
Those promotional spots for sponsors on public television have expanded precisely because there is increasing opposition to using taxpayer money to fund TV or the arts. So now the P in PBS now stands for something more like "public-private partnership," and it seems likely that public financing will play an ever smaller role.
And of course the most sacrosanct of public functions -- education -- is a constant battleground in the public-private wars. School vouchers, charter schools and for-profit educational companies that run schools all blur the line between what governments can achieve and what the private sector can.
In each of these cases, good civic and economic arguments can be made for more private financing. But with the loss of public money inevitably comes a loss of public control, and less of a voice for public debate over priorities.
AND that, at the heart of it, is the argument that will be shouted on the streets in Seattle. People who don't usually have much in common -- the Rainforest Action Network and the United Steelworkers, for example -- are convinced that the W.T.O.'s rise represents the ultimate victory for corporate interests that want the rules of the global economy written on their terms.
"There are enough examples on the table now, from the arguments over whether countries can ban genetically modified foods, or the argument that we can't ban products made by child labor because it violates some trade agreement," said Mr. Nader, the longtime consumer advocate who years ago moved beyond auto safety to make the case that a global economic rule-setter like the W.T.O. is unsafe at any speed. "People aren't buying the idea anymore that globalization is inevitable and their governments have to go with the flow of the market. That's what is unifying the protesters you are going to see."
THE fight over genetically modified food is a prime example of the alliance of governments and corporations -- and the growing frictions over national standards. While American companies and regulators argue that these foods are safe, Europeans have banned many of them as threats to consumer safety and the environment. Washington responds that health is a phony argument to justify trade barriers. So far, it's winning its W.T.O. case and losing European consumers.
Or consider the explosive issue of how to handle the concerns of labor. Unions will be in Seattle to argue that global trade agreements should protect the rights of workers, just as they have long protected intellectual property and investments abroad. They want the new trade agreement to include provisions that set minimum labor standards in factories around the world. They oppose imports from countries that ban unions, China included. In an election year in which Vice President Al Gore is desperate for deeper union support, they have more than a little political leverage.
But developing nations like India and China say that such restrictions are simply a form of American protectionism. They insist that labor issues are a domestic concern unrelated to trade, and want any rulemaking relegated to the toothless International Labor Organization. The Clinton administration supported that position a few years ago, but now wants a study group within the W.T.O. to take up the issue.
To the protesters on the street, a study doesn't go far enough. To the developing nations, it's far too much. All of this has opened up the new divide of globalization, the argument over who will make the rules, and on whose behalf. "It's not going to be the W.T.O. with its closed-door, big-business policies," vows Mr. Nader. He could be right: The very fact that a W.T.O. negotiation is triggering screaming in the streets could mean that the pendulum is beginning to swing back, and that global politics may rear its head and attempt to trump the imperatives of global economics.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 10; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 634 words

HEADLINE: A Turbulent Trade Meeting

 BODY:
Officials from the 135 member countries of the World Trade Organization will meet in Seattle starting Tuesday, not to solve the world's trade disputes but merely to set an agenda for the next round of negotiations. Even that will not be easy. Rich countries are squabbling with poor countries. Thousands of street demonstrators are expected to denounce the organization for trampling on the rights of third-world workers, the sovereignty of individual countries and the environment.
In such a turbulent setting, a productive agenda will almost certainly elude the assembled ministers unless they focus tightly on a few achievable measures aimed at expanding trade. The most important of these will benefit the world's poorest countries. 
 Third-world farmers want access to closed agriculture markets in Europe and Japan. This demand deserves to be met. Developing countries also want the United States to limit the use of "anti-dumping" laws. The rules governing the use of these laws deserve tightening. Unfortunately, the United States almost surely will not go along. Another proposal from third-world countries is to rewrite rules that force them to pay prohibitively high prices for pharmaceutical drugs. Here the patent rights of Western drug manufacturers must yield to common sense and decency.
Trickier than any of these issues is a proposal by the developed countries that they be allowed to impose tariffs on imports from countries that exploit unskilled workers. Poor countries believe this proposal masks a protectionist purpose. It is true that working conditions in third-world countries can be horrific, but the tariffs could eliminate the jobs of millions of workers in these countries. Rich and poor countries are nowhere near a consensus on fair labor practices, and the Clinton administration wants to set up a working group to study the issue. That makes sense.
The advanced countries also want to incorporate -- over the objections of developing countries -- environmental concerns into trade agreements. Environmental groups point with alarm to rulings by W.T.O. judicial panels that, they say, tampered with the United States' right to enforce high environmental standards. But these criticisms distort the record. W.T.O. panels did, for example, rule against specific sanctions that the United States imposed on foreign fishermen for practices that threatened dolphins and other endangered species. But the panels did not dispute America's right to set its own standards. They only insisted that American laws not discriminate against foreign suppliers.
The Clinton administration has offered some proposals that environmentalists can like. For example, it proposes to cut subsidies that governments provide for farmers and fishermen. Cutting subsidies not only improves trade patterns, but it also reduces incentives to overuse fragile land and fisheries. Environmental advocates object to an administration proposal to reduce tariffs on wood products. That, they say, would increase the demand for wood and, thereby, logging in Indonesia, Malaysia, Finland and the United States. This criticism deserves careful consideration, but on balance, the administration's general strategy -- to tackle key environmental issues case by case -- appears sound.
Lost among the disputes is the fact that open trade promotes prosperity. Economists are hard pressed to identify a single economy that prospers without a vigorous export-oriented policy. And for every exporter there needs to be a willing importer. The goal of trade talks is to guarantee that countries that want to export can find countries willing to import -- a goal that can start to be met if the trade ministers drop proposals that cannot yet be resolved by consensus and focus on the few that can. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Trump Shrugged

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

 BODY:
Greed is good, again.
Gordon Gekko's "Wall Street" homily and Ayn Rand's paeans to selfishness are the manifestoes of our giddy materialism. 
 As a young capitalist in Ms. Rand's novel "Atlas Shrugged" explained: "When I die, I hope to go to heaven. . . . So I want to be prepared to claim the greatest virtue of all -- that I was a man who made money."
Now it's not only Wall Street that is go-going; it's Main Street. Everybody wants to spin that wheel and make a mil -- on TV, on the Internet, on stocks and on the playing field.
Donald Trump is talking about ponying up $100 million to run for president. So, in this season of giving some and getting more, I asked the high-rolling plutocrat, spending the holiday weekend at his Mar-a-Lago mansion in Palm Beach, for a soliloquy on the subject of greedisgood.com.
"It really is not very different than the 80's," Mr. Trump says. "In the 80's, people had limos. Now they have all-terrain vehicles, which cost more than the limos.
"There was an anti-80's feeling for a while, everyone cutting back, but now the mood is 'Let's just do it!' I just got back from a golf course I built in Florida. It costs $300,000 to join. In the 80's, there was no such thing. Rich people are handing me checks like Godiva chocolates.
"Greed is not good. The line played well in a movie. But a lot of things play well in words -- like 'All men are created equal' -- that sound magnificent and beautiful, but that doesn't necessarily make them so. Greed is the bad part of success. And people have wanted to be successful from the beginning of time.
"My entire life, I've watched politicians bragging about how poor they are, how they came from nothing, how poor their parents and grandparents were. And I said to myself, if they can stay so poor for so many generations, maybe this isn't the kind of person we want to be electing to higher office. How smart can they be? They're morons. There's a perception that voters like poverty. I don't like poverty. Usually, there's a reason for poverty. Do you want someone who gets to be president and that's literally the highest paying job he's ever had?
"You don't need money to get beautiful women. All my life, I've had friends who were successful and can't get a date, let alone a date with a beautiful woman. I have watched men worth hundreds of millions who have all the trappings -- a G-5 Gulfstream jet , the Fifth Avenue apartment, the Palm Beach estate, and they cannot get a date. They're sitting at home watching television. They're brilliant all day long and at night, they don't have a clue.
"These people who eat people alive for a living, come 7 o'clock, they see a girl who's a solid 5 -- not supermodels, 10's -- and they look at her in awe, but they develop lockjaw.
"I fixed up a very well-known powerful, rich man with a very nice and very beautiful woman he'd been trying to meet for a year and a half. She called me the following day and said, 'Don't ever do that to me again,' and an hour later he called me and said, 'It was unbelievable. Could you call her and arrange a second date?'
"Ultimately, a woman can't make love to a G-5.
"People believe there's more glamour to being a very wealthy person, but there really is a lot of work. Once, a very rich guy calls me up and asks if I can get him reservations that night for Le Cirque. He can't get in. So I got him in, and he calls the next day and says: 'You got me the best table. But how do you deal with all that publicity?' Look, what's the point of being successful if nobody knows who you are?
"This dot-com nonsense? I think a lot of it will go away. Maybe it's all a mirage. It's pretty fragile. Every single I.P.O. coming out goes through the roof. I just don't see anything tangible. I like to see and feel and touch something -- bricks, mortar.
"A friend called me up the other day and talked about investing in a dot-com that sells lobsters. Internet lobsters. Where will this end? The next day he sent me a huge package of lobsters on ice. How low can you stoop?
"Bradley would be bad for the economy. He's a Marxist. As far as he's concerned, Communism is just fine.
"When the market goes down, we'll all be cleansed and brought back to reality. If I'm president, it won't happen for a long time. If I'm not, it will happen immediately."

HEADLINE: The Pitfalls InHospitals' Cost-Cutting

 BODY:
"Bitter Pills for Ailing Hospitals" (front page, Oct. 31), by Milt Freudenheim, looked at the drastic cost-cutting measures often recommended by the Hunter Group, a consulting firm led by David Hunter. The article drew various responses from readers.
 
To the Editor:
The fundamental issue that neither the hospital administrators nor the doctors of our country have grasped is that, as deliverers of health care, they have too often abandoned their role as patients' defenders and advocates. Hospitals and doctors have systematically refused to change the way they take care of patients. 
 Instead, many favor a role that seeks to protect their own incomes and lifestyles and have relegated medical decision-making to insurance companies.
About a third of all medical procedures performed in the United States are estimated to be inappropriate; some are done when they are not needed while others are not done when they are needed. When so much money is being wasted, it is hardly the time to think of rationing medical services by decreasing needed nurses and reducing medical research in teaching hospitals.
As a result of fast changes in technology, the numbers of physicians and hospitals in some areas far exceed the needs of patients available to use their services. They should close the excess beds, replace them with modern centers for stabilizing and transferring patients, and provide patients and doctors with resources to check treatment plans.
Short-term economic fixes provided by the Hunter Group cause accessible, affordable health care to slip further from our grasp. Arbitrarily reducing hospital overhead does not deal with the fundamental problem of how and why decisions are made to use medical resources in everyday delivery of health care. Patients and doctors must make better decisions about how resources are used in order for our health system to retain its superiority and financial viability.
The information and technology for better decision-making have been available for decades. Why don't our hospitals and doctors use them?
 
STEPHEN A. KARDOS, D.O.
West Long Branch, N.J., Nov. 1
 
The writer is chairman and chief executive of Health Network America, which provides alternative administration of health benefit programs.

HEADLINE: DATABANK: NOVEMBER 22-NOVEMBER 26;
A Rousing Week of Records Overseas

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
Investors in France, the Netherlands, Britain and Spain last week were like fans shouting ole at a bullfight, as they lifted stock markets in those countries to new highs.
 In the United States, the Nasdaq managed a new record during the holiday-shortened week, closing up 2 percent, at 3,447.81. The Dow Jones industrials and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell fractionally for the week. 
 The Brazilian market, meanwhile, flirted with a record, a remarkable turnaround from 10 months ago when investors dumped stocks because of the country's currency devaluation.
 The Bovespa index of 44 most-traded stocks closed at 13,888 on Friday, off a record high of 14,007. Analysts in Brazil said money poured into stocks from bonds in response to the central bank's move to cut overnight lending rates in half.
 Marcelo Guterman, a money manager at Lloyds Bank in Sao Paulo, told Bloomberg News: People are afraid of inflation, and fixed-income investments aren't keeping up with it. Since interest rates have been falling, funds are reallocating their assets in search of higher returns. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: The Real Challenge Is Inward

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Some advice to Casey and her peers: don't get too caught up in the race. It matters less than you think. I was close to the top of my class at Horace Mann in 1982, but not close enough to get into one of the top Ivies. Most of my friends had lower averages and did not even try. Every one of them is successful now, professionally, socially and in their family lives. As for the friends I made since college, I can't even tell you where most of them went to college. 
 Here's a little secret: regardless of where you go to college (and you will get in somewhere), getting into graduate school, even the most famous ones, is far easier than getting into college. I have seen the weakest of students go on to become doctors and lawyers. This summer a former student who had struggled in my courses came to school to work on her resume. She had just graduated from a college in the Midwest, and I pretended I recognized the name. Despite her academic challenges, she is a delightful person. Her goal was to work at a young technology company and get stock options. I gave her some advice on networking and interviewing. Not two days had passed when she came back in to declare that she had found a job. A twentysomething entrepreneur had hired her for his tech start-up.
Casey, there are thousands of colleges in the U.S. The economy is white-hot. You write like a novelist and know the right people. The only competition you need to engage in is with yourself.
 
MARC ROSNER
New York
 
The writer teaches in the computer department at Convent of the Sacred Heart.
