HEADLINE: Suspicion Following Sun Myung Moon to Brazil

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: JARDIM, Brazil

 BODY:
As far as the eye can see, there is almost nothing here but pasture, with the distant line of the horizon broken only by tall anthills and an occasional tree. But the Rev. Sun Myung Moon envisions this remote and sparsely populated corner of Brazil as what he calls "a kingdom of heaven on earth, a new Garden of Eden."
Mr. Moon, the 78-year-old founder of the Unification Church, who has been rebuffed in the United States and is facing financial trouble in his native South Korea, is seeking to reinvent himself here in the South American heartland. 
 Through a venture he calls New Hope East Garden, Mr. Moon has bought thousands of acres of pasture land and spent some $30 million, according to the project's manager, in hope of building a spiritual and business empire here that is to include investments in agriculture, industry and tourism, as well as a university.
Such investment was at first welcomed in the neediest part of Mato Grosso do Sul, a state whose own governor describes it as a land of "2 million people and 22 million cows." But increasingly, Mr. Moon's visible presence here is generating the same sort of opposition and suspicion that has followed him elsewhere around the world during a long career as the self-proclaimed "true father" and successor to Jesus Christ.
"No one knows what he's up to out there, what are the objectives of his investments or the origins of his money," the governor, Jose Orcirio Miranda dos Santos, said in an interview. "This has become an issue of national security, and I think an investigation is needed."
Mr. Moon's initial warm reception has quickly chilled, with charges in the news media and from local church officials that the sect is involved in illegal activities. In October, local Roman Catholic and Protestant churches jointly issued an open letter accusing Mr. Moon of 10 forms of heresy, urging "the people of God to keep their distance from the Unification sect."
"More than a sect, this is a business that hides behind the facade of religion in order to make money," said Msgr. Vitorio Pavanello, the Roman Catholic bishop of Campo Grande, the state capital. "He is trying to build an empire by buying everything in sight."
But Mr. Moon's associates offer a different explanation. "It is our goal and desire to do something great for this region," said Cesar Zaduski, a former president of the Unification Church in Brazil and the general manager of the New Hope project. "Rev. Moon has a lot of companies around the world, more than 300, and his intention is to bring some of them here so that this region can get the benefit of development and first world know-how and technology."
Mr. Zaduski said that Mr. Moon was prepared to commit much more money to make the New Hope venture viable. The objective, he said, is to produce fish, exotic meats, fruit and wood for commercial markets here and abroad, and to turn this area into a leading eco-tourism center within a few years.
Mr. Moon's representatives here said that their leader first visited the region five years ago on a fishing trip and was impressed by its wide-open spaces and variety of wildlife. Since then, his movement has bought 220 square miles of farmland in Mato Grosso do Sul and a 310-square-mile parcel near Fuerte Olimpo on the Paraguayan side of the border, as well as hotels and other businesses.
Mr. Moon's big push in this largely undeveloped corner of Brazil comes as the business conglomerate he controls in South Korea has nearly collapsed. Because of the economic crisis that swept across East Asia beginning in 1996, the debt of his Tong Il Group soared to more than $1.2 billion. Five of its 17 companies were forced into receivership last year, and an automobile manufacturing project in China has also failed.
His diverse enterprises in the United States appear to be in better shape. Those include a newspaper, The Washington Times, as well as Bridgeport University in Connecticut, a recording studio and travel agency in New York, and a cable network, the Nostalgia Channel. But Mr. Moon has indicated recently that he is disenchanted with the country that has been his main base of operations since the 1970's.
"America doesn't have anywhere to go now," he said in a speech in New York last year. "The country that represents Satan's harvest is America, the kingdom of extreme individuality, of free sex."
Mr. Moon's critics say that his view is growing harsher because of the decline of his influence in the United States, where he was imprisoned for a year after being convicted of tax evasion in 1982, and where he has been the subject of embarrassing books and news reports.
While he was once believed to have about 30,000 followers in the United States, the current number of church members is believed to be about one-tenth that number.
But Mr. Zaduski said Mr. Moon's interest in South America resulted from a desire to focus on the Roman Catholic world, after emerging from a Confucian and Buddhist environment and spending a long time in a predominantly Protestant atmosphere. No place, he added, has a larger concentration of Roman Catholics than South America, in particular in the region of the customs union called Mercosur, which consists of Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay, Bolivia and Chile.
"What unites South America is Mercosur, and what is the heart of Mercosur?" he asked. "This region here, where you can build a project that goes beyond borders."
In recent years, Mr. Moon has been active in Uruguay, Brazil's southern neighbor -- so much so that the capital, Montevideo, is now derisively called Moontevideo by some. There, the sect has acquired the luxury Victoria Plaza Hotel, operates the newspaper Tiempos del Mundo and retains an interest in a bank, Banco de Credito, in which the government intervened last year after complaints of irregularities.
Here, Mr. Moon built up good will early on by donating ambulances to mayors, sponsoring barbecues for residents and making donations to political campaigns. He also opened a school on his New Hope property, invited local children to enroll and even offered to provide transportation from their homes. But relations are now openly hostile.
"When they first began acquiring property here, we expected that they would promote and contribute to the prosperity of our region by generating jobs and taxes," said Marcio Campos Monteiro, the mayor of Jardim, a town of 21,000 people. "But all they seem to be doing is stockpiling land, without producing anything or hiring from the local labor force."
Mr. Monteiro contends that Mr. Moon's presence here has actually hurt the economy. The sect now owns 10 percent of the county, he said, and government revenues have dropped because he has withdrawn so much land from production and the tax rolls, claiming a religious exemption.
The New Hope site includes at least 20 buildings, but has less than 200 permanent residents and many of those who work there are Korean, Japanese, American and European volunteers who rarely leave the compound and come for 40-day courses of instruction, paying their own way as well as making donations.
Civic and church groups have also begun to complain loudly, and have even charged that local youths are being recruited and sent off for indoctrination in Sao Paulo, where the sect has its Brazilian headquarters. Though local police declined to discuss the matter, there are also complaints that converts are being held against their will at New Hope.
"I recently had two young people who had run away from New Hope come in here seeking help in getting back home to Pernambuco," 1,500 miles away, said Bruno Padron, the Roman Catholic bishop here. "They focus on the poor and the needy, and once they have them in their family, they refuse to let them go."
Recent reports in the Brazilian news media have also suggested that the sect may be involved in drug trafficking and other forms of contraband smuggling across the notoriously porous border with Paraguay in order to generate revenues.
Mr. Miranda dos Santos would say only that "the federal government is looking into those questions."
Mr. Zaduski dismissed such accusations as "crazy stories" and illogical. "Rev. Moon comes here quite often, so if his people were doing something illegal, he would not want to be so close," he said. "That would be stupid, because he is a big target."
Despite the increasingly tense atmosphere here, Mr. Moon apparently plans to plunge ahead. In September, the government extended Mr. Moon's visa for two more years.
"He is really amazed by the way nature here is so pristine," Mr. Zaduski said. "He wants the entire world to understand that the heavenly father wants this treasure to be kept for all mankind, and that is why he is putting so much of his own time and guidance into this."

HEADLINE: For U.S., Bradley Favors An Internationalist Path

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
In his first major campaign event on foreign policy, former Senator Bill Bradley will use a meeting with students this Monday to cast himself as a committed internationalist who believes that America's vital interests abroad can best be advanced through the free flow of goods, capital and ideas across national boundaries, his aides said.
Mr. Bradley, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, will also argue in an appearance at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University that the Pentagon budget should not be increased above current levels and that military spending should be redirected toward fighting new threats, including terrorism, biological warfare and nuclear proliferation. 
 And echoing one of his longstanding criticisms of the Clinton administration, Mr. Bradley will contend that American policies toward Russia have failed to stem corruption, political instability and economic decay there. Vice President Al Gore, who is Mr. Bradley's lone Democratic rival, has played a central role in overseeing policy toward Russia.
The Bradley campaign is counting on the Fletcher School event in Boston to showcase what they consider the candidate's command of complex international issues, gained in part from serving on the Senate Intelligence Committee during 8 of his 18 years in Congress. To demonstrate his facility with those issues, Mr. Bradley plans to outline his foreign policy views through a question-and-answer session with students, instead of through a speech prepared with the help of advisers.
"He can handle any foreign policy question from anybody at any point," said Eric Hauser, Mr. Bradley's press secretary.
Mr. Bradley himself has said that he thinks many voters use foreign policy as a yardstick to measure the depth, stature and trustworthiness of presidential candidates. "I believe it is a very real way that people assess a candidate, because they ultimately are asking themselves that question: Whom do I trust with my life?" he told reporters this fall.
But the Gore campaign has already begun trying to paint Mr. Bradley as naive and inexperienced about foreign affairs, saying he lacks a clear policy vision and is inconsistent about when to use military force overseas.
For instance, the Gore campaign has criticized Mr. Bradley for voting in 1984 against sending aid to Nicaraguan rebels fighting the Sandinista government, and then reversing field and voting for it in 1986.
Mr. Bradley, one of only 11 Democratic senators to support President Reagan's aid package to the rebels, said at the time that he became convinced the measure was needed to prevent the Nicaraguan government from trying to undermine democratic states in Central America.
Though his Fletcher School appearance will be his first prominent foreign policy event of the campaign, Mr. Bradley has been gradually laying out his vision for America's role overseas during the last year. At the core of that vision is the idea that technology and trade can spread prosperity to even the poorest nations, bring greater stability to global hot spots and encourage the growth of democracy.
In a speech before an Iowa nuclear disarmament group in September, he argued that a central goal of American foreign policy should be to reduce poverty worldwide. "If we do these things, we'll be a nation that has a clearer idea that we're not only standing up for our ideals domestically, but we're also influencing the world by knitting the world into a closer whole," he said.
Properly used, Mr. Bradley has argued, the global marketplace can provide powerful incentives to governments to resolve ethnic conflicts and improve human rights. Citing the case of Indonesia, where pro-Jakarta militias terrorized civilians in East Timor earlier this year, Mr. Bradley has said that the Indonesian government should be denied financial help from the World Bank or the International Monetary Fund if it does not prosecute militia leaders who are accused of mass murder.
"A globalized economy begins to exert new pressures to do things that serve the overall interests of human rights," he said in Iowa.
At the same time, Mr. Bradley has often urged caution about using American military forces abroad to quell ethnic disputes or calm regional tensions. In the Senate, he voted against sending troops to push Iraq out of Kuwait in 1991, saying he wanted to try economic sanctions against Baghdad first. He also questioned whether it was in the country's strategic interests to deploy American forces in Bosnia. And he described American policy in Kosovo as "bomb and hope diplomacy" that could have been avoided with earlier diplomatic intervention.
"I don't think the United States has either the resources nor the will to be the policeman to the world," he has said on many occasions during the campaign.
Instead, Mr. Bradley says, America needs to increase its reliance on the United Nations to resolve regional conflicts. He says the United States should have long ago paid the $1 billion it owed to the United Nations in back dues, arguing that it lost influence within the organization.
Russia policy may provide Mr. Bradley one of his clearest contrasts with the vice president. In an op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal in September, Mr. Bradley argued that the administration had allowed strategic arms negotiations with Russia to stall, erred in pushing for NATO expansion over Russian objections and done too little to encourage economic reforms. He also asserted that the United States needed to do much more to prevent Russian nuclear weapons and weapons materials from being sold to terrorists or rogue nations, and that the Administration had become an apologist for President Boris N. Yeltsin.
Instead of relying on Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Bradley contends, the United States should broaden its ties to other Russian political and civilian leaders, a position also advocated by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the leading Republican presidential candidate. Mr. Bradley also advocates increasing spending on a program he helped create while in the Senate that brings high school students from Russia and other former Soviet republics to study in the United States.
He also supports beginning negotiations with Russia on a Start III treaty that would require each nation to reduce its nuclear arsenal to 1,000 to 2,000 weapons. And he would push for passage of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty for nuclear weapons that Congress rejected last month.
Mr. Bradley says he would keep the Pentagon budget at current levels, in contrast to Mr. Gore, who has called for increasing spending. With the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the cold war, Mr. Bradley argues that the United States no longer needs to prepare to fight wars on two fronts, and so can trim its troop levels and forgo building expensive new weapons systems like the F-22 fighter. Mr. Gore supports building the F-22.
Like the Clinton administration, Mr. Bradley supports modifying the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, signed by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1972, to allow development of a defense system to protect the United States from ballistic missile attacks.
But Mr. Bradley has expressed skepticism about a national missile defense system, calling it a "difficult and expensive proposition." He has suggested that he would prefer a more limited system that could protect American forces overseas, such as in Japan, or shoot down a few missiles launched at the United States either accidentally by a superpower or purposely by a nation like North Korea.
Also like the Clinton administration, Mr. Bradley supported bringing China into the World Trade Organization. And he supports a "one-China" policy that would peacefully and gradually unify Taiwan and China. But until unification, he says he would be willing to use American military power to protect Taiwan, provided it did not declare its independence from China.
"Essentially we are buying time" for China-Taiwan relations, he said in Iowa recently. "If there is any country that understands time, it is the Chinese."

HEADLINE: M.B.A. Boom Fades as Candidates Seek Instead the Rewards of the Internet

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Michael Hyatt was dutifully following a traditional path for a future corporate executive. After college, he joined a consulting firm, where he advised blue-chip companies like AT&T, General Motors and I.B.M. He then applied to a few business schools, gained admission to Stanford, the most selective of them all, and prepared to enroll this fall.
During the summer, however, he took an eight-week job helping a friend who worked at a small Internet company in Southern California, and when it ended, Mr. Hyatt, 28, was hooked. So shortly before he was to sit down to his first finance class, he called Stanford to say thanks anyway: he wouldn't be showing up in Palo Alto after all. 
 "You need to do this now, before it's too late," Mr. Hyatt said of working for an Internet start-up. "If you wait two years, there's going to be consolidation in the industry. Right now, you have a chance to stake out your own claim."
As many of the nation's most talented young workers rush to stake that claim, business school has suddenly lost some of its luster. That has had a significant impact on applications to some top schools, particularly those that tend to attract the entrepreneurially minded. In the last year, applications to Stanford, M.I.T., Dartmouth, Michigan and the University of California at Berkeley, have dropped as much as 11 percent. On other elite campuses, like Northwestern and Carnegie Mellon, applications have leveled off. Some less prestigious universities have seen steep declines.
More students are also dropping out after the first year of the two-year M.B.A. program to remain with companies where they worked over the summer. And driven in part by the generally strong economy, the number of Americans taking the standardized admissions test for business school has fallen sharply in recent years.
The changes are a significant departure from the attitude toward the M.B.A. degree earlier in this long economic expansion. For the past decade, until last spring, applications increased at every elite school virtually every year, turning the M.B.A. program into one of the hottest areas of higher education.
Today, however, many potential students worry that two years is too long to be studying marketing and operations, and, unlike those aspiring to be lawyers or doctors, they do not need a degree to practice their craft. Much as William H. Gates decided in 1976 that starting a software company was more important than graduating from Harvard College, they are eager to get moving. Among the prizes they seek are the stock options available to the first employees of a start-up -- even if it means forgoing the six-figure salaries that M.B.A.'s often command.
Behind the eagerness is a broader anxiety shared by many investors and executives that the current Internet bull market could be at or very near its peak. That perception is encouraging companies to go public at a record pace to take advantage of current valuations, for example, and making stock prices gyrate.
Many people in their 20's and 30's also question whether the ivory tower is the place to learn about the emerging Internet world. "There's an urgency that this is happening so fast that you've got to be in it to really learn it," said George Daly, dean of New York University's Stern School of Business. Applications to N.Y.U. dropped slightly last spring after rising an average of 15 percent in each of the previous three years.
To attract students and recruiters, schools are overhauling curriculums to offer more Internet courses and even creating majors devoted to the subject. Some schools have increased advertising budgets and stepped up their own recruiting to compete with companies trying to lure skilled workers.
And for the first time in their histories, schools are seeing groups of students leave after their first year, perhaps abandoning the $25,000 or so investment many had made in a year of tuition. Twenty-five of the 765 members of the M.B.A. class of 2000 at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, for example, did not return this fall, and almost all now work for Internet start-ups, a spokesman for the school said.
In response, some schools are considering more liberal leave-of-absence policies, while others, including Pennsylvania and Northwestern, have dusted off little-used rules to allow students to take up to five years off. Around the country, said Donald P. Jacobs, Northwestern's dean, "people are wringing their hands" about the departures. Professor Jacobs said he expected most students to return eventually.
Though there are no statistics that offer a definitive reason for the changes, many observers said the Internet was a major culprit. More broadly, a low unemployment rate and an almost insatiable demand for high-skilled workers in corporate America has left people who would normally be pondering an M.B.A. quite happy in their current jobs.
Administrators also pointed to demographic factors, noting that the number of people in their late 20's is shrinking slightly, and added that the recent M.B.A. boom and the resulting lowered acceptance rates might be intimidating potential applicants.
Over all, the number of Americans taking the standardized business-school admission test has fallen 17 percent in the last four years, according to the Graduate Management Admission Council, which administers the test. That decline is exaggerated by the fact that the test, in its new computerized format, is no longer offered on college campuses, discouraging undergraduates from taking it. Still, top schools typically consider only applicants with at least two years of work experience, and the number of test-takers has dropped in almost every age group since 1995, according to the council.
Not every school has seen interest wane. Fueled by the six-figure salaries many graduates fetch and the continued growth in the number of foreigners who want American business degrees, applications to some schools are still rising.
Applications to Harvard, for example, rose 5 percent last year, and at Columbia, where one-third of the student body hails from other countries, they increased by almost 10 percent. Duke and the University of Chicago also saw increases.
But at top schools renowned for attracting entrepreneurs and technology experts -- like Stanford and Berkeley -- the number of applications fell or was unchanged last spring. Many people who traditionally apply to those schools now feel an urgent need to work at an Internet start-up, said Sally P. Lannin, a former Stanford administrator and currently the president of M.B.A. Strategies, a Minnesota-based consulting firm for business-school applicants. By contrast, Harvard, Columbia and Chicago -- while turning out many entrepreneurs as well -- are among the schools that aspiring investment bankers consider first.
Patty Benson, 26, is one of the nonapplicants. Like Mr. Hyatt, she had been following the usual course for ambitious people who want to work in corporate America. Ms. Benson majored in economics at Colby College in Maine, landed a plum job at Bain & Company as a consultant, and started to think about business school. Then the online explosion interrupted her thoughts.
"All these companies are growing very, very fast," Ms. Benson said. "I wanted to be in on it." So she applied to Internet companies rather than business schools and ended up moving to Seattle two months ago to work as an assistant product manager in Amazon.com's books division. "I love it," she said. Just as she imagines a business school to be, she added, "it's filled with a lot of very smart, enthusiastic people."
Even on campuses where applications have declined, school administrators say their schools continue to thrive. The most prestigious still admit only about one in eight candidates. Graduates are snapped up by consulting firms and investment banks -- and, increasingly, Internet start-ups. The heightened competition has forced some more traditional companies to offer new perquisites, like leaves of absence, in addition to starting salaries that sometimes reach $150,000.
"The market for M.B.A.'s is very exciting," Professor Jacobs of Northwestern said. "As long as we don't become irrelevant to what's happening in the marketplace, I think we're fine."
To stay relevant, schools are quickly creating new courses and changing lesson plans in existing classes to include Internet business. Earlier this month, Wharton announced that it was adding an e-commerce major, effective immediately, with 50 faculty members teaching courses.
At the University of Chicago this fall, two staff members had to stand outside a 9 a.m. Saturday Internet course on the first few days of class to prevent students not enrolled from sitting in on the lectures.
Still, a decline in the number of applications can be a serious matter for graduate schools, particularly in the M.B.A. world, where schools compete aggressively with one another. Such a drop can force admissions officers to be less selective in selecting a class, has the potential to drop a school's ranking in U.S. News & World Report's influential annual survey and can require a school to spend more money promoting itself.
Some less elite schools, which are often unknown in other countries, are faring the worst. At Tulane University, they fell more than 40 percent over the last two years, though the assistant dean for admissions, John Silbernagel, said he thought the pool was still of similar quality.
At the University of Iowa's Henry B. Tippie School of Management, where applications dropped by more than a quarter last spring, the acceptance rate rose to 37 percent, from 28 percent in 1998.
In response, the school has tripled its advertising budget and continued a recent push to send more unsolicited mail to people who take the admissions test, said Mary Spreen, the school's director of M.B.A. admissions and financial aid. "It has caused some concern," Ms. Spreen said. "When you have a larger applicant pool, you're able to attract a higher-quality class."
But business school can be a tough sell in the current, frenzied Internet environment. Many potential students hope to be among the early employees of a company, who typically receive a larger batch of stock options at a lower price than employees who join later. When Mr. Hyatt left his consulting job, at Mercer Management Consulting, for a summer stint at Winfire, which designs Internet software, it had 10 employees. It now has 40. Had he attended Stanford and joined after graduation, the company would have had 150 employees, he estimated.
The influx of venture capital even allows some Internet start-ups to offer high salaries, in addition to options, noted Mr. Hyatt, who said he was making more than $100,000 as the director of product management at Winfire.
The changing attitude toward the M.B.A. is particularly striking in Silicon Valley, a new center of American business and yet a place where business school has suddenly become less popular. Applications to Berkeley's program dropped by 11 percent last spring. At Stanford -- where school employees came up with the idea that led to the creation of Cisco Systems and whose graduates include top Internet executives like Scott McNealy of Sun Microsystems -- they fell 6 percent. These days, students worry that their chances of emulating such titans will decrease if they wait two years to start work.
Many of the start-ups are also making a big push to keep employees who have been at their jobs for two to seven years, traditionally a period of high turnover, Jacques Leger, a human resources consultant with Watson Wyatt in San Francisco, said. "Now, with two years of experience, you're considered a prime candidate with lots of experience," Mr. Leger said.
Students notice the difference. "The opportunity cost of going to school has gone up dramatically," said Cheryl Proctor, a second-year M.B.A. student at Berkeley, who watched some of her classmates quit this summer while many others work part-time jobs during the year to maintain contacts, she said.
Ms. Proctor herself spent last summer at a small Internet company in San Francisco that asked her to stay when her internship ended. "They made it really tempting," she said. But business school, she added, "seems like a safe bet."
Many school administrators predict that applications will start rising again everywhere as the Internet industry matures. One possible sign of resurgent interest in M.B.A. programs is already being seen: a small rebound in recent months in the number of Americans taking the admissions test.
"There is a gold-rush mentality" to the Internet, said Paul Danos, dean of the Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth. "A lot of potential students will make the wrong decision. Everybody thinks they're all going to strike it rich, and it's just not going to happen."

HEADLINE: In Land of the Car, All Take the Wheel, Few Deign to Park

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Los Angeles A to Z, an encyclopedia of this city's history and folkways published by the University of California Press, lists "automobile" as "a feature of the regional culture so dominant as to defy brief description," and that seems a safe understatement. Here in the region that perfected drive-through banking, drive-in restaurants and drive-by shootings, people do almost everything with their cars.
Everything, that is, except park them. 
 By the millions, Southern Californians routinely leave that task to others. In a city where the phrase "service economy" is taken for granted, valet parking thrives, and not just at restaurants, hotels and airports, where the service is increasingly popular around the country. Here you can leave the keys with Jeeves at hospitals and mini-malls, movie theaters and grocery stores, the occasional Starbucks and at least one gym, not to mention practically every fancy private party for 20 people or more. The Yellow Pages features 45 listings for Parking Attendant Service.
"Angelenos are lazy," said Chuck Pick, owner of Chuck's Parking Service, who has been parking cars for 40 years and provides valet service at special events for his third generation of Hollywood society. "No, not lazy," Mr. Pick quickly amended himself. "Service-oriented. But when I ever write a book, it's going to be how people lose their feet and legs when they go to a party. Suddenly, they can't walk.
"I have women call me up and say, 'Oh, I need valets,' and I say, 'Can I ask you a question? Do you walk from Saks to Neiman's?' And they say, 'Sure,' and I say, 'Well, why can't you walk across the street?' "
To be fair, there are so many cars in greater Los Angeles, and so many neighborhood parking restrictions, that valet parking is often the most efficient way to cram cars into a limited space. This is, after all, a city that had more than one car for every two residents as early as 1925, and where married couples still invariably arrive at workday movies or restaurant dates in separate cars and where the affluent often provide separate station wagons just for their nannies.
"People have grown to accept and expect it," said Herb Citrin, 77 and the chairman of Valet Parking Service. Mr. Citrin pioneered the industry here beginning in 1946 when he opened the parking concession at Lawry's Prime Rib in Beverly Hills, which he still serves today, along with about 60 other restaurants and hotels like the Regent Beverly Wilshire, plus the Burbank Airport. Mr. Citrin's business has 1,600 employees, many of them recent Hispanic immigrants, who earn an average of $6 to $7 an hour.
"Today, it's a major, major necessity," he said.
In fact, valet parking is so common that drivers of $70,000 luxury cars who would not entrust them to their own teenagers routinely hand them over to complete strangers, and sometimes assume that restaurants offer the service, even if they do not. At the Grill in Beverly Hills, the reigning power-lunch place for agents and moguls, there is no valet stand at lunch, because parking is so tight at that hour in Beverly Hills that it would cost the restaurant too much.
"But every once in a while, we will have somebody who pulls up, leaves their car running and goes in and eats lunch," said Bob Spivak, one of the restaurant's founding partners and now president of its parent company. "And they come back two hours later and the car's still sitting there, parked in the driveway with a ticket on it."
Most restaurants charge about $3.50, plus tip, for valet parking. On the other hand, even nonvalet parking in downtown office towers can easily cost four to five times as much.
In scores of places, though, valet parking is free for at least two hours, as it is in several municipal and merchant-sponsored lots in Beverly Hills. At the Century City Shopping Center, the sort of place where Betsy Bloomingdale goes to the movies, valet service is free with a $25 purchase of groceries at Gelson's, an upscale supermarket. Cedars-Sinai Medical Center has valet service, and so does the Commons at Calabassas, a giant mall in the suburban San Fernando Valley.
"I always valet park at Macy's men's store," said Marcella Benson, an office manager who was retrieving her gray Jaguar from the valet stand at the cavernous Beverly Center mall in Los Angeles, where valet parking is free with store validation. "It's convenient, they're trustworthy and no matter where you are in the mall, you always know how to get back here." Besides, Ms. Benson added: "I'm all for putting out money. It's good for the economy."
At the Sports Club/LA, perhaps the city's most luxurious gym, about 400 of the 1,600 daily visitors use valet parking, at $2.50 a car, twice the price for self-parking.
"We've really tried to coin the phrase of an urban country club," said Phil Swain, vice president and director of operations at the club, where a standard membership runs $1,250 for the initiation fee and $130 a month in dues. "It's a popular service, and members develop relationships with the attendants the way they do with their trainers. It really adds to that service aspect."
In 1978, Maureen Sullivan, a former shoe saleswoman to the stars in Beverly Hills, had the idea of using aspiring actresses for an all-female parking service, and now her Valettes Ltd., at $21 per attendant per hour, is a fixture at private parties here. The attendants dress in black jackets and pink tuxedo shirts and give a single rose to each car at the end of an event.
"In L.A., the parking's just gotten worse and worse, especially in the hills or the canyons," Ms. Sullivan said. "I have a lot of repeat business."
At Chuck's, whose attendants wear distinctive royal blue jackets, Mr. Pick is gearing up for his busiest season: 200 parties in the next two and a half weeks.
"There's nowhere else in the world that I could be making a living as nice as this, doing what I do," said Mr. Pick, who began parking cars at the old Romanoff's restaurant, a movie star haunt in Beverly Hills, and has parked cars at events for every president since Kennedy. "We do it all, whether it's one man or 100," he added. "We go from birth to death. We did a bris last week and we're doing two funerals this weekend."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1422 words

HEADLINE: Croatia Looks Wistfully to Europe as Leader Nears Death

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The imminent death of Croatia's founder and president, Franjo Tudjman, no matter who succeeds him, will take much of the personal animosity and heat out of the country's strained relationships with Washington and the European Union, turning at least a part of the Balkans more firmly westward, senior Croatian officials and Western diplomats say.
The medical status of Mr. Tudjman, 77, whose myth is being burnished by his shaken political party even as he lies incommunicado, was relegated today by doctors to "very grave." 
 With parliamentary elections now scheduled for Jan. 3 -- elections a center-left opposition coalition is expected to win -- Mr. Tudjman's ruling Croatian Democratic Union, universally known here as H.D.Z., is trying "to exploit his disease and death to appeal to the sentiments of voters," said Slaven Letica, a former Tudjman adviser and political analyst.
But Mr. Tudjman's death "will bring good news to Croatia in political terms," Mr. Letica said. "In general, the Croatian people are tired of authoritarian leaders in this century -- we've already buried four of them," including Tito, the Croat-born founder of Yugoslavia, whom Mr. Tudjman has tried to emulate.
His death should also greatly improve relations with a Western world that wearied of Mr. Tudjman's historical obsessions and xenophobia.
Mr. Tudjman is revered here for his crucial role in creating this modern Croatia in 1991, out of the collapse of the Communist federation founded by Tito. But as a historian and nationalist, Mr. Tudjman also articulated and thus fed the country's paranoia about Western conspiracies to undermine and destroy the state.
Mr. Tudjman's obsessions included his unorthodox view that few Jews and Serbs were killed by the Croatian fascist regime, the Ustasha, during World War II and his conviction that the West wanted to control Croatia. His constant lectures to Western diplomats and statesmen about their injustice toward Croatia and their dark designs against it were a more passionate mirror of similar lectures from the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, according to those who have heard both.
Under Mr. Tudjman, Croatia has been ostracized much as Mr. Milosevic's Yugoslavia has been. Although Croatia has so far escaped the economic sanctions imposed on Mr. Milosevic, the autocratic, corrupt and sometimes comedic nature of Mr. Tudjman's state, combined with his repression of independent media and his unwillingness either to make Bosnia work or to cooperate with the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, have deepened his country's isolation.
Croatia, despite its fervent desire to join Europe, has been kept from two of the main waiting rooms for integration: NATO's so-called Partnership for Peace, which even Albania and Kazakhstan have been allowed to join, or the European Union's program known as Phare, the French word for beacon, which provides financial and technical assistance to nearly every other post-Communist country in Central Europe.
"Whatever else Tudjman's death brings, Croatia has a chance now to join the main currents of European history," said a senior Foreign Ministry official. "A democratic Croatia, if it gets help from the West, can be pivotal to bringing peace, democracy and stability to the region, including Bosnia."
That is also the fervent hope in Washington and Brussels, where officials would love to see a new, more outgoing president, like the current foreign minister, Mate Granic, who is a moderate member of the ruling party, and a new Parliament and government dominated by the opposition.
"There's a real possibility for Croatia to turn from being a major part of the problem in this part of the world into a success story and a big part of the solution," a senior Western diplomat said.
Croatian reality is likely to be more complicated than that. Mr. Tudjman's party, a broad congregation that may fragment after his death, has not yet picked a possible successor and appears afraid to be seen to do so while the patriarchal president still breathes.
"We have been living in a form of prepolitics," said Marinko Culic of the weekly Feral Tribune and author of a new book: "Tudjman: The Anatomy of Unenlightened Absolutism."
"We've had enough of men of vision," he said. "But I'm not convinced the opposition will win. It won't be clear cut, and I'm not sure the opposition will hold together."
Some of Mr. Tudjman's nationalist obsessions "have been transferred to the opposition, too," Mr. Culic said. "Croatia won't be liberated so easily from the issues Mr. Tudjman pushed," like the paternalistic and constitutional ties to Bosnia's Croats. "In part this will remain a small, closed, xenophobic state, but Croatia will still find its place in the international community."
Drazen Budisa, the leader of the opposition Social Liberal party, admitted in an interview that the opposition must protect its "nationalist" front in the election. This May, Mr. Budisa refused to go on a trip to Washington to meet officials -- the only one of the six opposition leaders to stay home -- because of government criticism.
Mr. Tudjman's death "will define the character of the political campaign and it will be to the detriment of the opposition," Mr. Budisa said, especially after a huge state funeral with the participation of the church. The opposition coalition -- actually two allied coalitions of six parties in total -- will hang together, nonetheless, he predicted, even though it has also not agreed on a single presidential candidate.
"Tudjman's death will improve relations with Washington and the European Union, too," Mr. Budisa said. "But political support for us from abroad does not give us votes in Croatia. We need to have a balanced policy. So support us more after we win."
Ivica Racan, leader of the Social Democrats, admitted that both he and Mr. Budisa could end up running for the presidency. "I'm sure we will hold together," he said, although he admitted that there would be severe competition for limited posts even if the opposition wins control of Parliament.
The opposition's eventual rule might be short-lived given the severe economic problems it would inherit, including a bloated state sector, recession, $10 billion in foreign debt, a $2-billion budget deficit for next year and high unemployment. A responsible government would have to increase popular pain to begin to restructure the economy, and it is questionable whether the West, preoccupied with Serbia and Kosovo, will provide sufficient assistance to ease the transition.
Senior Western officials and diplomats say that Mr. Tudjman's tirades were tedious and deeply annoying. On the issues Washington pressed hardest -- democratization, compliance with the Dayton accords that ended the Bosnian war in 1995 and the return of ethnic Serbs to Croatian territory from which they were expelled that same year -- "Tudjman was fundamentally opposed to each of them and his leadership made progress difficult if not impossible on all of them," a senior Western diplomat said.
In general, he said, in a version confirmed by others, Mr. Tudjman had four constant themes. First, that "they" in the West were opposed to the creation of Croatia, so "they are punishing us for our independence and holding us to an unfairly high standard."
Second, that "it's all a plot" to keep Croatia down, whether the issue is compliance with the war crimes tribunal, membership in Partnership for Peace, World Bank reluctance to ignore economic corruption and mismanagement or highly critical reports on the state of human rights by Washington or the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.
Third, "they want to keep us in the Balkans and create a new Yugoslavia and stick us back where we don't belong."
And fourth, that the country is rife with "foreign enemies" -- spies and journalists and aid workers -- who "are in the pay and in collaboration with foreigners" and who "buy the loyalty of Croatian trash" who work with them.
Jagoda Vukusic of the newspaper Novi List said that Mr. Tudjman's death will change the whole tone of Croatian political life. "I can imagine the H.D.Z. winning, but still it won't be the same party," she said. "They have to grow up quickly too and are trying to become a real party and more democratic.
The death of Mr. Tudjman will be a kind of release for them, too, she said. "It gives us the possibility of becoming a more normal, boring country," she said. "Ah, to be boring. I'm waiting for that."

HEADLINE: Global Trade Forum Reflects A Burst Of Conflict and Hope

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
For the last half-century, government officials from around the world have gathered every few years to talk about trade. Delegates, who could often fit in a single hotel, debated arcana of tariff tables and export subsidies and were largely ignored by the world press.
When trade ministers assemble in Seattle this week to attend the meeting of the World Trade Organization, the scene will be almost unrecognizable. Negotiating teams from 134 countries have booked almost every hotel room in the city. Tariff reductions are still on the agenda, but they will be fighting for attention with health care, food safety, clear air, endangered species, child labor and cultural imperialism. 
 And that's only inside the closed-door sessions. Outside, tens of thousands of demonstrators plan to use the Seattle meeting to campaign against what they see as the trade organization's role in worsening air pollution, killing animals and undermining national sovereignty -- in short, letting globalization run amok.
The trade forum hopes that the meeting will start up a new round of global trade talks, tentatively named the "Millennium Round," that would flatten trade barriers to their lowest levels in modern history and gain greater access to world markets for service providers like telecommunications companies.
But the talks will also test support for freer trade in both rich and poor countries, especially since delegates will face a giant, 1960's-style protest campaign meant to mobilize worldwide opposition to new trade efforts.
Trade forum members and observers of the talks say there is a reasonable chance that the Seattle meeting will result in only token progress, disappointing agriculture, entertainment and electronic commerce industries hoping for new liberalization, but cheering critics who would like to see the group hobbled.
Despite weeks of meetings to work out a formal agenda for the meeting, negotiators broke off last week without agreeing on what to talk about. Further complicating the picture, the United States and the Europeans want the trade group to help resolve global disputes on labor and the environment that even a few years ago were considered beyond the purview of its small, specialized bureaucracy. The push for expanding the Geneva-based trade group's mandate has divided the developed and less-developed countries.
"There's a real worry that the W.T.O. could become a victim of its own success," says Daniel K. Tarullo, a former Clinton administration economics official who is now a professor at Georgetown University. "It was effective in freeing up trade, but it's straining under the weight of issues that go well beyond conventional trade."
The Clinton administration is determined to make the best of the Seattle talks. Charlene Barshefsky, the trade representative, says the United States hopes to make progress on reducing tariffs on farm goods and promoting trade in services. "Failure is not an option," she said late last week.
But Washington has an uphill battle. Japan and the European Union, determined to protect their heavily subsidized farmers, have fought broad cuts on agricultural tariffs.
The Clinton administration's effort to make labor and environmental issues a central part of negotiations has brought a backlash from poorer countries and only tepid support from rich ones.
Economic analysts are more optimistic about prospects for extending the tax-free treatment of electronic commerce around the world, a high priority for the United States and Internet companies.
Other rounds of trade talks have begun amid heavy politicking but have ended up producing broad accords that free up trade. Just four years ago, the trade organization was born of a much weaker negotiating group, the General Agreements on Tariffs and Trade. By many measures it has been a success. Borders are now more open, and trade is more important to the international economy than at any time since before the Great Depression.
Yet the issues this time are especially tricky, in large part because the definition of trade keeps getting broader. When the talks were mostly about tariffs, they involved the way countries treated imports at their borders. But with tariff levels lower, the emphasis has shifted to services like banking, telecommunications and even education and culture. Thus trade issues are cutting deeper into local policy and politics.
"Trade has become a more intrusive issue in domestic politics," said Peter S. Watson, a Washington trade expert and former head of the International Trade Commission, "and that has, unfortunately, made it a vehicle for discontent."
Seemingly overnight, the trade group has become the target of those opposed to what they consider the excesses of globalization.
The protesters now descending on Seattle represent groups pushing environmental, labor and third world development causes, and they do not speak with once voice. Among the divisions is whether the trade group should be abolished or reformed. But common refrains include accusations that the forum tramples social standards in the name of trade and that it acts in secrecy and without democratic oversight.
"This is about democracy -- about letting an unelected bureaucracy in Geneva undermine our laws," said Jerry Mander, director of the California-based International Forum on Globalization. "We need to stop it in its tracks, before it starts controlling agriculture and bioengineering and many other things."
In Seattle, which finds itself gearing up for large street protests, the celebratory mood that accompanied the city's selection as host site is clearly tempered by nervousness.
Protesters say they expect 50,000 people, possibly many more. Publicly at least, city leaders insist that the groups are welcome and that Seattle, site of the nation's first general strike in 1919, will be a model host for ministers and dissenters alike.
Some union members plan a Seattle Steel Party, modeled on the Boston Tea Party, in which they will dump Chinese steel into the city harbor here. (In deference to the environment, the steel will be retrieved.)
Free trade has many supporters, of course, and Seattle is also the home of Boeing and Microsoft, two of America's largest exporters. At least one group, Working Families for Free Trade, which is being organized by Christian conservative leaders, plans a rally on Monday.
The trade group has become such a target of ire in part because it has proved one of the most powerful world bodies of any kind. Unlike the trade and tariffs group, its predecessor, this trade group has the power to decide disputes on its own and impose penalties on countries that do not abide by its conclusions. To avoid pressure from lobby groups and possible adverse effects on international financial markets, three-judge panels decide cases in closed chambers without having to reveal much about the process. Most of the appointee judges are trade lawyers.
The group has heard almost 200 trade disputes in four years. Most are garden variety protectionist issues, such as whether Japan can tax domestic saki at different rates from imported whiskey, and whether Canadian scallops sold in France can be called coquilles Saint-James.
But several cases brought before the forum have linked trade to the environment and health. In one, for example, a trade group panel ruled against the United States, which had banned imports of shrimp from Asian countries that do not use fishing nets intended to protect endangered turtles.
The case that got the most attention was brought by the United States and Canada against the European Union, which banned the import of hormone-treated beef raised in North America. Two trade panels -- the first ruling was appealed -- decided that the European Union did not have an adequate scientific basis for excluding such beef.
Critics have argued that the ruling limits the rights of governments to set basic food-safety standards. But supporters of the trade forum dismiss the criticism as hyperbole. The group has not tried to legislate environmental or food safety standards, they say, but simply to ensure that a country does not use such standards as a pretext for discriminating against imported goods.
But even the Clinton administration, a strong proponent of the group, has called for changes. President Clinton, who will attend the Seattle talks for two days this week, plans to push for reforms. Among his proposals: introduce more transparency into the trade group's decision-making, and let observers attend some sessions.
One reason that the group has become more prominent -- and contested -- is that Mr. Clinton and leaders of the European Union keep trying to expand its role. Mr. Clinton has been seeking to persuade trade forum members that the group should set and enforce international labor standards and outlaw at least some kinds of child labor. This could give the group sweeping powers to police treatment of workers. The proposal seems designed to satisfy unions, many of which argue that recent free-trade agreements have given American jobs to countries with lower wages and less rigorous labor laws.
Developing countries have strenuously opposed the labor initiative as protectionism. The European Union has offered only tepid support, and experts do not expect major progress on the issue at this meeting.
There is stronger Western backing for another Clinton initiative: giving environmentalists more power to review trade agreements. Ms. Barshefsky, the trade representative, has called for the forum to monitor trade issues "proactively" to weigh environmental impact. Having had several environmental laws challenged by developing countries, the Clinton administration wants the group to respect its right to exclude imports that do not meet United States environmental standards.
"Many third world countries think environment and labor are a Trojan horse for turning the W.T.O. into a forum that enforces Western rights," said Mr. Watson, the Washington analyst. "To the extent that the W.T.O. is not about trade -- and reducing trade barriers -- it is on shaky ground."

HEADLINE: Sharpton Assails Crackdown on Homeless

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
The Rev. Al Sharpton yesterday denounced Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent crackdown on homeless people and called on New Yorkers to monitor and report police efforts to sweep the homeless off the streets. Mr. Sharpton said he planned to hold an all-night "tent city" vigil for the homeless at City Hall Park on Dec. 5.
Speaking to a packed room at a rally at the National Action Network, his headquarters in Harlem, Mr. Sharpton called the arrests a politically motivated attempt to curry favor with voters after a brutal attack on a woman in Midtown two weeks ago. 
 He was surrounded by civil libertarians, clergy, advocates for the homeless and Cornel West, the Harvard professor who is a leading scholar of African-American studies and a best-selling author of books about race in America.
Mr. Sharpton said he would hold the vigil, where participants would sleep on the grass and sidewalks of City Hall Park, with or without a permit.
He called the mayor's crackdown "unfair, class-based and in many ways, race-based," adding that New Yorkers had a responsibility for "protecting the rights of those who are the new targets of this mayor, who has gone out of control."
On Nov. 19, Mayor Giuliani said that the homeless had no right to sleep on the streets, and his police commissioner added that they could be arrested if they refuse shelter. That announcement came three days after a young woman, Nicole Barrett, was critically injured when she was struck from behind with a brick. Investigators have said they believe the man who attacked her could be homeless.
Since the crackdown, the police have arrested more than 100 homeless people. "Don't think that this is not an issue that the mayor is using as a political tool in the Senate race," Mr. Sharpton said.
The crackdown has been complicated by a Giuliani administration policy, which will go into effect soon, that forces people out of shelters if they refuse to work in the city's workfare program.
One of the rally's other speakers, Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said that the two policies, both of questionable legality, created a "whipsaw" effect that criminalized being homeless by pushing people out of shelters and into the streets, where they could then be arrested and put in jail.
Professor West echoed Mr. Sharpton's sentiments and also derided the mayor for other initiatives like forcing homeless AIDS patients to work or be kicked out of shelters.
But he cautioned that the problem was broader than Mr. Giuliani. "He's just a symptom of something else going on in this city," Mr. West said.
Professor West said that, even as the economy has boomed, "poor people are being segregated by powerful people like Mayor Giuliani."
A common theme among the speakers was that despite the good times, politicians need issues to galvanize support and that it appeared that Mr. Giuliani was using the homeless as scapegoats.
Patrick Markee, a public policy analyst for the Coalition for the Homeless, told the audience that Mr. Giuliani's policies will have the effect of pushing homeless people off the streets and into other more dangerous places, such as parks and abandoned buildings.
Mayor Giuliani has defended his efforts to force people in shelters to work and sweeping homeless people off the street as the compassionate thing to do, adding that his critics feel guilty about what little they have done about the problem.
Mr. Siegel scoffed at the notion. "When he talks about the homeless advocates being filled with guilt," Mr. Siegel said, "perhaps he is projecting, perhaps he feels guilty for having done nothing for the homeless in the past six years."
The speakers said that if Mr. Giuliani really wanted to help the homeless, he would divert the resources from law enforcement toward job training and low-income housing.
Mr. Giuliani's spokeswoman, Sunny Mindel, declined to comment.
Mayor Giuliani's supporters argue that he has done more for the homeless than his most recent predecessors. The budget for homeless services, now at $420 million, has been increased $30 million in the past six years.
Those supporters also argue that the Giuliani administration has put more money into mental health, substance abuse treatment, employment services and security at city shelters.
Organizers of the planned City Hall Park rally do not yet have a permit and would not be allowed to hold the event without one.
The Giuliani administration has been criticized for its reluctance to issue permits to groups the mayor disagrees with, but the battle over this rally could become particularly sticky given that city officials have restricted access to the steps and the plaza in front of City Hall since August 1998, after the bombings of American embassies in East Africa.
Marilyn Mode, the Police Department's chief spokeswoman, warned that "you can't spend the night in a park, and if Mr. Sharpton and his followers break the law by sleeping in the park, they will be arrested."
But Mr. Sharpton said that he and his followers will make the symbolic gesture of standing by the homeless, by sleeping in City Hall Park on Dec. 5.
"In the spirit of Martin Luther King," he said, "we'll park our tents in City Hall Park and tell Mayor Giuliani that we do not want to live in a city that locks up our homeless, but one that lifts up our homeless."

HEADLINE: Pataki Seeks a Trade-Off With Democrats to Cut Medicaid

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 27

 BODY:
In secret negotiations, Gov. George E. Pataki is pushing his Democratic rivals in the Legislature to cut Medicaid spending steeply as part of a deal to preserve a program that pays hospitals billions of dollars to treat uninsured patients and train doctors, according to people involved in the talks.
The $2.7 billion state program is set to expire at the end of the year, and Mr. Pataki has not said exactly what he plans to do about it. But Democrats and representatives of the health care workers' unions privately say that the governor is using the program's looming expiration to try to force reductions in Medicaid -- across-the-board cuts that he has sought nearly every year in office, usually without success. 
 The administration concedes that the two programs have been linked in private talks in recent weeks, but insists that it has not made renewal of the subsidies contingent on cutting Medicaid. The administration also notes that it would not be bothering to pursue the current negotiations if the other side had not signaled a willingness to consider the governor's proposals.
"All the parties have indicated that they want to negotiate in good faith," said one official close to the governor. "We believe that all the parties have an open mind."
The state program of hospital subsidies, the Health Care Reform Act, is financed through surcharges added to all hospital bills, inflating medical expenses. Mr. Pataki's business allies have urged him to reduce the charges, contending that employers end up paying most of them through higher insurance premiums for workers.
The stakes are enormous: New York's hospitals operate on thin margins, and would quickly be unable to meet their bills without the enormous subsidy created by the surcharges. The program also pays to insure children in tens of thousands of low-income families who will lose that health coverage if the program is not renewed.
Nevertheless, each side appears prepared to force a standoff with the Dec. 31 deadline fast approaching. The powerful hospital workers' unions and their Democratic allies vow to wage political war against the governor if he makes any move to scale back the program or greatly reduce state financing for hospitals. But officials close to Mr. Pataki privately say they doubt that he would suffer any serious political consequences, given his popularity and the fact that he is not up for re-election until 2002.
The Health Care Reform Act was adopted three years ago as part of an effort to deregulate New York's health care industry and open it to market forces. For decades, New York had been one of a handful of states that set the rates that hospitals could charge for all medical procedures, from an appendectomy to open-heart surgery. The hospitals had no say in what to charge, and insurers had no say in what to pay.
But in 1996, at Mr. Pataki's urging, the state stopped setting rates. That change introduced an era of fierce competition in which hospitals were forced to negotiate with powerful insurers over the price of procedures that now total $16 billion a year.
But one element of the old system was retained in an effort to shield New York's hospitals, many of them economically distressed, from the full brunt of market forces. The state continued to add charges to all hospital bills, although the charges are one-third less than they were under the old system, to provide subsidies.
The largest part of that money, about $780 million a year, goes toward reimbursing hospitals for payments they cannot collect from patients, usually those who are poor and uninsured. The second largest piece, about $540 million annually, goes to teaching hospitals to train doctors just out of medical school. A third piece, worth about $210 million, was created to provide health coverage for low-income children.
According to people involved in the negotiations, the governor is seeking to wring some savings for the state by restraining its fast-growing Medicaid program. The program, which pays for medical care for the poor and the elderly, represents the largest part of the state budget, totaling about $28 billion a year.
The scope of the cuts that Mr. Pataki wants is not clear. But according to people involved in the negotiations, he is at the very least seeking an extension of a series of Medicaid cuts that are due to expire on April 1. Those cuts total $1 billion a year in federal, state and local financing for the program, and the governor would like to renew them for at least four years.
Democrats who control the State Assembly have not completely ruled out Governor Pataki's proposal. But in the end, Democratic leaders are likely to take their cue from labor groups, most notably the leaders of 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, who say they oppose any reduction in state support for hospitals.
The governor has also indicated that he wants to cut the money used to pay hospitals to train young doctors, though he has not indicated how much of a cut he wants, according to those involved in the talks.
That proposal is likely to meet with stiff resistance from Democrats and union leaders, who regard the money as crucial to the survival of teaching hospitals. Their resolve is most likely to be strengthened now that Congress has made deep Medicare cuts for New York's teaching hospitals in the budget it has sent to President Clinton.
But some Republicans have suggested replacing the current funding source for doctors' training with cash that the state is expected to receive from last year's settlement of a national lawsuit against the tobacco industry. But it is not clear whether Mr. Pataki will do that.
The governor has offered some inducements, according to those involved in the talks. Privately, he has said that he is willing to expand health care coverage for the poor and the uninsured -- something that Democrats and union leaders support, though they would like to use tobacco money for such an initiative. It is not clear how Mr. Pataki intends to do that, though he is said to be looking into tax cuts as an incentive for small-business owners to provide health benefits to their employees.
One of the biggest uncertainties the governor faces is the response of the Republican majority in the State Senate. Its members are allied with Mr. Pataki and believe there is a need to cut health care costs. But they also want to avoid a battle with the health care workers' unions, since they are up for re-election next year, and to protect hospitals, which are among the biggest employers in most Senate districts.
So far, the Republicans in the Senate have stuck by the governor, allowing him to try to negotiate a deal with Democrats and the union leaders. But at the same time, some officials have indicated that the Republican majority is prepared to step in if the negotiations stall, possibly with a proposal to renew the existing system of surcharges before they expire. It is not clear, though, whether such a move would satisfy union leaders who are calling for some changes to the current system.

LENGTH: 1408 words

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Navigating the Bureaucracy After an Accident

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Scott MacDonough does not remember being hit. All he remembers is the car's headlights coming closer, and a last-minute instinct to protect his dog, Alexis.
After the accident on West 96th Street, in August 1998, Alexis got to live in a large house in Connecticut, but Mr. MacDonough, a former movie publicist who had worked on some of Woody Allen's most famous films, including "Annie Hall" and "Manhattan," was not so lucky. Despite three operations and countless hours of physical therapy, he still cannot walk, and is a virtual shut-in in the one-room apartment where he has lived since 1970. 
 "I was first told I'd be able to walk by December. Then it was going to be the spring. Then it was going to be the summer," he said. "Now they're not even bothering to tell me."
When Mr. MacDonough, 55, who has not been able to work since the accident, stopped receiving Medicaid payments for three weeks, he called the Community Service Society of New York. The service society's Public Benefits Resource Center helped him navigate the public assistance bureaucracy and obtain Social Security Disability Income and Medicaid coverage for his physical therapy.
The Community Service Society is one of seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which begins its 88th appeal today.
The fund was created in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of The Times, who was moved by a chance encounter with a beggar on Christmas Day, 1911. The man said he had just eaten Christmas dinner at a Y.M.C.A., but had no money for lodging and nowhere to sleep. Mr. Ochs eyed him carefully and decided he looked respectable, and gave him a few dollars and one of his cards. "If you're looking for a job," he said, "come see me tomorrow." When the man came to The Times, Mr. Ochs gave him a job.
Mr. Ochs soon decided that if his readers knew about the suffering around them, they would be eager to contribute. The first campaign raised $3,630.88 from 117 contributors. This year, the fund will accept donations by credit card via the Web for the first time, at www.nytimes.com/neediest. The Times pays the fund's administrative costs, so every dollar donated goes directly to those in need.
Individual donors allow the agencies, among the oldest and most respected in New York, to provide money at a critical moment in a person's life. The donations can keep a struggling family from breaking apart, give an abandoned child hope for the future or help a battered woman regain her confidence.
Last year, more than 13,000 readers donated to the fund, including two 8-year-old girls who gave the $80.50 they had made selling homemade cookies on the sidewalk; a couple from Ronkonkoma, N.Y., who raised $570 by asking the guests at their 50th anniversary party to give checks to the fund in lieu of gifts; and a group of young Wall Street analysts who each year organize a fund drive among their peers. All told, a record of $6,582,341.37 was raised for New York's poor.
For Mr. MacDonough, assistance came in the form of a professional caseworker, Leslie Boutin, who spent nearly 20 hours dealing with city agencies to make sure that his Medicaid was not lost in his transition to Social Security Disability Income.
During the three weeks that Mr. MacDonough's Medicaid coverage lapsed, he had to pay for his prescriptions out of his own pocket, and he found the expense was quickly becoming too high for him to afford.
Mr. MacDonough, who lives on Riverside Drive on the Upper West Side, was responsible for getting movies publicized in the media, but when he was working with Woody Allen, he said, much of his assignment was politely keeping people away. "I told Woody, 'You don't need a unit publicist, you need a unit doberman,' " he said.
Mr. MacDonough said he never imagined he could end up in such dire circumstances. "However careful you are crossing the streets, it can happen to anyone," he said. "We don't realize this until it happens."
As this year's appeal begins, there is plenty of evidence that New York City's economy is booming, from new construction projects to throngs of tourists to sky-high rents charged for apartments. Yet underneath these signs of prosperity is the hard fact that New York City has a much higher level of poverty than the country as a whole.
According to the most recent Current Population Survey completed by the United States Census Bureau, using data from 1997 and 1998, 24.8 percent of New York City residents live in poverty, almost double the 13 percent poverty rate in the rest of the country.
"New York State has, for a wealthy state, a very high level of poverty," said Frank Mauro, executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group in Latham, N.Y., that studies the state's economy. He said New York is the only state to be ranked in the top 10 by the Census Bureau both in poverty and per capita income. "It just shows that we're a city and a state of these extremes of wealth and poverty. It shows the need for both governmental and private efforts to address this situation."
One private agency that is working to make a difference is the UJA-Federation of New York, another charity that receives support from the Neediest Cases Fund.
"We have a remarkable paradox in New York City at the moment," said John Ruskay, chief executive of the UJA-Federation. "On the one hand, there is unprecedented wealth accumulation that is benefiting broad sectors of New Yorkers. However, at the same time, there is a less visible New York, which our agencies encounter every day in increased demand for food, cash assistance to pay essential bills, housing, and child care."
Mr. Ruskay said he is finding it harder to get members of the younger generation to give to the charity. "Many of our older donors, in their 60's and 70's, were themselves born in very modest circumstances, and therefore experienced firsthand the problems of the poor," he said. "At the moment, most of those in their 30's and 40's were raised in middle-class circumstances. Poverty was more distant, if not remote."
Philip Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, which also receives support from Neediest Cases, said: "That money that we receive is absolutely incredible because it enables us to do things that we otherwise absolutely couldn't do. It helps us with big things like helping to have their parents not be evicted, and little things like a birthday party."
Now that Mr. MacDonough is not so preoccupied with paying his medical bills, he can turn his attention to other things, like getting his screenplay, "Shadow on Barrow Street," which he said received a rave review from his friend the movie critic Rex Reed two days before his accident, made into a movie.
"Thank God they called me back," he said, referring to the Community Service Society's Public Benefits Resource Center. "If they hadn't come to my help, I don't know what I would have done."

HEADLINE: November 21-27;
U.S. Economy Steams Ahead

 BODY:
The government's latest snapshot of the nation's $8.9 trillion economy revealed even more momentum than had been thought.
With employment, incomes, consumer optimism and stock market indexes all at or near peaks, the Commerce Department raised its estimate of economic growth in the third quarter to an annual rate of 5.5 percent, from 4.8. percent. 
 That pace surpassed nearly all predictions. "How can you not be thankful?" asked James Glassman, chief United States economist at Chase Securities.
But some analysts warned that unless the growth slows sharply, the Federal Reserve could feel compelled to raise interest rates again and threaten the long-running expansion.
