HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Trying to Figure Out What Space to Save

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
MOST people get interested in land use at the moment that, say, Wal-Mart announces plans to build across the street. But Judy Jengo is the sort of person who started going to her borough planning board meetings -- after a day at work on environmental issues -- for fun.
Ms. Jengo is now the executive director of the new Garden State Preservation Trust, which just started shopping with the millions of tax dollars set aside for open-space preservation. It is is one thing for the voters to check "yes" on a ballot proposal to save more land, as they did by a 2-to-1 ratio last November, and another to figure out whose backyard will be preserved. 
 So the job of overseeing the state's spending went to a woman who has given her 13 years here to environmental concerns, most recently as a deputy commissioner of environmental protection, and whose absolute favorite subject is land-use planning.
"We have to focus both on preservation and on curbing sprawl," Ms. Jengo said of Governor Whitman's goal of preserving one million acres, about a fifth of the state, in 10 years. "You can't just do it all by buying open space."
As she spoke, in a gentle voice suited to a teacher, her fingers kept intertwining. The trust, she explained, has to choose from hundreds of applications by local governments and nonprofit organizations as well as proposals for state purchases, making sure that dozens of competing environmental priorities are served and that it all makes sense when the green spaces are all plotted on the map of New Jersey.
It promises to be a popular undertaking. "People have been supporting open space ever since the first bond issue in 1961, the first Green Acres bond issue," Ms. Jengo said. "And there are polls, and the public support is stunning, overwhelming, always by a 2-to-1 margin or better for curbing sprawl, for better planning, for open-space preservation, farmland preservation, lessening traffic congestion.
"The elected officials saw the same thing," she said. "This is what people want. It's very smart policy and very smart politics."
Ms. Jengo was appointed to the new post by the governor in October, three months after the trust was established, but she moved into her new office just last week. In the meantime, she was also finishing almost two years' work on the administration's revised regulations for development in coastal areas, only to get a kick in the shins when the Senate voted two weeks ago to send them back for redrafting.
As Ms. Jengo was turning over the job of fending off a subsequent attack in the Assembly, the trust was choosing its first candidates for acquisition, from one-third of an acre on the Raritan Bay to a 200-acre addition to a preserve in Hunterdon County. It also approved farmland preservation and recreation projects.
The trust, working from backlogged Green Acres and farmland preservation applications, assigned rankings to them. It will submit its list for the Legislature's approval, and the first $88 million will be dispensed.
Ms. Jengo will oversee the day-to-day work of this whole messy process from the trust's new home in a brownstone across from the State House. For now, she is wedged into an office with stacks of cardboard cartons and a small forest of dracenas and ficus trees.
Ms. Jengo, 43, has earned a long list of resume entries in this neighborhood. She arrived 13 years ago, from the Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management, as an environmental policy adviser for the Legislature. In 1994 she became Mrs. Whitman's senior environmental adviser and started working on what would become the governer's open-space initiative. She moved to the environmental protection department almost two years ago.
"She's a perfect fit," Michael Catania, director of the New Jersey chapter of the Nature Conservancy. "She's ebullient and just absolutely dedicated and passionate about open space. She was the one who had the most to do with the governor embracing the million-acre goal."
To Patrick O'Keefe, director of the New Jersey Builders Association, Ms. Jengo's appointment is is one of considerable concern." "If her track record is any indication," Mr. O'Keefe said, "we don't anticipate a very forthcoming and open operation."
But William G. Dressel Jr., director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, said Ms. Jengo was "accessible, very forthright." He also mentioned her fierce work habit, recalling the time he called to leave a voice mail message before leaving home for the weekend.
"It was like eight o' clock on Saturday morning and she was at her desk," he said. "In this business, quite frankly, you don't meet that many state bureaucrats that are that conscientious."
Ms. Jengo says she spent many 13- and 14-hour days at the Department of Environmental Protection, leaving her postgraduate work at Rutgers, where she is a Ph.D. candidate in land-use policy. She spent many of them with municipal officials along the Shore and Delaware Bay areas ("we made house calls," she says), poring over maps, explaining the proposed development regulations and bending them to address local complaints.
Yet Mr. O'Keefe maintains Ms. Jengo and her staff shut out the builders association. "They went out and met with selected groups,' he said. For her part, Ms. Jengo said she met with the association's top staff members as well as many builders in the coastal areas.
"There are builders who think these rules are good," she said.
The experience sealed Ms. Jengo's reputation for persistence. She cannot even say how many legislators, mayors and township managers she met. "I so lost track," she said. "My car put on a lot of mileage."
The open-space plan, she said, can only be good news for local governments, as Mrs. Whitman insisted when she took it on.
"When the governor made this decision to go ahead, she said she was going to get it done and she was going to get it done in 1998, period," Ms. Jengo said. "And she went out and stumped around the state every day for months."
Now, she said, "towns are realizing the economic benefit of preservation."
"Folks really used to think, understandably, that all development would bring in the ratables and help the budgets," she said, "but as more and more people have been doing the math, they realize it's not that simple that it's true that if you build in the right places, but not if you build in places that cant sustain it.
"In those places it just raises taxes," she said. "It is no mystery that we have the highest property taxes in the nation and are the most densely developed. Property taxes in New Jersey more than doubled in the 1980's when we had the building boom."
She added, "In the 1990's, people started to sense an even greater urgency," approving local open-space funds to stave off development.
Ms. Jengo glimpsed these concerns long ago. "I grew up in suburbia, in sprawl, if you will," she said, "after being born in Jersey City and moving out to the suburbs."
There followed a common 1960's story: "When we moved to our house it was all woods behind us, and shortly afterward it became another subdivision and all of the trees came down. We lost our place to play."
Ms. Jengo took an interest in trees anyway, and majored in environmental management at Rutgers. She earned a master's at Colorado State University and worked in Idaho for the federal Fish and Wildlife Service.
Then, she said, apologetically, "I said, How can I have the most impact? It's not collecting deer poop on some slope. I realized it means being involved where policy is being made."
So she went into government, first in Rhode Island, and realized that policy is all about using money. Now she has to devise ways of leveraging enough to protect one million acres with $1.5 billion to spend on property that many environmentalists say is unattainable.
When she speaks to local groups about using money, she sometimes mentions her own town, Hopewell. Ten years ago, when the city planner had every square inch of the borough map covered with little houses-to-be, some questioned the wisdom of all that growth, only to be told that the experts knew best.
When a 57-acre farm came up for sale, "this little group went door to door," she said. "Fifty-seven acres in our town cost a boatload of money."
But they raised $250,000 in three weeks, and got a matching $250,000 from a donor to buy the property for the town.
"And suddenly," she said, "the mayor became very supportive."
 
A Sample of the State's First Acquisitions
 
TRENTON
The Garden State Preservation Trust announced its first round of spending this month, choosing from projects that were eligible for money through the Green Acres program but were stalled when the fund ran out of money.
Here is a random sample of the acquisitions and recreation projects:
* $4 million for a total of 35 acres in Emerson and Haworth in Bergen County to preserve land around the Oradell Reservoir.
* $50,000 to improve a playground in Ringwood, Passaic County.
* $1.2 million for 168 acres of woodland in Hopewell Township, Mercer County, to include hiking trails.
* $1.5 million for five acres in Edison Township to expand a park and add athletic fields.
* $500,000 to restore a portion of the Asbury Park boardwalk.
* $500,000 to Bridgewater Township, Somerset County, to buy open space in the path of development.
* $140,000 to create a wildlife refuge and nature center on a reservoir in Clark and Scotch Plains.
* $240,000 to purchase 22 acres of Pine Barrens habitat in Medford Township, Burlington County, as part of a plan for a 4,000-acre preserve.
* 500,000 to the Greater Newark Conservancy for an outdoor ecology center.

HEADLINE: Transfixed by New York;
Whether as Dream or Nightmare, the City Looms Uncommonly Large in the Minds of Dominicans, New York's Largest Immigrant Group

BYLINE: By SETH KUGEL

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic

 BODY:
HE who dies without seeing New York dies blind," goes the Dominican saying, and countless citizens in this Caribbean nation of eight million have heeded those words. Although the Dominican Republic is only the 85th most populous country in the world, it has been the No. 1 source of legal immigrants to New York City for 23 of the last 25 years, sending an estimated 345,000 people in that period.
Like most other groups of immigrants, some Dominicans establish themselves in New York and succeed financially; others find only unhappiness in a crowded, confusing city. The majority fall somewhere in between. But the sheer scale of the
influx -- about 30 flights a day go from the Dominican Republic to La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark Airports on American Airlines alone -- has injected images of New York into the daily life of the Dominican Republic to an extent that might be unparalleled anywhere else in the world. 
 Here in the capital city Dominicans can get their hair cut at the Manhattan Barbershop, whose facade features a painted image of the Statue of Liberty holding hair clippers. They can shoot pool at the Bronx Billiard Club and pick up a necklace at New York Jewelers. In the city of Santiago, Dominicans can get their picture taken at a photo studio that offers backdrops of New York scenes like the Brooklyn Bridge.
So many returning Dominican immigrants live in the city of San Pedro de Macoris that residents there have informally renamed two neighborhoods Queens and Harlem. A map of North America distributed by a Santo Domingo car rental company shows New York as a region stretching as far west as Cincinnati. Some less-educated Dominicans routinely refer to secondary destinations for Dominican migration, like Massachusetts, Florida and even Spain, as "states" of New York. The terms "abroad" and "New York" are sometimes used interchangeably.
Immigration to New York is a common theme in Dominican popular culture, especially in merengue music. "How many big things does New York have?" sings Luis Vargas. "The Twin Towers, avenues that go up and down, Broadway, St. Nicholas, anyone would go crazy. How many sirens? How many strange things? My God!" The most popular Dominican film of the 1990's, "Nueba Yol," named for the way some Dominicans pronounce "New York" in Spanish, chronicles the struggles of the popular television character Balbuena as he mortgages his house to chase his dreams in the Big Apple.
The presence of New York in daily life is taken for granted by most Dominicans, who often have well-developed opinions on the merits of living there versus staying home. Dominican immigration to the United States began en masse after the assassination in 1961 of the dictator Rafael Trujillo brought an end to an era of terror and persecution that included highly restrictive emigration policies.
"Previously, there were only small nuclei of Dominicans established in New York City," said Franc Baez, a sociologist at the Autonomous University of Santo Domingo. "When the big push came, Dominicans followed the Puerto Ricans there, and New York became the place par excellence to build a migratory utopia."
According to a survey cited in Patricia Pessar's book "Visa for a Dream," a study of Dominicans in the United States, 9,330 Dominicans came to this country annually in the early 1960's, nearly 10 times as many as in the 1950's. There are now around 750,000 legal and illegal Dominicans living in the five boroughs, largely concentrated in Washington Heights and the western Bronx. In most parts of the Dominican Republic it is hard to find anyone without at least one relative in New York.
 
Images of New York: 'Dollars in the Street'
How do Dominicans on the island view the faraway city that looms so large in their lives and their imaginations?
Sitting in the library of the Universidad Catolica Madre y Maestra, Rosanna Luciano described her first childhood impressions of New York. When she left the Dominican Republic at age 9 to visit relatives in Washington Heights, her older brother made an intriguing request. "Rosanna," he said, "bring me back all the dollars you find in the street there." She still remembers walking around Manhattan with her eyes glued to the ground.
Ms. Luciano, now 19, is studying to be a dentist and is no longer so gullible. She has heard repeatedly how hard immigrants must work in New York, how little they are paid, how bad discrimination can be. Yet she still plans to move to New York to join her boyfriend in Inwood when she graduates, despite the language and licensing barriers that may prevent her from practicing her profession.
She is not alone. Even for many professionals, the image of New York as the land of opportunity has survived the negative publicity. It's not difficult to understand why: many Dominican doctors could quadruple their salaries by becoming livery cab drivers in the Bronx.
For poorer Dominicans like Jose Rafael Gomez and his wife, Trinidad Sanchez, New York can be a lifeline. The couple, coffee and avocado farmers in a rural town, Salitres de Moca, don't earn enough to support the eight grandchildren and other relatives who live with them. So they depend on the generosity of their five daughters in the Bronx and New Jersey, who wire them several hundred dollars a month. "We're eating every day because of our daughters," Mrs. Sanchez said. "God bless them."
Mr. Gomez thinks his hard-working daughters are thriving in New York.
"They have changed their system of living and their physical appearance as well," he said, and he describes them as glowing when they return for a visit. "To me, New York is a great country."
Hipolito Melendez, a merchant familiar with both worlds, has a far less complimentary view. Mr. Melendez, who is in his 40's, lives in Villa Trina, a picturesque farming and cabinetmaking hill town up the road from Salitres de Moca. In 1988 he traveled illegally to New York via Central America, finally crossing the border in Tijuana before heading for New York City. He spent two years working 13-hour shifts in a Washington Heights bodega for $200 a week, sharing a cramped rented room in the western Bronx with a cousin. He saved nothing.
Since returning home in 1990, he speaks freely about his experience to friends and neighbors, calling New York "a disaster" and swearing he will never return.
"People think it's the apex," he said. "People say, 'If I can get there. . . .' But 'there' is very difficult." He realizes that his words mean little in a town where most barely scrape by. "If there was an opportunity to leave," he acknowledged, "all Villa Trina would go. Except for me."
Mr. Melendez may be exaggerating, but not by much. A 1997 Gallup-Hoy poll found that more than half of adult Dominicans would emigrate if they had the chance, a vast majority citing economic motivations. (Older and more financially stable Dominicans were less likely to want to go.) Strict American immigration laws restrict entry to people with specific job skills or with close relatives who are United States citizens or legal permanent residents.
Even then, there is often a long wait and a difficult interview process. Some Dominican siblings of American citizens, the lowest-ranked preference category, have been waiting 11 years for an interview.
 
'New York Is Hard, My Country Is Hard'
In practically every working-class corner of Santo Domingo, the beat of merengue pounds from homes, nightclubs and corner stores known as colmados. Dominicans of all ages listen, usually at astoundingly high volume. The lyrics often explore political and social themes of Dominican life, and a frequent topic is the Dominican exodus to New York and the success or heartbreak it can bring.
"Merengue has been at the forefront of the effort to document migration," said Silvio Torres-Saillant, the director of the CUNY Dominican Studies Institute at City College, noting that the first songs about Dominicans who went to New York appeared before scholars began studying the issue.
The 1995 hit "A Day in New York," by the Hermanos Rosario (the Rosario Brothers) documents the downside of immigrant life for Dominicans. In the song, which saturated Dominican airwaves for months, an out-of-work Dominican New Yorker describes a typical day in the Bronx to a friend back home. He scans the want ads in vain, is told by the superintendent that the pipes have burst, gets a parking ticket and witnesses a machine-gun killing. At the end of the song, he asks if his friend still wants to come to New York. "I love the warmth of my land," is the reply.
Two songs released this year by the group Oro Duro (Hard Gold) reflect the internal conflicts that characterize Dominican views of New York. The first, "Nueva York 'Ta Duro" ("New York Is Hard") describes the difficulty of life in the city, citing harsh welfare reforms, high rents and parking tickets. In the sequel, "Mi Pais 'Ta Duro" ("My Country Is Hard"), the singer describes returning to Santo Domingo after two years, only to be overwhelmed by the poverty, blackouts and epidemics that caused him to leave in the first place. The only feasible option, he concludes, is to move to the moon.
In another merengue, the popular group Cocoband describes a common ritual that takes place when a relative arrives from New York with suitcases full of gifts.
Everyone congratulates you, when you come from over there,
He came with seven suitcases, the man arrived loaded . . .
What has New York got, that makes everyone look so good?
And what did you bring me?
A pair of sneakers.
And what did you bring me?
A polo shirt.
And what did you bring me?
Two boxes of corn flakes.
But some Dominicans borrow money to fill those suitcases; others rent jewelry to project an image of success. "They'll come back to New York totally broke," said Greta Gilbertson, a professor of sociology at Fordham University who studies Dominican migration to New York, "but they've fulfilled their social obligation."
 
The Returnees: 'Dominican Yorks'
Dominicans who return to Santo Domingo to live are known as "Dominican Yorks." Some come back with enough money to settle comfortably, rising several rungs on the socioeconomic ladder upon their return. Others have simply tired of the United States. Still others might be children sent back by the parents for disciplinary or academic reasons. Some who have never left see the Dominican Yorks as further proof that the city means success; others consider their ostentatious behavior reprehensible, proof that living in New York corrupts values.
In the 1980's, a particularly pretentious category of Dominican Yorks captured the spotlight. They were known as "cadenuses" because of the heavy gold chains (in Spanish, cadenas) they wore that linked them in people's minds with New York's illegal drug trade.
Alberto Escoto, a Dominican factory worker who moved to the Bronx with his family in 1992 and now lives near Yankee Stadium, remembers the influences the brazen returnees had on young Dominicans in Villa Duarte, the poor sector of the capital where he grew up. "They came from New York with a lot of money," he said. "They stood on the corner, treating people to beers, handing out 500-peso bills to show the neighborhood they had power. People would mob them, saying give me this, give me that."
Dominican Yorks sometimes lead double lives, spending part of the year in New York and the rest in the Dominican Republic. Sociologists call such a way of life transnationalism, and attribute its recent rise to technological advances in communication and transportation. Although transnationalism is increasingly common among many immigrant groups, it is particularly resonant for Dominicans, whose native land is even closer and often cheaper to fly to than California.
Aura Fernandez leads a typical transnational life style. She lives part of the year with her three brothers in Downtown Brooklyn, where she does seasonal factory work, and spends the rest with her husband and children in Juma, a rural village. Signs of Dominican York abound in her tidy island home: new appliances, a Toyota Camry in a town where cars are exceedingly rare, a HIP health plan T-shirt drying on a stone wall in the backyard.
She is seeking so-called green cards, residency cards, for her family. When permission is granted, she and her husband will decide whether to relocate permanently. Their two sons and their stepdaughter are "dying to go," Ms. Fernandez said. The family's prosperity has influenced the neighbors' children as well. Mercedita Vallejo and her brother Fermin want to emigrate, but their only relative in New York is an undocumented older brother.
Some Dominicans are repelled by what they consider the decadence of many Dominican Yorks. Luis Manuel Lora of Santiago, a member of a working-class family who attends the Autonomous University of Santo Domingo, was shocked when an 11-year-old acquaintance returned home, asked Luis whether he smoked, suggested that he get an earring and demanded to know whether he was still a virgin.
Nowhere is disdain for Dominican Yorks more prominent than among those who stayed and did well. Victor Perez, 37, who grew up poor, now works as a banker, living comfortably in Santiago. Like many other professionals who struggled to make it at home, he says that in his opinion returnees took the easy way out.
"Even if they have money, they have no education," Mr. Perez said. "When a nonimmigrant Dominican looks for an apartment or builds a house, he wants to see who his neighbors are going to be, to make sure there are no Dominican Yorks."
 
Risking Their Lives On a Rickety 'Titanic'
In Miches, a quiet fishing town on the northeast coast where every other street light is burned out and packs of stray dogs roam the streets after midnight, the imprint of migration is everywhere. In the town square, Amanda Linares, 14, sucks the juice from a stalk of sugar cane and adjusts her Yankee cap. Her mother, who lives in New York, recently filed the paperwork for Amanda to join her.
At one of the city's money exchange agencies, between $3,000 and $4,000 arrives daily, a small part of the $1.5 billion that comes into the country annually from immigrants in the United States but "a big chunk of change here in Miches," said Gricelda Reyes, who works in the office.
At the Amparo Bakery, a group of men sit on plastic chairs drinking Presidente beer. They include Fernando Amparo, who spent eight years in New Jersey and New York and returned with $5,000 to run the family bakery-cafeteria; Elvis Pimentel, who grew up in the Bronx and is in town for six months visiting relatives; and Rafael Candelaria, the local district attorney, who has never been to the United States. Speaking a fluid mixture of Bronx street English and proper Dominican Spanish, they flip the channels on the television set between a National Hockey League game and ESPN.
The biggest sign of immigration here is the yolas. Miches is best known as a departure point for the rickety wooden boats that transport Dominicans across the shark-inhabited waters of the Mona Passage to Puerto Rico, where many continue to New York. Despite stepped-up enforcement by local authorities, Dominicans from throughout the country descend on Miches, paying up to $1,000 to risk their lives to enter the United States illegally. Mr. Candelaria remembers one large vessel nicknamed "the Titanic," an allusion to both its size and possible fate. No one knows just how many people drown on yola trips, but almost everyone agrees the number is significant.
Jose Manuel Fabian, 30, a driver of a motorcycle taxi, has spent his life savings on four unsuccessful trips from Miches. The fourth time the yola went off course, and 120 passengers spent eight days at sea before they were picked up and returned home. He spent three days in the hospital recovering from dehydration. Yet he would go again tomorrow, he says, "even if New York was breaking into pieces."
 
The Other Side, Looking Back
Dominicans who immigrate typically romanticize their home country as much as they once romanticized New York. Dominican businesses are frequently named after their owners' hometowns. Dominican newspapers are flown in daily. The word "alla" literally means "there," but is used as a synonym for "Santo Domingo." A few weeks ago, La Banda Gorda released a merengue, "Aqui, pero alla" ("Here but There"), which, despite its upbeat rhythm, captures the longing felt by so many.
I'm here, but my mind is there,
And I don't lose hope that one day I will return
I had to leave my country in search of a future
I came loaded with dreams, but they died here
It wasn't as I thought, or how I imagined
My people are so different, I want to go back.

 CORRECTION:
The main front-page article in this section last Sunday, about perceptions of New York City in the Dominican Republic, misstated the number of daily flights from there to New York on American Airlines. The figure of "about 30 flights a day" to Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark Airports includes trips that require connecting flights. On a typical day American has five nonstop flights from the Dominican Republic to Kennedy and two others that make one intermediate stop.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Toyota Echo;
An Odd Lesson in College Economics

BYLINE: By DAN LIENERT 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
AFTER pulling me over at 1:30 a.m. on a recent Thursday, Trooper Antone Wilson of the Massachusetts State Police offered an enthusiastic, Bostonian "How ah yah?" followed by a more pointed question: "Is this car gas or electric?"
The new-for-2000 Toyota Echo had caught the eye of Trooper Wilson as I drove down Commonwealth Avenue. He had stopped me to discuss the car's merits. 
 What's going on here? Sure, police officers might flag down a Plymouth Prowler for a closer look, but why would they even notice an entry-level Toyota like this two-door Echo, a car that shares subcompact status with nearly invisible appliances like the Hyundai Accent and the Daewoo Lanos?
Because the Echo stands out in the cluttered bargain basement of the new-car market. The small Toyota is unusual in several ways, but its unorthodox styling makes it impossible to ignore.
Undeniably, the Echo makes a statement. But just what is it saying?
Trooper Wilson, who appeared to be in his 30's, is a bit older than the Echo's target market: 20-somethings like me and my friends. Toyota expects the car to generate a buzz on campuses; to test this premise, I, a 20-year-old Harvard University student, took the keys for a week. I loaded an Echo with my friends and drove around Boston, the higher-education capital of the world, seeking the opinions of other students.
Some liked it. Some didn't. But everybody -- and I mean everybody -- had something to say about the Echo's design.
For instance, Amanda Gill, a Harvard junior from Atlanta, said the car looked "insectlike" and "buggish." Indeed, with its stunted front end and awkwardly high roof, the Echo looks as if someone had pushed it into a wall. Oddly enough, many spectators found the quirky design charming.
Sean Boyland, 19, a Boston native, called the car "unapologetic and fun" -- a characteristic that may limit its appeal to conservative car shoppers. "No one will know what to make of this," Mr. Boyland said.
Jay Chaffin, 21, an actor from Hammonton, N.J., was flabbergasted, particularly by the pinched-looking front end. "If this car were a dog," he said, "it would be a pug."
John D. Couriel, a 21-year-old from Miami who plans to attend law school, was lukewarm, too, but gave the Echo a closer look when told of its economic virtues.
With a base price of $9,995 (plus a destination charge of $455), territory usually reserved for somewhat unpolished Korean imports, the Echo calls out to cost-conscious buyers. The car particularly stands out because of the specificity with which Toyota has singled out young consumers.
Don Esmond, group vice president and general manager of the Toyota Division, said the Echo was "the first in a line of new vehicles being developed by Toyota to appeal to the specific, distinct demands of younger new-car buyers." The car is being heavily promoted on the World Wide Web, and the percentage of its advertising budget that goes to network television is unusually low -- just 30 percent, compared with 70 percent for other Toyota products.
 So what, in particular, should put the Echo on the shopping lists of students and other newly licensed drivers? Here are a few compelling reasons:
 
* Its price. At a range of $10,450 to $14,200, the car's low cost of admission is its single defining characteristic.
 
* Its brand name. Toyota's sterling reputation for quality should give the Echo an edge over low-priced rivals from the likes of Kia, Daewoo, Hyundai and maybe even Chevrolet and Dodge. On the quality front, only the Honda Civic -- and possibly, the Ford Focus, though it's too soon to tell -- have as strong an image.
 
* Its space. With a cabin that is exceptionally vertical, the Echo is truly roomy for up to four people. With 39.9 inches of headroom in front and 37.6 in the back, my 6-foot-2 frame fit comfortably in every seat, a feat unequaled in two-door Cavaliers, Civics, Saturns and Mitsubishi Mirages.
 
* Its performance. The Echo is solid in every way, easily surpassing the low expectations raised by its price. The 16-valve four-cylinder engine is small -- just 1.5 liters -- but it has a sophisticated design unequaled at the price, with dual overhead cams and variable valve timing for high efficiency and steady delivery of power. It puts out a respectable 108 horsepower, and with a five-speed manual transmission its pep should disappoint no one shopping in this class.
 
* Its fuel economy. The mileage rating (34 city, 41 highway, according to Environmental Protection Agency estimates) is among the best for gasoline-powered cars.
 
* Its ride and handling. The body is tight and very quiet, with light, user-friendly steering. What the car may lack in world-class manners -- its turning circle and suspension are adequate, at best -- it makes up for with its maneuverable size and enough zip to get out of a jam.
True, only a lapse in judgment would cause anyone to drive in Boston, but the Echo was nimble enough to easily negotiate the Hub's roads, which are straight out of the 17th century, and compensate for its drivers, who are straight out of "A Clockwork Orange."
And the Echo is certainly easier to parallel-park than those sport-utility vehicles with which my generation is so preoccupied.
The Echo makes another compelling case for itself from within, with a cabin that is nearly as eccentric as the exterior design. The interior has a clean, spartan feel. I don't know if the minimalist interior design was determined by aesthetics or by cost-cutting. (Is the center-mounted speedometer there for looks or to reduce the expense of converting the car from right-hand drive?) But the design works in a way that is appealing without feeling bare.
Perhaps this is because the Echo makes substantial allowances for a defining feature of my generation: our stuff. Toyota has riddled the car with storage spaces, including large door pockets, bins for tapes and CD's all around the audio system, dual cup holders in front and back, and an especially neat clamshell glovebox that opens in two parts to reveal two shelves.
Despite a $1,020 upgrade package on the model I tested -- with options, the sticker price was $12,945 -- comforts like power mirrors, windows and locks were missing.
Small-car shoppers will, no doubt, stack the Echo up against the Focus. Both represent new and unconventional efforts in a fairly boring market; both are high and deceptively spacious inside, with large windows that provide excellent visibility, and both ride and drive better than the run of the small-car pack. The more expensive Focus does have a slight performance edge, with its larger engine and tighter handling, and it has more standard features -- some for the young, like a CD player on the ZX3 and ZTS models, and some for the grown-up, like a tachometer. Not only that, the Focus alone offers side air bags for an extra $350.
Although Toyota disappoints by offering only an AM-FM stereo on the stripper model, buyers can toss in an extra $170 and get a cassette deck and six quite decent speakers.
So far, the Echo-Focus race is too close to call. But it is fair to say that the Echo's ride and comfort are among the best in this class. And the bottom line is that this is a solid car for a low price. So the appeal of the Echo comes back to design, and a subjective question: Does the look work for you?
Young people here seemed willing to at least give the Echo a chance. This would seem to be less a result of Toyota's explicit marketing to them than of the price. Given the poverty levels of most people my age, demand for the car will ultimately rest on its value, which is considerable.
 Let's put it this way: I'm 20 years old, and my interest in the Echo would be strictly economic. I wouldn't say the car looks or feels particularly young, despite Toyota's concerted efforts to present it as a car for the "Net generation," and the company's marketing reliance on the Internet.
Still, the styling of the Echo is unconventional for the explicit purpose of appealing to a younger market. At some points, Toyota goes a little over the top. One choice for exterior color is Absolutely Red. As opposed to what? Somewhat Red?
The opinions of friends and passersby confirm that although the Echo is eye-catching, it's not necessarily hip. "I've never seen a car like that before," said David Joffe, 21, a Harvard student from New York. "And I hope I never do again."
 
INSIDE TRACK: Screwball or savvy? The Echo looks like a little of both.

 CORRECTION:

Although the equipment indeed costs $590, it requires the purchase of two other options, for a total of $2,285 on two-door and $2,330 on four-door models.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Phoenix

BYLINE: By SUZANNE WINCKLER; SUZANNE WINCKLER, who lives in Mesa, writes about natural history.

 BODY:
Winter in the Valley of the Sun is nearing, with its limpid blue skies, opalescent sunsets, cool starry nights and balmy days. No wonder people from the higher latitudes, burdened by subzero wind chills, icy roads and gray days, flock to Phoenix and its sister cities from November to April.
The valley is a sprawling amalgam of a dozen or so communities that budded in barren desert and then spread, thanks to ever more steady supplies of water pumped from underground or siphoned from other places. What looks like a seamless urbanscape from the air is in fact a handful of cities bumping up against each other. 
 Five of them -- Phoenix, Scottsdale, Tempe, Glendale and Mesa -- took root in the 1870's. More than 100 years later, each remains distinct, and their differences make the valley ripe for exploration. Mesa and Glendale, are family towns, while Scottsdale is tony and Tempe, home to Arizona State University, is laid back. Phoenix runs the gamut from urban chic to quiet bungalow neighborhoods.
The unifying chord through these communities is an obsession with water. Today, 1,265 miles of canals shunt it through the valley from reservoirs on the Salt and Verde Rivers, as well from the Colorado. With all this water, the 2.8 million citizens of the valley have created an emerald-green city of grass and swaying palms, where most public spaces -- museums, shopping centers, hotels -- have some sort of babbling sculpture, fountain or sluice.
 
Events
The season's blockbuster at the Phoenix Art Museum, 1625 North Central Avenue, is "Monet at Giverny," which includes 22 large paintings from the Musee Marmottan in Paris, through Jan. 2. Advance ticket purchase is recommended, from (480) 503-5555 locally or (800) 638-4253; tickets are $12 and $6 for children 6 to 12, plus a service charge of a dollar or two.
For a more Southwestern flavor, the museum has "Taos Artists and Their Patrons: 1898-1950," Dec. 18 through March 5. This exhibition offers nearly 100 works by Georgia O'Keeffe, Walter Ufer, Victor Higgins and Ernest Blumenschein, among others. The museum is open daily except Monday. General admission is $7, $5 for ages 65 and up and students, $2 for ages 6 to 18; free on Thursdays. Information: (602) 257-1222 or www.phxart.org.
The Heard Museum, 2301 North Central Avenue, houses the American Indian collections of Dwight and Maie Bartlett Heard, a couple who settled in the Valley in 1895. The museum's Spanish Colonial-style building is on what was their estate, in the historic Los Olivos neighborhood, north of downtown Phoenix. Through March 19, "Powerful Images: Portrayals of Native America" combines pop culture and Indian art to examine contemporary Indian culture, with contributions from 10 North American museums. The museum is open daily. Admission is $7, $6 for ages 65 and up, $3 for ages 4 to 12; (602) 252-8848.
First Fridays, a program of self-guided tours of art galleries and studios in downtown Phoenix, is held from 6 to 10 p.m. on the first Friday of the month from October through June. The next one is this Friday. Information from Artlink, (602) 256-7539.
Las Noches de las Luminarias, Thursday through Saturday at the Desert Botanical Garden, 1201 North Galvin Parkway, is a nocturnal holiday tradition in Phoenix. Visitors stroll along candlelighted pathways through a weirdly wonderful desert scape of saguaro, ocotillo and palo verde and mesquite trees while musicians perform from 5:30 to 9:30 p.m. Tickets, which must be bought in advance, are $12.50, $4 ages 5 to 12. Information: (480) 754-8188.
International Christmas, at the Bank One Center, 201 North Central Avenue in downtown Phoenix, offers treats for the kids. This free festival runs everyday from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M., today through Dec. 30. The centerpieces are 45 decorated trees, representing 45 ethnic cultures from the area, and choral concerts the first two weeks. On Dec. 4, there will be a concert, puppet show and ornament making; (602) 221-1005.
The Phoenix Open, Jan. 24 to 30, billed as the world's best-attended golf tournament (more than 400,000 spectators are expected during the week), is played on the Stadium Course of the Tournament Players Club of Scottsdale, 17020 North Hayden Road, Scottsdale. Although the field has not been set, last year's competitors included Tiger Woods and Justin Leonard. Tickets are $20 a day. Information: (602) 870-4431.
Horses probably rank next to golf as the most popular diversion in the valley. In Scottsdale, WestWorld Equestrian Center, 16601 North Pima Road, has sales, exhibitions and competitions, including the United States Team Roping Championships, Dec. 31 to Jan 2. Most events are free. Information: (480) 312-6802.
 
Sightseeing
With the moderate temperatures from November through April, the best way to get a lay of the land is to park your car and start walking. More than 90 hiking trails weave through metropolitan Phoenix, and AZ Trails, at www.azcentral.com /travel/hiking, has listings that include distances, difficulty and directions.
Among the choices is the Summit Trail on Squaw Peak, (602) 262-7901, a fairly strenuous 2.4-mile round trip, that provides a panoramic view of the city. The Waterfall Canyon Trail in the White Tank Mountains, (623) 935-2505, west of the city, is an easy two-mile trip that goes past Indian petroglyphs carved into boulders on the way to an 80-foot waterfall; much of this trail is accessible by wheelchair.
The 1983 Guide to Architecture of Metro Phoenix, though a tad outdated, is the best introduction to the valley's urban history. It costs $5 from the Central Arizona Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, 802 North Fifth Avenue; (602) 257-1925. The chapter is just north of downtown near several classic 1920's and 30's neighborhoods, including Encanto-Palmcroft, Willo and Coronado. These areas are living museums of such styles as Mission Revival, California Bungalow, Craftsman Bungalow, Art Moderne and International Style.
The palm-tree-lined campus of Arizona State University in Tempe offers a sleek modern setting for people watching. The most avant-garde of the buildings is the A.S.U. Art Museum, Mill Avenue and 10th Street, an Egyptian-looking vault of shimmering pink stucco designed by Antoine Predock. Regardless of what is on display, it's a joy to walk through the subterranean walkway adorned with sculpture and the three levels of large white, echoy galleries; (480) 965-2787.
A glimpse into the future lies a mile west of the campus, at University Avenue and McClintock Drive, where Arizona Public Service's Solar Test and Research (STAR) Center is testing photovoltaic technology. The more than two dozen mirrored contraptions of various sizes and shapes glinting in the sun are beautiful to behold as you drive by. For tours, call (602) 250-4990.
 
Where to Stay
The 107-room Best Western Executive Park Downtown, 1100 North Central Avenue, (602) 252-2100, fax (602) 340-1989, is quiet, comfortable and convenient to museums and other central-city attractions. There is a restaurant, lounge, pool, sauna and exercise area, and in-room modems. Doubles average $110.
Budget: The Tempe Days Inn, 1221 East Apache Boulevard, (480) 968-7793, fax (480) 966-4450, has 102 rooms and is close to the Arizona State campus. Doubles run from $59 in the summer, to $99 in winter.
The Econolodge Scottsdale, 6935 East Fifth Avenue, (480) 994-9461, fax (480) 947-1695, is in the heart of Old Town, an area of shops, restaurants and galleries. It has 92 rooms, with doubles ranging from a summer low of $49 to $94 in February.
Luxury: The Arizona Biltmore Resort and Spa, 24th Street and Missouri Avenue, (800) 950-0086, fax (602) 381-7600, is cloistered within the 1,000-acre Arizona Biltmore Estates at the end of a long and winding road. Designed by Albert Chase McArthur, with assistance from Frank Lloyd Wright, it is a grand, rambling ghost-gray palace with a stark, cool lobby and spare Mission-style furniture. Of the 730 rooms, 120 are in a new wing that opened this month, less than two years after the resort built a spa and fitness area. There are eight swimming pools (including the original Catalina pool, with its gorgeous multicolored tiles), seven tennis courts, a croquet lawn and a chess board with three-foot-tall pieces. Doubles start at $315 now, and winter rates will run from $330 for a double to $1,695 for a two-bedroom villa suite.
In Carefree, 12 miles north of Scottsdale, the Boulders, 34631 North Tom Darlington Drive, (800) 553-1717, fax (480) 488-4118, is a 1,300-acre retreat surrounded by two golf courses and the desert. Guests stay in their own little casitas, each with a deck and fireplace supplied with aromatic shaggy-bark juniper. There are five restaurants and three swimming pools. Rates: $185 in summer to $565 from Jan. 16 to April 29.
 
Where to Eat
Cafe Terra Cotta, 6166 North Scottsdale Road, in the Borgata Scottsdale shopping center, offers such neo-Southwestern dishes as pork tenderloin adobado, corn risotto and pepper filet cooked rare when the customer says rare. The wine list focuses on zinfandels, but numerous other wines and beers are available. Dinner for two with wine costs about $80. Open daily for lunch and dinner; reservations, recommended for evening weekends, at (480) 948-8100.
Marquesa, at the Fairmont Scottsdale Princess Resort, 7575 East Princess Drive, lies at the elegant extreme of dining in the Valley of the Sun. With indoor and patio seating, it specializes in generous portions of Catalan and Mediterranean food served by attentive waiters. Signature dishes include gazpacho, garlic soup and seafood paella. Dinner for two with cocktails and wine costs about $250. Open Tuesday through Saturday for dinner and Sunday for brunch. Reservations recommended, (480) 585-4848.
The Chuck Box, 202 East University Drive in Tempe, is the place for really big hamburgers, fries, onion rings and beer in mason jars. It prides itself on simple decor, with Arizona ranch and cowboy photos on the walls. A meal for two with beer costs about $15; (480) 968-4712.
Mrs. White's Golden Rule Cafe, 808 East Jefferson Street, is a downtown landmark, serving Southern-style plate lunches, including smothered chicken. Two can eat for less than $12. Open 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Friday; (602) 262-9256.
A fine and friendly example of the city's many family-owned Mexican restaurants is Los Picos, 1542 West University Drive in Mesa, which focuses on seafood dishes from Mexico's Pacific Coast, like Sinaloa-style coctel de camaron with shrimp, salsa, cucumber and avocado. Dinner for two with appetizer and beer costs about $30. Breakfast, lunch and dinner daily; (480) 833-4711.

HEADLINE: Shaping The Future In Seattle

BYLINE: By Bill Gates; Bill Gates is the chairman of Microsoft.

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
This week, representatives from more than 130 countries will gather here for a meeting that will help set the global economic agenda for years to come. The greater the success of this meeting at establishing fair and predictable conditions for expanded world trade, the better the future prospects not only for our own economy but for global prosperity.
The World Trade Organization is the principal organization dedicated to developing international trade rules, maintaining nations' access to one another's markets, resolving trade disputes and encouraging trade liberalization. This round of meetings will provide an important opportunity to explore ways that government, industry, interest groups and the public can work together to ensure the continued expansion of free, open and fair trade. 
 I became co-chairman of the Seattle host organization for this event because I believe that fair and open international trade is good not only for companies that depend on exports; it is good for the global economy and for opening up lines of communication and progress throughout the world.
Perhaps more than any other city in America, Seattle illustrates the benefits of global commerce. More than $34 billion in exports flow through our region's ports each year, making the Seattle-Tacoma region the nation's No. 1 exporter. One of every three jobs in Washington State is directly tied to international trade -- exports, imports or both -- and the figure is much higher in the Seattle area itself. Our region is vivid proof that trade creates jobs and bolsters wages, stimulates economic growth, expands consumer choice and ultimately increases productivity and competitiveness.
At Microsoft, overseas sales of our software products totaled $10 billion last year, nearly two-thirds of our revenues. Another company in our region, Boeing, is America's largest exporter, shipping $30 billion in aircraft and other goods and services overseas last year. A third, Weyerhaeuser, shipped more than $1 billion in wood and wood products to 60 nations. And our region's farmers shipped nearly $2 billion in wheat, apples, livestock and other products to literally dozens of countries.
And Seattle's story is increasingly the nation's. The economic health of the United States as a whole is increasingly based on international trade. Thanks in part to lower trade barriers and strong exports, our economy is the strongest it has been in a generation. International trade can continue to drive domestic economic growth and job creation, so long as we have the appropriate global framework in place.
The World Trade Organization provides its member countries with exactly that: a forum for negotiating agreements that remove barriers to the free exchange of goods and services and for resolving trade disputes before nations take unilateral actions that could threaten millions of jobs and global economic progress. If the W.T.O. didn't exist, the nations of the world would have to invent it.
The recent agreement to bring China into the trade group has the potential to open new opportunities for American goods and services, ultimately benefiting the United States as well as China and the rest of the world. Those of us who helped arrange the conference hope significant strides will be made here to help bring this agreement closer to fruition, and we will continue to encourage Congress to ratify the agreement and support permanently improved trade relations with China.
Trade affects virtually every community and every industry, and high technology is no exception. The W.T.O. agenda includes a number of issues critical to the continued growth of the American high-tech industry, which now accounts for more than 8 percent of the American economy and one-third of our economic growth in recent years.
The high-technology industry supports creation of a "tariff-free zone" for economic transactions over the Internet, as well as other free-trade steps to encourage the growth of electronic commerce. We support consistent international rules for the electronic marketplace to give companies the confidence to invest and consumers the benefit of greater choice. And we encourage the trade organization to finish putting in place the international treaty for protection of intellectual property rights, which is fundamental to the continued strength of American technology companies.
In addition to providing a meeting place for the governmental delegations, Seattle expects visits from thousands of citizens and advocacy groups. Their concern emphasizes the effect that international commerce increasingly has on every aspect of our lives, from the environment and public health to education and international labor standards.
The Seattle meetings will provide opportunities for a wide range of viewpoints to be heard, and the W.T.O. needs to continue its efforts to open up the dialogue and provide more opportunity for citizens and advocacy groups to follow its work.
Regardless of one's view on any single issue, one fact cannot be disputed: The world we live in is changing. Borders and barriers are coming down; actions in one corner of the world will affect people around the globe. The World Trade Organization will play a vital role as we learn to adapt to a new world economy.

LENGTH: 1144 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Gifts for Celebrating the Century or Just Relaxing

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:
Well, they finally did it. The publisher Benedikt Taschen has issued a book called "Sumo," a collection of photographs by Helmut Newton, edited by his wife, June Newton. Which may sound innocent enough. But here's the thing: it's 465 pages long, measures 20 by 28 by 4 inches, weighs 66 pounds and comes with its own chromed stainless-steel folding table designed by Philippe Starck. So the dream of Seinfeld's Kramer of a coffee-table book that is actually a coffee table has been all but realized.
Because "Sumo" bears a price tag of $1,500, a review copy was understandably not sent to this office. I therefore can't recommend it as a gift this season. But the following books, arranged by ascending price, will do very well in its place. 
 INTERNET COOL GUIDE, edited by Rula Razek. Designed by Tika Buchanan and James Tung of Eric Baker Design Associates, N.Y. (187 pages. Te Neues Publishing Company. Paperback, $14.95.) O.K., so this guide to the 1,000 best Web sites will probably be obsolete by the day after tomorrow. But in the meantime there's lots of useful advice here on search engines and how to use them for everything from buying a car online to playing chess against Gary Kasparov. And you can get updates on www.internetcoolguide.com.
HOME COMFORTS: The Art and Science of Keeping House, by Cheryl Mendelson. Illustrations by Harry Bates. (884 pages. Scribner. $35.) A guide to all the domestic arts -- from choosing fabrics to folding sheets to mending book bindings to throwing out old documents -- by an articulate, witty woman who is a philosopher, lawyer, sometime professor and a homemaker, wife and mother all rolled into one.
SAVEUR COOKS AUTHENTIC FRENCH, by the editors of Saveur Magazine. Designed by Jill Armus, Michael Grossman and Amy Henderson. (320 pages. Chronicle Books. $40.) This sequel to last year's "Saveur Cooks Authentic American" explores the traditions of French cuisine -- particularly those of Burgundy, Alsace, the Southwest, Provence and a few others -- and is packed with illustrations that look good enough to . . . well, send you out looking for truffles, duck's liver and frog's legs.
FULL MOON, by Michael Light. Essay by Andrew Chaikin. (Unpaged. Alfred A. Knopf. $50.) In case you haven't gone there yet, these magnificent two-page (and occasionally four-page) spreads, newly released by NASA, capture the visual sensation of landing on, walking around and taking off from the mysteriously beautiful landscape of the Moon. Published on the 30th anniversary of Apollo II, the first moon voyage, it answers some of the questions posed by Les Paul and Mary Ford in the song "How High the Moon?"
Looking in another direction, namely back over the last hundred years, the following four volumes view the 20th century from multiple perspectives. The first -- CENTURY: One Hundred Years of Human Progress, Regression, Suffering and Hope, conceived and edited by Bruce Bernard (1,120 pages; Phaidon Press; $49.95) -- is a history told in more than 1,100 photographs, many familiar, some never before published. The juxtapositions are often shocking -- President John F. Kennedy at a street party in Ireland across from the moment of the second Oswald shot -- and remind you that these truly have been the best and worst of times. The next two -- THE AMERICAN CENTURY: Art and Culture 1900-1950; by Barbara Haskell (408 pages; $60) and THE AMERICAN CENTURY: Art and Culture 1950-2000, by Lisa Phillips (398 pages; $60; both published by the Whitney Museum of American Art, New York, in association with W. W. Norton) -- offer rich records of the recent shows at the Whitney, considering American art as a response to political, social and economics conditions, and tracing its expression in painting, sculpture, photography, architecture, film, literature, dance, theater, music and the decorative arts. And finally, THE LOOK OF THE CENTURY, by Michael Tambini (288 pages; DK Publishing; $39.95), a striking visual record of how changes in taste have been reflected in everything from furniture to cereal boxes, from Coca-Cola bottles to the Porsche 911.
As always the Bronx is up and the Battery's down in NEW YORK: An Illustrated History; narrative by Ric Burns and James Sanders; picture editor, Lisa Ades (575 pages; Alfred A. Knopf; $60) and NEW YORK 1880: Architecture and Urbanism in the Gilded Age, by Robert A. M. Stern, Thomas Mellins and David Fishman (1,164 pages; Monacelli Press; $85). But the first, a companion to the PBS television series, also shows the city from its beginnings to the present, while the second concentrates on a period of great technological change that transformed the city from a harbor town to a world-class metropolis.
WOMEN. Photographs by Annie Leibovitz. Essay by Susan Sontag. (239 pages. Random House. $75.) The haunting images in this mesmerizing book show women in such astonishing variety that no cliche or generalization about the sex will ever again suffice.
Here are two volumes filled with waters so beautiful that one finds it hard to understand how anyone could resist the sport of fishing. The first, TROUT AND SALMON. Photography by R. Valentine Atkinson (176 pages; Lyons Press; $39.95), sends you all over the world: to Ireland, Chile, Norway and Russia, among other places ridden with magnificent fish. The second, LAND OF LITTLE RIVERS: A Story in Photos of Catskill Fly Fishing, by Austin McK. Francis; photography by Enrico Ferorelli (279 pages; Beaverkill Press; distributed by W. W. Norton. $100), zeroes in on the birthplace of American fly fishing and shows you not only fish and waters but also the people and equipment that helped to develop a great sport.
AFRICAN CEREMONIES, by Carol Beckwith and Angela Fisher. (Two volumes slip-cased: Vol. 1, 384 pages; Vol. 2, 360 pages. Harry N. Abrams, $150.) A monumental survey in pictures and text of tribal rituals, rites and ceremonies across the entire continent, spanning the human life cycle, birth, puberty, courtship and marriage, illness and death. Arresting views, often forbidden to outsiders, into the heart of humanity.
THE BEST OF FLAIR. Edited by Fleur Cowles. Foreword by Dominick Dunne. (337 pages. Rizzoli International Publications. Boxed, $250.) Remember Flair magazine (which ran for 12 months, February 1950 to January 1951), with its elegant design and its accordion foldouts once celebrated in a New Yorker cartoon showing a reader with an extra arm and hand, and its reputation for being either too lavish or too far ahead of its time? You don't? Well, here's the best of it, with prose by Winston Churchill, George Bernard Shaw and Tallulah Bankhead, among others, and with lots of pages to keep your two hands busy. In a bright red folding box that will look great on the coffee table even if you never crack it open.
And a happy holiday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Waiting for 2000, wondering if the economy will keep surging and watching for Fed signals.

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
WITH about a month left in the millennium, the three major stock indexes are poised to record annual returns of more than 10 percent each for the fifth year in a row -- an unprecedented streak.
But the wealth generated by the indexes' gains may also pose the biggest threat to a repeat performance in 2000. 
 If the indexes keep rising, some economists argue, the stock market will continue to fuel consumer spending. Such buying makes it unlikely that the economy, which surged at a 5.5 percent annual growth rate in the third quarter, will slow enough to satisfy Federal Reserve policy makers. The Fed will then be forced to raise short-term interest rates, adding to its three quarter-point increases since June. And higher rates could spook equity investors if they conclude that the economy and earnings growth will finally slow significantly.
"If the stock market continues to go up at the rate we have had in the last couple of months, the Fed will be unhappy and raise interest rates," said Stephen D. Slifer, the chief United States economist at Lehman Brothers.
The Dow Jones industrial average has jumped almost 1,000 points, or 9.7 percent, in six weeks. In the same period, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks is up 13.6 percent , while the Nasdaq index has surged 26.2 percent. In light holiday trading Friday, the Dow slipped 19.26 points to 10,988.91, while the S.& P. 500 fell 0.46 point, to 1,416.62. But the Nasdaq rose 27.31 points to a new high of 3,447.81.
Stocks were higher earlier in the day after the government reported that personal income jumped 1.3 percent in October, the largest monthly gain in five-and-a-half years.
Mr. Slifer suspects that these rallies have given a new impetus to consumer spending and housing construction, and in turn may reverse the slight slowing in economic growth that was reflected in flat retail sales in September and October, a slowdown in automobile sales those months and a plunge in new home sales in September.
While he cannot be sure yet, he sees possible signs of new economic vigor in the jump in the consumer confidence index back to its recent highs and the return to the highs of this summer in the home purchase index.
"While we are seeing a few signs of slower growth right now," he said, "if these new signals are right, we will see faster growth a couple of months down the road."
Because of this, he said, he is tempted to raise his already strong outlook of 4.3 percent growth for the fourth quarter and is considering the addition of a Fed rate increase to his year 2000 forecast. He had expected the increase earlier this month to be the last for the near future.
Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, has already added a Fed rate increase to his forecast. "I think the economy is going to remain strong through all of next year," he said.
Since the Fed raised its interest rate target on federal funds, which is the rate banks lend money to one another overnight, a quarter of a percentage point to 5.5 percent on Nov. 16, bond investors have worried about the persistent strength in the economy and the possibility of more rate increases. But stock investors do not appear to have skipped a beat.
The divergence in views is obvious in the markets' performance. Since then, the Nasdaq index has moved to six new highs, the S.& P. 500 to two and the Dow, until Friday, was back to more than 11,000 points the first time since Sept. 13.
But the bond market has sold off. In a short day of trading Friday, the price of the 30-year bond fell 13/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.23 percent from 6.20 percent Wednesday and 6.02 percent the day before the Fed rate increase. The yield on the two-year note, which is more sensitive to the threat of a Fed rate move, rose Friday to 5.98 percent from 5.94 percent Wednesday and 5.75 percent before the Fed's action.
One factor that has blunted fears about a strong economy next year is the belief that the Federal Reserve's speed limit for acceptable growth has risen. While no one knows the actual number, analysts suspect it is about 3 percent to 3.5 percent, rather than the 2 percent to 2.5 percent of years past. The reason for the change is a sharp rise in productivity, which means workers are producing more goods at the same cost and keeping inflation pressures more subdued.
Mr. Steinberg expects the gross domestic product to grow 3.7 percent next year, while Mr. Slifer sees a more modest 3.4 percent. So the economy may attain an acceptable level without more rate increases.
But if growth in the fourth quarter comes in as expected at more than 4 percent, the pace of the last six months will be about 5 percent. And assuming that the economy will be easy to slow contradicts its performance over the last several years.
Fed policy makers signaled this problem in the statement that accompanied their last rate increase. "Despite tentative evidence of a slowing in certain interest-sensitive sectors of the economy and of accelerating productivity," they said, "the expansion of activity continues in excess of the economy's growth potential. As a consequence, the pool of available workers willing to take jobs has been drawn down further in recent months, a trend that must eventually be contained if inflationary imbalances are to remain in check and economic expansion continue."
Policy makers added that the three rate increases this year, along with the rise in market interest rates, "should markedly diminish the risk of inflation going forward."
Mr. Slifer, who has been confident that prices are in check, admits to "getting a tad nervous" as he looks at the recent rise in the prices of oil and new and used cars. "We are pushing this envelope as far as we can push it," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The Super Bowl is attracting a crowd of new competitors.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IF Beethoven were commissioned to rewrite his Fifth Symphony for Super Bowl XXXIV, he would undoubtedly begin this way: "Dot, dot, dot, com. Dot, dot, dot, com."
The mad scramble by Internet companies to increase recognition of their brand names by advertising in traditional media outlets will accelerate on Super Sunday, typically the biggest day of the year for Madison Avenue. Dot-coms are paying record prices -- an estimated average of more than $2 million for each 30-second commercial during the game, which is at least 25 percent higher than the 1999 rate -- to elbow their way into the ranks of mainstay Super Bowl advertisers like automobiles, beers, credit cards and soft drinks. 
 For the first time, a dot-com, the E*Trade Group, will even sponsor the halftime show, until now the province of purveyors of prosaic products like lunch meat.
"The dot-coms need to generate awareness and attention, to introduce themselves to the public, to get noticed by Wall Street," said Joe Mandese, editor of The Myers Report, a media industry newsletter. "What better way to do that than the ultimate advertising event?"
To be sure, the big gamble by the dot-coms that the exposure gained during the game on Jan. 30 will be worth the expense could be proved wrong. If the performance of their pitches is deemed sufficiently weak, what was intended as a shrewd business move could backfire badly. Not only might those dot-coms not be back for Super Bowl XXXV, they might not be in business by then either.
"There's going to be a major-league shakeout," said Gene DeWitt, president and chief executive at DeWitt Media in New York, which buys commercial time and ad space for advertisers.
"They all seem to have decided it's live or die, spending gobs of money," he added. "There's a kind of desperation to it."
Of the estimated 30 companies buying commercial time during the game, which will be broadcast by ABC, a dozen or so will be dot-coms. That is four times as many as last year. In fact, that is more than have appeared during all previous Super Bowls combined.
The estimated 125 million American viewers of Super Bowl XXXIV will see commercials for companies like Angeltips.com, Computer.com, Kforce.com, Ourbeginning.com, Pets.com and Screaming Media, all seeking to draw traffic to their Web sites or sell various online goods and services.
"The Super Bowl is the one time of the year when the viewers look forward to the commercials," said Jon Mandel, co-managing director at Mediacom in New York, the media services arm of Grey Advertising.
"It's a one-of-a-kind event," he added, "reaching everybody: men, women, children, pets. If you're trying to stand out, it's the place to be." Grey is creating a Super Bowl commercial for Kforce.com, a job search Web site owned by Romac International that is formally known as the Knowledge Force Network.
"It's a very intense, hyperconcentrated atmosphere for these companies, some of which you've heard of and some of which are coming in cold," said Ted Sann, co-chief executive and chief creative officer at BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, which will create Super Bowl work for the Charles Schwab online brokerage division as well as advertisers without dots like Federal Express, PepsiCo and Visa.
"There's a potential for confusion because the dot-com category will be so cluttered, so they're going to have to differentiate themselves on the spot," he added. "If they don't have an execution that's incredibly good, absolutely riveting, they'll just be throwing the money away."
And what money it is. The estimated average of more than $2 million for each 30 seconds of commercial time compares with the estimated average of $1.6 million charged by the News Corporation's Fox Broadcasting unit for each 30-second spot during Super Bowl XXXIII.
"If ABC could add a fifth quarter, they'd do it," Mr. DeWitt said.
Because of the demand from dot-coms, as well as the overall strength of the advertising market, commercial time during the game is almost sold out, though nine weeks remain before kickoff. Reflecting that bull market, ABC is selling some of the last commercial slots left for prices estimated at $3 million each.
"The dot-coms recognize they need that quick and effective reach to drive people to their sites," said Marv Goldsmith, president for sales and marketing at the ABC Television Network in New York, part of the ABC unit of the Walt Disney Company. "And several are coming in on a competitive basis, reacting to each other."
For instance, besides the Kforce job search Web site, which is a newcomer to the Super Bowl, two other job-search sites are buying spots -- Hotjobs.com and Monster.com, part of TMP Worldwide. Both are returning from last year.
"It's obvious why we're back: the Super Bowl really worked for us," said Dean Harris, senior vice president for marketing at Hotjobs.com in New York. "It drew traffic to our site and grew our business."
But this year will be tougher. "Last year, people hadn't been asked to remember as many dot-com brands," said Edward Boches, chief creative officer at Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., Monster.com's agency that is part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. "Now it won't be as easy as putting a name up on the screen with a dot-com after it."
"You're going to have to give people a real reason why, make them take a course of action," said Mr. Boches, whose agency is also creating a spot for Oxygen Media, a Web site and cable TV network aimed at women. "That puts more pressure on the advertising."
Julie Wainwright, chief executive at Pets.com in San Francisco, said, "You have to have a strategy, a point of differentiation." The commercial for Pets.com by the San Francisco office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom, will emphasize the Web site's breadth of merchandise as well as its mascot, a sock-puppet dog.
The creative content of most dot-com commercials tends to be frenetic, cheeky, sometimes deliberately provocative, to help the spots stand out. That affects not only the other dot-coms but also other advertisers.
"When you know the commercials will be interesting, different, contemporary, exciting, it keeps you on your toes," said Tony Ponturo, vice president for media and sports marketing at Anheuser-Busch in St. Louis, which for the 12th consecutive year will be the exclusive beer advertiser during the Super Bowl. "It makes you lean forward and make sure you're sharp as well.
"Our estimates are that there's $500 million to $700 million of dot-com money in the marketplace," he added. "That's huge, more than the beer category."
If by some chance the commercials for brews like Budweiser and Bud Light fare poorly with viewers and critics on Jan. 30, Anheuser-Busch will open for business come Jan. 31. That may not be true for some dot-coms.
"There'll be smart money out there and there'll be dumb money out there," said Michael Sievert, vice president for marketing at E*Trade in Menlo Park, Calif. "Unlike the 'newbie' entrants in the dot-com marketing craze, our approach is investment, not expenditures.
"The dot-com clutter in some cases helps us because we're one of the top four e-commerce brands," he added. "The more focus and attention on the Internet space, the more focus and attention there is on the leaders." E*Trade will spend an estimated $3.8 million on its halftime show sponsorship and accompanying commercials by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of Omnicom.
"We all have a concern whether or not this pays off," acknowledged Jorge Cauz, senior vice president for Britannica.com in Chicago, which will run a Super Bowl spot created by Deutsch Inc. in New York. "But we feel we're taking a calculated risk."
He added: "Most dot-com brands were not here two years ago, a year ago, the day before yesterday. We have a brand that's 231 years old, so we're not coming to the dot-com environment as a fly-by-night. The fact we're Britannica will make people ask 'What are they doing on the Internet?' "
Whither the clamor for Super Bowl commercial time if the dot-com boom goes bust? What primarily determines whether rates rise or fall is the health of the general economy. And for now at least, as Mr. Mandese noted, "there's still huge demand from existing advertisers" like "direct-to-consumer pharmaceuticals, telecommunications and financial companies."
CBS, which is to broadcast the Super Bowl in January 2001, has traded equity stakes in several dot-coms for commercial time. Some of those spots could certainly run during Super Bowl XXXV.
That inspired Mr. Mandese to predict "the first deal for an advertiser to trade equity to a network specifically for a Super Bowl spot."
And of course, Super Bowl mishaps are not confined to dot-coms. Take Just for Feet, a retail chain that was a first-time Super Bowl advertiser last January. Its commercial was roundly criticized as offensive. Then problems like an ill-timed expansion and changes in footwear fashion led the company to file for Federal bankruptcy protection.
The result: the first Super Bowl spot from Just for Feet may very well have been its last.
"You don't have to be a dot-com to be stupid," said Mr. DeWitt of DeWitt Media.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
In Prosperity, Nagging Pangs Of Uneasiness

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
Consider this a letter to a friend.
It's not, of course. Who writes letters in this era of e-mail and cell phones? So, O.K., this is not really a letter to a friend, but letters to (and from) friends are great journalistic devices to create an instant sense of perspective.
Hence, a letter to this friend, a former New Yorker. Now living in L.A. 
 November 1999
 
DEAR, uh, Friend,
I haven't written in nearly three years -- a virtual generation in the life of a city, certainly in this ever-evolving place that you once called home.
I thought you'd like to know how it's doing.
It has changed -- moving in the direction it was going when you left, and in most ways that direction was up.
The city still feels safer, Midtown streets are thronged and Times Square is a fantasyland, more and more so. Dazzling lights, disappeared sleaze, stores filled with Disney and Disney-like tchotchkes, TV studios, lights, camera, action.
Tourists are all over the place, which helps the tone of the city, helps businesses, even helps the street people -- from the panhandlers to the portrait artists, mostly immigrants who turn block after block into minicarnivals.
Parts of the city are so fat that even the wealthy gasp at the price of apartments. And gentrification is out of control -- great for those with money, awful for those without, many of them illegal immigrants already living in closets.
Traffic is terrible, but other cities have it worse. And our water is still good (though environmentalists are getting queasy; but that's for another letter).
I guess what this all boils down to is: If you are wealthy, or at least comfortable, New York City is a great place to live now, and affluence, while it eludes many, trickles down to others.
And yet, and yet. Having lived through more cycles in this city than I care to remember, I have this disquieting feeling about where we are going.
I worry about what we are not doing with our affluence, how we are ignoring problems or sweeping them out of sight, how the politicians often need a crisis or tragedy to act, even when they know the solution, how the mayor always turns to the police, and keeps assaulting the First Amendment.
I worry that it takes a woman's death at the hands of a disturbed man to shake up Albany. Not until that tragedy did the governor and Legislature focus on the problem of mentally ill people on our streets. And still, the city isn't getting anywhere near as much money as it needs for an approach that even skeptics agree works -- housing these mentally troubled people in buildings with counselors on the premises.
At least tragedy got Albany to do the right thing, however modestly. In the city, a tragedy provoked nothing but a headline-grabbing quick fix.
After another woman was badly injured by a man believed to be homeless, the mayor directed the police to arrest vagrants who refuse shelter. We know from experience and exhaustive studies that most homeless vagrants are drug addicts, alcoholics or mentally ill and need real help to make the rest of us safer, not a few nights in jail.
I worry even more about our children. The schools remain a mess. Some are still burning coal, roofs leak, windows don't open or close, classrooms are overcrowded. There have been improvements, given where we were. But with all our wealth, why don't we fix up all the schools immediately? Why doesn't Donald Trump take on that mission instead of pursuing this nonsense about the White House?
I know. Simplistic. Especially in a city where the rich have no investment in the public schools because their children are not in them.
The frustrating thing is, we know what to do about the schools. We know we need longer days and year-round schooling, better pay for teachers, smaller classes. So what do we debate? Vouchers, test scores and charter schools.
New Yorkers are like everyone else. We like to have a good time and enjoy our affluence and babble about Regis and his trivial pursuit of televised millionaires. We like lights and fun and safer streets. I'm for all of that. I just think we have to get serious about things that aren't so great, more so in the good times.
Maybe with the first lady and the mayor running for the Senate (we think), New York will get down to basics.
Then again, maybe not.
More later, and sorry to have been out of touch. I promise to write regularly from now on. . . .
